PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Leo McLeay) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.PRESENTERS: CATLEY; DOWNER; GALLUS; HALL; SAWFORD; SHACK
PETITION.TITLE: Petition Against Government Funding of Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned Australian citizens shows that:
Every abortion kills an unborn human baby. More unborn Australians are killed every year (80,000) than the Australian death toll for the whole of World War II (30,000).
Australia's population is aging. Our live birth rate is below replacement level.
About 98 percent of abortions in Australia are performed for non-medical reasons (see SA Health Commission statistics).
Post abortion depression is a silent epidemic and is linked with the growing incidence of child abuse by mothers who have previously had abortions.
The Australian Government should not fund the killing of future Australian citizens.
Mothers with problem pregnancies need positive help to carry their babies to full term.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will:
pass the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1990, and
help pregnant women with problems to continue their pregnancies.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Catley (from 79 citizens), Mr Downer (from 49 citizens), Mrs Gallus (from 79 citizens), Mr Steele Hall (from 55 citizens), Mr Sawford (from 38 citizens) and Mr Shack (from 20 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Croatia and Slovenia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows:

That 92% of Croatians who voted in a referendum on 25 April 1991, supervised by the Constitutional Court of the Republic of Croatia, declared their support for Croatia as a sovereign and independent State and their opposition to Croatia remaining in the Yugoslav Federation;
That 88% of Slovenians who voted in a referendum democratically expressed their support for Slovenia as an autonomous and independent State;
That both Slovenia and Croatia have declared themselves to be independent Republics and that each Republic is prepared to defend its territorial integrity.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should request the Australian Government to:

Establish diplomatic relations with the legitimate representatives of each Republic and of any currently subjugated country whose residents by a democratically expressed popular vote have declared their wish to be independent; and
Establish trade relations with the Croatian and Slovenian Republics, to take advantage of the very favourable attitude which exists between the people of these Republics and the Australian people.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale (from 612 citizens), Dr Charlesworth (from 329 citizens), Ms Fatin (from 128 citizens), Mr Griffiths (from 821 citizens) and Mr Martin (from 89 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Arms Trade: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members in the House of Representatives assembled.

The petition of the undersigned shows the very deep concern of people in the community against the proposed AIDEX exhibition of weapons of war in our country. We firmly believe that it is not in Australia's interest to become dealers in death and destruction. Particularly at this time when our planet's environment is in a parlous condition and demands statesman-like leadership to the world on its rehabilitation. We therefore ask that:-

The Exhibition to take place be one which shows instead the ways in which we aim to overcome the dangers to our world from poisoned soil, air and water by high-lighting the need for tree-planting, solar-powered homes, electric cars, etc. as a means of attacking the global warming and other hazards to our fragile environment.
And we, your humble petitioners will as in duty bound, ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Bilney (from 20 citizens), Mr Griffiths (from 20 citizens), Mrs Kelly (from 79 citizens) and Dr Theophanous (from 20 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn baby.
That the right to life of all innocent human beings is the most fundamental of all human rights.
That the first duty of the Parliament and of the Government is to protect this right to life.
That in 1989/90 alone Medicare subsidised 69,587 abortions at a cost to taxpayers of $7.8 million.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will protect the right to life of unborn Australian babies by ceasing to subsidise abortions through Medicare by passing the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1990 and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Burr (from 13 citizens), Mr Kerr (from 46 citizens) and Mr Miles (from 97 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
that every abortion kills a baby
that in 1989/90 alone the Federal Government paid for 69,587 abortions through Medicare
that to pay for the killing of unborn children is to endorse each such act of killing
that the protection of human life is the first duty of parliament and government

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will act to protect the right to life of unborn babies in Australia and cease to subsidise the killing of unborn children through Medicare by passing the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill and in any other way possible. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Catley (from 166 citizens) and Mr Sawford (from 24 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The Petition of the certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House their deep concern that the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
(1) (a) makes inadequate provision for a subjective judgement by parents as to what is in the best interests of their children,
(b) makes inadequate provision for parents to use their discretionary powers to act on such judgements.
(2) creates the potential for conflict between parent and child (rather than the atmosphere of happiness, love and understanding mentioned as valuable in the preamble).
(3) will produce closer monitoring by Government agencies of relationships between parents and children.
Your Petitioners therefore pray that:
(1) By Act, Parliament ensure that all international treaties (excluding national security) are debated by the Parliament.
(2) The Parliament take action to have the Convention amended in order to pay the highest regard to the importance of the family unit, and to the rights and responsibilities of parents.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cobb (from 42 citizens), Mrs Kelly (from eight citizens) and Mr Allan Morris (from 26 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Croatia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain residents of the State of New South Wales draws to the attention of the House the current campaign which is being waged by the Communist Government of Serbia and its agents against the aspiration for independence of the Republic of Croatia.

We particularly draw to your attention the fact that Croatia has satisfied the conditions of international law for independence, and that it has made every effort to enter into meaningful dialogue with its opponents in Serbia. These have been to no avail.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House as a matter of urgency offers immediate recognition to Croatia as a sovereign nation.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Crosio (from 19 citizens), Mr Martin (from 273 citizens) and Mrs Sullivan (from 52 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: SBS: Dutch Language Broadcasts
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draw to the attention of the House that under the new broadcast schedule of the Special Broadcasting Service the members of the Dutch community in Victoria have been deprived of a disproportionate amount of transmission time in their native language on radiostation 3EA. That the decision to so reduce the amount of broadcasting time in Dutch precludes an adequate functioning of the Special Broadcasting Service as required by the Broadcasting Act and leads to great concern and disappointment amongst those residents of Victoria who were born in the Netherlands, Flanders and the former Dutch East Indies.

Your petitioners therefore ask the House to advise the Governor General to command the Chairman and members of the board of Directors of the Special Broadcasting Service to review the relevant decision and to give proper regard to the demographic realities in allocating broadcast time on radio 3EA.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Charles (from 503 citizens) and Mr Peacock (from 17 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain residents of the State of New South Wales draws the attention of the House to the need to redress falls in the real value of the pension relative to wages, and the need to alleviate poverty among low-income Australians.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House to:
(1) Increase the basic pension rate by $15 per week
(2) Introduce a $20 pw supplement for pensioners with no other income
(3) Increase rent assistance
(4) Abolish the "deeming" legislation
(5) Extend fringe benefits to all pensioners, and
(6) Remove the $2.50 and other charges for prescriptions, in the 1991/1992 Budget of the Commonwealth.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Tim Fischer (from 21 citizens) and Mr West (from 271 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Brisbane Airport Task Force
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives Assembled in Parliament:
We, the undersigned petitioners, reject the final report of the Brisbane Airport Task Force, because it failed in its basic charter to "minimise the impact of aircraft noise on surround communities."

It failed to recommend their own conclusions that an extended Cross Runway would "significantly reduce aircraft noise" and that an extended cross runway could operate as the "main or supplementary runway", which, along with the Main Runway would enable 80% or more planes to go in and out over Moreton Bay, as promised. Although it rejected these solutions because the cost would be $105 million, it recommended that a further Parallel Runway be built at a cost of $395 million (today's price) which could escalate to double or more in 15 to 20 years, thus forcing north and southside citizens to suffer increasing aircraft noise with no end in sight.
We urgently request that money be made available for an extended Cross Runway as the most cost effective and practical solution to Brisbane Airport noise and safety.
We also request that changes be made to flight paths over Hemmant, Tingalpa and Bulimba- Balmoral, Morningside areas.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Gibson (from 1,819 citizens) and Mr Jull (from 20 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Slovenia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The Petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:

That the democratically elected members of the Parliament of the Republic of Slovenia proclaimed on 25th of June 1991 that the Republic of Slovenia be an independent and sovereign state, as it was requested by the Slovenian people in the referendum held on 26th December 1990.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House
Takes all action within its powers to bring about:
The recognition of the Republic of Slovenia by the Australian Government as an independent and sovereign State.
The condemnation by the Australian Government of any action of force against the Republic of Slovenia and its people.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Grace (from 2,108 citizens) and Mrs Sullivan (from 1,014 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
That in 1987/88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided medical benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Langmore (from 22 citizens) and Mr Webster (from 100 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
That in 1989/90 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided Medical Benefits for 69,587 abortions totalling $7.8 million.
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Electoral Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we call upon Honourable Members to reject legislation denying Australians the right to advertise electoral material on radio and television, believing such bans amount to a denial of free speech, an unfair advantage to an incumbent government, and a denial of information to print- handicapped and other Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Reith (from 17 citizens) and Mr Somlyay (from 18 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Hospitals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
(1) They are completely satisfied with the existing Repatriation Hospital system.
(2) They are aware that the Prime Minister and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs have guaranteed on a number of occasions:

(a) no Repatriation General Hospital will be transferred to a State until a satisfactory agreement has been reached on matters such as priority of access and quality of health care for Veterans and War Widows and unless the interests of hospital staff have been adequately safeguarded; and
(b) no final decision will be taken if the R.S.L. has reasonable cause for dissatisfaction with the proposed arrangements.
(3) They have reasonable cause for concern that integration of Repatriation Hospitals into State systems will represent a serious erosion of their rights and privileges.

(4) They are also aware that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and the S.A. State Government have agreed that one criteria that must be met prior to the transfer taking place, is that the ex-service community is satisfied with the arrangements.

(5) After almost three years of consultation, the majority of the ex-service community of South Australia have decided they are not happy with either the arrangements for the transfer or the proposed Patient Private Health Scheme.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will propose and pass a motion that "the existing Repatriation Hospital system be retained under the responsibility of the Commonwealth Government to ensure Repatriation General Hospitals remain centres of excellence for the health needs of the Community".
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Hospitals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
(1) They are completely satisfied with the existing Repatriation Hospital system.
(2) They are aware that the Prime Minister and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs have guaranteed on a number of occasions:

(a) no Repatriation General Hospital will be transferred to a State until a satisfactory agreement has been reached on matters, such as priority of access and quality of health care for Veterans and War Widows, and unless the interests of hospital staff have been adequately safeguarded; and
(b) no final decision will be taken if the RSL has reasonable cause for dissatisfaction with the proposed arrangements.
(3) They have reasonable cause for concern that integration of Repatriation Hospitals into State systems will represent a serious erosion of their rights and privileges.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will propose and pass a motion that "the existing Repatriation Hospital system be retained under the responsibility of the Commonwealth Government to ensure Repatriation General Hospitals remain centres of excellence for the health needs of the Community."
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Housing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The Petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the increase in metropolitan house prices, which, together with the escalation in interest rates, is causing great hardship for many Australians attempting to provide housing for their families.

The petition also draws to the attention of the House the widely expressed need for a higher level of saving in Australia and the fact that the savings of ordinary Australians are currently penalized by taxation.
Your Petitioners therefore request the House to enact legislation to provide for:

(a) The establishment of a savings fund open to all Australians but directed to young people for the deposit of a fixed percentage of their income from the time of their entry into the workforce until the age of 25 or earlier marriage;
(b) The exemption from income tax of interest earned on money invested in such a fund; and
(c) The provision by the fund of low interest housing loans to contributors to the fund.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Employment Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The Northam Branch of the Commonwealth Employment Service is failing to perform its duties by not informing people of vacant positions. This jeopardises individual ability to obtain employment and meet the criteria for unemployment benefits.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Commonwealth Employment Service be forced to perform its stated objectives.
and your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The Petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that citizens of Australia, believe that burning of the Australian national flag should be an offence.
We ask that the House consider drafting legislation that would make burning the national flag illegal and punishable by law.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia: Christian Commonwealth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we, the undersigned, call for the full and total recognition by Federal Parliament and the High Court and all government agencies that Australia is a Christian Commonwealth according to law and its heritage traditions and customs.

That as Australia prepares for the Centenary of Federation on 1st January, 2001 AD, we celebrate our Centenary as a Christian Commonwealth as described by the Founders of Federation such as Sir John Downer, who said "The Commonwealth will be from its first stage a Christian Commonwealth" and as stated in our Federal Constitution--"humbly relying upon the Blessings of Almighty God. . . "
That our Federal Parliament therefore implement the following policies before 1st January, 2001 AD.
(1) The Adoption of a Christian National Anthem--"God Bless Australia" to the tune of "Waltzing Matilda".
(2) The Adoption of a Christian National Motto--"One Nation Under God", for use on our coins, banknotes, etc.
(3) The appointment of practising Christians as Vice Regal Representatives of our Christian Queen, Elizabeth II.
(4) The retention of our Christian Prayers at the daily opening of Parliament in the standing respectful presence of all Members of Parliament.
(5) The retention of "God Save the Queen" for Vice Regal Functions as our Royal Anthem and as our National Hymn for all other civic functions.
(6) The retention of Christian Christmas Carols in our State Schools and other civic functions during the Christmas Season.
(7) Officially inform the United Nations and all the other nations of the world that Australia is a Christian Commonwealth.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will reaffirm our Christian Heritage as a Christian Commonwealth.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(1) The overwhelming majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian National Flag.

(2) We are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, unless such proposed change is first voted on by the people of Australia and passed by a majority of voters in a majority of States.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom 0055 Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
(1) Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

(2) The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
(3) These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the House, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to remove these services so that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Brisbane Airport Task Force
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of The House of Representatives Assembled in Parliament:

We, the undersigned petitioners, reject the final report of the Brisbane Airport Task Force, because it failed in its basic charter to "minimise the impact of aircraft noise on surrounding communities."

The endorsement by the Task Force to build a Parallel Runway at a cost of $395 million adjacent to the existing main runway will bring additional aircraft noise back over suburbs on the northside of Brisbane as well as southern suburbs.
Aircraft traffic has substantially increased since the new airport opened and it is expected to progressively double.

The new airport has no curfew between 11 p.m. and 6 a.m. and therefore the Task Force decision to build a future Parallel Runway will `maximise' noise for northside residents, and not `minimise' the impact.
We urgently request that Parliament review and reject the Brisbane Airport Task Force recommendations, regarding the building of any Parallel Runway, now or in the future.

PETITION.TITLE: HMAS Nirimba
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled:
The humble Petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectively showeth--

That HMAS NIRIMBA is a vital training facility for the Navy apprentices with training expertise that does not and cannot exist at any other location. The expertise is not just the knowledge which is passed onto the Navy apprentices but the years of goodwill at the facility and the interaction with the community which enhances the education process.
If the proposal for consolidation of Navy's technical trade training at HMAS CERBERUS is realised, then not just the Navy, but Australia, will lose a vital centre for training in trade excellence.
Further, HMAS NIRIMBA is vital to the local business community which services not just the base needs but those of the personnel and their families.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will reject outright any proposal for the functions of HMAS NIRIMBA and HMAS CERBERUS to be consolidated at HMAS CERBERUS.

PETITION.TITLE: Slovenia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives Assembled in Parliament.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to:

the invasion of Slovenia, an independent and sovereign state, by the occupation forces of the Yugoslav Army and the urgent need for the immediate recognition by the international community of Slovenia as an independent and sovereign state.
We note that:

(1) In December 1990 Slovenia exercised her rights under the Federal Constitution of Yugoslavia as a constituent Republic to become an independent and sovereign state, with a Referendum being held to determine the will of the Slovene people as required by the Federal Constitution; the Referendum overwhelmingly supported that Slovenia should become an independent state.
(2) Democratic elections were held in 1990 and the first democratically-elected Government was formed with Mr Milan Kucan being elected the President.
(3) On 25th June 1991 the democratically elected Government of Slovenia proclaimed Slovenia to be an independent and sovereign state.
(4) On 26th June 1991 the Yugoslav Army attacked the Republic of Slovenia and the occupation forces of the Yugoslav Army remain in Slovenia to this time.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House:
(1) Takes immediate and urgent action to urge the Australian Government to immediately recognise the Republic of Slovenia as an independent and sovereign state.
(2) Immediately proclaims its complete and utter condemnation of any aggression or use of force against the democratically elected Government of Slovenia, its people or its territory.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That attention is drawn to Australia's location and involvement in the Asia/Pacific region where there exists a number of actual and potential conflicts, along with several countries which can ill afford to pay for the importation of military equipment yet feel obliged to do so.

That Australia is increasing its role in the arms trade in this region, and in particular, it is supporting and participating in AIDEX 1991. The arms trade is detrimental to Australians affected by the diversion of public money away from health, education, social welfare, and is an integral factor in the oppression and poverty of people of the Asia/Pacific region.
The petitioners therefore appeal to the Australian Parliament to:
Stop all military aid and training to governments engaged in repression of their own people.

Direct those Government Departments participating in AIDEX 1991, i.e. Defence, Austrade, Industry, Technology and Commerce, to cancel their bookings for space at the exhibition and withdraw their support for AIDEX 1991.
Redirect all monies currently being used in promoting the arms industry to socially useful research, development and production.
Explore the possibilities of setting up an Agency for the development of techniques for conflict resolution.
Increase overseas aid to counteract the reduction since 1983/4.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Wool Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain Woolgrowers and Citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the perilous state of the wool industry.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House places an immediate ban on the export of any Merino rams and or any genetic breeding material to protect the heritage and development of the fibre that has given us the unique trading advantage to date.

PETITION.TITLE: Jervis Bay
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:
That Jervis Bay is a place of exceptional beauty, relatively undisturbed on an increasingly populated coastline, with outstanding natural and cultural heritage values.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled call upon the Government to establish a Jervis Bay Marine Reserve and National Park protecting the waters and total catchment of Jervis Bay.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Jervis Bay
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives as assembled.

We, the undersigned concerned residents, visitors and holiday makers, reject the proposed military and industrial developments in Jervis Bay and support the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment &Conservation 1986 which recommended that: "the proposed Environmental Impact Study for naval development at Jervis Bay should be undertaken only when a comprehensive planning study and public review of naval facility requirements and alternative sites demonstrates that relocation to Jervis Bay is necessary; and the proposed development at Jervis Bay be considered and planned in the context of the overall proposal for Fleet facilities and bases around Australia."
We call for your Honourable House to conduct a Public Inquiry into the proposal to relocate naval facilities to Jervis Bay.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The Petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide, independent radio and television service and should therefore be properly funded to continue to provide the same comprehensive range of services;
that the ABC should not be subject to the 1.25% efficiency dividend for the 1990/91 financial year;
that the ABC be provided with supplementary funding to avoid the need for the proposed cuts in staff and services;
that the ABC be provided with fully indexed funding for the next three years with an agreed formula for indexation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That in 1988/89 the Federal Government paid $6.9 million from taxpayers funds for 64,788 abortions under Medicare Items 6469 and 274/275 alone.
That in the same year Federal Government grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by supporting the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1989 and by all other means at its disposal.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House of Representatives that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469, 274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the House will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: Rural Families
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The Petition of certain undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that there are many in rural communities who are not eligible for financial assistance. The depressed state of the Economy means there are now many rural families who have little cash for basic living needs.
Your petitioners therefore request that the House pay urgent attention to the above statement with feeling and sincere thoughts for those rural families who are presently in financial difficulties.

PETITION.TITLE: Bulla
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of the under-signed Citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that the road through the township of Bulla in the State of Victoria and particularly the Bulla hill is dangerous, unsuitable and inadequate for existing traffic conditions.

Your petitioners therefore pray the House will provide an alternative road route be provided around the township of Bulla and in particular the notorious Bulla hill in the form of a northern by- pass route.

PETITION.TITLE: Political Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we call upon Honourable Members to reject legislation denying Australians the right to advertise political material on radio and television, believing such a ban to be arbitrary and discriminatory, a denial of freedom of speech and a curtailment of criticism (or support) of political parties and/or their policies.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Arms Trade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the central role played by the arms trade in creating an environment in which wars such as the Gulf War can occur.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to:
(i) call on the Federal Government to outlaw sales of armaments and arms-related technology to overseas organisations, government and private.

(ii) call on the Federal Government to lobby internationally, including at the United Nations, for the banning of sales of armaments and arms-related technology to unstable regions and to countries with dictatorships.

PETITION.TITLE: Kings Highway
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The Petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the deplorable condition of the NSW Main Road 51 (Kings Highway).

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House, on behalf of the undersigned, request the Federal Minister for Land Transport, Mr Bob Brown, to negotiate with the NSW State Government to reclassify the Kings Highway to become a Federal funding responsibility.

PETITION.TITLE: SBS: Hungarian Language Broadcasts
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The SBS Board has rescheduled the air time for language programmes on SBS Radio 3EA. As a result, the Hungarian Language Programme has been cut by half. This created serious anomalies at the expense of the Hungarian community. We do not wish to gain at anybody's expense, but we point out that, based on 1986 census date, several times smaller ethnic communities have been given more air time.
We call upon the Parliament to address the grievances of the Hungarian listeners of SBS Radio.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: SBS: Indian Language Broadcasts
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain residents of Australia draws to the attention of the house its deep disappointment and sadness at the decision of the SBS Board to virtually remove six Indian language programs, including the Tamil program from the new schedule for Radio 2EA.

For fourteen years the Tamil program has catered to the cultural, educational and religious interests of the Tamil community. The homeland news on the program is eagerly listened to by Tamil speakers in Sydney, Wollongong and Newcastle. The Tamil community does not have a daily or even a weekly newspaper to serve its interests. Therefore it is essential that the Tamil program be continued on Radio 2EA.

The Tamil community has grown dramatically in numbers since the last census of 1986. This fact has not been taken into account by the SBS Rescheduling Committee. In fact this move by the SBS Board is a retrograde step which will have serious repercussions in terms of the Community's support for the Federal Government's policy of multi-culturalism. In the light of what happened how can the Tamil community believe that the Federal Government is sincere in its commitment to multi-culturalism?
Your petitioners therefore request the House to instruct the SBS Board to prepare a new schedule for Radio 2EA that gives regular air time to the Tamil program.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: --On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations I present Special Report No. 1 of the Committee entitled Recommendations to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs incorporating a dissenting report.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —-This special report to Parliament essentially comprises two letters written to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) from the Committee. The Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, as part of its terms of reference, has determined that where necessary and appropriate it will provide advice to the Minister on matters where, for reasons of urgency or otherwise, it is not practicable to await the tabling of a report to Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Often issues of concern to the Committee arise during the course of an inquiry. However, sometimes issues not the subject of specific inquiry are considered and, if it is decided that further consideration is warranted by the Minister and his Department and possible amendment required, the Committee has agreed that it will notify the Minister accordingly. The Committee has further determined that any such letters of advice will be tabled in Parliament at the earliest opportunity.

Prior to July 1991, only one such letter had been transmitted to the Minister. This was included in the report to Parliament called Change of Status tabled in May of this year. That letter included a number of recommendations relating to the Committee's inquiry into change of status on marriage or de facto grounds, recommendations which the Committee was concerned to put to the Minister prior to a deadline of 30 November 1990 and before it was possible to finalise its report on that issue.

This special report includes two letters of advice, one on the current refugee- humanitarian arrangements and one relating to a number of other issues. The former arose out of the Committee's current inquiry into the refugee-humanitarian arrangements and the latter was prompted by correspondence to the Committee, direct references from the Minister's office and a consideration of issues arising from decisions of the Immigration Review Tribunal.

The major issues dealt with in the second of the two letters include: the section 121 aggregation procedure; the balance of family test; certain requirements relating to the family extended eligibility temporary entry permit; special need relatives; and the complexity of the immigration legal system.

On the last point I must emphasise the continuing difficulties experienced by everyone who comes into contact with the immigration process as a result of the very complex nature of the system. The Committee is of the view that this problem must be rectified before the regulatory process is properly workable. I thank the members of the Committee and the staff and I commend the report to honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —- Thank you for giving me this opportunity to speak to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations. What needs to be understood is that this special report is before us because there is a great deal of urgency attached to the issues raised and that to leave these matters without their being addressed would certainly not be in the national interest.

SPEECH.PARA: The first letter to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand), which deals with the evidence taken to this point in time in relation to the refugee and humanitarian inquiry, deals with one particular aspect of an issue that is of the utmost importance to this nation at this time. It arises because the fact is that the whole question of refugee determination and related humanitarian issues is leading to a situation where our ability to effectively control entry to this country is severely at risk. It needs to be understood that this report is written against that background.

The Committee raised with the Minister certain very positive initiatives that might be undertaken to get to the point where applications for refugee status are promptly dealt with--that claims, where they exist, are promptly put before the Department and that there are certain time limits involved in relation to that; that the Government provide advice and counsel to those so that they are able to meet deadlines; and that border claimants--boat people particularly--be given priority in assessment of their claims. We indicated that there ought to be a time limit for dealing with boat people of about three months, that a target time should be set.

Why these recommendations? The reason is very clear. At this time, we have over 300 undocumented arrivals in Australia that have been languishing in camps for something like 18 months. To this point in time their claims have not been dealt with. We know that there are some people who have come to Australia later in time after the first arrivals who are clutching in their hands letters stating, `Look, we have got here safely. We are in Australia now. Our immediate needs have been met and our children are receiving some education in English and nothing seems to be happening. Nobody is sending us back--it looks all right'.

The fact is that that is the message that is going out right now. It is occasioned by a far greater risk. At this time, we have 17,500 people in Australia who are making claims for refugee status. That probably understates the size of the problem. Even with all the additional resources, such as the 300 additional staff to undertake this processing, that the Minister has been able to muster out of the Government and all the advice attached to the estimates that have now been given to us associated with this Budget, the Government will be able to deal with only 3,000 cases through all stages of processing. That means that, as each person presses the claim and presses the Government, the time that it takes to process claimants for refugee status will extend. The prospect is that the processing will take probably five to seven years. That sends out a message to people who are anxious to stay here--that all they have to do is put in a claim for refugee status and wait out the time.

Then there is the absorption argument that we have heard before in this House: after people have been here for five or six years, it is unreasonable to send them back; it is unreasonable because they have come to rely upon the support of family and communities; it is unreasonable because their children have been receiving an education in English and they have become absorbed into the Australian community. We are dealing with a very major problem about our ability to control or own borders.

I do not mean to be alarmist about these things because it is not my style in relation to handling immigration questions. At some point in time, unless the right decisions are taken and these matters are dealt with quickly, resolutely, sensitively and sensibly, acknowledging our commitments under the international covenants, we run the risk that one day somebody will commandeer a larger vessel and arrive in Darwin and we will have numbers of a size that we just cannot manage.

That is what happened recently in Italy. The Italians showed that they had no resolve and that they were not handling these issues in relation to their own border. They had thousands of people. We have all seen what has happened. It is not impossible to imagine that that could happen in Australia today. That is the warning that I have been sounding to this Government. It is the warning that I have been giving every day that I get the opportunity. The fact is that we are at this time out of control in relation to our ability to handle our own border arrangements.

I am not without ideas in relation to how these things can be handled. The other day I wrote to the Chairman of Radio Australia, Mr Richard Broinowski. It seemed to me that this question of the way in which we deal with refugee matters is not clearly understood. It seems to me that it would be perfectly proper and appropriate for Australia to have Khmer language programs in which accurate information about people's entitlements, the testing that is undertaken and the claims that they have to substantiate are put clearly before them so that they know that it is not an easy path and so that they know they will be returned if they are not bona fide.

I am told that putting in place on Radio Australia a program in Khmer where this accurate information could be provided again is not a priority for this Government. Radio Australia does not have the funds to be able to undertake this task. It is more important that we have language programs in French, German and other European languages rather than addressing an immediate and pressing problem in our own region right now.

This report is part of the bipartisan effort to give the Minister advice. I note, positively, that in relation to the recommendations on time limits the Minister did act. In relation to the recommendations in regard to providing, particularly to legal aid commissions and refugee and advice case work services, I noticed that additional funds were provided in the Budget. I commend the Minister for taking up those recommendations from the Committee as promptly as he did, this letter having been sent to him a little while ago.

Likewise, the second letter deals with amendments to the Migration Act and regulations that we have suggested to the Minister might be helpful. The letter deals with specific areas of detail--the aggregation question in section 121; the application of the balance of family test; the extended eligibility of temporary entry permits in family situations; special need relatives; and the complexity of the Migration Act and scheme.

The Committee remains concerned about the failure of the Government to address this question promptly. We have been promised for over 12 months that there would be a redraft of the regulatory scheme in order to simplify it and make it understandable. Regrettably, to date we have seen no sign of those new proposed regulations. While we are still tinkering at the edges, the fact is that enormous technical difficulties are being presented day by day. People appear before the Immigration Review Tribunal to present their cases. The circumstances are understood. However, the Tribunal is unhappy. I think most of us would be equally concerned in terms of some of the decisions that are taken. For instance, we have made recommendations in relation to the balance of family test. In particular, we have addressed the issue of aged parents who might be sponsored by relatives in Australia. The way in which step-children are counted along with children of a marriage can, in certain circumstances, lead to hardship. This matter needs to be addressed by this Government.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee of Public Accounts: Report No. 310

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House take note of the paper.

I am very pleased to have the opportunity to speak about report No. 310 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts entitled Business Migration Program. I think this report of the Public Accounts Committee is probably unique. It was tabled in the Parliament on 21 June this year with a number of very significant recommendations, the foremost being that the business migration program should be abolished. That action was actually taken by the Government on 25 July. So the major recommendation of the Committee was accepted by the Government and acted upon between 21 June and 25 July.

The accredited agents scheme, which has been abolished, was introduced on 1 July 1988. The scheme was designed as a self- financing means of providing counselling services and assessment of applications for business migrants. Its principal purpose, I suppose, was to give the Government a measure of control over the activities of private sector consultants who were assisting business migrants with their applications for settlement in Australia.

It became very evident from the evidence presented to the Committee that there were a great many shortcomings in that scheme. The evidence identified two concerns in particular about the operations of subagents. The Committee felt that this arrangement had a significant impact on the selection of business migrants. The subagencies operated outside Australia, were owned and operated by foreign nationals and were beyond the control of the Department.

The other concern was the reliance that accredited agents in Australia placed on the subagencies to assist in the generation of business migration applications just to maintain the viability of the agencies. We very quickly came to the conclusion that the BMP was very vulnerable to abuse. That vulnerability was exploited in two main ways: first, by the use of illicit means such as false and forged documentation to obtain a business migration program visa; and, secondly, by the agents' focus on selling the BMP to applicants rather than concentrating on assessing the applicants' backgrounds and suitability for migration under that program. So what we had was a distortion in the way the program operated in that it sought not to benefit Australia as such but to benefit the individual migrants who were seeking to come here.

It was also interesting to look at the source countries because, obviously, the business migration program had as its objective to obtain business migrants from all over the world. Looking at the countries from which business migrants came for the period July 1982 to March 1990, we find that 32.29 per cent came from Hong Kong, 15.33 per cent from Taiwan, 12.04 per cent from Malaysia, 5.57 per cent from Indonesia, 4.78 per cent from Singapore, and 4.5 per cent from South Korea. So a total of approximately 75 per cent of all business migrants who came here under this program came from the South East Asian area, with particular emphasis on Hong Kong and Taiwan, which accounted for nearly 50 per cent of all business migrants coming here.

The major recommendation, apart from the abolition of the old scheme, was that there should, in fact, be a positive response and that a new scheme should be introduced. We recommended that the migration program should continue to have a category of entry which recognised business and entrepreneurial skills as eligible criteria for entry to Australia, because we believe that it is absolutely essential that we maintain the flow of entrepreneurs to this country--that we maintain the flow of migrants who can make a contribution in more than one way. There was a public perception--whether it be true or false--that a great many of the migrants coming here are going to be drains on our economy.

The positive thing about the recommendation of the Committee was that we are seeking to have a new scheme of business and entrepreneurial skills. The primary purpose of this entry category would be to introduce to this country migrants who would actually establish a business in Australia. It was quite obvious in the evaluation of the previous scheme that, while money came in, there was not a great deal of action taken in actually starting new businesses. Money came in and, of course, there were allegations that money went out again, too--that there was laundering of money. There is some evidence--not a great deal--to suggest that that is true, but not only of business migrants. This has been happening with other migrants as well. So there is definitely a need to tighten up and to make sure that Australia, in bringing business migrants in, actually receives--to coin a phrase--value for money.

We recommended that there should be a category of entry that recognises business skills as criteria for entry to Australia, that that category of entry should be based on the assessment of business skills developed to replace the business migration program and that, first and foremost, the establishment of a business in Australia should be one of the major objectives of this category of migration.

We also thought that it was appropriate that there should be a separate points test for the age qualification. For any migrant coming to Australia there is a table of points. In age it starts at 18 to 29 years and in that age group people get 30 points. If one was 50 years or more one would get zero points for age. I point out to the House that, if the Prime Minister were to be assessed as a migrant coming to Australia, while he would undoubtedly get points for language skills, he would get zero points for age. When assessing this new provision which the Committee has recommended, I think we have to make allowance and give credit for experience and for wisdom. It is all too common in our society to denigrate knowledge--we tend to throw experience out the window. So I was very pleased, personally, that the Committee made the recommendation that there should be a separate points test for age qualification.

I also note that in the Australian Financial Review of 27 August this year there was a story headed, `Migration agents call for government regulation'. In that story Australian migration agents indicated that they would urge the Federal Government to regulate their industry under new rules prepared for business migration. Such a step should be followed.

If we are going to have a new form of accreditation, we have to be a little more careful and stringent in appointing agents. The national president of the Australian Migration Consultants Association, Mr John Gillespie, said that his Association would suggest that the Government issue licences to agents after taking into account their competence and standing, and that only those licensed agents could accept fees from prospective migrants and lodge claims.

I have grave doubts about that system. I base those doubts on having seen prospective migrants in my electorate who have paid fees of $3,000 to some people just to fill in a form which could be filled in by my staff for nothing. If we are going to have a licensing scheme for agents it is essential that it provide control for the benefit not only of the prospective migrant but also for Australia as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I support and welcome the report on the business migration program by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. I congratulate the Committee members for the work they have done on this program. The report was long overdue. Over a number of years there have been allegations and suggestions about the potential abuse of the business migration program. It is unfortunate that the warnings about the operation of the program were ignored and that in the end the whole program had to be abolished. Had the problems concerning the business migration program been taken up and had amendments been put in place to fix up some of them, it may have been possible to retain the program rather than end up in the situation we are in now where the whole program has been abolished.

SPEECH.PARA: Way back in 1986 the Caucus immigration committee was presented with evidence about problems concerning the business migration program. At that time we were assured by the Department of Immigration that these problems were under control and that many of the alleged malpractices were not taking place. The matter was again raised in 1988 in the Caucus immigration committee, and again further assurances were sought from and given by the Department. As this report proves, those assurances were insufficient. No amendments were made to try to deal with some of the obviously critical areas. Clearly, the most critical area has been capital being transferred into Australia as part of a supposedly genuine application for business migration. That capital has not been invested in a genuine business but has been taken out of Australia. The same capital has then been used to bring either a second or a third person into Australia.

When the Department was asked whether it was possible to put into place procedures which would control this matter, it said it was not. Of course, the ultimate upshot of that meant that as more people, even reputable agents, came to see that the Government was not checking on this issue and was not following it through, it became clear that more and more people could apply under business migration. I am not saying that those people did not bring any money at all, but if they could not bring the full amount, there were ways and means of bringing in lesser amounts and, therefore, the actual legislative purpose of the program was not achieved.

TALK.START.PARA: —-What do you mean by `legislative purpose'? There was no legislation. The Minister put out a bit of paper on it.

—-The honourable member opposite will have an opportunity to have his say later. In 1982 the program was brought in. I am referring to the regulatory requirements in relation to the program, if honourable members opposite want to be technical about that point.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to the question of what we do from now on, I welcome the new category of entry on the basis of business and managerial skills. But it is very important that we get this new category right. It is very important, for example, that we do not make the new category so stringent that we actually exclude people who do have significant amounts of capital and entrepreneurial skill, on the basis of over-rigidly enforcing other criteria which we might wish to enforce in other cases of independent migrants. I think it is one thing if a person simply has a skill but no capital and no entrepreneurial experience; we might bring that person in and, in that case, the age qualification may be highly relevant. But it is quite another thing to say to someone who has been a successful businessman and who is over 45 years of age that he is to get zero points because of his age, even though he has all this entrepreneurial skill and he has very significant capital. If the program is not looked at carefully, that may undermine its purpose.

What is the objective that we are aiming at? It is to bring people to Australia who can contribute significant amounts of capital and who do have the managerial and entrepreneurial skills to set up enterprises here and to make a contribution to Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Create jobs.

—-And, therefore, to create jobs, as the honourable member says. One of the impertinent things that have been said about this program is that it has been a total disaster, that there have been no successes. That is not correct. All of the surveys indicate that there have been significant successes, and there have been a significant number of entrepreneurs who have come here and who have set up companies. Some of them have been very successful. In fact, some of them have given employment to a large number of Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: We should recognise that this country does lack entrepreneurial and managerial skills. There is still a lack in that area, especially when we are talking about our competitiveness in world terms. We can learn from bringing some significant individuals who have trained in these areas into in Australia. They should be welcome here, especially when they bring capital to establish their enterprises. It is important that we take a broad-minded view about how the criteria are going to apply in relation to this new category so that we are not going to exclude people who do have that potential contribution.

However, in relation to that, I want to say a word of caution about the English language skills criteria. It is clear that there are some people who have insufficient English language skills but have entrepreneurial skills, so we have to balance that with some requirement in the English language area. If there is a proven entrepreneur who wants to come to Australia, we have to be ensured that that person is given adequate training in the English language so that we do not lose his particular skill simply because he does not have sufficient knowledge of the English language. I think this matter has to be handled sensitively so that we do not lose someone or some persons who might be prepared to bring to Australia millions of dollars of investment simply because that person's or those persons' English language skills level is insufficient. We should not simply say, `Your level is insufficient; forget it'. We should say, `Let us see what we can do to assist you in relation to the English language requirement so that we can in fact gain from your skills and from your potential capital investment'.

In overall terms, therefore, let us hope that we have learned from the lessons of the past in terms of the abuse of the program. One thing we have learned is that if we introduce any kind of business migration program and make it clear that agents are able to come in, charge lots of money, offer quick solutions and ways of getting around the law, as has happened with some agents--I do not say it has happened with the majority, but it has with some--then we will get into trouble.

The honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) mentioned in a previous debate that many people who failed to succeed in change of status applications when they were here as visitors or students have now decided to make applications for refugee status. One of the most outrageous aspects of this problem has been the fact that some immigration agents have been openly advertising to people and saying, `If you really want to stay in Australia we can help you by making a refugee application'. That is a further example of where the use of agents in the immigration area can certainly be a real difficulty. We have to tighten up in this area where agents are assisting people with immigration applications, but we especially need a tightening with refugee applications. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I take the opportunity, firstly, to congratulate the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on its report. I thank the Committee for it. As a former member of that Committee, I am pleased that the Committee has again demonstrated its capacity to report fearlessly on the views that it has formed about government administration. In this case the Committee accurately records the failure of the Government over time to effectively administer the business migration scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: On behalf of the Opposition, as its shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, I had from time to time drawn attention to many of the shortcomings which I had identified and which I know the Committee picked up in its report. I have been at pains, on behalf of the Opposition, to mention that it was certainly our view that the baby should not be thrown out with the bath water and that there were important objectives which the scheme, properly administered, could achieve. The fact is that the scheme as it was administered was severely flawed because of decisions taken by Ministers under the Labor Government.

The most outrageous decision that was taken was to appoint accredited agents. That decision was taken by former Minister Young under this Government. It was a decision that ignored every basic tenet of agency and ethics. The Government had a fear that, if people were appointed agents of the Government, they might do a Khemlani and go and represent themselves as people who could do all sorts of other things. The Government said, `We are not going to have agents of the Government; we are going to make them agents of the person who wants to come here'. What is a person who employs an agent to get him into Australia going to expect? He expects his agent to act in his interests. There is no ethical position, there is no consideration given to what lawyers regard as their obligation to the court, their obligation to clients built up over a long period--there is nothing of that nature. We had a government that was prepared to license over 300 people. Those who wanted to come along and be a business migration agent accredited by the Government were given a licence. That situation was not going to work. It never could.

What we had from the Committee was a damning indictment of the way in which that scheme was administered, the way in which accredited agency arrangements worked, and the Committee's principal recommendation was that that part of the scheme ought to be thrown to one side. The Committee did recommend an alternative--firstly, that the business migration scheme as it presently operated should be scrapped and that a new business skills entry arrangement should be put in place, and that it should be points tested. The Committee obviously had very comprehensive evidence from the Department as to how that could be done. It seems clear to me, from the evidence that was made available, that the Committee's recommendation could have been put in place immediately.

What did this Minister do? He scrapped the scheme and gave everybody two weeks notice to put in their present applications. What an outrageous proposition! We know it is flawed--we know the administration has been flawed--but he said to all the world, `I am going to scrap the scheme in accordance with the Committee's recommendations, but I am giving you two more weeks to get all your applications in'. Then he said, `I am not ready to put the new scheme in place; that will have to come six months down the track'. He should have made the announcement that the scheme was scrapped immediately that he received the report. He had the material, developed by his Department, upon which the new points system could have been put in place immediately.

The message that has gone abroad is that business migration to Australia is a stop-start program. To the serious business migrants, the message is, `Do not look at Australia'. Our interest has been sold short again. The Public Accounts Committee has done the job, but the Government has failed. The Government failed in relation to the administration of the scheme, the Public Accounts Committee tells us, and the Government's record since the Public Accounts Committee reported demonstrates that it has no capacity to make the correct decisions in this important area of responsibility.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: --In considering the report on the business migration program of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I quote from my discussion paper Immigration and Consensus:

SPEECH.PARA: In 1983 a program had been introduced designed to attract business migrants. Its introduction and subsequent justification is almost a classic case of the colonial mentality in action. Given that locals were considered second rate we had to import business people. In January 1988, under Mick Young as Minister, the prevailing belief in deregulation and the deification of the market saw the administration of the program virtually handed over to private enterprise middle men whose driving motivation was the profits they could make. They, at one and the same time, were employed and paid by prospective migrants, mainly from Hong Kong and Taiwan, and also entrusted by the Government to decide which migrants gained entry to Australia! When rumours of mismanagement arose, the bulk of the media relied on the testimony of these middle men and others in the immigration industry. They, of course, including representatives from the Immigration Department, claimed the scheme was working well and did not hesitate to smear critics as racist. The Business Migration Program became a byword as a massive rort, but for years nothing was done about it. Finally this year the all party Federal Public Accounts Committee was directed to investigate the program.

In The Australian of April 25 this year the Australian Federal Police stated in a submission to the Committee that it was concerned that: "individuals are arriving in Australia under the Business Migration Program by using funds provided by organised crime. It is thought that the funds are then recycled and used to fund further immigrants under the BMP. It is also suspected that the scheme is being used to launder money by known criminal groups which lend the immigrants the money required for the scheme. No apparent checks are made to ensure that the funds for the BMP are kept and used within Australia." The AFP believes that Triad crime gangs are using the scheme to help them relocate to Australia before Hong Kong is taken over by the People's Republic of China. About 10,000 business migrants and 30,000 dependants have entered Australia under the scheme.

The Australian Tax Office noted that in 1987 the Immigration Department had given it a list of names of 100 successful business migration applicants, but had been unable to provide any other personal information. The Tax Office could trace only seven of the migrants and only two of those had lodged tax returns. Despite evidence such as this, the Immigration Department continued to claim that the program was working well right up until the Committee delivered its report on June 21. The report was a scathing indictment of the Business Migration Program and also stands as an indictment of the integrity and professional competence of the Immigration Department itself. The Committee said that the program was flawed from the start, had been "disastrously" mismanaged and called for its abolition.

In spite of this, the Secretary to the Immigration Department, Chris Conybeare, subsequently claimed in letters to newspapers that the scheme had not been so bad after all and that any new scheme would be based on what he called the success of the old. What does it take before the Immigration Department and other immigration advocates face up to their failures?

Further, given that the power elite are so desperately afraid of how Australia is perceived in Asia--sections of the press continue to harp on this--it is interesting to note that the scheme became a standing joke among the Hong Kong business community. Far from increasing our prestige in Asia it, along with the education for export fiasco, has significantly diminished it. Australia has gained a reputation for mismanagement and confusion in dealing with Asian countries and it seems to be sadly lacking in confidence.

It is true that the business migration scheme has been scrapped, but there will be some new business scheme put in its place in line with the belief in skilled immigration among the elite. This means that in considering the business migration program the whole rationale behind skills immigration has to be considered. If Australia is ever to be anything other than a colonial dumping ground, it must train its own people. In doing so it must cut the intake of skilled workers as a matter of long term policy to ensure that employers, with government assistance where necessary, make the commitment to training. Immigration can be used to supplement skills shortages. There may be, under these circumstances, openings for a small number of business people who have been rigorously selected.

Apart from locals losing opportunities for training, our unthinking cargo cult commitment to skilled immigration has also meant an oversupply of skills in some areas. The Budget Papers acknowledge that over-servicing by GPs is caused by the oversupply of doctors. The AMA recognises that this oversupply is caused largely by the immigration of doctors, and it is rightly concerned about it. Like engineers, whom we are continuing to import--(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I would like to compliment previous speakers, and also the Public Accounts Committee for the splendid work it has done on the business migration program. The Public Accounts Committee dealt with three basic areas, namely, the business migration program, the accredited agents scheme, and a proposal it developed for business skills migration.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee found that there was criminal activity involved in the business migration program, but not to a large degree, nor on an organised basis. The Committee was certain that individuals had used this program to gain entry to Australia. It is interesting to note that, during the period the scheme was being developed, large numbers of community leaders of ethnic groups, particularly those from Asia, raised with me and the Minister their concern that this was not a scheme with integrity. In fact, 82 per cent of the participants in the business migration scheme are of Asian origin. That should have been enough to alert the Government that it needed to monitor and evaluate the program.

The Committee looked at the proposition that funds were being recycled--that people were paying $500,000 to buy their way into Australia under the business migration program and then sending that money back, without making an investment here, for somebody else to use in the chain. There was no necessity for compliance or monitoring established by the Department.

The Committee also examined the transfer of capital and the necessity to monitor whether or not capital was actually transferred in the business migration program. The recommendation of the Committee is that there be an assessment after two years to make sure that capital has been transferred. It was scathing in its attack on the accredited agent scheme. I would like to refer to statements I made on behalf of the Opposition at the time. On 5 November 1987 I said:
The Opposition is extremely concerned about the Government's proposal to introduce private sector processing for Business Migrants from January 1, 1988.
I also said:

We are not against the private sector playing a significant role in the Business Migration Program nor the opportunity to expand the program, however, we must not get into the situation where we hand over our sovereign rights.

It has been all downhill since then. Successive Ministers, one after another, have failed to acknowledge the weaknesses of the business migration scheme, and in fact used to launch regularly into attacks on members of the Opposition for daring to question their integrity by pointing out obvious weaknesses. On 30 August 1988, the then Minister, Mr Hurford, was quoted in the House of Representatives by Mr Holding as saying:
To date, no single example has been produced in respect of that practice--
