that business migration is being used as a method of buying one's way into Australia--

and that there are inadequate safeguards, and that in some cases the funds involved are the proceeds of illegal activities such as prostitution and drugs . . . To date there certainly has been no evidence to substantiate some of the wild assertions that have been made . . . It should be pointed out that business migrants are selected on the basis of their successful business background.

Well, Hurford is wrong; the whole bunch of them are wrong. The honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), on behalf of the Government Caucus committee, endorsed the whole lot. Government members sat there and attacked the Opposition, and now we have one of the prime committees of the Parliament saying that this is a shambles. A bipartisan committee has pointed out that the Government, year after year, disclaimed any responsibility for the business migration program, and now it has been found that there has been criminal activity, that there has been a recycling of funds, that nobody can find many of the so-called business migrants who are supposed to have come here and invested in Australia, and that there has been, in some instances, no transfer of capital.

I understand that the Taxation Office, out of a list of 100 so-called business migrants, could find only two. The very highest estimate that I have seen of legitimate participation in this program is 25 per cent. We have had a program running now for four years which has been inadequate and not monitored, and the Government has denied that it is inadequate. The Government stands condemned on this part of its migration program, as it does on the rest. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —- Any history text which deigns to tell the story of the growth of this great nation of ours would have to include at least one lengthy chapter on immigration. No word in the dictionary has had a greater influence on our development than that word-- immigration. Immigration is a big ticket item, but all big ticket items have an upside and a downside. They develop admirers and they develop enemies.

SPEECH.PARA: Controversy grows about the benefits of immigration, the acceptable level of immigration, the place of origin of immigrants, the language that they speak, the colour of their skin, the god they worship, their health, their education, their social class and so on. Because of public unease about immigration, governments strive to achieve immigration policies which will take the heat out of the issue; immigration policies with which no-one can argue; policies which will please everyone and get sensational immigration stories off the front page. The business migration program seemed to fit into that category.

It was thought that no-one would question the correctness of a scheme which provided great economic benefit to Australia by allowing wealth and business skills to migrate in order to boost our technological knowledge, to boost our exports and to boost our employment opportunities. The business migration program was not a failure, but we found it was not the unqualified success that we had hoped it might have been.

Many BMP success stories can be told; but despite the successes, things such as program monitoring, post-settlement service, the accreditation scheme, criminal involvement and a few other problems, such as the laundering of money, seriously flawed a worthwhile concept. The business migration program inquiry was long and demanding. Many days were spent in quite a few capital cities of Australia on public hearings.

It is pleasing that the recommendations finally arrived at were supported wholeheartedly by all members of the Committee. It is even more pleasing that the Committee recommendations have been accepted by the Minister. As a member of that Committee, I join with others in congratulating everyone involved on the work and cooperation evident in this report.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The time allotted for the debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Government give greater recognition to the worth of the unemployed by giving greater choice of Newstart activity agreements including the option of two days community work for Newstart payment.

I bring this motion before the House because I am sure that everybody in Australia is very much aware of the crisis of unemployment which is facing so many families and young people--not only young people, but also many people in middle age and towards retiring age. It is a great concern of the coalition that the blow-out in unemployment in this country is causing such devastation on the lives of people. Seemingly, the Government is totally unconcerned about their plight.

This week, the focus of this Parliament has been on unemployment. Unfortunately, the focus of the Government has been on the one top job in the country. While there are one million people out there unemployed, the Government fiddles around and is totally absorbed with who will be Prime Minister. It is a great tragedy that at a time when there are so many people--

TALK.START.PARA: —-It will do nobody any good. That is the problem.

—-Absolutely, it will do nobody any good. It does not matter whether it is the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) or the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). It is a great tragedy that there are one million people in Australia at this moment who cannot find jobs, and the Government shows very little concern for them. I was interested to go back and have a look at a particular quote by the Prime Minister on an MPI on 4 December last year. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The truth is this: unemployment will not reach double digits.

Unemployment figures are to come out for this month in a few days time. I wonder whether the Government is prepared to commit itself to what the Prime Minister told this Parliament only about eight months ago when he said--this is the truth, from the Hansard of 4 December--that unemployment will not reach double digits. Yet in the Budget we see the Government estimating that unemployment will go to 10.75 per cent.

One would think that the Government would show some genuine concern for the people who are unemployed. In this regard, I went back to the proposal for Newstart to have a look at what was said at that time. The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) said:
We have to find out why people are having difficulty in finding work.

They are having difficulty finding work because there are no jobs there, not because they are untrained or do not have the skills. What are the unemployed being trained to do in many of the training schemes which are now in place? They are being trained to be better keyboard operators. What do we find amongst the unemployed people? Hundreds of people with keyboard skills. So we are training more people to be unemployed.

It does not matter which areas we look at, we find that there are unemployed people with skills, but the Government has the concept that it should bring in the people who do not have any skills, train them and they will then get jobs. The reality is that that is not working. I have a particular concern for people who are 45, 50 or even 60 years of age who are looking for a job. I wrote to the Minister and requested that he allow some of these more senior people in our community--they are very able and skilled people--to do some voluntary work in a school or in a nursing home for one or two days to fulfil the Newstart agreement.

Let me illustrate the type of people I am referring to. A widow, aged 48, has a family of four children. One or two may still reside at home. She goes to a government department and is asked, `What new career would you like to take up?'. She has never been in employment before, is quite an able person and has managed her family well. She would like to contribute but she says, `I have already knocked on the doors of 50 employers and they all tell me the same thing, "There is no job here for you"'. Yet the Government is forcing these people to do these things when they would voluntary go down to----

TALK.START.PARA: —-No it is not.
—-I have the letter here.
—-Read it.

—-The Government is forcing these people to do these sorts of things and I believe that is demeaning to them. They are willing to go down to the local primary school, sit in a classroom and help young people learn to read. It was only this week that the Government talked about literacy, yet there are people out in the community who could help in a very practical way at the coalface. I say to the Government, `Look at these people more compassionately. Allow them to select the types of jobs for which they already have the skills and the capacity to go and help. They do not need retraining'.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me give another illustration. A leading carpenter, aged 57, has been in charge of over 50 men. He goes to the counter and is told, `On 1 July you have to show that you have either been downtown and knocked on a lot of doors and you are continuing to do that or that you will undertake some training program'. He says to me, `Over the last four or five years I have already done several training programs and it made no difference. The CES has not rung me in the last five years to offer me a job. When I go in there they say that I am too old'. Yet on 1 July 1991 this person is being asked at the counter, `What new career are you going to take up?'. I think that is very demeaning for these citizens of Australia. That person could go out and do voluntary work at a sheltered workshop or could do some repair work at the local recreation centre. He would be very happy to go and do it voluntarily. The Government should allow these people to do it.
The honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) has invited me to read the letter which I wrote to the Minister. I think that is a good idea. It states:
To meet the needs of the unemployed greater choice should be afforded to the more senior unemployed, many of whom would find positions to work in the community whilst unemployed.
That is the essence of my letter. These are some of the comments I got back:
However, establishing such a scheme would be prohibitively expensive and the coordination of all the participants involved would make such a program very complex and expensive to administer.

I was not asking for some grandiose scheme at all. But it shows the ideology of the Government--it does not want people out there working in the community for their unemployment benefits, because the ACTU will not allow them to do it. We see it time and time again: while there is a need out there in the community, the Australian Government is locked in with its union mates and will not face up to the changing realities of people's lives. The reply continues:

. . . it would have to contain a vocational training component providing skills which would be applicable to other employment. . . This approach makes more sense than a community work scheme from the community's point of view and from the point of view of unemployed people themselves.

What utter rot. People out there are saying to me that they want to go out and do the work, they want to contribute the skills that they have, they want to be effective participants, but the Government scheme will not allow them to do it. I ask the honourable member who is going to respond, the honourable member for Eden-Monaro, to get up and say whether these people will be allowed voluntarily to go out and do community work.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —-Is the motion seconded?
—-I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I certainly respond with an unequivocal yes. People should be allowed to go out and do voluntary community work, and they are allowed to. In fact, I would like to think that this is a fairly harmless motion which, if it were not for the wording, could be supported. It is a harmless motion if the two days community work is an option for the Newstart client. The trouble with some of these contributions from Opposition members is that there is an innuendo that it ought to be compulsory. These people have the option now. If they have been jobless for less than 12 months and more than three months and are aged, say, between 16 and 18, they can have not just two days of voluntary community work but 20 days if they so choose. If, like the people that the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) has just mentioned, they are aged 55 years or over, they can have six months--two lots of 65 days of community work. It is available to them; it just has to be proposed by the client.

SPEECH.PARA: The Batemans Bay RSL veterans' group, for instance, has offered voluntary help schemes to the CES, which it is very interested in. I thoroughly endorse the idea of people being available in the schools, and that is up to the schools. But if a voluntary work proposal is put forward by an unemployed person to the CES, that has to be looked at. If the CES feels that it is going to help the person, if that person is older, or if it will enhance the employment prospects of someone who is younger, then there is no doubt that it will be accepted. It certainly would be accepted if the spirit of the scheme were adopted.

But if the option is for the CES to say, `Look, you do that two days community work or you will not get an allowance', then the motion is a bad one because really what it is doing is requiring people to work for two days per week for the dole. That seemed all right to me perhaps 10 years ago, but I happened to be in London and saw how the Thatcher scheme worked in that regard. Along the Thames people were working; they were supposed to be cleaning up the river. There was an absolute lack of discipline. There was argument amongst the people. Only two out of the 10 people that I saw there were doing anything. It was obviously demeaning for them. It produced counter-hostility, with people particularly protecting their integrity by being belligerent. In other words, their self-esteem had dropped because of the type of scheme that it was. Working for benefits or an allowance compulsorily requires an infrastructure.

Opposition members have said that we do not need much extra money, but we do. I can recall schemes being offered to local government. They said, `Don't just give us people on the dole unless you are prepared to give us people who are going to be full time, unless you are prepared to provide overalls and boots, unless you are prepared to provide funds for a supervisor, unless you are prepared to provide insurance--which is extremely costly--and unless you are prepared to give us extra equipment that we can give them to use'. It just does not work and it is costly.

The community employment program, which was a great scheme, was costly. But working for the dole costs more. Penny Lockwood, the chairman of Queanbeyan Skillshare, has told me that working for the dole costs twice as much as the dole itself. Including government administration and everything, I believe it would cost more than a weekly wage.

Of course, there are areas in which this sort of thing can be done. For instance, the community development employment project for Aboriginals can be introduced voluntarily by the community. That is actually being done but it is being done outside that sort of environment. It has to be voluntary. The person has to be interested in doing the work. It also has to be done in conjunction with the CES.
Work for the dole is expensive and inefficient. The whole concept of the dole has been abolished and has been replaced by an allowance which is subject to an agreement between the client and the CES.

The motion also assumes that the option of two days community work will give greater recognition to the worth of the unemployed. That shows that the Opposition has gone nowhere since it was decisively tossed out of office in 1983.

We then had the wage pause, which was a bit better than the regional employment development scheme under the Whitlam Government because it gave women opportunities. The only thing wrong with it was that it was considered in conjunction with a cut in wages for workers and pensioners throughout Australia. Other than that, it was a bit of an advance. But those opposite have not advanced one bit since 1983. The Hawke Government introduced the community employment scheme, which was good but costly. But quite often people were left with nothing after three months involvement in the scheme.

We have now woken up. We have pretty good leadership, not only in the Federal Government but also in community groups, in State governments and in local government. We have realised that our primary aim is to fulfil the needs of the trading and service industries as much as possible. It is all very well to hark back, as people do, to the worthwhile work done by Roosevelt and to the work done in Australia during the Depression when people were made to build roads and bridges and were given what they called the susso. But that is now unsuitable because there is very little room in the Australian work force for people who do not have any skills; there are no jobs for them. And it is quite ridiculous to ask a local government to give people picks and shovels when it wants them to use sophisticated equipment.

We need to train people. We certainly can put people into award jobs, perhaps even with wage subsidies. Time and again it is drawn to our attention that the Opposition does not read the reports that come forward. The Finn report, an inquiry by the Education Council Review Committee into young people's participation in post-compulsory education, talked about the needs of these people and what we should be concentrating on. We should not be looking to find some stopgap measure for two days a week but rather looking at people's need for mathematics. I can recall a girl leaving in tears because she could not do basic arithmetic in the scheme.

Scientific and technological understanding, cultural understanding, problem solving, and language and communication should all start in primary school. I strongly support the recommendation of the honourable member for Braddon that older people should be allowed to go to schools and tutor people. I know one young lad who cannot go to school for more than an hour or two a day because he is difficult to manage. If he were to have one to one teaching with an older person it would make a lot of difference to his life. So I strongly support that.

People need to be able to speak English; quite often migrants cannot. So language and communication is important. We are beginning to realise that personal and interpersonal characteristics are extremely important. It will be a delicate process. That is why the Australian Council of Social Service and others are worried about it.

I believe we will come to a good result, because it is important how people appear when they present themselves for a job. It is important that they have self-esteem and that their interrelationships with other people are reasonably sophisticated so that they can get on with other people.

The real problem today is to bridge that gap between the high number of unemployed people and the jobs that are, and will certainly be, available as this country, along with other countries, pulls out of the present recession. We need to have people ready to take those jobs, whether they involve keyboard skills or a whole range of skills. We need people with self-esteem and social skills so that they can take those jobs.

At the moment there is a fairly low number of unemployed people who have even the semi-skills required for the work force. It is extremely important that we bridge that gap. That is what we are all about. We will not do it with measures like shunting people out--locking them out for a couple of days from the opportunities that can be made available. Sure, we have a lot to do to get that training right. We have a lot to do to get that training properly directed. We have a lot to do to assist people to develop their personal characteristics. But that is a far better and more productive exercise than shunting people out of the opportunities that should be available into dead-end activities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am delighted to have this opportunity today to second the motion moved by the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), because Newstart clearly is a failure. It is nothing but one more centralised Labor Government initiative--the big brother approach--to try to answer the lengthening dole queues of unemployment for which this Government has no answer.

SPEECH.PARA: I would not propose to this House that the solution to the question of unemployment today is simple. Certainly there are many complex issues that need to be addressed. There are many initiatives that we need to take in order to change the whole nature of our economy, to allow us once again to go back and approach the 1940s, the 1950s and the early 1960s when Australia had full employment. It will be difficult. Training is an important aspect of allowing us to regain our culture, and allowing full employment for all Australians.

However, the dole queues in my electorate of La Trobe are particularly devastating. There is a CES office next door to my electorate office. From memory, unemployment in the past 12 months has increased by something like 294 per cent--the largest increase in any electorate in the whole of Australia. I should like to draw to the attention of the House one small example of this Government's callous disregard for the unemployed in my electorate.

A very enthusiastic young man walked into our electorate office last week, a clean-cut young man aged in his early twenties. Prior to July 1991 he had been unemployed for some six months, but he did manage to work for about 10 weeks at some point during the past nine months. The young man did not have particularly high skills, nor was he exceedingly well qualified. But he certainly was unemployed.

He wanted to work and he was actively looking for work. He had proven his desire for work and his willingness to work by taking a temporary job for 10 weeks. My young constituent, whom we will call John, had just come from the local CES office where he had found on the job board just the sort of job that he could do. It was a cleaning job for which he had the appropriate experience and qualifications. John proceeded to take a job card straight to the CES officer in the hope that he could obtain an interview and, very quickly, employment.

Guess what happened? This Government's special kind of assistance for the unemployed really played a cruel trick of fate on John. He could not be considered for the cleaning job; he was not eligible because he had not been unemployed long enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Because he had worked for 10 weeks.

—-That is right. He had worked for 10 weeks, so he could not get the job and now he has to stay home. I think the proposal of the honourable member for Braddon for community service work is an excellent proposal. I believe the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) thinks it is a good proposal, too; he just wants to make sure that we do not say it is compulsory. I have no problem with that concept at all. The concept of compulsory work for the dole, as pointed out in a number of examples by the honourable member for Eden-Monaro, causes a lot of heartache and problems for many people.

SPEECH.PARA: But we do need to work very hard at trying to figure out what we are going to do to create real employment--that is, make real jobs for real people out there--and we had better do it pretty quickly before another

million people lose their self-esteem and their ability ever to go back into the work force again. So this whole issue of training is an issue which, as a member of this House, I will address again and again and again. It is my view that many of these training programs which the Government now operates--and there is a massively long list of them--are too short term, too open-ended, and not directed towards a structured improvement in work skills and vocational capability. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —- The wording of this motion demands careful analysis because it contains assumptions which do not stand up under scrutiny, and it dresses up a discredited policy in the clothes of compassion. I take on board the comments of the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles). I believe that he is sincere in what he says; nevertheless, the motion is indeed a misleading motion. For instance, the apparently simple request that the Government give greater recognition to the work of the unemployed implies that the Government does not already give the maximum recognition to the work of that particular group of people in our community--and that is not true.

SPEECH.PARA: This implication is, in fact, belied by the facts which bear testimony to the assiduousness with which our Government has addressed the needs of unemployed people in terms of their incomes, their self-esteem and their opportunities for education, training and jobs. We have consistently increased the budgetary allocations in the employment, education and training portfolio with the needs of unemployed people very much in mind.

The motion also calls for greater choice of Newstart activity agreements, including the option of two days community work for Newstart payment. Unfortunately, this request is only a thinly disguised re-run of the work for the dole concept with which the Opposition parties have been so closely associated for so very long. It is, in fact, a plea for cheap labour, which shows little understanding of the breadth of options which are available to unemployed people under the Newstart program. These agreements are meant to be tailored to the needs of each individual and each individual's abilities. As mentioned by the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow), individuals can already undertake elements of community work if that is the best option for them.

As far as community work in general is concerned, I totally support proposals aimed at providing jobs for unemployed people through community projects of substance as well as elements of work experience; especially, though, those that are financed by capital works brought forward to achieve publicly necessary infrastructure in local government areas and so forth, which is happening with some State Budgets at this very moment. However, such projects must pay an acceptable and appropriate wage to the people employed and must not be undertaken in the expectation of obtaining cheap labour. I believe that the Government has gone a long way in terms of wage subsidies to assist people who are currently unemployed to obtain work and to assist community groups with worthwhile objectives for whom unemployed people can work at a slightly lower wage than otherwise would be the case.

The motion before the House does nothing to highlight the coalition's avowed intention to cut everybody off the unemployment benefit after nine months. It does nothing to acquaint the people of Australia with the coalition's reluctance to maintain support for the wide range of labour market programs contained within our Government's active employment strategy. The truth is that those opposite have no intention of pursuing policies that will assist unemployed people into jobs through economic reconstruction, training, education or progressive skills acquisition. This motion is therefore window- dressing--but their policy shop is, at best, empty and, at worst, uncaring.

As is obvious from the comments of the honourable member for Braddon, the Opposition continues to support the concept of work for the dole, albeit not necessarily compulsorily. This motion is therefore an example of deceptive rhetoric.

Our Government, however, does recognise the worth of the unemployed. It recognises that worth by providing each person with an opportunity to develop, improve and to build on his or her existing abilities and interests with a view to obtaining and maintaining meaningful paid work.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The time allotted for the debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 April, on the motion by Mr Gibson:
That this House:

(1) notes the major contribution to enhancing local facilities made by the Commonwealth Government's Community Recreation and Sporting Facilities program through provision of financial assistance to sporting and recreational organisations;

(2) notes that the purpose of this program is to encourage the development of high quality sport and recreational facilities across Australia to enable greater community participation in sport and improved development of skills to enhance Australia's national and international sporting performances, as recommended by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration reports of May and December 1989 entitled "Going for Gold" and "Can Sport be Bought", respectively;
(3) seeks a continuation of this program in the 1991-92 Commonwealth Budget to enable additional support to be provided throughout Australia for development of further community facilities; and
(4) calls upon the Government to allocate:
(a) a sum of not less than $20 million over a three year period for the Recreation and Sporting Facilities program; and

(b) a similar sum for the establishment of a National Sports Facilities program to provide substantial financial support for the construction of sporting facilities of national significance, particularly in regional centres, in accordance with recommendations contained in the above-mentioned reports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Atkinson Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —- Like most Australians, I have a great appreciation of sport and of sportsmen and sportswomen. The contribution of sport to this country is well documented--we are a sports- loving nation. I therefore accept that there are very good intentions behind the motion and I hope that my contribution this morning will be seen as positive. I accept the assurances of the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) that there are no partisan political objectives behind this motion. I concur with the sentiments of the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) that there is not a lot of disagreement between members of this Parliament on the need for funding for sport. The difficulties arise when we must decide on the method of funding and the question of priority.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality facing Australia is that we are embedded in the worst recession since the Great Depression. Nearly one million Australians are out of work, small businesses are facing the greatest crisis in 60 years, and Australia has a foreign debt which is totally unacceptable. For eight years we have had a Federal government which has applied bandaid solutions when major surgery has been required. Indeed, it took a long time for Government members to admit that Australia is in severe economic recession. In such times, the Federal Government must be very careful about how it allocates public money. In tough times--and these are exceptionally tough times--we must get our priorities right and be very careful about how taxpayers' dollars are spent.

Like all honourable members, I am constantly being approached by community groups seeking Federal assistance for very worthy causes, and in most cases I am pleased to support these causes. As the local Federal member, I am willing to make representations on behalf of these community groups. It is then for the relevant Minister to make a decision regarding merit and priority, and we as local members must accept that there is a limited budget and that the Federal Government cannot be expected to fund everything. I suggest that this is the flaw in the motion moved by the honourable member for Moreton. It has merit, but there are limited dollars to go around.

Undoubtedly, there is a role for the Federal Government in the funding of sport. At the same time, there is a funding role for State governments and for local government, and all tiers of government must establish priorities and expenditure levels based on need and merit. To this end, I advocate that the primary role for the Federal Government must be the development of sporting excellence, and Australia's participation and contribution in international competition. This is a fair and reasonable position for a national government to assume.

I think that some honourable members forget that we are members of a federal parliament. We are not members of State legislatures or local councils. The Federal Parliament has a limited role. Its powers are limited by the Australian Constitution and residual powers and responsibilities remain with the States. I am not aware of any constitutional provisions giving this Parliament power or a role in the funding and administration of regional and community sport. I am well aware that the role and power of the Commonwealth has been constantly expanding since 1901, but that does not mean that we have to continue that trend.

Rather than seeking to expand the role of the Federal Government in the funding and administration of sport, I would advocate that it is time to return some of these functions to the States and to local government and that the Federal Government should concentrate its efforts on the promotion and development of sporting excellence and international competition. The development of further community sporting facilities should not be the concern of the Federal Government--there are unfortunately more serious issues deserving of our consideration and attention.

The showpiece of Australian sport surely is our performance at the Olympic and Commonwealth Games and at the various world championships. For a relatively small nation, our performances over the years have been outstanding, and Australian pride and nationalism have greatly benefited from the fine performances of our athletes. To this end, successive Australian governments have made significant contributions to Australia's sporting missions at numerous Olympic and Commonwealth Games. More recently, the Australian Institute of Sport has become the focus of Federal attention, and as a nation we have reaped the benefits of this fine sporting institution. This is a valid role for the Federal Government and there would be bipartisan support in this House for the continuation of such programs and expenditure.

The difficulties and divisions arise when it is suggested that the Commonwealth's role should be extended to finance regional and community sport. This suggestion is flawed because it presumes that a Commonwealth bureaucracy would be capable of administering and allocating Federal funding fairly and equitably to sporting bodies across Australia. The allocation of funds would be determined by a central Commonwealth bureaucracy, and this causes me great concern.

Finally, in speaking to this motion, I have the benefit of knowing what decisions were contained in the 1991-92 Budget. The honourable member for Moreton did not have the benefit of this knowledge when he presented this motion to the House on 18 April 1991. My reading of the Budget, as it applies to sport and recreation, suggests that the honourable member for Moreton should not be unhappy with his lot. The Government has decided to provide an additional $30m over three years and to continue the community recreation and sporting facilities program. This will amount to some $10.6m, including a carry-over of $2.6m in 1991-92. It is also important to note that the Government has made a significant commitment of $150m if Sydney's bid for the Olympic Games in the year 2000 is successful.

The Budget Statement for 1991-92 made the observation that over the last decade, outlays in sport and recreation have increased in real terms by about 109 per cent, and this includes significant increases in funding for sports development, community recreation and sporting facilities. In 1991-92, outlays on sport and recreation will increase by $7.8m to $78.6m, a real increase of about 8 per cent.

Earlier in my comments I suggested that too little recognition is given to the fact that this country is in the depths of a very serious recession. The Australian taxpayer is already overburdened and as a nation we continue to live beyond our means. The motion before this House has been presented with the best of intentions, but economic reality tells us that there are insufficient funds in the coffers and that it is time for us to put away the chequebook.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —- I am pleased that the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Atkinson), who has just resumed his seat, at least gave credit to the Government for the Budget initiative, but I was amazed at some of the comments that he made. He seemed to say that at times when there are economic difficulties we should not get involved in sport, recreation and cultural pursuits. I think that is an amazing claim; it shows an enormous degree of ignorance as to the importance of those three areas when it comes to the economic viability of any nation. It amazes me that he would put forward such a proposition. He obviously does not understand the importance of the bricks and mortar aspects of the sports industry and the cultural industries, and the advantages to a local community when someone builds a facility, whether it be a stadium of some note or some sort of athletics field.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Isaacs obviously does not understand the important contribution that is made in dollar terms to transport and travel. One can add tourism to that and also the enormous amounts of money that are paid to insurance companies across this nation that come back to sporting and recreational pursuits. One can add the salaries, the coaches, the advertising, the importance of sporting and cultural pursuits for television, the repairs and maintenance of equipment and human beings, and the health consequences. It comes back again to regional and parochial advantages.

I would suggest to the honourable member that he is wrong when he runs the line which says, `When things are tough economically, put aside those other issues'. I believe the motion that we are debating here today, which was introduced in April, is very timely. The honourable member made the point that the Government has acted on the proposal put forward at that time by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson). What he was putting forward at that time mirrored the aspirations at least of the members of the Government. I am surprised that the honourable member for Isaacs, who has resumed his seat, has not grasped the importance of what is in this Budget. I wonder whether he will go out to his groups and say to them, `Don't bother to apply because this is untimely. You don't have these things in times of economic recession'. We will see how many applications come from his electorate.

My electorate has already been told of the program's importance and this very day we are sending out copies of the application information so that people can get ready for 6 December, which is the deadline date. We are explaining exactly what people can do and how important this project is. It is important. It is an extension of what this Government has done through its previous sports and recreational programs, but it has gone further: it has added the cultural areas, something that members of the Government kept saying to Ministers in the past, including to Senator Richardson and the present Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly). She needs to be commended for including cultural pursuits in this program. It is an excellent idea and it will be applauded, just as it was applauded when the 382 organisations throughout this nation were able to access the $13m previously allocated.

There will be another $8m allocated for the rest of this financial year, starting from December; another $12m in the following year; and then another $10m. It is money well spent. It is money that is going into local areas to ensure that projects can be completed. It will ensure that new facilities can be undertaken, that facilities can be improved and, more importantly, that there can be coordination between local authorities and State and Territory governments, because that is what this is about. It is the Federal Government giving a lead, putting its money where its policies are and saying to the States, the local authorities and the community, `There will be $30m available to you over the next three years to ensure that you, the citizens of your area, benefit'. It surprises me that the honourable member for Isaacs has not come out applauding what is happening here. I thought he would have.

There are some controls--and so there ought to be. The Federal Government is saying that this time around it is prepared to give up to 100 per cent funding for projects that are worth no more than $50,000. After that, it has got to be dollar for dollar. There is also a limit of $250,000 on the sorts of projects that can be funded; that is responsible. If the Government has only $8m to give away in one year, then obviously it will not give it away in lots of $1m; it will want to spread it out as widely as it can to areas where there is a proven need or demand. That is what this is about. It is going to ensure that those who have the initiative at a community level--be they sporting groups, recreation groups or cultural groups--can now apply to this Government and say, `We need this money. Here is the need. Here is the demand. We have also raised some money, so we are making a contribution. Please support us'. That is what the Minister and the Hawke Government is doing.

It is a flow on from the Whitlam era. Honourable members will remember that under Whitlam we had the CALF program, the community and leisure facilities program. It has been Labor governments that have taken the initiative. It has been Labor governments that have realised the economic importance of ensuring that the quality of life of all Australians is continually improved by cultural, recreational and sporting pursuits.

When the Fraser Government came into power in 1975, it dropped the program. We had a gap, a void, for all those years, which was a great pity, because many organisations suffered during that time. Regional areas and small areas suffered because they did not have the dollars. I am sure the honourable member for Isaacs and other honourable members realise how difficult it is to raise that first $5,000 or $6,000 to get a project off the ground. But the real problem is finding the final dollars to finish it.

In Emu Park, an area in my electorate, the community raised almost $90,000 for a swimming pool, and yet summer after summer people could not use it because it was never completed. The Hawke Government went in there and said, `Okay. Let us do a deal with the local authority and the community', and $30,000 was given.

The Country Women's Association had tennis courts in a place called Thangool. It could not get them completed because the contractor went broke and the work that he did was substandard. This Government, at the request of the CWA, said, `Look, here is $20,000. Finish it'. There would only be a few hundred people in the Thangool area, but they then had an excellent facility. At a place called St Lawrence, it received $8,000 for a tennis court. That money was applauded by everybody, regardless of political persuasion. I too applaud what this Government is doing. I believe the applause is warranted and timely.

I agree that we have to be careful about too much Federal involvement, because this ought to be a coordinated activity at the State, local and Federal levels. There is never enough money for all applications. We found that with the thousands of applications that came in last time. We need to be very careful to ensure that we are not involved in duplication. We need, where possible, to promote multi- purpose centres as we see in some of the new mining towns in my electorate and throughout Queensland. We need to use those existing facilities in a better way. There are halls and schools that are under-used, schools that are only used for limited hours during the day and halls that are used sometimes once or twice a week. We need to look at what we have got and say, `Let's expand, let's be more efficient, let's maximise this usage'. However, as I said, let us not get involved in duplication.

I think we ought to come up with a coordinated activity. I would like to see future funding programs have this State and local government involvement. Let us strike some percentages; 20 per cent from the local authority, 30 per cent from the State and 50 per cent from the Commonwealth. Let us give priority to those types of schemes that involve that coordination and that three-way cooperation.

We also need better planning. There are cities in which there is a swimming pool for the community, yet the school does not have one. It seems to me that we ought to re-think this at a local authority level, as many authorities are doing, and build those facilities, be they swimming pools, squash courts or athletic grounds, so that the schools take advantage of them. It has happened in all sorts of areas in my electorate. Again we need to make sure that they are multi-purpose facilities, that we do get the advantages for education users as well as the general community.

I also think there is a need for a special program for isolated and regional Australia. I know that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, would understand that there are many people out there in regional and isolated Australia who never get these opportunities. I know that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Snowdon), as a representative of the Northern Territory, would understand that problem.

There are kids who could really make it to the top but never get that edge. I advocate that we get further involved as a Federal Government and give some sort of catalyst by way of dollars to ensure that an experiment that we tried in the electorate of Capricornia last year with the backing of teachers and the Education Department is emulated right across Australia. We went to six or seven small schools, little one-teacher schools and two- teacher schools, and asked the parents and citizens associations to pick the four or five best. We then got the railway unions through their institute at a place called Coppabella to provide the facilities and the P and Cs from the Nebo and Coppabella schools to look after the grounds. The teachers gave of their time and the kids came in for a crash clinic for three days. It was an unbelievable success, backed by the unions, backed by the Education Department and backed by the community. We need to do that sort of thing right across regional and isolated Australia.

If we are going to do any more by extending what we are doing already as a Federal Government, let us look at that. Let us get the local authorities, the States and the Commonwealth together to look after those young people out there in isolated Australia to ensure that they get the chance. There are kids out there who could be champions but never get that edge. They never get that extra bit of training that lifts them above the average. I believe that the experiment that took place at Coppabella last year, backed by the trade union movement, the railways and the education department, was a supreme success and ought to be taken up and used as a model for the whole of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sawford Mr R.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) in his address to the House today emphasised in a very telling way the importance of community sporting facilities and the crucial role that the Federal government can play in coordinating the roles of State and local government. I am very pleased to support the motion moved by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson), which calls on the Government to develop programs dealing with local sporting community facilities.

SPEECH.PARA: The development of elite sporting centres for excellence and assistance for improving the infrastructure of community facilities are not separate issues. They should, in my view, always be considered together. They are interdependent.

There is no doubt, in my opinion, that the exposure to choices of participatory sport to children in the age range of 7 to 12 significantly determines the success or otherwise of all our future athletes and provides the foundation for a healthy lifestyle for all Australians. Implicit in that statement is the quality and the sensitivity of coaches, role models and the encouragement offered by family and community members.

For many young Australian children their first exposure to sport comes when they attend their local primary school. In the past, primary schools generally have only offered participation to the few in traditional sporting facilities on a fairly ad hoc basis. Today that participation is not exclusive, yet questions could be raised as to its effectiveness when there is a general absence of specialist teachers in physical education in our nation's primary schools--state and private. With the many tasks expected of primary teachers it is not feasible that without additional teacher resources much will be achieved in that very crucial foundation school sector.

I point out to honourable members that a primary teacher probably works about 900 person hours a week; a secondary teacher about 400; a TAFE lecturer, 150 hours plus; and a higher education lecturer, 150 hours minus. So, in many ways, the expectations of primary teachers in physical education is unreal. For sport to be successful and to cater for elite athletes, a strong foundation must be built. For too long in this country we have had an attitude of the quick fix--piling in resources at the top and forgetting about the real needs of the beginnings. For example, we would not build a house with fragile foundations and paper walls and then put in chandeliers. Yet when it comes to tackling issues of whatever description we often fall for the trap of `chandelier thinking'.

The role of the Commonwealth is to coordinate the roles of State and local government and community activity in sport. We should have decentralised sporting centres of excellence to allow athletes of whatever age to live near their home or to be able to live in their own State. However, community sporting centres play a much more important role than simply a setting off point for future elite athletes. In those community centres sporting skills are realised and attained. Often children are exposed to role models in the form of encouraging and sympathetic adults and peers who in a subtle, informal, yet very effective way, provide opportunities for many children to build their confidence, self-esteem and acceptance within the community. Is that not what this motion is really about--the building of confidence in Australia's young people?

The most important skills that young people gain are the subjects: confidence one, confidence two and confidence three. Once they have majored in confidence our young people are capable of anything. Once confidence is gained, people do not run away from problems; they find solutions and they work their way through them. It is the development of courage on the inside, not the brash cockiness and bravado on the outside. Community sporting centres provide real opportunities for our young to find their way in the world and to be the very best in their chosen field. It may be at an elitist sporting centre but it may be as an artisan, engineer or whatever. The most important result is a confident young Australian prepared to play a positive role in Australian society.

I note that I have a few seconds left. Perhaps I could mention the role of the greatest participatory sport in Australia--netball which, for many years, has been offered, and has acted, on very few resources. In my electorate of Port Adelaide, Ruby Oakey, a woman in her 80s, has assisted thousands of young women in that sport who have been responsible citizens in the electorate. I have great pleasure in supporting the motion moved by the honourable member for Moreton. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —- Order! The debate is adjourned and resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House:
(1) congratulates Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania on finally regaining their independence from the Soviet Union;
(2) welcomes President Gorbachev's acknowledgment that the Baltic States have a right to independence;

(3) calls upon the Soviet Government to expedite its formal recognition of the independence of the Baltic States and rapidly withdraw its remaining troops and paramilitary personnel from the Republics; and
(4) urges the Australian Government to examine ways of supporting the reconstruction of the economies of the Republics.

As the events in recent weeks have overtaken the appropriateness of the content of the original motion that I placed on the Notice Paper some weeks ago, I take this opportunity to put this amended motion before the House.

We all know that the recent events in the Soviet Union have given rise to historic changes in the political, social, economic and strategic landscape of eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. One of the consequences of these changes has been the regaining of independence by the Baltic states of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania after 52 years of illegal annexation by the Soviet Union under the terms of the notorious Ribbentrop-Molotov pact of 23 August 1939.

But their independence has come at a cost. When the new Lithuanian Parliament declared unilateral independence from the Soviet Union in March last year, economic sanctions were imposed against the republic and were later lifted only when the Lithuanian Government suspended its independence declaration. We can all remember those matters; I raised them in a motion in the House at that time.

On 1 March and 1 April 1990, respectively, Estonia and Latvia also declared their independence, to take place only after a period of transition. In early January 1991, when most of us were absorbed by the horrors of the Gulf War, Soviet troops occupied a number of public buildings in Lithuania and Latvia. On 12 January, Soviet troops occupied a broadcasting centre in Vilnius, the capital of Lithuania. Tragically, at least 13 people died and many hundreds were wounded as a result of this illegal occupation. Killings have occurred also in Latvia where the Soviet military seized a government building.

On 19 August, after the communist hardliners had removed President Gorbachev from power, Soviet forces stormed television stations, blocked harbours and seized strategic sites as the Moscow backed hardliners declared that they were taking control of the secessionist republics. I think we all watched in horror as those events unfolded. The courage, patience and quiet resolve of the Baltic peoples have been demonstrated time and time again over the years. Under extreme provocation the Baltic people have deplored the use of violence and have resisted the use of military retaliation to press their legitimate claims.

Undoubtedly, the determined resistance of the Baltic and the other Soviet republics contributed to the failure of the communist coup, which in turn led to their independence. I can recall the British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, saying:
You can't run a country with the KGB, the Communist Party and the Army--you need the people.

After that abortive coup, many of us look back with hindsight and consider those events. We are glad to see that the comment from Douglas Hurd was true, but the fact is that the KGB, the Communist Party and the army went very close to pulling it off. I must say that one of the real fears that I have is that we have been lulled into a false sense of security. In part, if they had been resolute enough, determined enough, determined to take enough lives, determined to suspend all of the communications and determined to deny Yeltsin and the leaderships of the other republics the opportunity to speak, we might well be discussing today a motion of a very different character. I must say that I am undoubtedly pleased at the way in which events have unfolded, but I think we have to be very much on our guard that we do not see these circumstances as justifying an absence on our part of vigilance and continued concern.

The people of the Baltics are to be congratulated on regaining their independence. It was one of the quirks of history which found us commemorating the anniversary of the Ribbentrop-Molotov pact so shortly after it looked like there would once again be a military army occupying the Baltic States. For that reason I took a particular interest in this matter.

I proposed, in my original motion, that we express concern about the events that had occurred just in advance of and during that military takeover in which there was a tragic loss of life. It was then appropriate that the anniversary of that pact fell at a time when we were reminded so poignantly of the ease with which democratic aspirations could be undermined and destroyed, with these events taking place in the Baltic states.

It is important to acknowledge President Gorbachev's statement that the Baltic states have a right to independence. We must call upon the Soviet Union, as we do in this motion, to expedite its formal recognition of the independence of the Baltic states and to withdraw its remaining troops.

But the fact is that there are signs, even now, that events are further changing. We may see recognition by the Soviet Union of the independence of each of the Baltic states. Reports overnight suggested that President Gorbachev may in fact recognise that that Molotov-Ribbentrop pact, about which we have so frequently commented, was an illegal annexation--thus the three states are entitled to their independence--and that the Soviet Union recognises this is the case.

Notwithstanding the recognition that Australia and each of the other major Western powers--save the initial hesitancy of the United States of America--has accorded the Baltic states, the Baltics live in the shadow of an omnipresent threat to their sovereignty until the Soviet Union says it also accepts the reality of this situation.

We, in the Opposition, have put many motions to the Senate and to this House demanding that the Soviet Union give the Baltic people their freedom. In the spirit in which this motion is proposed, I congratulate the Government on recognising the Baltic republics. It was a little time coming. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that he hoped that Australia would be one of the first countries to recognise the Baltics, but in the end we followed well after most of the Nordic countries and well after much of Europe and Canada.

TALK.START.PARA: —-That is not correct.
—-It is correct; the honourable member might like to check the history of that. The honourable member interjected a sour note into a debate in which I had just offered congratulations--
—-You didn't put it in the motion.
—-I offered congratulations to the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Dr Theophanous interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-If the honourable member believes, with the Government's record in relation to the Baltic states, that we ought to bend over backwards to be an apologist for it, when those opposite were the very people who, at the other time of test, walked away from the Baltic people and gave de facto recognition to the Soviet takeover--and only after it became a political issue did they change their minds--let him introduce that note.

SPEECH.PARA: But I do not want to tarnish this motion, which recognises the importance of the independence that the Baltics have. We are glad they have achieved it; they have earned it and they deserved it. I hope we can continue to support them in the reconstruction of genuine democratic regimes in each of the republics.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —-I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Government supports the general thrust of this motion, but is extremely disappointed at the total lack of generosity of the Opposition. It gives no recognition--none whatever--to the courage of the Government in being one of the first countries in the world to recognise the independence of the Baltic states.

SPEECH.PARA: A moment ago the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) said that we recognised the Baltic states after the Europeans did; he should get his facts right. The fact is that Australia recognised the Baltic states before the European countries, before the European Community. I challenge him to contradict that point.

As a person who has been involved for a long time in this struggle for the recognition of the independence and sovereignty of the Baltic states, I take exception to the honourable member's comments that, in fact, we came to this rather late, and only when it became political. What nonsense! It is very easy for the Opposition to make comments; it is another thing for the Australian Labor Party, which is in government, which has the actual responsibility of governing and making determinations and decisions.

If one looks at how this process came about, one sees that one of the most significant things has been the fact that the Australian Labor Party passed a resolution at its national conference in June this year in support of the independence and sovereignty of the Baltic states. That went far beyond the fact that the Hawke Government has never recognised the incorporation of the Baltic states into the Soviet Union.

We went beyond that point in the national conference this year. We recognised the events and called for Australia to recognise the independence of the Baltic states and to call on the Soviet President, Mr Gorbachev, to go further in the recognition of the independence of the Baltic states. The latest news is that he will exercise his powers as President of the Soviet Union and finally disown the infamous Molotov-Ribbentrop pact. That is a very important development.

The Opposition's motion does not in any way signal the important fact that Australia was one of the first countries to do this. This gave great heart to the Baltic people. I would have hoped that that would have been incorporated into the motion. The fact that it has not been incorporated into the motion is a glaring omission.

The most important thing that has happened for the Baltic people in Australia in many years has been the act of recognition by Australia of their independence, which as I said gave heart to and in fact encouraged other countries around the world. It was certainly the first Anglo-Saxon country and one of the first countries in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development to do so. So to suggest that Australia and the Australian Labor Government have not been forward in this matter is a nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Followed Canada.
—-It should have been included in the motion.
—-Followed Canada, followed the Nordic countries.
—- Order! Interjections must cease.

—-There is no reference to this. Imagine having a motion on the Baltic states and ignoring the most important fact that this Parliament, this Government, was one of the first to acknowledge their independence; ignoring the act of recognition by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) of their independence. I was very moved by the wonderful work of the Baltic people of Australia, especially the work done by the Baltic Council of Australia in Victoria and its Chairman, Valda Liepens. Three days before Australia's recognition, on the fifty-second anniversary of the infamous pact, I was proud to be amongst those who attended a vigil outside the arts centre in Melbourne. That vigil was to express solidarity, as was the lighting of bonfires throughout the three Baltic nations on that same day. As happened in medieval times, these bonfires signalled to the world the very real danger that the Baltic states still faced. As we know, there was a coup in the Soviet Union at that time. The conservative forces were ready to reinvade the Baltic states. Fortunately, the Soviet coup collapsed and within days Australia recognised the independence of the Baltic states.

SPEECH.PARA: The work of the Baltic Council and many people from our great Baltic communities--the Estonians, the Latvians and the Lithuanians, who for many years have wanted independence--has finally come to fruition. It was a very emotional moment and after the recognition was announced, I was proud to attend meetings of both the Lithuanian and Latvian communities--I will soon be attending an Estonian function--which celebrated their independence.

Those people--not the politicians--are the ones who deserve our congratulations for their persistence over many years in what has been a just cause. Why has it been a just cause? Because the Baltic states were forcibly incorporated by the infamous Molotov- Ribbentrop pact between Stalin and Hitler. Those three nations are culturally different, and proud of it. They do not hate the Russians. They do not have anything against Russians as such, but they are a culturally different people from Russians. Their cultures are more akin to those of that region of Europe than they are to the Russian culture.

Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia have persisted with their claim that they were very hard done by. The whole international community should feel ashamed that action was not taken earlier to pressure Mr Gorbachev and others to grant those states their independence, because they are not the same as the other states of the Soviet Union; they are completely different. They were forcibly incorporated, and that was a gross violation of human rights which should have been reversed many years ago.

It is better late than never, as they say in life. A very important act has been carried out. It has provided a symbol for many other people around the world who are oppressed and who are forcibly prevented from undertaking acts of self-determination. It is time that we in the international community recognised that, simply because as a result of some war some superpower decides to draw boundary lines on a map and forcibly incorporate people into that boundary, it does not follow that that constitutes a natural nation.

We must recognise that if we are serious about human rights one of the fundamental human rights is that of self-determination. The Baltic peoples satisfy all of the conditions for being separate nations. They have done so from the beginning. It is a shame that this matter was not dealt with by the international community much earlier. It is amazing that the United States still has not recognised the Baltic states, and I hope that it does so as soon as possible.

Several of the superpowers are having trouble coming to grips with the fundamental principle of self-determination. That principle must be respected in relation not only to the Baltic people but also to many other groups around the world that have a clear claim and who have been forcibly incorporated. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: --It is with a great deal of pleasure that I support the motion moved by the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) which congratulates Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania on finally regaining their independence from the Soviet Union. Most honourable members know how the Baltic states were annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. A grubby deal was done by Hitler and Stalin, both renowned butchers of this century. It is something that the Baltic states have had to live with for many years.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Soviets took over the Baltic states it is alleged that an average of 60,000 people from Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania died. Many of those people were taken as captives into the gulags and were never heard of again. I recently took a trip to eastern Europe, and I believe that some of those people may even still be there if they have been fortunate enough, or unfortunate enough, to survive.

I visited Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Bulgaria and Poland. When one speaks to the people in those countries one is amazed at the great load that has been lifted from their shoulders. I say to the young people in the gallery that we in Australia are not really aware of the meaning of freedom and democracy. They are a precious flower that should be guarded very strongly. Given what is happening in the Soviet Union and other places today, young Australians should closely study the history of those countries.

On returning to Australia from eastern Europe, and knowing how wonderful those people felt, we heard of the Communist coup in Russia. It seemed that once again the conservative forces were going to take over. I was terrified to think of what this would mean to those people whom I had met in eastern Europe if this were to happen again. I was terrified to think of what would happen to their families, work, freedoms--in fact every facet of their lives. All of that would be affected. I doubted whether they could take it. If a Communist coup had happened again, heaven knows what would have happened as far as revolutions and counter-revolutions were concerned.

When I was a young boy, I met a fellow called John. He was the first Baltic person I met. He had come from Lithuania. At the age of 10 years, he told me stories of murder. His father had been killed by the Russians. At the age of 10 years he was able to tell me that his mother and sisters were raped by whatever armies were going through that particular part of the country at the time. He was in Australia and he finished up in an orphanage because he had no father to look after him.

That was my first experience of someone from the Baltic states. From that time onwards we know that the Baltic people here in Australia have made a tremendous contribution. We know that the Baltic states were perhaps better treated than some of the other satellite states of Russia in that they had more food and better opportunities because they were close to the Scandinavian countries where news would come from.

By 1950 a lot of the resistance to the Soviet invasion had almost ceased because the KGB and the Soviet Government had ruled supreme. But in recent years there was a movement in the Baltic states. The flame of freedom was never extinguished, and the movement developed. Now we see countries all over the world recognising the Baltic states and their freedom. Lithuania has borne the brunt of the problems with the Soviet Union, but now there is great joy in those states as we see them being recognised by other countries.

I congratulate the Baltic Council of Australia on the work it has done in trying to impress upon our Government the need for us to recognise the independence of the Baltic states. I should like to say to John, my friend of many years ago, `I hope you have had a good life in Australia. I hope things have gone well for you. I am so pleased for you and the country of Lithuania which holds your heritage'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Catley Dr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It gives me great pleasure to rise to congratulate Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania on gaining their independence from the Soviet Union; to welcome Gorbachev's acknowledgment of the independence of the Baltic states--a right which they have; to call upon the Soviet Government to expedite its formal recognition of the independence of these three states; and to urge the Australian Government to examine ways to support the reconstruction of their economies.

SPEECH.PARA: Since I became the member for Adelaide, I have attended a number of rallies and spoken at a number of rallies on behalf the three Baltic nations, many people from which live in my electorate. After the motion was passed at our Australian Labor Party convention in June urging the recognition of Lithuania, I wrote to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) in the following terms:

During the last 18 months Lithuania's democratically elected government has declared its independence but been recognised, I believe only by Iceland. At critical moments when the Gorbachev leadership's utility to the West are in evidence--at the outset of the Gulf War, when Gorbachev received his Nobel Prize, and during the recent Moscow summit--Lithuania has been subjected to repression and killings by Soviet special forces . . . I write to ask you two things. Could we make diplomatic inquiries to the Soviet government about its future intentions with respect to the Baltic states and the level of repression it regards as appropriate? And could you also provide me with a public statement concerning Australia's current policy towards those states of the Soviet Union pursuing independence by democratic means.

Shortly after I sent that letter, before the Foreign Minister could reply, the fortunately abortive coup took place in the Soviet Union, which spurred me to then write to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the following terms:

I believe it is well beyond the time when Australia should recognise the sovereignty of Lithuania, and I urge you to take steps to rectify our current foreign policy with regard to this State. I would suggest that we look to extending this recognition to the other Baltic States of Latvia and Estonia at some time soon.

A couple of days after that, on 27 August, I was pleased to note that the Prime Minister announced that the Government had decided on that date to establish full diplomatic relations with the Baltic states of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. I was very pleased to note this early recognition by the Australian Government. I was able to take these messages, together with the letters that I had written to the Foreign Minister and the Prime Minister, to a rally that had already been organised for Saturday, 31 August, on the steps of the South Australian Parliament House situated on North Terrace. That was last Saturday. I explained what I had tried to do. I read out the Prime Minister's statement of recognition and the hundreds of people not only from the Baltic states but also from other nations still held captive by the Soviet empire passed the following resolution unanimously. I assured them I would bring it to this House and read it out, which I now propose to do:

The Baltic communities of South Australia wish to express their gratitude to the Prime Minister of Australia, the Hon. Bob Hawke as being among the first leaders of english speaking countries to recognise the de facto independence of Estonian, Latvian and Lithuanian States.

Of considerable significance for Baltic communities in South Australia is the fact that diplomatic recognition by Australia of Baltic States came ahead of the European Community and United States confirming its leading role--
that is, the Australian Government's leading role--
in human and national rights.

As the Governments of the independent Baltic States are facing enormous challenges in restoring damaged environment as well as rebuilding the economy after fifty years of Soviet occupation and mismanagement, generous economic assistance and cultural exchange should be made available to the people and governments of the Baltic States.
They conclude:

The Baltic communities of South Australia also wish to express their gratitude to the Opposition for their support, and all friends in parliament for numerous resolutions promoting the independence of the Baltic States.

Finally, I should say that this coming Saturday, at 11.30 on the steps of Parliament House of South Australia, North Terrace, Adelaide, there will be a rally held by the Ukrainian community of South Australia to seek a similar movement towards independence by the Ukrainian state. I will be attending that rally and will be speaking there in the same terms as I have to the Baltic peoples. Essentially what I will say will be this: when the Ukrainian state has control of the population, control of the territory and is capable of entering into diplomatic relations and foreign relations with other states, I will be urging on our Government that we undertake exactly the same course of action as we have recently taken with respect to the Baltic nations, that is, entering into diplomatic relations with the sovereign state of the Ukraine.

—-Mr Deputy Speaker, I read it out. Thank you.
