PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 14 March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

It is a great pleasure to be able again to present to this Parliament the Flags Amendment Bill. This is the 1991 version, the same as the 1990 one. In fact, this is the fourth time that the coalition parties have presented this Bill to the House of Representatives. It really behoves the Government to take up the challenge this time and accept this Bill and to allow it to be passed. It has already been passed in the Senate six years ago on a motion by my colleague Senator Durack, and I find it extraordinary that a Government that continues to claim that it supports the Australian flag is not prepared to support a Bill which does nothing more than allow the Australian people to have a say in whether or not they maintain this flag. I have formally moved the second reading of the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —- Do you wish to receive a seconder at this stage?
—-Yes.
—-I second that motion and I reserve my right to speak at a later time.

—-As I say, it is extraordinary that the Government, which professes to support the Australian flag and, in fact, uses parts of it in its own logo, is not prepared to allow the people of Australia the right to have a say in whether at any time they wish to keep the Australian flag or change it. All this Bill does is to say that any suggestion of changing the Australian flag should be put to a referendum of the Australian people. It does nothing more, yet on every occasion when this is brought to the House the Government refuses to allow the matter to be voted upon. One can only ask the question: what is it hiding; why is the Government not prepared to take the Australian people into its confidence and to show them that it is serious about the fact that any proposals to change the Australian flag have to be voted on at a referendum? I cannot for the life of me see why the Government is refusing to take up that challenge.

SPEECH.PARA: So again we present this Bill, and again I call upon the Government to respond in a positive manner, to accept the Bill as it is and to allow its passage through this chamber to complement what has already happened in the Senate. In that way, we will then be able to allow the people of Australia to have a say in any proposals to change.

It is interesting to note that the last time this was debated, namely, last year, the Government accused the Opposition, of all things, of taking up valuable time of the House. I found that quite extraordinary because it is entirely in the Government's hands. As I say, this is the fourth time we have put this Bill up. If the Government were serious about its supposed support for the Australian flag, it would allow the whole matter to proceed forthwith.

It also is very interesting to note that until 1988 the Labor Party had as part of its platform the abolition of the existing Australian flag. Then in 1988, it just quietly slipped off the platform. One wonders what was really going on. But I still think we have to ask where the Government's sincerity is, because clearly there are a lot of doubts. The fact that this Bill has had to be re-presented in itself shows that we have very grave doubts about the Labor Party's sincerity on the matter of supporting the current Australian flag.

It is interesting to note that a senior member of the Government in another place, Senator Evans, was quoted in Hansard in 1981 in his disparaging remarks about the Australian flag, which are well known but worth repeating here, as having said:

We can do. . . better than the present undistinguished and undistinctive bit of cloth which we have inherited from our colonial past and which manifestly does not set anybody's pulse racing in the community at large, except, perhaps, the occasional Returned Services League blimp or a proportion of the tory back bench opposite.

That is an extremely insulting statement from Senator Evans. It is one that shows total lack of understanding of the people of Australia, and lack of understanding of the contribution that so many have made to this country, particularly in the name of our Australian flag. I guess that highlights why we continue to doubt the sincerity of the Labor Government in its continuing refusal to accept this Bill.

We are presenting this again to give the Government the opportunity to change, the opportunity to actually take up this challenge and the opportunity to show that this Labor Party does in fact have the chance to support the Australian flag, as indeed another leader of the Labor Party did in years gone by. I think it is worth reminding honourable members opposite of just what one of their former leaders, Mr Arthur Calwell--a great leader of the Labor Party--said in 1953 when the Flags Act was introduced by the Menzies Government. It is worth noting that the Act was signed personally by Queen Elizabeth II. In supporting the Government, the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Calwell, said:

Every nation needs a symbol of its unity. . . It is true that a flag is merely a piece of bunting, but it is also true that it is something round which the whole nation can be rallied. . . Now that we are to have a national flag, let us give it pre-eminence on all occasions.

Those are fine words from the leader of the Labor Party of the day. I think those sentiments ought to be brought home to honourable members opposite, who should again be asked why they fail to support what is a very basic amendment? I refer honourable members to section 9 of the Bill:
The Australian National Flag declared by section 3 shall not be altered except in accordance with a proposal to alter that flag that has been:
(a) submitted in each State and Territory to the electors qualified to vote for the election of members of the House of Representatives; and
(b) approved by a majority of all the electors voting.

That is very straightforward and I welcome the support of my colleague the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford), who is seconding this Bill. I therefore call upon the Government to take up the challenge and allow this Bill to pass through the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —-There are two questions here. One concerns a mechanism that would be invoked to either assist or deny change to a symbol of Australia--that is, the Australian flag; the second question concerns the credence that one gives to the current Australian flag. I want to distinguish both elements, because I find it is difficult to accept the proposition of using the mechanism of a referendum in order to get change. We know that it is difficult to put a positive point of view to the Australian people--in order, for instance, to change the Constitution--and get it up successfully. The very mechanism of a referendum is one that is very difficult to use to produce change.

SPEECH.PARA: If one wants to use the mechanism of a referendum in order to stop change, then it is almost certain it will have that effect. The use of a referendum to stop change in Australia is almost certain to succeed. That is the difficulty I have about using the mechanism of a referendum on potential changes to the flag, which would almost certainly mean there would be no changes to the flag. That is the difficulty I have with the Bill and why I will not support it.

Let us look at how changes take place. I am thinking back to the Whitlam era. In that great Labor Government's period we got used to very simple terms such as the `Australian Government'. We moved away from the older term of `Commonwealth', even though `Commonwealth' referred to the Commonwealth of Australia and not to the Commonwealth of Nations--that British notion. Whitlam's very use of the language helped to mature this nation, because he used the term `Australia'-- `Australian Commonwealth', `Australian Government'. I think even the cups and saucers in this place used to carry the insignia `Commonwealth Government' and it was changed to `Australian Government'. I know that some honourable members opposite refuse to eat their food off plates which have `Australian Government' on them.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Nonsense! Rubbish!

—-It is true. A couple of the honourable member's mates refuse to eat their meals off plates with `Australian Government' on them. Perhaps the honourable members are no longer here; they may have been tossed out at some previous election. But the story is certainly true.

SPEECH.PARA: Whitlam was elected with a clear notion that he wanted to make Australia a prouder country, a more mature country, and he did that by introducing new language and so on. To try to lock in a current symbol of the nation is, I think, folly. The nation does need to make up its own mind, but one cannot put in an absolute blocker on one's ability to make that change.

During the many times that I have explained the symbolism of the current Australian flag to school children in my electorate I have always regarded the flag as a map of Australia's history. Of course, we were discovered and then later populated by the British, and it is fair that at this point in our history we retain the Union Jack, because it is an accurate description of our history. Then, of course, with the blue background, there is the notion of moving from the British Isles, across the sea, to discover this great land in the southern ocean symbolised by the Southern Cross.

Thus the symbolism of the current flag is absolutely accurate in terms of describing our history. When I am talking to school children, I go on to ask them whether that description--now, in a sense, a couple of hundred years old--will be relevant 50 years down the track. I see the Australian flag as being on a scroll where, over time, the relevance of British institutions and the notion of discovery will lessen, the flag will roll on and the Union Jack will eventually slide off the flag. It will need to be replaced by other symbols of Australia, circa 2050 or whenever.

There will come a time when a very large number of Australian people will probably seek more relevant symbols for Australia at that time, and we must not seek to stop them achieving those new symbols by using this device which we know is very heavily weighted against change.

I do not like the device and I want to encourage debate about the notion of the flag as it exists today. Of course, I am very proud of our flag. As I have mentioned, it is a very accurate description of where we have come from. We have the seven-point star, the star of the Commonwealth of Australia, which indicates the notion of bringing six States together, the extra point symbolising the Commonwealth itself. All these things are entirely accurate and are an appropriate description of Australia today, but they may not always be so. It may not always be that the Australian people will wish to have the flag exactly as it is today. In time we may well want that scroll to roll on; we may well desire the change.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Have a referendum.

—-The referendum, we know, would make it almost impossible to get the change, because every time a referendum is run in this country it is next to impossible to achieve change. I predict that it would be absolutely impossible to achieve change over such an emotional thing as the symbol of our country in an Australian flag.

SPEECH.PARA: At the moment I cannot give an alternative mechanism that would satisfy both the mover of the Bill and me as to how we might achieve change with a complete consensus of the Australian people. I am not quite sure. For instance, one could not simply put a series of flags to the Australian people and have a series of questions on a referendum. That would be a dog's breakfast. It would be difficult if we were to put half a dozen flags before the Australian people.

Remember that in about 1903 the current Australian flag was designed in a competition, probably worldwide, for which the prize was, I think, #200. It was never put to a referendum. One of the successful entrants was a Kiwi. A New Zealander and a couple of Australians were equally successful in designing the current Australian flag. There was no referendum--there was a prize; like a lottery. We have a fascination with lotteries and prizes in this country--free, new, whoopee, terrific. We did that back in 1903. It is strange to say that from time to time since then the flag has changed--in minor ways--again without reference to the people.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The same as currency.

—-Absolutely; currency has changed. We should have kept the quid rather than take up this notion of the dollar--it is disgraceful. It is very American and very New World. I would rather have stayed with the pound and the quid. That is to indicate my conservative credentials on this question.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us not confuse the question. Our flag was drawn up by means of a competition. It was judged by governments--not at that time by the Australian people. It has been changed consequently, but not through the will of the people, and--as the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Mr Price), who is at the table, indicated--so have other important symbols of Australia such as our currency. To all of a sudden halt what is now a tradition of drawing up and then changing the flag by using a most conservative mechanism--that is, a referendum--would fly in the face of almost 90 years of tradition. Ninety years of tradition would dictate that the Australian flag is a moving target; it has changed from time to time.

I want all those school children whom I address to think about changes they might want to make. They may not want to make changes to the Australian flag, but when the time comes that they are mature and able to vote, they should have the right to join the rest of us and not be cut off by this device of a referendum. So, with great respect to the honourable member who pursued the Bill, I find that I cannot give it my support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: --I am very pleased to second the motion for the second reading of the Flags Amendment Bill. I am disappointed that the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) was unable to support it. I think he has created something out of this proposal which just is not there. The Flags Amendment Bill is not about preventing change--and I want to remind him about that and to make that point strongly; it is merely about setting in place the process for change and establishing a methodology for change.

SPEECH.PARA: We were reminded by the honourable member for Petrie about the Whitlam years. Most Australians are still horrified to be reminded about the Whitlam years because many of the valued institutions and values that existed in our society at the time were changed. Changes were imposed on us from above, often insensitively, and, with the value of hindsight, I think, ill-advisedly. With great enthusiasm, the people of Australia eventually threw the Whitlam Government out on its ear and Malcolm Fraser came in with the biggest majority in history and maintained that majority through to the next election.

The honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), who is the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister and who is at the table, interjected--with some levity, I take it--that we had changed the currency and we did not have to have a referendum for that. I take that interjection seriously because it completely downgrades the importance of this issue. We cannot compare the Australian flag, and the tradition that it represents, with the Australian currency. It is not a matter of changing the quid for the dollar in this case. Many Australians have died to preserve what this flag represents. Australian sportsmen have served with distinction underneath this flag, and they have been inspired by it.

This private member's Bill seeks to ensure that the flag, because of the tradition it represents for many Australians, is not changed lightly or without the fullest consideration of the implications of change. The ultimate decision for such a profound change ought to rest directly with the Australian people, not even with the Parliament. I do not say this lightly: I say it because perhaps we cannot trust parliaments. That is probably a terrible thing to say, but the Whitlam experience showed us that we cannot trust Parliament. To be even-handed, I hesitate to say that it is only the honourable member for Chifley's Party that we do not trust. The point is that we believe that even the Parliament should not make such a profound change to a cherished tradition without reference to the Australian people by a referendum.

Having said that--and in fairness to what the honourable member for Petrie said, I took the point of his contribution--I believe that it ought to be said that I, and perhaps many others who support the Bill, do not necessarily believe that the flag should remain forever. The honourable member for Petrie is right about that. It may well be that a persuasive case could be made for change, because he is right--things do change over time.

It should be recognised that many countries have made changes to their flags but, in my view, we do not want to make change without a clear indication from every individual Australian that there should be such a change. There must be good reasons for change. I suspect that sometimes we are tempted in this place to make change for the sake of change, but unfortunately some people have little respect for tradition; and there is a big difference between nostalgia and tradition. If we tear down or destroy tradition, we tear apart the very fabric of our society. I suspect that perhaps that is what some honourable members on the other side of this place want to do.

Perhaps the time to change the flag will come, but this Bill seeks to put in place a process or a methodology for change, and the question that the Australian people ought to be asked in that situation is, `Do you want a change?'. Let us not muddy the water about giving them different designs to choose from. The fundamental question that this Bill seeks to entrench is that the Australian people will be asked that question at a referendum: every individual Australian will be asked, before any change is made, `Do you want change?'. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gayler Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —- My comments will be brief but, I hope, to the point. I say at the outset that I have some difficulty in understanding the necessity for this legislation. Whilst I do not oppose it in its form, I find the necessity of it quite unwarranted. There are many areas of legislation that pass through this place and become law that also, I believe, are unwarranted. I believe that the educative process is the way to approach this, as it is in many other areas of legislation. I believe we are putting into place legislation which could inhibit the respect of our Australian standard: the national flag. When we look at the situation where the law enforcers in our community have legislation in place which they have to act upon, would that not focus more for those who wish to express their views against our national flag? I just pose that question.

SPEECH.PARA: No-one to whom I have listened has mentioned the basis or make-up of our national flag. I have no difficulty with it, but I note that no-one on the opposite side who has spoken has mentioned the presence of the Union Jack. I have some difficulty with the presence of the Union Jack. I do not really see that in this day and age the presence of it has anything to do with the nation of Australia.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has said on innumerable occasions that there will be no change to the Australian flag without a referendum. I do not see that as being a problem. Personally, I would not like to see it changed without the consent, the feeling and the views of the majority of Australians--

TALK.START.PARA: —-That's what we are asking for.

—-I know those opposite are asking for it. They will be the first to run out if there is a referendum and muddy the waters--as they do in every referendum--and mislead the Australian public on the voting of referendums. They have a sickening record of that. The honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) has not been here very long. If he has enough time up there on the Gold Coast he should look in the history books and he will see the Opposition's record on referendums. The Opposition cannot even get its tourism industry going up there--the Government has got it up and running in Cairns and it is leading Australia in its recovery--let alone talk about the standard of the Australian flag.

SPEECH.PARA: Those opposite muddy the waters and mislead the Australian public, as they have always done, on the voting of referendums. This piece of legislation is useless. The Opposition's record speaks for itself. The putting into place of regulatory sanctions could, in the long run, be counterproductive. There is no doubt of that in my mind.

Quite frankly, as one trained in `legalese', I find the Flags Amendment Bill to be a very vague piece of legislation; in fact, the preamble is certainly not met by the contents of the Bill. The last part of the preamble is not even enshrined in the legislation. Whilst I have no difficulty with the legislation per se, I believe it could have been better drafted. It really is not necessary. If these are the sorts of things that the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) wants to bring forward in this place, I feel sorry for the constituents of his electorate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave --There were a lot of red herrings in the speech of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler). He spoke about tourism, which was getting off the track. I will put the honourable member's mind at ease. He accused us of going out and muddying the water over referendums. That would not be the case here. We will not go to the Australian people and misrepresent the question. We are saying this is such a cherished tradition that we would not want to see the flag changed without every Australian being asked, `Do you want to change the flag?'. What is wrong with that? We can only suspect the motivation of those opposite if they do not agree to this proposition. Why would they want to impose such a fundamental change on the Australian people? The honourable member for Leichhardt has said that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) intends--he does not have very much time left; we ought to recognise that his days are numbered--to change the Australian flag. I take that as a serious affront, as a direct threat to the traditions that I cherish.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier, many Australians would be very suspicious of the motivation of this Government and this Prime Minister, who stands up and says, `I am going to change the flag'. We believe that the flag is fundamental to our traditions--and traditions are important. Perhaps the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) does not believe that tradition is important--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to the fact that the honourable member is speaking about the flag with his hands in his pockets. I do not believe that is appropriate.
--Order! There is no point of order.
—-I am chastised. I shall remove my hands from my pockets. This issue is not a complex one. I am disappointed that the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns), is a Queenslander--
