PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The abject failure of the Hawke Labor Gover- nment and the Australian Taxation Office, the ATO, in redressing extensive abuse of interest withholding tax--appropriately called the `out of harbour schemes' by Mrs Barbara Smith of the Phillip Institute of Technology in Melbourne, who has consistently and courageously researched this subject in great depth--is a matter of continuing disgrace.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said in my grievance speech on 7 March this year, estimates of the revenue lost to the Commonwealth through these schemes vary significantly, but it has been estimated that up to $1 billion a year in tax is being avoided or evaded through these schemes. Furthermore, the Martin Committee report entitled Follow the Yellow Brick Road, tabled in this House on 18 April last, concluded among other things on page XI:

That specific measures aimed at countering the withholding tax arrangements identified during the inquiry are both warranted and necessary in order to reinforce existing anti-avoidance measures available to the ATO.
In addition, the Committee said on page XV:
The low priority accorded to the withholding tax area by the ATO was evident from the absence of administrative controls which are now being implemented by the ATO.
It was further stated on the same page:

In the view of the Committee, the lack of administrative controls in this area has been an important factor contributing to the continued abuse of the withholding tax provisions through non-resident beneficiary and other tax avoidance/evasion arrangements.

There has been ample time for the Government to study the exhaustive findings and recommendations of the Martin Committee, so it is more than reasonable to have expected action in this last Federal Budget to stop this blatant loss of revenue.

Not only did reform not eventuate but a regressive step was actually taken, as correctly reported in the lead item of the Fagin column in the Sydney Sun-Herald of 1 September. As background to this backward move, I point out to the House that Budget Paper No. 1, on page 4.21, states:
Revenue from withholding tax was $901 million in 1990-91, 13.4 per cent below the Budget estimate. The estimate for 1991-92 is $1,100 million, an increase of 22.1 per cent on 1990-91.

This apparent increase comes about because the interest withholding tax collected at 10 per cent on interest paid to non-residents has quite surreptitiously had included under its head of revenue the resident withholding tax, an entirely separate tax collected at the top marginal rate of 48.25 per cent on the interest of resident bank accounts where a tax file number has not been quoted. Mrs Barbara Smith is aptly quoted as saying in the Fagin column that this `bears all the hallmarks of creative accounting'. In fact, it is difficult not to believe that this is a deliberate measure aimed at confusing the Parliament and ensuring that no further analysis of non-resident interest withholding tax and thus quantification of interest paid to non-residents will be possible.

Odd as this change might be, it must also be added that it is only the latest in a series of strange events that have occurred in the formulation and administration of tax policy since the Hawke Labor Government was first elected in March 1983. Why, for instance, was section 14 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, relating to the annual report, amended in May 1983 to take effect from 18 July 1983, from a precise requirement in the former section 14(2) that, `the Commissioner shall draw attention to any breaches or evasions of this Act', to a more bland wording that effectively allowed the Commissioner of Taxation to discontinue the publishing of the names of tax defaulters in the annual report?

More recently, what lay behind the extraordinary allegations in the media in April of this year that tax file numbers were being sold as part of a tax fraud racket? The subsequent conviction in a Sydney court on 30 April of an illegal immigrant on nine charges relating to misuse of another person's tax file number and other tax related offences still left unanswered questions about this bizarre episode.

I turn now to the most disquieting matter I wish to raise in respect of taxation policy and administration, and that is the role performed over time by Mr Mark Leibler. In my grievance speech of 7 March, I referred at length to Mr Leibler's representations in 1986 to a senior level of the ATO, which resulted in the withdrawal of 700 standard letters sent out by the Melbourne branch of the ATO to trustees of schemes taking advantage of withholding tax arrangements. In essence, those letters questioned the legitimacy of arrangements made and required `prompt payment of the full amount of tax assessed'.

Mr Leibler is well-known as a senior partner in the Melbourne city law firm of Arnold Bloch Leibler and is a taxation lawyer of long standing. I am sure the House will be most interested to know that Mr Leibler has for some years also been a member of the Commissioner of Taxation's advisory panel, the national tax liaison group and the capital gains tax subcommittee. In addition, it must be pointed out that Mr Leibler is the only non-ATO person to sit on all three of these key tax advisory bodies. It quite clearly places him in a position of enormous influence.

I would also suggest, given Mr Leibler's record over an extended period, that it puts him in a position of acute conflict of interest and potentially compromises the integrity of the ATO. Let us look at some aspects of Mr Leibler's most interesting history over the past decade. In a Melbourne Age report of 5 June 1982 concerning the McCabe-Lafranchi report on tax avoidance, Mr Leibler was reported as being director or secretary of seven companies that went to the bottom of the harbour.

On 10 December 1985, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the AAT, in the case of Arnold Bloch Leibler and Co. and the Federal Commissioner of Taxation, determined that the entire text of ATO procedures manuals sought by Arnold Bloch Leibler were exempt documents as their release would jeopardise the effectiveness of ATO procedures. Yet, incredibly, the ATO had already granted Arnold Bloch Leibler access to 90 per cent of the procedure manuals, guides and other documents sought.

Furthermore, within a month of Mr Leibler's appointment to the Commissioner's advisory panel in May 1989, Arnold Bloch Leibler instructed for the taxpayer against the Commissioner before the AAT in a case involving sham transactions of money never remitted to overseas beneficiaries. Not long after a vicious attack on ATO operational staff by Mr Leibler in the Age of 26 September 1990, Mr John Thorburn, one of the best ATO auditors in Melbourne on offshore tax avoidance, was moved elsewhere.

Mr Leibler accused the Martin Committee of conducting a witch-hunt, yet an Age report of 18 April 1991 pointed out that he has been frequently quoted as advising two of the 15 companies identified as major users of tax havens by the Martin Committee.

Undoubtedly, one of Mr Leibler's most extraordinary acts was writing a letter to shareholders as chairman of the companies Numinous Nos. 3, 4 and 5. The letter, which was enclosed with the notice of the annual general meeting, read in part:
Your directors believe that they have solved the problem of potential capital gains tax on vendors' gains and this enhances the appeal of the public shelf company concept.
This letter is written by the same man who then and now advises the ATO on capital gains tax matters as a member of the capital gains tax subcommittee.

It is clear that the time has arrived for a major public inquiry into the management, administration and operational effectiveness of the Australian Taxation Office by a principal committee of this Parliament such as the Parliamentary Joint Committee of Public Accounts. Moreover, such an inquiry should closely examine the membership of ATO advisory bodies and their relationship with the ATO.

In conclusion, I seek leave to table details of the AAT cases I referred to and also the letters concerning companies Numinous Nos. 3, 4 and 5. I have already shown these documents to the Minister at the table.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I want to spend a little time this afternoon defending but at the same time evaluating the Australian Government's better cities program.
—-It is not one to defend.

—-It is not difficult to defend, and I think that it needs to be because it is mostly misconstrued. It is misconstrued because in a sense we have made a number of announcements whilst we, the Commonwealth, are still in negotiation with the State governments.

SPEECH.PARA: Everyone would acknowledge that we ought to hold as a principle the fact that there ought to be a greater choice of housing in Australia; that is, that we cannot continue to build three- bedroom houses on a quarter-acre block because in a sense that leaves out those people who cannot afford it or who do not need that style of housing. We would also acknowledge that our very low density cities, our sprawling cities, are particularly energy wasteful and polluting and that, by and large, because we have to travel such very large distances in order to perform daily functions such as travelling to work or to the shops or whatever, there is built in a locational disadvantage to those who have to locate at the fringes of a city.

There is also this question of fairness; that is, whether people have sufficient physical access to the sorts of services that people, say, in the middle and inner suburbs have access to but those in the outer suburbs do not. There is a corpus of concerns that arise where Australian citizens do not have equal access to services or, as a group, are energy wasteful in terms of the degree of travel they have to undertake just in order to lead their daily lives.

I think it is fit and proper that the Commonwealth have a concern for these matters, especially with respect to the efficiency of cities as well as to the fairness aspects. However, the question arises: how does the Commonwealth intervene? That is one that I am happy to talk about because the Commonwealth is literally still negotiating those sorts of matters.

I am chairing a subcommittee of the Standing Committee on Long Term Strategies that is looking at the patterns of urban development. We want to concentrate particularly on the mechanisms that will create change in Australian cities. For instance, the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) has already announced that there will be some money for capital works which will most likely be used for demonstration projects to be built on Commonwealth land, probably in our major cities. These would be mainly along the styles, I would guess, of medium density developments whereby we could demonstrate that there are alternative ways to house people very happily and suit their needs, a bit more cheaply, closer to the city and much closer to existing arms of public transport. I applaud that. I think that is the decent and proper thing to do.

However, more powerful mechanisms to change the rules of play may be available to the Commonwealth and these, of course, are the politically more difficult ones. For instance, are we going to change the relative costs of different sorts of housing? I understand that the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce has reported that the cost of building a medium density unit as opposed to a stand-alone house is often higher, but for quite artificial reasons. Often it is because not sufficient land has been released to medium density housing by local governments, although that--for instance, in Adelaide, where I was last week--is hotly contested. Often it is because there is a distinct prejudice against the whole notion of medium density housing, so local governments purposely slow down the building of such developments, and of course those residents who live on the quarter-acre block do not want next to them a medium density housing development. So, there is a prejudice against that type of development.

There is a third element, that is, the awards under which builders pay their wage rates differ between building a single house as opposed to a two- or three-storey medium density development. We have to look seriously at whether we are artificially raising prices of a certain form of housing in Australia as opposed to our more common and much loved stand-alone house.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Take my word for it; you have.

—-I think so too. It seems to me that withdrawing some of the impediments to building certain forms of housing will be perhaps the most powerful mechanism that can be used. Much as I love my house on its quarter-acre block--it is possibly a bit more in Brisbane because land is a lot cheaper there--I certainly would not want to buy an alternative medium density house somewhere in the city if it was dearer. If I had to give up my beautiful backyard and it was going to be as costly to buy a unit, however pretty and delightful it was, I would not do it. There would have to be a significant differential in price for me to make the shift. Also, I might not make the shift at this stage in my life with two young children and, who knows, more on the way at some stage.
—-Does your wife know about this?

—-No, she does not, but when I get home later this week we will talk about it--or maybe we will not. Perhaps in 15 or 20 years time, when my children move on, my partner and I will not want such a house as we have now. We may be looking for something that is more appropriate to us. We will not care about tending the garden and we will not need as many rooms--in fact, I am sure we will be upset and distraught because the kids have run away and left us, and we are looking for alternative accommodation.

SPEECH.PARA: Will there be enough of this accommodation, and will the price differential be enough? I am not that fussed about money because I am paid very well, but there are those who have to be very careful about selling one property and buying another. Presumably, if we can make this alternative available whereby, as one reaches an age where the kids move on, there is a significant enough price differential, I will want to buy into accommodation that suits me better--just two bedrooms or the one rather than three or four. I do not have a three or four-bedroom house, but I am just making a comparison.

We need to look significantly at those mechanisms that will really count every time there is a purchase of a house. Of course, those mechanisms will be far more powerful than the Commonwealth spending money on a demonstration project. As I said, I think we need the demonstrations but we may also need to change some of the rules of play.

The cost of movement within Australia by individual motor cars is really quite cheap, much as constituents would not agree with me on that. At some stage, the Commonwealth will have to bite the bullet on the issue of whether or not there ought to be a carbon tax--that is, a tax on all sorts of burnable fuels that are not renewable--in order that we make sure we get the best use out of those fuels. Again, it would not be readily supported by people. It is the cost of moving around by means of individual transport which is the very cause of low density cities. It is possible to commute 40 or 50 kilometres because petrol and cars are relatively cheap. If we are fair dinkum about changing the rules of play, we would have to seriously debate the cost to the individual of moving around.

If we want people to make more acute locational decisions, it will concentrate the mind very readily if it becomes more expensive to travel around in individual cars. Of course, the danger of that is the distributional effects. We would not want to harm those people who live great distances from the city and do not have a great deal of income. We are not looking to tax them. We need devices whereby people will be far more aware about their locational decisions and the consequences of them. Only by those means are we going to rearrange our cities sufficiently so that we get some decent efficiencies and save some of the very wasteful costs that we now have on the public works and infrastructure in Australian cities. That is what the Common- wealth is in the middle of discovering. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My grievance concerns the state of the mining industry in Australia and, in particular, the condition of it in Western Australia. My concerns are confirmed by a consulting geophysicist in my electorate. My constituent points out that he has both undergraduate and postgraduate qualifications in his field. He has some 30 years experience in geophysics, mainly in the area of mineral exploration. For the past 13 years this man has been the proprietor of his own registered company, once employing two other people. The firm has a considerable amount of computing equipment and other capital items.

SPEECH.PARA: As he himself has pointed out, one would expect such a person to be drawing an income in the vicinity of at least $50,000 a year before tax, even making allowances for the impact of the recession we had to have. However, this chap's earnings in recent years were only half that amount. In the 1989-90 financial year his income was something like $25,000, on a turnover of $48,800. Last tax year he managed to draw an income of only $20,000 on the basis of a turnover of $40,000. During 1990 he estimates that he had two days work a week throughout the year. He has not had any paid work since May of this year.

The man concerned cannot qualify for Jobsearch allowance while he is nominally employed by his own company. To qualify for a benefit of that sort he would need to give up his company and his considerable personal investment in its development over many years. He joins some 500 geologists out of work in Perth at the present time. Job advertisements for geologists in Western Australia invariably rate 100 or more applicants for each position.

Mineral exploration expenditure has fallen considerably in Australia in recent years. From a peak in 1987-88 of $799.2m, mineral exploration expenditure has fallen to $607.5m in 1989-90 and a similar amount in the last financial year. Contributing factors to the exploration slump include the stock market crash of 1987, which has since discouraged speculative investment of the type which mineral exploration embodies. The introduction of a gold tax has obviously not invigorated the goldmining industry. Various changes to companies law have made the establishment of new enterprises more difficult and much more costly.

A number of decisions by the Federal Government, such as that over Coronation Hill, have created uncertainty and undermined investor confidence. A new tax ruling has disallowed the deductibility of the cost of airborne surveying outside leases held by an exploration company. Previously, Western Australia and Queensland benefited from the practice of mining companies flying over large areas in order to select sites for leases, which was not permitted in other States. This tax ruling ignores the realities of mineral exploration which requires the study of geology, geochemistry and geophysics of large tracts of land in order to choose an area with potential for mineralisation.

The result of all these factors and others depressing the mining industry will be a brain drain of geologists and others with related qualifications to overseas countries, or to other vocations where their qualifications might be usefully applied. Exploration companies are increasingly focusing their attention overseas due, in part, to the unfavourable environment in Australia at the present time. BHP has extensive activities in Chile--most notably the Escondia copper mine--and MIM is also beginning to explore there. CRA operates in the Philippines and Indonesia. Western Mining Corporation Ltd has operations in the United States, Canada, Liberia and Chile and is expanding those overseas operations. Obviously, the profits from these ventures will be repatriated to Australia, but we lose out on the employment and activity that would result if these operations were conducted in Australia to a much greater extent than they are now able to.

Australia has fallen from the position of the leading minerals explorer to around thirteenth place over a number of years. Chile is the leading explorer at the present time, which may be somewhat surprising. Australia is thus experiencing a relative decline as an explorer for minerals to the long term detriment of mining activity in this country.

The current vogue amongst policy makers and others in Australia is to increase the level of value added production in our secondary industries. The focus on value added production looks to manufacturing in order to boost our production of traded as opposed to non-traded goods and thereby improve our export performance. It seems that primary industries, such as mining and the various service industries, are considered to be of inferior value in making a contribution to our future economic development. Increased value added production is something to be valued in itself, but it should not occur at the expense of the development of those industries in which we have a comparative advantage.

In terms of international competitiveness and increasing our production of traded goods, developing those areas in which we have a comparative advantage will be more important than looking for value added production in the areas in which we are less competitive. Mining is one of the industries in which we have traditionally had a comparative advantage, and this is something we should continue to nurture.

It also happens that there is significant scope for Australia to add value to our mining activities through the secondary processing of our minerals prior to export. Adding value and developing our natural advantages need not be mutually exclusive activities. As with any other industry, this involves creating a favourable economic climate with as few distortions and disincentives as possible.

No-one needs reminding that the current economic climate is not a favourable one, but this climate is not simply the result of a monetary policy induced cyclical downturn. Even before the recession there were numerous obstacles in the way of Australian industry, including the mining industry, which need to be swept away before we can make further progress in the development of those industries. The situations on the waterfront and with coastal shipping are obvious obstacles in the way of the mining industry and the exports it can generate.

Our taxation system and, specifically, the various imposts on the mining industry, as such, create numerous problems which inhibit our economic development. The Australian labour market is not really a market at all but more like a rationing system for jobs, where the price for labour is set by a central authority with no regard to the circumstances of the individual workplace. Many of our product markets are sclerotic and in urgent need of micro-economic reform. Our government business enterprises need to be fully privatised before they will deliver productivity comparable to that in the private sector. Extracting this country from recession is only the first of many challenges that confront the nation. We are also faced with the massive task of overhauling decades of economic inefficiency and underproductive government activity. While this situation continues to exist, we see, through the various approving agencies, paralysis by analysis. No industry in Australia is more affected by that than the mining industry, particularly in Western Australia. All the talk in the world is not going to change that. It is time for this Government to take action and, where necessary, to take action in cooperation with the governments of the various States.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —-On 3 June this year, the report of the Task Force to Review the Operation and Planning of Brisbane Airport was presented to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Senator Bob Collins. This report, I am sorry to say, did not meet with the satisfaction of the community members of the task force and certainly does not have the support of a large section of my electorate. This is evidenced by the presentation this morning in this place of petitions signed by over 1,900 citizens of Brisbane rejecting the findings of the task force.

SPEECH.PARA: In presenting the report and subsequent recommendations, the task force appears to have failed to consider its basic purpose for existence. I must explain to members of the House a brief recent history of Brisbane Airport and its noise problem. The whole problem was caused by the very poor decision of the Fraser Government to locate the new Brisbane Airport at the mouth of the Brisbane River. No reasonable impact studies were done on the likely noise implications for Brisbane residents and a lot of false claims were made about its effects. In fact, when the airport plan was developed in the late 1970s, my friend, colleague and neighbour, the honourable member for Griffith (Mr Humphreys), put in a minority report opposing the development plan. He knew then what the problems would be.

The matter was further compounded when the Liberal Government cut back on the original airport development plan by reducing the length of the cross runway, preventing its use as the major runway and forcing the majority of flights to take off and land over the city. The people of Brisbane were sold a pup by the Liberals when they were told that aircraft noise would reduce considerably or disappear entirely in all areas of Brisbane when the new runway was commissioned.

The construction of the new airport did not reduce noise disruption, but it has largely transferred the problem from one side of the city to the other--thus the inception of the Brisbane Airport task force. Within days of the airport's opening, hundreds of complaints from southside residents poured in. My colleagues the honourable member for Griffith and the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca) have worked very hard to have positive action taken to alleviate the noise problems since the airport's opening. Many measures that have been implemented have improved the situation, but the basic problem will always remain because of the original short-sighted decision of the Fraser Liberal Government to locate the airport at the mouth of the river.

Since my election in March of last year, I have also taken up the cause for my constituents who have been affected by aircraft noise. Brisbane's residents had been advised by the Department of Civil Aviation when the new airport was developed that the majority of aircraft--between 80 and 90 per cent--would take off and land over Moreton Bay. This, however, is not the case.

I obtained figures from the Civil Aviation Authority which show that only approximately 55 per cent of planes take off and land over Moreton Bay. In June this year, the figure was 54 per cent and in July it was 56 per cent. The conclusion that more than 80 per cent of planes would take off and land over the Bay was based on the false assumption that there would be two main runway alignments: that is, a north-west/south-east runway, which they call the 14/32 runway, and a north/south runway, which is called the 01/19 runway. That was the original plan for the airport, but it was dramatically cut back in 1981 when the length of the 14/32 cross runway was reduced. Only 55 per cent of planes take off over the bay because the 14/32 runway is not long enough or wide enough to take large aircraft over the bay.

In 1989, after much pressure from my colleagues and the community, the Brisbane Airport task force was set up. However, the task force was flawed from the start, both in its composition and in its terms of reference. The terms of reference were contradictory in nature and the composition of the committee severely limited the effectiveness of community representation. The terms of reference were:

The Task Force will review and make recommendations on the operation and planning of Brisbane Airport to minimise the impact of aircraft noise on surrounding communities while still providing an airport that will meet Brisbane's needs into the future.
The Task Force is to take the following guidelines into account during the course of the review:
- The airport is to remain curfew free.
- The airport is expected to meet Brisbane's future aviation needs.
- Additional runways would only be provided when justified by capacity levels.

This final point was the crunch clause of the terms of reference that tied the committee's hands and prevented it from recommending early action on lengthening the cross runway to enable greater use of flight paths over the bay. Further, the terms of reference stated:
In carrying out the task public involvement will be maximised by close liaison with community groups, industry and State and local government.

The committee did contain three community representatives, one nominated by each of my colleagues from the seats of Griffith, Bowman and Lilley. Unfortunately, the seat of Moreton was not represented on the task force because of the failure of the previous member for Moreton to fight for the interests of his constituents. The total committee consisted of 13 members, of whom 10 were departmental, local government and airline company representatives and only three were from the community.

Protecting vested interests and covering up for past failures and very poor decisions, rather than responding in a meaningful way to the concerns of residents reflected in the views of the community representatives, became paramount in the work of this group. The three community representatives were continually out-voted and out-manoeuvred by the Department-airline coalition. It is little wonder, then, that each of the community representatives contributed dissenting reports to the final report of the task force.

Despite the fact that the first paragraph of the task force's terms of reference identified that noise was the major issue, the task force has quite clearly provided no relief from aircraft noise for the long suffering residents south of the Brisbane River. The task force has recommended the construction of a runway parallel to the main 01/19 runway, which is causing the noise problems at present. The task force opted for this rather than a cross runway, despite the fact that the task force has stated in its report:
Noise impact is greater--
for the parallel runway--
than for the alternative 14/32 cross runway development.

Even to the casual observer this must be a clear breach of the terms of reference which had been set. The recommendation to construct a parallel runway clearly did not take due consideration of the task force's terms of reference. Such a plan would prove to be a total disaster for the whole city of Brisbane and cannot, in fact must not, proceed.

The only proposal which will not adversely affect densely populated suburbs is the extension of the cross runway. The task force has clearly failed to minimise noise for Brisbane residents--one of its prime reasons for existence. In doing so, the task force ignored the evidence provided.
In a submission to the federal Public Works Committee in October 1979 on the planning of the airport, the Civil Air Operations Officers Association of Australia stated:
A north-west, south-east runway alignment allows aircraft to operate from the north mostly over water.

Further, the most common wind in Brisbane during bad weather is a south-westerly--thus the need for a two-runway system. At the same time, the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, in a submission to the inquiry, stated:
Runway 14/32--you approach from the sea and take off over the sea. Unless we can point out to you the total disaster this airport is going to be without a cross runway I think we have failed.
How true those words proved to be for southside residents. The Fraser Liberal Government ignored this advice and the task force has compounded this crime.

The task force also had the option of shifting landing beacons in order to alter flight paths and divert them away from homes and over the bay. The task force has ignored the option of placing a flight navigation beacon on or near Stradbroke Island, which would have put flight paths over Moreton Bay and not over homes.

At present there is a flight navigation beacon located at Colmslie near the bay and at Laravale near Beaudesert. This means that when guided landings and take offs are required--that is, at night or when the weather is unfavourable--planes must fly over homes and over suburbs in my electorate stretching from Tarragindi and Ekibin to Camp Hill, Coorparoo, Greenslopes and Annerley. This practice effectively means that planes do not fly over the bay. It deliberately takes them over densely populated areas. The task force ignored the relocation of the flight navigation beacons to the bay, which would have avoided the problems of noise for most households.

If not addressed now, the problem of aircraft noise will only become worse. The eastern suburbs are one of the fastest growing areas of the city. I look forward to continuing to work closely with my colleagues, and in particular with the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, to find better ways to deal with the aircraft noise issue. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —- In recent weeks, and particularly during the past week, there has been a great deal of public debate regarding gun laws in Australia. A number of differing perspectives have been articulated within the context of that debate. This debate follows the recent Strathfield Plaza shopping centre killings in suburban Sydney in which eight people died and a number of others were injured. We are all well aware of the tragedy associated with that event. Many people, particularly those who were involved in this horrendous occurrence, were moved to tears. The Premier of New South Wales, the Hon. Nick Greiner, yesterday described those killings as `one massacre too many'. Indeed, he was right--nobody would disagree with that. Today's Sydney Morning Herald carries a report that Mr Greiner will announce today the composition of a bipartisan committee to report on the State's gun laws. Mr Greiner said that there was agreement within the State Parliament to produce `cleaner and tougher gun laws that are enforceable'. In addition to this, the New South Wales Government has undertaken to agree immediately to a moratorium or a cooling off period--however temporary that may be--while this serious matter of gun control is looked at.

SPEECH.PARA: My personal view, of course, is one of sympathy with the basic principle that has been proposed. But, of course, I am opposed to any moves that will result in the disarming of the ordinary people. One of the themes of the former communist manifesto in respect of gaining control was the importance of disarming the people to make them weaker. But the action that is being taken is very necessary. No Australian, and certainly nobody in this House, would disagree with the absolute necessity to review the whole situation and for a moratorium to be put in place. I applaud all those initiatives and I am sure that all in this House would agree that a sensible, well thought out strategy is desperately needed.

There is, however, a far greater threat to the well-being of our fellow Australians, in particular our women and children--a threat that is far worse, I believe, than the weapons currently under debate. One of the things that prompted me to get up and speak this afternoon is the fact that for days after the massacre at Strathfield all our newspapers carried front page stories with headlines printed three inches high suggesting that guns must be banned.

Research has shown that the person responsible for the Strathfield massacre had been subjected to the sort of diet of violent videos and publications that we know are part and parcel of such a tragic scene. Yet, even though the headlines said that guns must be banned, it was hard to find anything in print that suggested that something should be done about the violent videos et cetera that we are confronted with daily on our television, through various video outlets and in theatres.

I believe that a loaded gun which has a much greater potential for destruction is being held at our heads. I refer to the violent and hard-core pornographic videos and literature that are readily available in our communities. I will direct a few of my comments along those lines today. I can speak from vast experience in this field. Before I entered Parliament for 17 years I was involved in criminology--not as a criminal, of course, but as someone who dealt with those who perpetrated many horrendous crimes in this nation. For 11 years before coming into Parliament I was chief superintendent of a large institution to which all the inmates committed by the courts of New South Wales were juveniles.

There is clear evidence coming from courts around the country that the ways in which crimes of violence are now committed have greatly changed. We are faced with a very serious problem, and I think it is a problem that the community has not fully grappled with. If it had, there would be a lot more activity within local communities with regard to the effect that these videos are having on certain people in our communities who have this low control over impulses. The majority of people, of course, do not have that problem. But there are many people in our community who have a very serious problem with regard to controlling their impulses, and it only takes a violent video of some kind or a hard-core pornographic video or piece of literature to spark them off along the way to a quite dastardly crime.

The time has come for this House to stop brushing aside this very serious problem that confronts us which, as I suggested earlier, is really a very large, dangerous loaded gun that is pointed at the heads of our women and children, in particular, in this great nation in which we live. Ten years ago a man could leave home in the morning, say goodbye to his wife and not worry about the doors and windows. Today, when a man leaves home he suggests that his wife makes sure that all the doors are locked and the deadlocks fastened, and that she is very careful about whom she opens the door to. The situation has changed dramatically; our community has become a very dangerous place. It is largely due--and we do not need any research to back this up, although there is voluminous research coming out now--to the impact and effects of violent videos, movies, literature and hard pornographic material on those in our community who are less able to control their impulses. We have a very serious situation indeed.

A Melbourne barrister by the name of Mr Richard Read--he is now, and has been for the last 12 years, a prosecutor in the courts in Melbourne--has become very concerned about the many criminal activities in Victoria. He has become so perturbed about the need to come to grips with this problem that he has now gone on a public speaking campaign in strategic areas to bring before the community the awareness that it needs to have with regard to the effects of these influences upon it.

I commend him for the action that he has taken. In some of the cases that come before him which he finds quite distressing--as, indeed, do I--he puts forward a very good case for all parliaments to sit up and take notice. In this House it is very easy to brush the issue aside and say, `Look, let's just leave it idly there and not make too much of a fuss about it. We don't want to be branded as wowsers in this regard'. Really, it does not matter whether one is the president of the world society of atheists or the Pope, commonsense tells us that we have a very grievous problem here that is far worse than the guns that we are debating so much about at the moment.

We have a problem that no-one seems to be taking any notice of. I call upon all the people of Australia--particularly the women of Australia--to rise up against this tide of hard- core pornography that is overwhelming us. We have taken no responsibility here in this Parliament. Two Senate select committees and a joint select committee have said that we should do something about the pornography that our country is awash with.(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I wish to continue the theme of the remarks I was making yesterday in the Budget debate by saying that one of the areas in which we are most likely to notice the polarisation of debate in Australia between the neo-conservatives on the Opposition side and the Labor Party is industry policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Industry policy ought to be the central focus of most of our thinking. Too often it is sidelined and commented on only incidentally in discussions of macro-economic matters. When it is all brought to a proper place and into perspective, we have to realise that what we make and do in this country is essentially what sustains the economic viability of our economy. Without our Government having a clear grasp of what it is seeking to achieve in terms of industry policy, we will be likely to fritter away what advantages we obtain from macro-economic settings being in their correct place.

I would say the starting point has to be the statements made earlier this year by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the then Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in the document Building a Competitive Australia. Those initiatives--including the establishment of additional funding for the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation, the changes in tariff levels and major initiatives in establishing cooperative research centres to improve the amount and quality of research and development--are not going to be matched by the Opposition. Indeed, the comments of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) in his reply to the Budget indicate that he would, indeed, draw back from the commitments made in March in the document Building a Competitive Australia.

The Opposition spokesman for industry matters, the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), is even more inclined to ignore industry policy and be committed to simplistic notions of a level playing field--notions which no longer do Australia any favours.

However, if we move past Building a Competitive Australia--taking it as a document which sets out landmark achievements--and look beyond it, one of the areas where we need to look, most importantly, is how we get into our mix of industry policy an appropriate mechanism for funding the commercialisation of research and development.

In this country we probably now have some of the most exciting research and development anywhere in the world. The CSIRO, cooperative research centres and universities are all active players in bringing forward a constructive and exciting intellectual work which needs to be assessed commercially and, once that assessment is done, developed and marketed. But in Australia the gap is at the commercialisation end. We do well at research and reasonably well at development to a prototype stage, but we do appallingly badly at commercialising it. With the decline of the management investment companies and the failure of the second board to fully establish itself on the stock market and now, if the stock market has its way, its eventual abolition, we are going to have grave difficulties in funding research and development--in capitalising it.

For that reason, the Government has been looking, quite properly, at ways in which additional work can be funded. One of the arguments I have advanced in the Labor Caucus and publicly to the Committee for the Economic Development of Australia is that we should look to superannuation funds to play a responsible part in funding this commercialisation of research and development by seeking from them a commitment to spend not less than one per cent of their invested funds in that area.

It seems to me that, given the enormous tax advantages that are inherent in our arrangements for superannuation, a mutual benefit to Australia can be obtained. Firstly, the funds themselves ought to be investing in this area, as pension funds in comparable countries make similar investments in this area. Most importantly, the long term sustainability of Australia's living standards will not be enhanced unless investment managers take aboard their responsibility in this area.

There have, however, been fairly negative responses from the superannuation industry. I must say that I find it very difficult to understand the superannuation industry's suggestion, coming as it does from an industry that so frequently made bad investment decisions about the property market and about other matters during the frenetic period of the 1980s, that it would be irresponsible of it to invest one per cent of its members' funds in such projects,.

I think there is no doubt that a small, but not insubstantial, investment in the development of commercialisation of research and development ought to be in the investment profiles of any substantial fund. But that is a matter which I think the Government still has to address, either voluntarily or through means that involve legislation, to see that funds do manage their investments, not only in the short term with regard to their obligations to their members to increase the return to those members, but also to the long term benefit of this country, so that the jobs that eventually fund the superannuation schemes can be maintained.

I also draw the attention of members of the House to an alternative mechanism that might be available for funding the commercialisation of research and development. The mechanism, called tax exempt special savings accounts, was developed in Great Britain. The tax exempt special savings accounts were introduced by John Major, the then Chancellor of the Exchequer, as a mechanism for increasing domestic savings in the United Kingdom. With relatively small amendment, it could be made an appropriate vehicle for requiring or allowing investment in research and development.

I can explain the scheme briefly. What happens in the United Kingdom is that investors are permitted to place up to #9,000 over a five-year period into accounts which carry interest. Provided they maintain those accounts for five years, they are permitted to take the profits without paying tax on those earnings. That is, of course, enormously popular because one of the effects of the tax system in our country and the United Kingdom is that there is no inflationary component to compensate for capital gains on interest. Bank interest is, therefore, one of the least well-treated forms of earnings. So there was a very large surge of investment into these accounts.

It would be a relatively minor adjustment to the scheme to require the investment holders of tax exempt special savings accounts to invest a fixed proportion of such funds, perhaps 40 or 50 per cent, into earmarked investments which would have TESSA approval and which would be related to the commercialisation of research and development. I commend these ideas to the Government for further investigation. I believe that we need to work strongly to increase our infrastructure expenditure in this country and to look towards long term strategies designed to improve our industrial capacity and not simply rely on the market. (Time expired)

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Securities Commission: Data Processing Centre

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: --I wish to address the House today on the siting of the information processing centre of the Australian Securities Commission, as raised by the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Riggall) during the adjournment debate last night. Leaving aside the gratuitous insults added by the honourable member, the issue is indeed a difficult one for all of the parties concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: In becoming involved in the issue of the location of the IPC, I have sought a limited goal based on a concern I had with a matter of public administration. Specifically, I simply sought to have assessed an alternative adjacent site in the city of Sale which only relatively recently became available on the basis of its prospects for providing a better commercial return for the Commonwealth. The twin office block facilities site was made available as a result of the decision by Esso to relocate its main administrative functions to Melbourne.

In bringing this prospective alternative site to the attention of the ASC and others, I have not sought to overturn a tendering process which had been legally concluded and wound up. The fact of the matter is that there was still some brief time to look again at the figures and the costings applying to the alternative adjacent sites in Traralgon and Sale before the relevant agreements were finalised and commitments entered into. Nor did I seek to prejudge or influence the outcome of an evaluation of the alternative site. It is a matter of record that I have always stood happily to accept the umpire's decision in this matter, based, as I think it should be, on commercial considerations alone.

I will not labour the detailed history of the process which resulted in the proposal to site the ASC's data processing centre at Traralgon. As a result of a national tender carried out by the Commonwealth, the State of Victoria won the right in late 1989 to establish the IPC. Presumably, this right was conferred on the State because it was able to provide the best commercial proposition for the Commonwealth. The Victorian State Government then proceeded to make arrangements to develop the IPC site in the city of Traralgon. The proposed greenfield development was to incorporate an assistance package in the order of $4m to be transferred from the State Government to the ASC to maintain the terms in which the Victorian Government had won the initial tender.

As best I know, no formal legal or commercial agreements have, as yet, been entered into with developers. Again, so far as I understand, no binding agreements have been entered into between the State Government and the ASC regarding the legal obligations of the parties regarding the planned transfer of the funds which constitute the assistance package. Admittedly, however, the ASC had identified a preferred tender for a site and was well advanced in its thinking about the establishment of the IPC. It must also then be admitted that the prospective alternative site offered by the Esso facilities has entered into calculations late in proceedings.

I fully recognise this has caused disruption to administrative processes dealing with the establishment of the data processing centre. It is a matter of unavoidable regret that the timing of developments on all fronts could not have been more fortuitous than it has been. But in respect of the integrity of the commercial processes which should guide the development of the processing centre, this is hardly a cause for failing to give due consideration to the cost and benefit offered by the Esso Sale site.

Again I emphasise that this is all I have sought in this matter--due consideration alone of the commercial advantages of a nearby site. In seeking to set this process in motion, I was acting on data compiled by parties which demonstrated, on the basis of various assumptions, that the alternative site in Sale would accrue savings to the ASC in the order of $50m on the basis of a 25-year lease option and, I stress, a 25-year period. Given the scope of these claimed savings, it was obvious that they had to be tested against the facts of the case.

Indeed, I think it would have been a source of considerable community concern if the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) had failed to investigate practical opportunities for savings of taxpayers' moneys on this scale. Such a test, however, could come about only if the ASC showed a willingness, at the very least, to visit the Esso site in Sale and conduct a close analysis of the commercial opportunities it provided. It behoves a public body to be seen to be entirely unrelenting in its efforts to ensure taxpayers' resources are used efficiently and with an eye to the best return on outlays. Moreover, it falls as a particularly heavy responsibility on the shoulders of such a body as the ASC which must be seen to be scrupulously transparent and open in dealings of this nature. As I said, I have sought to have the claimed projected savings offered by the Esso site closely costed by the ASC in the context of its own proposed development package for Traralgon and on the basis of whether the facilities suited its needs.

I have always been aware that other cost issues are associated with the possibility of reconsideration of the Sale site. Amongst these must be a realistic assessment of the impact of the labour force employed to work within the data processing centre; the cost of refurbishing the Esso office blocks to meet the ASC's specifications; and the actual terms of the lease cycle to which the ASC wished to be committed.

It was, however, a matter of considerable concern to me that in order to prompt such a course on the part of the ASC I found it necessary to raise the matters publicly. It is a matter of record that the ASC had rejected invitations by the city of Sale and others to visit the Esso facilities and conduct an audit of its commercial advantages on the basis of a reviewed lease package.

Approaches by local business and community bodies, as well as by the city of Sale and groups such as the Sale development group, were unable to attract the interest of the ASC. To these approaches the Chairman of the ASC, Mr Tony Hartnell, claimed that the issue was virtually beyond renegotiation. Regardless of this, he also claimed he was not free to act unilaterally but needed the consent of the Victorian State Government to investigate the commercial prospects of an alternative site. Events seem to have proven otherwise.

In the last two weeks the ASC has finally taken on its responsibility to at least scrutinise the Esso facilities and evaluate the commercial advantages of the available lease options. I am not familiar with the details of the costings involved in these respects. Indeed, I have no interest in investigating them in any personal or direct way. It has been my role to act as a broker between the parties to ensure that they have all had the opportunity to meet finally and conduct a complete inquiry into the relevant matters. As to the outcomes, that is a market based issue in which I wish to have no role.

Again, in the relocation of the IPC to Sale I realise there are possibly external costs involved beyond the terms of the lease--the costs of refurbishment and so forth. However, I trust the ASC will provide Esso and those acting on its behalf with the opportunity to address these extra potential costs in constructing their options for a lease package. Presumably this process is already in action.

I also add that I am concerned with the Victorian State Government's assistance package in respect of the development of the IPC site. The ASC has claimed that it would be forced to reimburse the Victorian State Government to the value of the assistance package if it should choose to relocate to a nearby, more commercially advantageous site. I am anxious to ensure that the assistance package is based on commercial principles and seeks the best return for public outlays. This concern is consistent with my position on the necessity to at least review the commercial viability of the Esso office site.

Accordingly, I find it difficult to accept that the assistance package is targeted to a site specific location and cannot be transferred to a viable, more commercially advantageous adjacent site, should one become available. In this regard I find to be of further concern claims by the ASC that, should commercial determinations require it to elect for the Sale site, it would be required to repay the State Government to the full value of the assistance package. In effect, such a policy position suggests that commercial outcomes and net savings concerns are not relevant factors to concluding developments in which public resources are involved. To be frank, I consider this to be a questionable administrative practice, one which ought to be of concern to the community. In this regard, I also feel that the integrity of the ASC could be impugned if the arrangements it has entered into with the State Government are not seen to be commercially driven and transparent.

Notwithstanding this, I am delighted that the ASC has conceded, after some modest pressure, that it does carry an obligation to the public to investigate the commercial viability of the Sale site. I only hope it sees through the entire process in a thorough and comprehensive manner. I trust that the ASC will demonstrate the same commitment to exhaustive and searching procedures which characterise its statutory duties. The matter should not be left under any sort of cloud.

If there are costs associated with external matters upon which the decision on the location case of the IPC will turn, I hope these will be made public. I hope they are carefully accounted for and presented to those who are charged with presenting the Sale lease package for consideration. If, when all courses of practical action have been pursued, there is no considerable net gain in the transfer of the data centre to Sale, the matter should be put to rest--the ASC will have been seen to have done its duty and public confidence in the Commission's commitment to the public interest will be satisfied. So, if in some quarters there is a bit of high drama in these matters, it is because the ASC is just catching up on its responsibilities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham Mr D.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I joined the Australian Labor Party because I saw it as the only party which stood for social justice and equity, because it was the only party with vision. I am proud to say that this year's Budget will, in time, be recognised for its visionary outlook. The changes concerning superannuation and the building better cities program will be seen as great achievements of this Labor Government. The impact of these decisions will not be immediate, but will be realised in years to come.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to concentrate my remarks on the building better cities program. As is customary, the Opposition has done nothing but deride and totally oppose the whole concept behind the better cities proposals. This should not come as a surprise to anyone, as the Opposition is totally bereft of vision and is purely reactionary.

A close look at the history books will reveal that the Labor Party, at Federal and State levels, has been the party which has had the courage to make visionary decisions. The Snowy Mountains River scheme, World Heritage listing of the Franklin River and Kakadu National Park, Medicare, the provision of legal aid, the Opera House, the Sydney Harbour Bridge, greater access to higher education and the better incomes and retirement policy are but some of Labor's initiatives. They are now recognised as great achievements yet were, and in some instances still are, bitterly opposed by our conservative opponents.

The vehement opposition expressed by the coalition only reinforces my belief in the greatness of the building better cities program, which combines the twin Labor objectives of social justice and vision. It aims at improving the quality of life of urban and suburban Australians by improving their surrounding environment. The fact is that the majority of the population spends most of its time--both work and leisure--in the cities and suburbs. By improving our cities we will, in fact, be improving the living and working conditions of the majority of Australians.

Well might we ask ourselves why the coalition is opposed to this basic concept. The answer is simple. Studies have shown that residents in the western suburbs of Sydney and Melbourne suffer from a lack of services and opportunities. The coalition does not want money spent on the people of western Sydney and Melbourne because it wants to continue extending privileges and benefits to its friends on the north shore and in eastern suburbs.

The better cities program recognises the disadvantages faced by people living in the western suburbs. It is an attempt to improve the infrastructure of our cities and to promote a greater quality of life and increased opportunities for millions of Australians. The benefits will be many and varied. The Australian dream of the quarter acre block has led to an ever expanding urban sprawl and all the problems associated with it. Often, there is a lack of essential services and opportunities for people on the suburban fringe. Housing costs have soared, making home ownership difficult, while people have to travel long distances to their place of work.

The problem of transport is a real one for the people of the western suburbs. Hours are spent each day commuting to and from work on overcrowded trains and roads. As a result, pollution levels are dangerously high. It is no coincidence that the incidence of asthma is greatest in western Sydney.

By identifying the problems of our cities and targeting resources to overcoming these problems, we will be ensuring that the disadvantages associated with geography are overcome. The commitment of this Government to provide money for the University of Western Sydney is but one example of addressing the needs faced by the people in western Sydney. The building better cities program will link all levels of government to provide a coordinated approach to build on and improve the existing infrastructure of our cities. In time, it will redress the inequalities which currently exist by providing millions of Australians with opportunities previously denied.
I am proud to be part of a government that is committed to social justice and vision. The building better cities program will be recognised as a great statement and the snake oil
salesmen in the coalition will be exposed for the frauds and charlatans that they are.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! It being 1.45 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106, as amended for this session, the debate is interrupted and I put the question:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I will not get involved in the claim of having a mandate for compassion and social justice: the Australian Labor Party thinks it is the only party that cares for people or that has ever done something for people. According to the Labor Party, the only thing the Opposition cares for is the rich. Gosh, with a wife, five children, their grandmother and grandfather, I must have made a big mistake with my choice of party! What a lot of poppycock! Do honourable members believe that sort of stuff? Government members ought to go away and dry their tears somewhere else. I am sure the gallery does not believe it.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members talk about people owning their homes on quarter-acre blocks and so forth. People work hard to get such homes. Some people do not work hard. Those who work hard are entitled to a house on a quarter-acre block; it has nothing to do with social justice.

What I was going to say nicely and quietly is that there has been turmoil in my lovely State of Tasmania in relation to politicians. I have been a politician for 17 years and everywhere I go I hear that politicians are not held in very high regard. People are suspicious of us; people seem to think that we do all the wrong things, but that is not true. Nearly all of us come into Parliament to try to make Australia a better place. We are outdone by the Executive Government. Backbenchers are not recognised today. They are considered to be just a little bit of dirt under the ground of some people. We are not given the role that we should play. We represent people in the Parliament, but I am afraid that the Executive Government has taken us over. (Time expired)

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Securities Commission: Data Processing Centre

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Last night in the adjournment debate the Liberal member for McMillan (Mr Riggall) accused the National Party member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) of taking an unethical and unprofessional approach in order to discredit the tendering process that was used by the Australian Securities Commission to locate its data processing centre in his electorate. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The ambit claim that $50m savings can be made is without foundation and totally discredited.

I call on the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) to sort this matter out. If the honourable member for McMillan is correct, the National Party's shadow front bench member should resign from the shadow Cabinet. If he is not correct, the honourable member for McMillan should apologise. It is quite evident that there is a division between the National and Liberal parties and one wonders whether the National Party attitude on tendering in Queensland has come to Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Misinformation has been a feature of the debate on the Opposition's plans to reform the Australian tax system. There has been considerable speculation, perhaps understandably, that good things come to those who wait. Apparently Peter Hartcher, the Sydney Morning Herald Canberra bureau chief, just cannot wait. In his piece in today's Herald he is guilty not so much of speculation, but of pure conjecture. More, it is absolute fantasy; it is a fairytale; it is blatant and comprehensive rubbish. Not a single source is given by Mr Hartcher for his story. Indeed, there cannot be any source because none of those named by Mr Hartcher as being the inner Cabinet were contacted by him. I assume that, if Mr Hartcher came to write an obituary, he would check to make sure that the reports of the death in question were not greatly exaggerated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Neil Mr L.R.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I think it is entirely appropriate that I raise a matter of deep concern to me when the Minister for Local Government (Ms Fatin) is at the table. One of the biggest problems in Australia today is the big drift of people from regional and country areas to the cities. The social ramifications for the towns in decline are horrific. Many of these smaller towns are becoming ghost towns. I am delighted that my representation to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on this matter seems to have borne fruit. I advocated that at the Special Premiers Conference all the State Premiers, the Prime Minister and local government should have some input into seeing how we can redress this obvious dilemma. I think it is imperative to look at things such as zone allowances, tax allowances and a number of other things that we can do to redress this obvious problem.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a real problem for local councils and governments at a time when we have high unemployment, which everybody here acknowledges. Such unemployment is very tragic indeed. As the Minister for Local Government is at the table and is onside, I look forward to some constructive and positive input towards redressing this obvious problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson Mr M.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-There is a responsibility on a large number of people in this place. There is responsibility placed on senators, honourable members, staff and the press. The responsibility that has been placed on the press--and I might say that 99.9 per cent of the time it accepts that responsibility--is to report the truth and not report fiction. I think it is a serious reflection on the whole Press Gallery to see in today's Sydney Morning Herald comments attributed to that paper's Bureau Chief with regard to the GST and the so-called deals done between the leadership team.

SPEECH.PARA: I am extremely disappointed to have to raise this matter. I have a great deal of respect for the Press Gallery. But I really think Mr Hartcher has overstepped any bounds of reasonableness. The other day he gave us the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean), as the next leader. But that Minister is still trying to find out where the shoelaces are on elastic-sided boots, so he is hardly likely to be the next Prime Minister. Mr Hartcher should accept his responsibility as Bureau Chief. He should not report the tripe that was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald today. Quite frankly, he owes the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and this Parliament an apology for the matters he raised in the paper this morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hulls Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Speaker, as you would know, 90-second statements are usually used by members to talk about something parochial in their electorates. But today I want to draw the attention of this House to the deplorable headline `Resurrect the death penalty' which appeared in last week's Mornington Leader.

SPEECH.PARA: Mornington is a bayside suburb in Victoria in the electorate of the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith). It is near where my parents live and I thank them for drawing this to my attention. Apparently, some crazy right wing fascist group on the peninsula has called for the return of the death penalty and will be holding a public meeting on 11 September in an attempt to gain support for its stance. One wonders whether one would have to bring one's own hooded bed sheets to be allowed into the meeting!

None of this would or should be taken seriously if it were not for a State Liberal MP, Robin Cooper, who has not only backed the group but also called for the return of the lash. What sort of society do we live in when we have supposedly responsible elected members of parliament making such ludicrous, outlandish statements without any reference at all to the underlying reasons for crime and appropriate, realistic programs for crime prevention?

It is also interesting to note that the group supported by Mr Cooper is considering running candidates at the next election against MPs who do not support its stand. I wonder whether this type of knee-jerk nonsense has the approval of the shadow Treasurer. If hanging and the lash are to become Liberal Party policy in Victoria, I am sure we will see more and more Victorians moving to the more progressive and enlightened State of Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-May I reassure the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Hulls) that lots of Victorians are moving to Queensland; and they are moving to my electorate of Moncrieff.

SPEECH.PARA: At the weekend, I had the pleasure of attending the opening of a new hotel in my electorate--the new Kooralbyn Resort Hotel, which is situated in a rural area some distance south of a country town called Beaudesert. The Kooralbyn resort itself has existed for over 10 years. It is a characteristically Australian resort where one can enjoy such pleasures as billy tea and damper and all sorts of outdoor sports.

Approximately four years ago this resort was bought by Japanese financial interests, which led to the predictable outcry about Japanese investment in Australia, particularly in respect of such a uniquely Australian hotel and resort. I am pleased to say that the Japanese investors in this case have done an absolutely superb job with this new hotel. They have built a beautiful hotel in the bush which is environmentally friendly. They have pioneered a method of manufacturing pressed earth aggregate which uses clay from the area, so the resultant three-level hotel is not sticking out like a sore thumb, as one would expect. In fact, it blends in beautifully with the environment.

Japanese investment has established a multi- million dollar asset in the area which is totally accepted by the locals. Those investors have shown themselves to be very good local citizens in their support of endeavours in the Beaudesert region and, indeed, in their support of the general Gold Coast tourism effort. I congratulate the manager of the hotel, Mr Chris Diamandopoulos, who is an Australian- Greek, and all who are associated with that hotel. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I would like to defend the Sydney Morning Herald today for exposing the duplicity of the Liberal Party of Australia and its goods and services tax. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am absolutely appalled at the comments of the previous member. At a time when the Labor Party is putting one million Australians out of work, the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) can come in here and, as a defence, repeat fabricated stories from today's Sydney Morning Herald. SPEECH.PARA: Mr Courtice interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The member for Hinkler.

—-It is a fabrication raised by the Labor Party to cover its tracks over the massive unemployment and bankruptcy that it is creating. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no great science in determining the magnitude of reductions, but the Bank believes that the one percentage point cut is consistent with maintaining the downward momentum of inflation and does not risk re-igniting demand pressures.
Against the proper adherence to due process by an independent statutory officer and his Board, we now have this offensive attack by the Leader of the Opposition--

—-Could the Treasurer explain to the House the reforms to the taxation system introduced by the Labor Government and what additional measures are intended to make the tax system better and more equitable?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank the honourable gentleman for his question. As I came into the House today there was a bit of a debate about taxation and then some more chiacking about the honourable member for Blaxland. Let us see what was achieved with tax by this Government and why some of the attacks about what the honourable member for Blaxland said some time ago were nonsense when we have changed things completely.

ANSWER.PARA: When we came into government we inherited a taxation system that was in disrepair and disrepute. The top personal rate is now 47 per cent; in 1983 it was 60 per cent. The bottom rate is now 21 per cent; in 1983 it was 30 per cent. The company tax rate is now 39 per cent; in 1983 it was 46 per cent. The effective rate of company taxation in 1983 was an astonishing 78.4 per cent. We have reformed the taxation system in this country. Of course, the Opposition opposed every bit of reform, including capital gains, fringe benefits and entertainment expenses. It did nothing for business. The introduction of dividend imputation means that the effective rate of company tax has reduced. The bias against equity investment has been corrected.

TALK.START.PARA: —-You are a high tax government.
—-The Leader of the Opposition!

—-Labor has ensured that foreign income is properly taxed. Elaborate tax structures can no longer be used to disguise foreign income. The introduction of the resource rent tax was opposed by the Opposition in 1987. Substantiation requirements, the reforms to the prescribed payments system, increased audit activity by the Tax Office and the tax file number system have all acted to reduce evasion. Our concept of fairness underlies our absolute rejection of a flat rate income tax regime and our absolute commitment to the capital gains tax. In the newspapers this morning there is a very interesting story.
—-Order! There is far too much noise. Members on my left will cease interjecting.

—-I warn the Leader of the Opposition.

—-Currently the taxation liability for those three sums equates to $1,420, $4,694 and $27,064 respectively. If we had a flat tax of 30 per cent the liability would change to $3,750, $7,500 and $22,500. If one is earning about half average weekly earnings, one's tax liability increases from about $1,400 to $3,750. That is an increase of 164 per cent. If one is earning about average weekly earnings, one's tax goes up by 60 per cent. If one is at the top end of town, on a salary of $75,000, it goes down; it is a decrease of 17 per cent. Let us look at all the proposals being put forward by the Opposition, whether it is a 15 per cent tax or a 22 per cent tax, a consumption tax----
—-I rise on a point of order, Mr Speaker.
—-Order! Members on my right!

—-My point of order relates to standing order 145 and it concerns relevance. The points being made by the Minister now do not relate to Government policy.
