—-I have been getting around the corridors a bit and I hear the honourable member for Flinders being referred to as Mr Kleenex. This has been going on for a long time. I bought a packet of Kleenex and there I found the clue: thick and soft, like his question.
—-Can the Prime Minister advise the House of the implications of a consumption tax on the level of national savings?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank the honourable member for Parramatta--who will continue to be the honourable member for Parramatta, I might say--for his very important and relevant question. The fact is that the overwhelming evidence from overseas is that a consumption tax would have no impact on the level of national savings. That is what the evidence shows quite clearly. Indeed, in many countries the level of national savings has fallen. Interestingly enough, the Leader of the Opposition conceded this fact when he was talking about it--not this year, but in 1990. This is what he had to say in an interview.
—-What about 1985? Talk about yourself. Never mind your weasel words.

—-I know honourable members opposite do not like having their words quoted back at them, but they should listen to what their glorious leader had to say in April last year. These are the words of the Leader of the Opposition:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . even if you did have a 15 per cent across-the- board consumption tax with all those political advantages it may only make a marginal effect on savings.

That is what he said in 1990. That is a different story from what he tells now. This is what he had to say on 25 July this year. He was asked to sum up the essential rationale for a consumption tax. The interviewer said to the Leader of the Opposition:
You've got three sentences, no more: explain what a consumption tax is.
The Leader of the Opposition, the man who had said in 1990 that it would have no impact on savings, responded:

Well, a consumption tax is a broad-based tax on expenditure. The principal purpose in a country like Australia, which spends too much and imports too much, if you like, is to change people's expenditure and savings patterns, to encourage people to spend less and to save more and to use the tax system as an essential element of that.

In other words, when asked in July this year what was the essential rationale for a consumption tax, the whole rationale given was that it would increase savings. The evidence is that it will not. The contradictions between what the Leader of the Opposition said in 1990 and in 1991 are absolutely breathtaking. As we on this side of the House have been saying, it is about time the Opposition really came clean on what it has in mind in regard to the consumption tax and what is its hidden agenda. They started to be flushed out in today's Sydney Morning Herald, which suggests----

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The House will come to order.

—-Order! The House will come to order.

—-Order! The honourable member for Gilmore will cease interjecting. If he interjects again, I will name him, too.

—-My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I thank him for his concise and indeed revealing answer to my question yesterday. I ask a follow-up question on behalf of a constituent of mine. His name is Ray and he is a mango farmer. Farm incomes are down and his projected taxable income for this year is about $13,000. I ask: what would be the effect of a broad-based consumption tax for Ray? What initiatives has the Government taken to address the problem of low incomes for farm families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I met Ray when I visited that area with the honourable member for Kennedy last week to talk about the future of the horticultural industry because the honourable member for Groom suggested doing so. The mango producers up there are a great success story. But let me come to the question. Yesterday when I answered the question about the impact of the goods and services tax on farm families I indicated that, apart from the detail that the Opposition had not come up with, the reality and the reason why the Government opposed a goods and services tax was that it was both inflationary and regressive.

ANSWER.PARA: Yesterday I said it was regressive, particularly for low income families, only in the knowledge that the Opposition was proposing a goods and services tax across-the-board. I find out today, from reading the Sydney Morning Herald, that not only does the proposal contemplate the level of that tax being 22 per cent but also it contemplates not just a goods and services tax but a flat tax rate as well.

A goods and services tax itself is regressive because it imposes the same level of tax on everyone according to expenditure, not income. But a flat rate tax is even more regressive because it also taxes people at the same rate regardless of the level of income. So what we have is the great double that is really going to sink into further depression those people on farms who have very low incomes at the moment. The reason it is regressive is that people on low incomes consume everything that they earn.

Let us take the example of a person on $13,000 a year. If we have a 22 per cent goods and services tax and a 30 per cent flat rate tax, do Opposition members know what happens to Ray the mango farmer on $13,000 a year? He becomes $4,000 worse off as a result of their initiative. Do they know how many people earn the same level of income expected this year as Ray? Half the farm families in this country--33,000! The Opposition's measures are going to slug them with even more taxation. I will go further on the point, because the Treasurer alluded to this and it shows the unfairness of the situation. It is no wonder that the National Party is having second thoughts about what this great consumption tax package means. Do Opposition members know what people on an income of $100,000 get out of the package? They get $9,000 plus. For a person on $13,000, it is minus $4,000; at average weekly earnings, it is something like minus $3,000; and the $100,000 league gains substantially. What sort of a compensation package is that?

In any event, even if they do not accept that argument--and I would ask them to go away and at least do some sensible figuring rather than the stuff they have churned out in the last couple of weeks--how is their compensation package going to accommodate those people who are on negative incomes or not paying any tax at all? I ask the Leader of the National Party: how does he propose to do that? I ask him to come forward with his proposal because the fact of the matter is that 40 per cent of broad acre farmers in this country will not pay tax next year. Where is their compensation package? They will put an impost of 15 per cent more on them.

As to that part of the honourable member's question which asks what this Government has done in relation to the circumstance of this particular example, I said yesterday that under our proposal and under the March economic statement all direct inputs which are taxed through the wholesale sales tax will have an exemption on that component for people on the farm. All direct inputs will be exempt, including any freight component that attracts that tax. So do not give us this rubbish that no input relief has been given. Read the March economic statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —-You still have not got it right.
—-Order! I warn the honourable member for Mayo!

—-Look at the Leader of the Opposition, who has his back turned to me at the moment, because he is saying in his Budget response that that $200m which provides that relief should not be given. In addition, because of the plight of the farm sector we have given specific income relief through RAS, through extending the family allowance supplement, through specific sectoral initiatives for the wool and wheat industries in particular and, in the case of the mango growers, through the innovative agricultural marketing program. That is a scheme which has resulted in that industry being able to get off its feet through a grant that this Government has made and export to the tune of a significant amount of dollars for this country and their incomes. They are the sorts of programs, in constructive terms, that this Government is developing.
—-What are the figures?

—-If I have time, I will read the numbers. I happen to not like reading answers that are from time to time prepared for me but if honourable members want the answer to that question, I will do it. The Government gave a group of mango growers a $200,000 grant last year under the marketing skills program. Following the success of the exercise, which while only a trial involved experts worth more than half a million dollars----

—-Exports. They would become experts as a consequence. It involved over half the total annual value of previous mango exports, and the Government has provided over $550,000 in three grants under the innovative agricultural marketing program to develop and expand the export markets for high quality fresh mangoes and sliced and pureed mangoes. The growers expect to export $2 1/2m of fresh mangoes this year, rising to over $5m in later years. The honourable member for Groom ought to get the detail of this and himself go back and talk to the horticulturalists, as I have done.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, the Government has provided a $4.3m package of assistance for regional and economic development in this country. I say to Opposition members: rather than slug the farm sector, rather than make farmers harder up under the circumstances, as their consumption tax will do, this Government has addressed the real need. That is why farmers will return us and not the Opposition.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Resign!
—-Order! The House will come to order. The Leader of the National Party will cease interjecting. I warn the honourable member for Corinella.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thought that when I came to this portfolio I had to deal with people who knew what they were talking about in relation to their constituency. Clearly, I do not have to think that any more. The question that the Leader of the National Party specifically raised is about sedans and motorbikes. —-You are wrong.
—-It is not wrong. I would suggest that those on the other side not only read it but also stop misleading their constituency.

—-Order! The House will come to order. The honourable member for Gippsland!
—-The changes to the sales tax arrangements announced in the 12 March economic statement will virtually remove all sales taxes paid on inputs used by miners, manufacturers and primary producers.

ANSWER.PARA: Exemptions are going to be widened to match a broader view of production and they thus cover a wider range of activities. I simply make the point that the Leader of the National Party ought to read the detail of the initiative, because until this consumption tax debate came on again I do not believe he understood the initiative for primary producers that was in the March economic statement. I simply say to him: I hope that the people who are deliberating on the future in terms of the policies of the National Party have far more sense and understanding than he does, because with him leading them, quite frankly, they have no hope.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

One of them appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning, which was the occasion of a denial in probably the most demented press release I have seen in this place since the honourable member for Deakin used to produce press releases on the security services. One of the most interesting features of that press release is that, whilst it was aggravated in the extreme and was the authentic product of somebody other than a press secretary, its denials were very much away from the point--very much to process rather than to the substance of the article which concerned whether consideration had ever been given to flat tax arrangements and a level of 22 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: There was plenty of denial in regard to the processes and who has approval. That must be one of the features of the press report which is inaccurate because, whether or not the four people indicated are participants, one of those who was not indicated as a participant was the honourable member for Mackellar.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The honourable member for Goldstein will cease interjecting!
—-We know that the honourable member for Mackellar is actively involved in developing the Opposition's tax proposals.
—-Order! I warn the honourable member for Goldstein.

—-He is very much involved in that, and that must be a source of the most extraordinary comfort to the Opposition back bench. The fact of the matter is that that particular proposition is in the ether. What would be the impact of a 22 per cent tax? A telephone connection fee would increase by $55.66. ANSWER.PARA: Of course, we know where members opposite are getting a fair bit of this advice and we know where they come from ideologically. They do sing a siren song in this place of concern and compassion for what happens to ordinary people in this country. When they are off with their mates and off in their ideological heartland, we hear a very different siren song. Most recently, the Leader of the Opposition had an opportunity to sing that at the National Party conference in New Zealand, and then, for some reason that is totally unfathomable to me, decided he would circulate his speech for the world to read. It is, indeed, a revealing speech.

There is a very good film called The Manchurian Candidate. I would recommend it to all honourable ladies and gentlemen. We are producing a B version, `The Rotoruan Candidate'. That is what we have from the Leader of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order under standing order 145, concerning relevance, and support your attempts today to bring some propriety to this Parliament.
—-I know one can expect support from strange quarters, but sometimes I would like to choose the support.

—-In the circumstances, would it not be a good idea if the Minister's answer became relevant to the question, which, as was proper, asked him about Government policy? I am sure the question did not ask him to read from a speech made in New Zealand by a member of the Opposition.
—-The Minister was asked a question about telecommunication services and their future, and the Minister is answering the question.

—-That is absolutely right. Indeed, this speech, among other things, canvassed exactly the tax on services that I am discussing here. What the Leader of the Opposition had to say to his National Party colleagues is very reassuring, I am sure, to all honourable members who seek to find where the honourable gentleman comes from. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: I am also impressed to see that you do keep in touch with other parts of the electorate, and having two soup kitchens is a very nice touch.
The rest of his speech to this particular gathering endorsed programs that had been implemented by successive governments in New Zealand, referring also to their economic consequences.

The other people in the electorate who will be able to approach soup kitchens will be people such as pensioners and the poor. Because we have a very high penetration rate of telephone services, they will have an opportunity to pay for their visits to the soup kitchens. Under the Opposition, they will be able to pay for those through the taxation arrangements, if soup kitchens are publicly provided. They will be paying an extra 5.3c for every telephone call; and I think that an extra 5.3c on their calls will pay for a large number of new soup kitchens.

What a tragedy the view of the Leader of the Opposition is; it comes from somebody who approaches politics on the basis: `I flash in and I flash out. I make a pile; I come into politics. I turn the place upside-down; I disappear. I am not committed'. There are people in this place who are committed to a lifetime in politics; there are people in this place who are committed to a lifetime of public service. When one is committed to a lifetime of public service, one can adopt no other position. If there is any decency in those opposite, they will maintain their compassion for those in this country least able to protect themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I direct my question to the Treasurer. I refer the Treasurer to the ranting on telephone prices just delivered by the prime ministerial aspirant, the Minister for Transport and Communications.
—-The honourable member will get to his question.

—-I am coming to my question, Mr Speaker. Will the Treasurer confirm that the sales tax already paid by Telecom on plant and equipment alone in 1990-91 was around $375m, which averages out at around $50 for every telephone subscriber?
—-I cannot quite understand what the point of the honourable gentleman's question is.
—-Mr Speaker--
—-Order! The honourable member for Mayo will resume his seat.
—-Part of the reason was that I did not hear the first part of his question. Perhaps he could just repeat the first part of his question. I could not hear him for his own mates.
—-Does the Treasurer want the question repeated?
—-Yes.

—-Thank you, Mr Speaker. I am happy to repeat the question. In the first part of the question, I referred to the Minister for Transport and Communications, who answered a previous question on telephone prices and taxation. I asked the Treasurer whether he would confirm that the sales tax already paid by Telecom on plant and equipment alone in 1990-91 was around $375m, which averages out at around an extra $50 on a subscriber's telephone bill. They are Telecom's figures.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I understand the point now, but what makes the honourable gentleman think that they will not pay it if there is a consumption tax?
—-There will be a tax on all goods and services.
—-Order! There is far too much noise. The House will come to order.

—-Let us just get to the core of this issue on tax. It is quite obvious that the Opposition is not opposed to putting a tax on goods. It intends to put a tax on goods and services--on all goods and all services. That means the price of bread and milk and eggs goes up; the price of a Mercedes comes down. That is what it is all about. The wholesale sales tax currently in place is also on goods, but at the wholesale level, not the retail level.

ANSWER.PARA: So what are the differences? We tax some goods including luxury goods, and exempt necessities. The Opposition would put a 15 or 22 per cent tax on all goods and services, and the 70 per cent of goods on supermarket shelves not now taxed would be taxed for the first time. A 20 per cent wholesale sales tax is less than a 15 per cent retail sales tax in most cases. It depends on the retail margin.

So go out there, Opposition, tell the people that luxuries are going to be taxed at a lower rate and that all goods and services are going to be taxed for the first time; tell the people how they will love it. While it is at it, the Opposition can convince the people that the moment this is in place it is not going to be put up, such as has occurred in every other country that has one. The Opposition can explain what this will do for inflation in this country and explain how people on pensions and the lower paid are going to be compensated. Answer Eric Risstrom. How is the Opposition going to compensate a person on $23,000 a year, when to compensate him it will have to give a 64 per cent cut in tax. Go out there and tell them--tell them the Opposition is going to take the tax off luxuries and it is going to tax the necessities.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the Minister aware of comments from the ILO expressing concern about the state of Australian industrial law, in particular its lack of compliance with conventions to which Australia is a party? What is the Government's reaction to this complaint and what steps will the Government take to address it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am aware of the findings referred to by the honourable member for Oxley. They were made by an ILO committee of experts on the application of conventions and recommendations. That committee comprises highly qualified people, including some judges of the International Court of Justice, and has a mandate to examine the extent to which the law and practice of states party to ILO conventions conforms with the standards under those treaties.

ANSWER.PARA: In May this year the committee made what is known as a direct request to the Australian Government in which it found that the existing state of Australian industrial law, including the common law, section 45D of the Trade Practices Act and the New South Wales Essential Services Act, was incompatible with the freedom of association standards set out in ILO conventions and called on the governments of Australia and New South Wales to bring the law into conformity.

TALK.START.PARA: —-What about the state and actions of the unions?
—-I warn the member for Moore.

—-The Government is concerned by those findings. It puts us in breach of our international obligations, which we accepted when we ratified those conventions. If we do not amend our law we will be subject to a report to an ILO conference pointing out Australia's non-conformity with its obligations; that is, we will be internationally exposed and criticised for not adhering to our obligations under international law.

ANSWER.PARA: The questioner also asked me about a Government response. The Government is intending to respond to this situation. That response is being developed by the Minister for Industrial Relations and will be considered by the Government later this year. Another part of the Government's response is absolute horror at the reaction of the Liberal Party spokesman in relation to these findings. In New South Wales the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Fay, said he could not accept the ILO's strong criticism of the State legislation. He said that ILO conventions were designed mainly for Third World countries and had little relevance to Australia. In regard to these comments, let me say that ratification of ILO conventions is undertaken only after all the States agree, and New South Wales agreed to ratification of the relevant conventions at the time of the Askin Government in 1971.

As for their being of little relevance to Australia and mainly for Third World countries, let me say that it is mighty relevant to us if we ratify conventions but then do not adhere and so are in breach of our international obligations. The conventions are not just for Third World countries. All major developed countries are members of the ILO, which is an agency of the United Nations, and most developing countries are also members. Over 100 countries have ratified these conventions.

The third point I would make about Mr Fay's comments is that when the Greiner Government was putting its legislation before the New South Wales Parliament I, as the then Minister for Industrial Relations, in May 1988 wrote to Mr Greiner, pointed out that this legislation may well put us in breach of ILO conventions and asked him not to go ahead and put us in such breach. He wrote back saying New South Wales did not accept that it would be in breach, and went ahead with the legislation. Now he has been found to be in breach, his Minister says, `Well, who cares about the ILO; it does not matter'. What an incredible reaction.

Worse than that is the reaction of the Opposition spokesman on industrial relations in this House. His remarks are just about beyond belief. In the Melbourne Herald-Sun on Tuesday of this week, he is quoted as follows:

A coalition Government could cut ties with the International Labour Organisation because of the body's `foolish observations' of Australia, the Opposition industrial relations spokesman, Mr Howard said yesterday. Mr Howard told the Herald-Sun the Opposition was not interested in gratuitous advice from the organisation, a UN agency. `I am disassociating the Opposition from the ILO. In Government, we would examine our association with the ILO'.
`It does not understand the Australian scene'.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I note with great interest all the idiotic `Hear, hears' from the other side. Let me say that those remarks by the Opposition spokesman and all those `Hear, hears' that we just had reflect exceedingly badly on the Opposition, and on the Opposition spokesman in particular.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia is a foundation member of the ILO and it has hitherto had the across-the- board support of governments and oppositions throughout the period that we have been members--since 1927. However, now Australia has been found to be in breach of its obligations under international law, the Opposition members are effectively saying, `Who cares', and making insulting remarks about that body. Yet in other circumstances, of course, they like to parade themselves as bastions of supporters of the law. So it is an interesting dichotomy of approach.

The Minister for Industrial Relations has made a detailed response to the honourable member for Bennelong's comments, and I am not going to go through the detail of all of that except to note that withdrawing from the ILO--which he says the Opposition is contemplating--would not avoid our obligations under the conventions. They would have to be denounced, and the opportunity to do that comes up every 10 years. The next opportunity is in the year 2000. So we would have to wait until 2000 or 2001 before we could do it. We would continue in complete breach of our obligations in that time--assuming, of course, that the Opposition is in a position to do anything about it, which it will not be.

Finally, I am quite shocked that the Opposition spokesman should be so dismissive of the ILO. He has previously shown a great interest in it. He has been to its last two international conferences in Geneva, and I assume that, now he has such contempt for the organisation, he will not be going any more. He has a unique opportunity this afternoon to explain first hand to the ILO in what contempt the Opposition holds it, because the Director-General of the ILO, its chief executive officer, is in Australia. In fact, he is in Canberra and he is up in the gallery at the present time.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am seeing him at 5 o'clock this afternoon, and I will tell him.

—- When the honourable member for Bennelong sees the Director- General this afternoon, I hope he does not just discuss niceties and talk about the weather. He has a perfect opportunity to explain to the Director-General the Opposition's contempt for the ILO, how it regards its committee of experts as a body which is making foolish observations and gratuitous comments about Australia, how they do not understand the Australian scene, and why the Opposition is contemplating dissociating itself from the ILO. When he is putting all that, I hope that he does not in any way convey that this represents the position of the Australian people. I am quite sure that the Australian people have a great concern about the Opposition's position on this matter. They would have great concern about our international reputation, how we are seen by the rest of the world and the way in which we support the United Nations agencies. In no way can the Opposition be said to be taking a position which has the support of the Australian people.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I refer the Treasurer to the remarks of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, who expressed his great concern about the regressivity of indirect taxes, which I am sure the Treasurer will say he shares. I ask: has the Treasurer read the report of Neil Warren to EPAC on the regressivity of the existing wholesale sales tax, Labor's hidden consumption tax? If the Treasurer is fair dinkum on this issue, what is his response to the revelation of Mr Warren who, in his report, concluded:

QUESTION.PARA: Recent changes to the wholesale sales tax have been directed at rationalising the rate structure and broadening the base of this tax. These changes, combined with the increased consumption of the goods taxed, have resulted in a significant increase in the relative level of tax collections from this source. Its regressivity appears to have increased as a result, particularly affecting the lower income deciles.

TALK.START.PARA: —-First of all, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition wanders around the country saying that the current wholesale sales tax is the Government's hidden consumption tax. Let me put this down once and for all: a wholesale sales tax is not the same as a retail tax. There is a retail tax on everything one buys, all goods, every service--everything. A wholesale sales tax, which we have at present, has three rates: 10, 20 or 30 per cent.
—-Order! The honourable member for the Northern Territory!

—-There is a 30 per cent tax on luxuries; there is no tax on the necessities of life. There is no tax on 70 per cent of all the goods on supermarket shelves. The Opposition wants to put a tax on all goods and services.
—-What about an answer, John?
—-Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition asked his question; he shall listen to the answer.
—-Yes, let's have an answer.

—-The honourable member talks about regressivity. What does he think his tax is all about? It would put up the price of bread and milk and put down the price of Ferraris--regressivity. This is absolute nonsense. I do not know how he has the hide to come in here and talk about regressivity when those opposite want to impose on the Australian public the most regressive tax this country will have ever seen.

—-My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware that today Yugoslav army units have again seriously breached the cease-fire in Croatia, as negotiated by the European Community? Can the Prime Minister inform the House of the Government's response to developments in Yugoslavia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I know that the honourable gentleman is among those who have taken a special interest in this issue. I particularly commend him for his efforts, along with others, to establish in this place a bipartisan parliamentarians group to address these issues.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia was among the first countries to acknowledge that the democratic wishes of the people of Slovenia and Croatia for independence must be respected. The principal challenge now is to ensure that the future of Yugoslavia's constituent republics can evolve peacefully and with proper acknowledgment of the rights and the interests of minorities in those areas. Against this background, we strongly condemn the use of force between Serbians and Croatians in Croatia, and in particular the unwarranted actions of the Yugoslav army against Croatia.

The Australian Ambassador in Belgrade has put our views directly to the Government in Belgrade. We are especially concerned that recent Yugoslav army action seems directed not just at control of Serbian majority areas in Croatia, but it seems to be directed at strategic objectives throughout the republic. We have supported, and we will continue to support wholeheartedly, the efforts of the European Community and the CSCE to mediate a cease-fire and a settlement. We will be deeply disappointed if the breaches of the cease-fire overnight, to which the honourable gentleman referred in his question, prevent the convening of the peace conference scheduled for the weekend.

I am glad to say and to convey to the honourable gentleman that the latest information we have suggests that the conference will go ahead. We certainly hope that is the case, and we wish it well. We have been consulting closely with those who are defying and obstructing the European endeavours to understand that behind the Europeans stands the world community.

It is obviously too early yet to say that the efforts of the Europeans will not succeed, but it is not too early to make it clear that should the European effort not succeed, Australia would not be prepared to let it rest there, to stand back and let the tragic conflict continue. In those circumstances, we would want to see the matter taken up by the United Nations. I am sure that many other countries would agree with us in that situation.

I am glad to see that the Europeans have already taken steps to keep the Security Council informed of the situation. I know the honourable gentleman will be pleased to hear that the Australian Ambassador at the United Nations in New York has been instructed to liaise actively with other missions there on this issue. At this stage we are not proposing any specific United Nations action, and we do not overlook the difficulties that this specific situation presents to the United Nations, a fact that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, made clear in the Senate this morning.

Obviously, the question of recognition of Croatia and Slovenia is very much on our minds. In addressing it we have had to give close consideration to the internationally recognised criteria which must be applied and which I have previously spelled out in this place. We must also consider the effect that recognition would have on the situation in Yugoslavia itself and on the European efforts to find a settlement. I have said that, when the circumstances permit, we will be among the first to recognise Croatia and Slovenia, and I am glad to repeat that undertaking in this place.

I know that this is an issue of great concern to the communities in Australia, a fact which is very much in the mind of the honourable gentleman who asked me this question, and very much in the minds of many honourable members. I can say to the honourable gentleman, as I think he knows, that I have spoken to representatives of those communities over recent months on a reasonably regular basis.

I hope that I would have the support of all honourable members of this place when I say that our Yugoslav communities, representing all the diversities of Yugoslavia itself, have shown, I believe, marvellous restraint in these very difficult times. I say to them directly that we sympathise with the anxiety they feel and we applaud the responsibility they have shown. I am sure that I speak for all honourable members when I say that we are proud of them all, and we urge them to maintain their restraint in what I fear may be even more difficult days ahead.

I finish my answer to the honourable gentleman and to the House by informing the House that today the Government has agreed to contribute $100,000 in response to a special Red Cross appeal for emergency relief for those afflicted by the fighting in Yugoslavia.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Before returning to the fray, I generally endorse the Prime Minister's remarks. My question is directed to the Treasurer. I would not presume that he would deny that since 1982-83 his Government has tripled the hidden consumption tax--or wholesale sales tax--in that time. I ask: what compensation has his Government paid to the low income earners it claims to be so concerned about?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-This is quite incredible. First, the economy has expanded considerably since 1983. But if those opposite want to talk about compensation, I would remind them that there have been the family allowance, family allowance supplements, tax cuts, reform of the taxation system right across the board, and the greatest program of economic reform that this country has ever seen. The list just goes on and on and on. Why do not honourable members opposite try to explain to the people how they are going to put on a consumption tax and then compensate the people for the effects of the consumption tax and at the same time cut out $4.7 billion worth of government spending--whichever figure it is? Even last year when we had an $8 billion surplus in prospect it was, `Cut, cut, cut--plus a consumption tax'. Now we are in deficit it is, `Cut, cut, cut--plus a consumption tax'. It is all they know. Why do they not learn a new tune? There has been an enormous amount of compensation.

ANSWER.PARA: Our society is fairer than it has ever been. We can go through the whole program of social and economic reform. But I just do not know how those opposite have the hide to get up here and talk about regressivity and compensation. They would do nothing for the poor in our country, they would do nothing for low and middle income earners; they would wipe them out.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I direct my question to the Minister for Finance. Is he aware of continuing calls for tighter fiscal restraint? Can he inform the House of the implications of such an action for economic activity and employment levels?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am aware that after the Budget the Opposition has been calling for a tighter fiscal policy. That call was repeated yesterday in a press release issued by the Leader of the Opposition, to which the Prime Minister referred earlier in Question Time today. That deplorable press release, which attacks the Governor of the Reserve Bank in an unprecedented way, also has another aspect to it which is extraordinary, and that is that essentially it says that there should not have been an easing of monetary policy; there should not have been a cut in interest rates announced by the Reserve Bank or by the Treasurer on Tuesday. They are the two clear messages: those opposite do not like the Governor of the Reserve Bank; and interest rates should not have been cut.

ANSWER.PARA: I found it a rather amazing revelation that the Opposition was really saying somewhat obliquely in this press release that it was against any cut in interest rates. The heading of the press release talks about the Budget strategy and forecast, but the message that is right through this press release is that it was most inappropriate for interest rates to have been cut without a change in other aspects of macro-economic policy, in particular, fiscal policy.

The whole thrust of what the Leader of the Opposition was saying yesterday was that we must change other arms of policy, particularly fiscal policy, if we are going to have any reduction in interest rates. So the starting point for consideration of the Opposition's policy is that, with the current stance of fiscal policy, it is absolutely against any reduction in interest rates. All businesses and all home buyers in Australia should understand that given the current settings of macro-economic policy in the Budget, the Opposition says that there should not have been a cut in interest rates. That is absolutely what it says. It also says----

TALK.START.PARA: —-Can't you even get that right?

—-Read the press release. It is right through it. If the honourable member cannot get that out of it, he cannot read English. The other point that comes through it is that those opposite are saying that the only condition in which we can get a cut in interest rates is if we have a tightening of fiscal policy. What they are saying is that we have to have either--
—-Didn't you read it?

—-I have read it thoroughly. I would say that the Leader of the Opposition may not have read it. He must have somebody putting out press statements for him that he does not even look at, if he thinks that that is not what is in it. It says quite explicitly--
—-You didn't understand it.
—-I will read it to the Leader of the Opposition just in case he has not read his own press release. It says:

ANSWER.PARA: But what the Governor could not, or chose not, to say was that getting real long-term rates down on a sustainable basis will require the settings of the other arms of policy to be radically altered to tackle the fundamental structural problems which underpin those high real interest rates.
He mentioned the other arms, which are fiscal policy, wages and micro-economic policy--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Plural--three.

—-I am quite happy to talk about them. In relation to fiscal policy, those opposite are saying that we can only have a cut in interest rates if we do not have an easing in fiscal policy. In other words, they are saying there has been an easing in fiscal policy. In the context of this Budget there was no net new expenditure, so there was no easing on that front. The only discretionary easing was the tax cuts, which, as we have already seen from their previous press statements, they say we should not have had. But how much further would they go in saying that we should not have an easing of fiscal policy?

ANSWER.PARA: If the movement from the $8 billion surplus that we budgeted for last year to the $4.7 billion deficit this year is regarded as the easing of policy, would they go right back to the $8 billion? Is that what they are saying? Are they saying that the easing of fiscal policy is all of that amount, and that we should have had a $13 billion turnaround in the outcome by massive cuts in government expenditure and increases in taxes? Is that what is being said? Or would they only go back to the $2 billion that was the outcome for last year? How much easing of fiscal policy do they say there has been, and how much easing of fiscal policy do they say we should have had a turnaround on?

TALK.START.PARA: —-Did you ease?

—-This Opposition is clearly saying that there needs to be a much tougher fiscal policy if we are to have interest rate reductions. So either way, with the present Budget setting, those opposite say, `No interest rate reductions'. They say that if we are to have interest rate reductions, we must have a much tougher Budget; in either case we must have a much tougher macro-economic policy. The two arms of it have got to be bearing down much harder on the economy in the midst of a severe recession; that is what they are saying. In other words they are saying, `We need more unemployment; we need that unemployment to go on for longer. We need to delay the recovery because we have got to have a tougher macro-economic policy'. That is what those opposite are saying and have said all over the two pages of this despicable press release of yesterday. That is what they are saying.
—-Do wage rates.

—-I am happy to do wages. Firstly, we have never had a situation before in which the union movement has said to the Government, `We are happy to work with you in terms of bringing about the wages policy for the future which will give us an inflation rate comparable with the level of our international trading partners'. Never in the history of this country has there been that commitment from the trade union movement. But we have that commitment. In the last 20 years there has been one year in which we have had an inflation rate below the level of our major trading partners. Now we have a commitment from the ACTU to work with us to make sure that we can, year after year after year, have an inflation outcome which is at the level of our major trading partners, and hopefully a little bit less. That is a massive turnaround in the attitude of the trade union movement, a massive change for Australia, because we are improving our international competitiveness.
—-Do wages now.

—-Do not tell us that we do not have a wages policy. In the whole of the period we have been in office, the highest level of wage increase in any one year has been 7.4 per cent. In the whole period of the Fraser Government, the lowest increase in wages in any one year was 7.4 per cent; the average was 11 1/2 per cent. So do not tell us that we do not have a wages policy. We have had highly responsible wage outcomes. This year we will have a wage outcome of 4 1/2 per cent compared with last year's level, giving a slight real wage increase, and we are back onto the basis of low nominal wage increases but real wage increases, which is the best position for the Australian work force to be in. So we are quite happy to talk to the Opposition about wages policy and on micro- economic policy--
—-What about economic policy?
—-What a terrific one this is!
—-And then the waterfront and shipping.
—-I was about to tell the Minister for Finance that he should not respond to interjections; but the House seems to be enjoying it, so I think he might continue.
—-Let me say that in the 80 years--
—-This is the worst thrashing you have had.
—-Where is your health policy, Brian?
—-Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.
—-Let me just say that in the 80 years--
—-Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—-In the 80-odd years of this country being a federation prior to our becoming the Government, no government had even contemplated, let alone undertaken, anything like the structural adjustment process which this Government has set in place. Of course, in 30 of the previous 33 years we had conservative governments before we were elected in 1983, and throughout that period what we had was not structural adjustment but structural maladjustment, with the economy going completely the wrong way, with our manufacturing industries being developed under high tariff walls in a totally non-competitive economy, with a totally unproductive culture, with our workplaces being historical anachronisms compared with the workplaces of other countries.

ANSWER.PARA: All of those things are changing under this Government, in an array of structural change the like of which this country has never seen. What that is doing is giving this country a much more competitive economy, a much more productive economy, one which is much more internationally focused than it has ever been before, and one which is going to be on the right path for economic recovery from here on.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—-Mr Speaker, I wish to address a question to you. In asking the question, I refer you, Mr Speaker, to the advice of the Minister for Finance to this House today that the Director of the ILO is interviewing certain members of this Parliament. I ask you as Presiding Officer of the chamber: has the Director given you the courtesy of advising you if he is also interviewing the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for a job at the ILO in Geneva?
—-All I can say to that is that I guess no-one would be interviewing the honourable member for O'Connor for a job like that.

—-I have a question of you, Mr Speaker. I intended to ask this of you at the end of the last sitting and I sought to do it today. During several of the sitting periods in the last 12 months, we have seen a consistent strategy of interruption of Question Time and wasting of Question Time by the honourable member for O'Connor, who has now given it away and now has an apprentice in the honourable member for Isaacs. The Prime Minister has allowed more questions during this session than we have had for a long time, and I am asking you to have a look at this deliberate strategy.

—- The Chair has an obligation to hear points of order that are raised by members. Many of those points of order tend to be points of explanation or points to break up the debate and are found not to be points of order, but the Chair does have an obligation to hear them. My recollection is that in the past when honourable members have persisted in disrupting the affairs of the House, the House has taken action on that conduct.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Aboriginal Reconciliation)

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—-Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—-Yes.
—-The honourable member may proceed.

—-Today, immediately following Question Time in the Senate, Western Australian senator Senator Crichton- Browne made some remarks which made reference to me and to an alleged incident with Mr Ken Colbung, Chairperson of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies. If left uncorrected, the remarks could leave an impression which is totally false and misleading.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, it was suggested by Senator Crichton-Browne that I had been asked to open the open day at the Institute held yesterday and that I had accepted and then declined. This is false and no such invitation was ever extended to me.

On Friday last, an invitation was faxed to my ministerial office inviting myself and my staff to join the open day `for some stage during the day'. This fax was subsequently confirmed by the hard copy which arrived on Monday this week. I was not able to attend the open day, owing to the late notice and the fact that I had already explicitly obtained leave from the Parliament to open the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies Centre at the ACT College of TAFE and had accepted this engagement some weeks ago. I did ask two of my staff members to represent me at the Institute open day and they did so.

During the course of Tuesday afternoon of this week a message was left in my office that the Chairperson of the Institute council, Mr Colbung, wished to see me. At my express request, my staff contacted Mr Colbung to invite him to Parliament House to meet me as requested at the first available opportunity that night. At no time--I repeat, at no time--was Mr Colbung asked to leave my office by either myself or my staff, and any suggestion to the contrary by Senator Crichton-Browne is absolutely without foundation.

I place a high priority on the work of the Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies, as reflected in my earlier personal visits to the Institute after my appointment as Minister, my invitation to the Institute council to dine at Parliament House, my subsequent meeting with its members, my continuing close liaison with the Principal of the Institute, Dr Bill Jonas, my recent launch of an important publication of the Institute by Judith Wright, as well as the close ongoing work between the members of my staff--

TALK.START.PARA: —-This is going on a bit. I rise on a point of order. This is now into the realm of debating the issue. The Minister has met the point of objection that concerned him and that should be it.
—-I think the Minister is concluding.
—-Mr Deputy Speaker, this is the first personal explanation that I have made in this Parliament.
—-I rise to a point of order. Your determination is not based on the numerical total of the numbers that have been made. The Standing Orders are clear, and the Minister has got to wind up.

—-Mr Deputy Speaker, this is the first personal explanation that I have made. I am concluding my remarks. I conclude on this remark, if I could be heard in silence. Because of my respect for the past work of Mr Colbung, I have no intention of commenting on any matter which could cause embarrassment to him but wish to place on record that at no time did I or my staff conduct ourselves in anything but a patient and totally proper manner in an effort to be sensitive to the interests of both Mr Colbung and Senator Crichton-Browne. I only wish that the senator had extended me a similar courtesy.
—-Sit him down. He is not allowed. You've got to be fair.
—-Order!
—-I deeply regret that Senator Crichton-Browne has sought to raise the matters in the Senate, which were absolutely without foundation.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Social Justice for People with Disabilities

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; HEALTH, HOUSING AND COMMUNITY SERVICES

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOWE
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to make a statement on the Government's social justice strategy in relation to people with disabilities.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —-In November 1989, as Minister for Social Security, I made my first major statement to the Parliament on the Government's disability reform agenda. Today's statement reports on the Government's achievements since that time and brings into focus Labor's vision for the ongoing reform of disability services, and the crucial role the strategy occupies in the broader struggle for fairness, for expanded opportunities, and for better communities for all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor vision of a socially just society is one where all Australians can share equitably in the distribution of resources, especially employment opportunities. In a society that revolves around the activities of production and consumption, those who are denied participation in the work force are fundamentally marginalised. It is the Government's belief that, by enabling people with disabilities to participate fully in society, benefits accrue not only to the individual and his or her family, but also to employers, the economy, and ultimately society as a whole.

The package of new labour market and income support arrangements, known as the disability reform package and introduced in the 1990 Budget, is one demonstration of the Government's response to implementing practical measures for full and active integration of people with disabilities into the labour market. The package is built on earlier Government initiatives in the provision of support for people with disabilities; it involves an active system of payment and support for people with disabilities, and links new disability support pension recipients with appropriate vocational training, rehabilitation and employment placement services. The disability reform package will bring into sharper focus the special needs of clients with disabilities and is an outstanding illustration of the Government's broad approach to reform.

Building on the foundation of the disability reform package, the Government is now turning its attention to tackling the next stage of the reform process--overcoming the barriers that exist in the workplace for people with disabilities.

To achieve workplace reform, however, will require fundamental changes in attitudes and practices. The Government is undertaking a number of key initiatives in order to facilitate this change. The development of a new wages system specifically designed to open up employment opportunities for people with more severe disabilities is one example. This system will provide an effective system of measurement of the skills of workers with disabilities and will have important implications for extending employment opportunities for a group of people in the community who are currently unable to obtain employment because of their severe level of disability.

Attitudinal changes in employers, the general community, and indeed people with disabilities themselves, have also been identified as essential to ensure the successful integration of people with disabilities into the open labour market; an exciting workplace initiative to address this need for attitudinal change involves raising the level of awareness of employers and workers about the capacities, and largely untapped potential, of people with disabilities through a broad based communication strategy.

As identified by Ms Chris Ronalds, in her discussion paper, National Employment Initiatives for People with Disabilities, access to employment and other opportunities by people with disabilities should be regarded as a fundamental right with the full support of the law. The introduction of national, comprehensive anti-discrimination legislation for people with disabilities would secure them the same rights and opportunities as are enjoyed by Australians generally.

The Government is well advanced in planning for the introduction of such legislation. I have no doubt that this initiative will be regarded as having far-reaching implications for all people with disabilities. It also signifies a major step forward in legislative reforms for disadvantaged Australians.

Another unprecedented step forward in the Government's disability reform agenda is the rationalisation of the provision of disability services between the Commonwealth and State and Territory governments. By clearly delineating areas of responsibility and eliminating duplication and gaps in the provision of services, both levels of government will be able to better and more equitably target their resources to those with the greatest need of support, removing duplication at the same time as eliminating gaps in the provision of services.

At the Special Premiers Conference in July, all States and Territories signed the Commonwealth-State disability agreement which defines new Commonwealth and State government roles in relation to the provision of disability services. The agreement requires that each State and Territory enact legislation complementary to the Federal Government's Disability Services Act prior to the agreement's taking effect in that State, with the result that the quality of disability service provision Australia-wide will improve markedly once the agreement is implemented.

The new arrangements give responsibility for employment services to the Federal Government in recognition of its national responsibility for both employment services and the income security system; while the States will assume responsibility for accommodation and other support services in recognition of their traditional role in this area.

The significance of the Commonwealth- State disability agreement is enormous. It marks a turning point in the provision of more efficient service delivery for people with disabilities and signifies a new era in Commonwealth-State cooperation.

One challenge that arises from both the Commonwealth-State disability agreement, and more broadly across the disability reform agenda, is the need for all levels of government to gain improved knowledge about individuals with disabilities and their specific needs. With this knowledge, governments can direct program funds to where they are most needed, and programs and services can be shaped to suit the needs of individuals--rather than shaping individuals to suit existing support infrastructures.

Two new approaches to the administration and planning processes in my Department's disability services program will be crucial in realising the potential efficiencies of the Commonwealth-State disability agreement: the adoption of a needs based planning approach, which will address the unequal distribution of disability services across regions and social groups, and identify areas of highest unmet need; and the introduction of a consumer focused funding approach wherein funds will be directed through service providers to provide an agreed type and level of support for individual consumers.

Over the next decade, the vastly improved information base that these new approaches will engender--in tandem with the efficiency gains of the Commonwealth-State disability agreement--will produce more effective use of program dollars and better targeting to those most in need, as well as increasing the accountability of the disability services program in relation to improved outcomes for individuals.

I have outlined here only some of the Government's initiatives in the area of disability reform: there has also been considerable progress achieved in the crucial area of enhancing consumer rights since 1989, details of which are documented in my accompanying tabling statement.

All told, the combination of initiatives undertaken by the Government since 1983 has produced an integrated and coordinated system of supports that are becoming increasingly responsive to the needs of people with disabilities. Changes to the income support arrangements, and improved training and employment opportunities for people with disabilities; the concerted effort to tackle attitudinal barriers across society and enhance consumer rights in disability services; the development of more equitable and accountable methods of determining funding in relation to individual need; and the rationalisation of Commonwealth-State relations in the provision of disability services will all ensure that Labor's vision of a socially just society--where people with disabilities share equally in society's resources and are able to make choices that will fully develop their potential--becomes more tangible with every passing day.

To conclude, it is imperative that, as we approach the end of the United Nations Decade of the Disabled, we ensure that the process of reform is an ongoing one that engenders irreversible changes in the lives of people with disabilities. I now table the full statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave --In speaking to this ministerial statement by the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) on social justice for people with disabilities, may I say, particularly as the shadow Minister and, I believe, on behalf of the coalition, that we believe that the subject of people with disabilities should be bipartisan and above politics. We share with the Government a vision for social justice not only for the present but well into the future. So talk about social justice should not be the monopoly of any person or any party in this place. What we have to do is to ensure that those people who suffer grave disadvantages within our society have every right to the same opportunities as other people.

SPEECH.PARA: In the course of the last two to three months we have laid on the table of this House our problems and grievances with the present implementation. In 1986 the Disability Services Bill came into both Houses and became legislation with the full approval of people from both sides of the Parliament and from right around Australia. What we have done in the intervening period is to look at the Act and see what some of the difficulties are. Whilst it is the purest of spirits that moves us within these places, sometimes those purest of spirits get mixed up in the Department and do not filter down to those people with the needs.

I will refer to a few of the aspects of the statement that the Minister has just tabled. I thank him for the opportunity to have perused this for the few hours that I have had it. Whilst I will not go into detail on the major tabling statement, I just want to pick up on a few comments in the Minister's speech itself.

We are looking at the programs that the Government has implemented over the last 12 months to 24 months. The Minister refers to such things as the disabilities reform package, but I must reiterate that we had some initial complaints about the legislation. It was forced into this House under guillotine with little opportunity for debate. It now seems that it would have been desirable to have had that debate as, following discussion in the Senate, there are now over 100 amendments. My point is that, if we are to get proper legislation for people with disabilities, we want to make sure that it is accurate and will carry out the task that it is supposed to perform. After a delay and the carrying out of a survey, over 100 amendments will be made to this legislation. I believe things could have been done better.

The Government is pushing towards the goal of giving disadvantaged people every opportunity. I recognise the potential for the devolution of accommodation services to the States and employment to the Commonwealth, but the Government has made a fundamental error of judgment in assuming that all people with disabilities have the same degree of disability and can participate equally in the workplace. The big issue in the community at the moment is whether sheltered workshops will be allowed to continue for those people who cannot have access to full employment in the workplace. There are one million people unemployed at this stage, and most of them would be described as able-bodied, so it is difficult to see how people with disabilities will get an equal opportunity.

I think it is reasonable to draw the Minister's attention to our private member's Bill, in which we do ask for certain things--including a wider choice of programs so that those people who will not be able to participate in the work force are not left out in the cold without any social justice, probably to return to the homes whence they came. We need to emphasise the statement by the Minister that sheltered workshops will be continued. The transition date of 1992--which cannot be met with the funds available--should be extended. We must also look at recreation and living skills for those same people. If we are going to have social justice, this is a very important part of social justice--not just for the people with that need, but also for their parents and relatives at home who are looking after them. I think it is a very important ingredient in that regard.

I want to recognise the great work being done in the disability services area by carers and advocates right across the broad spectrum of Australia. I believe in their own way they are giving the best quality of service that they can and that it is comparable to what is available anywhere else in the world. I also include in that people who are the advocates for them; but, more importantly, I say with a degree of sincerity that the consumers have also played their part.

Another area that the Government is looking at is the devolution of responsibilities. People within the field want to know of any savings that will eventually come about with the stopping of wasting and duplication, and whether those funds saved will be returned to those people with disabilities. Perhaps it is a question which I should direct to the Treasurer (Mr Kerin), because he is in control of the purse strings. There is a need for more funds within the disability services area, and perhaps these can be generated from within the savings that have been mentioned.

There are some tremendously dedicated people within the industry who should be consulted on the minimum wage for employees with disabilities. I mention just one organisation of people, the Disabled Workers Union in Perth, Western Australia, which is affiliated with the Trades and Labour Council. I believe that some of the work of these smaller unions and groups has not been noted in the past. I believe that they would give a tremendous insight by way of practical demonstration of what is happening and what is required.

I also mention in connection with consultation the consumer focus funding approach, which was implemented on 1 July this year. As I understand it, consultations are usually had, reports are then drawn up, recommendations are made, and then the Government implements them. As far as I know, the consultations are still being finalised. In those consultations the carers and consumers alike have indicated grave concerns about the concept. In spite of this, the program was implemented on 1 July.

At the moment, the program is wallowing around without any direction or guidelines within the Department. I believe that when we talk about consultation, as the Minister's statement does, we should talk about meaningful consultations where people can be listened to and their concerns observed so that the final recommendations and actions thereon reflect what has really been put forward in that consultative process. While I have not had much input into the present consultations with Ms Ronalds, I can only say the first round of consultations on aged care left a lot to be desired from the point of view of talking to people who are prepared to listen.

As I have said, a lot of this information is from the past, and it also is associated with present policy and direction; but I believe that it is up to all of us here to ensure that this social justice is delivered in the manner in which it should be. As I said in the course of my address, there have been severe doubts about where that social justice has been delivered by the Department itself and about the manner of its implementation. I know that the Minister has read the grievance debate speeches that we made here a couple of months ago and I just refer them to him for his further reading on this subject.

DEBATE.TITLE: DISCUSSION OF MATTER OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The unravelling of the Government's economic policy in the face of the worst recession for 60 years and soaring unemployment.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —-When the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) inherited the job of Treasurer back in June of this year, he inherited Australia in the grip of the worst recession for 60 years. At that stage, we had witnessed four negative quarters of growth out of the last six, unemployment over 9 per cent and heading towards 10 per cent, and a massive foreign debt of $130 billion, climbing month in and month out at $1 billion a time. To say that the new Treasurer had a huge job in front of him was an accurate reflection of the huge mess he had inherited from his predecessor. He knew it and everybody in the country knew it. For that reason, most people were prepared to give him a fair go, to give him an opportunity to come to grips with Australia's basic problems.

SPEECH.PARA: But one would have to say that for the last three months this Treasurer has bumbled and stumbled and fumbled his way around in the economic management of this country to such a degree that when he and the Prime Minister fronted up to the Midday Show with Ray Martin, just a week or so ago, the band played a tune--it was the Laurel and Hardy theme. It would be funny if it were not so tragic, if there were not 831,000 people out of work, if businesses were not being closed from one end of the country to the other, and if Australian families were not under such considerable stress.

The people of Australia are desperate for a clear sign that the Government that they elected to office 18 months or so ago is going to face up to the problems that Australia has and provide some decisive leadership about the future direction of Australia. The people of Australia just want some action. They do not want a Treasurer who has reluctance written all over his face. They do not want a Treasurer who will only hazard a guess when he is asked what our immediate economic prospects are. They want a Treasurer who is going to get on with the job of making this country more productive and more competitive so that people can have a better prospect of getting a job and higher living standards in the future.

We all know that this country has major economic problems and we have a huge challenge in front of us. We are crying out for a Treasurer who can display a grasp of the situation, a sense of where we are going. We have a Treasurer who is bumping into light posts and falling over chairs just like Laurel and Hardy.

Today I will focus on some of the mixed messages--I am being very kind to the Treasurer in my choice of words--that we have had from this Treasurer on key policy issues since he first reluctantly took hold of the economic levers three short months ago. I do so to ram home the point that he has to get a grip on himself, get a grip on policy, make some clear assessments of where Australia is and start to set a path for the months ahead.

If we take the Treasurer's assessments of where the Australian economy has been and where it is now, he is all over the place. In June he said that things were coming good. A few days later he said that we are in a recession. He was then asked where we are going. He said, `Your guess is as good as mine'. Then he said that we were in a depression. During the last MPI he told us that we were in a depression. A month or so later he said that the outlook was strongly positive. This week, just to underscore the uncertainty in his own mind, in his press conference on the interest rate we got not one, not two, but three assessments of where we are. He said:
The decision will underpin the recovery underway . . .

A few sentences later he said that it is not under way, it is in prospect, and that the economy is now on the turn. Which of all these different assessments is the right one? Are we in a recession? Does the Treasurer really think that we are in a depression? Does he think that our prospects are only prospects or does he think that things are on the turn? It is important that he comes to a clear assessment of where we are so he has a firm base upon which some of the big policy decisions can be made.

We should look at interest rates. On 20 August the Treasurer had a very interesting tete-a-tete with Michelle Grattan on interest rates. He was asked, `What is your view on interest rates? Do you still stand on your views of a few weeks ago?'. He said:
Yes, we are taking an overall medium term look . . .
Michelle said to him:
But John, you did say a lot more than that.
He said:
Not at that time.

The Treasurer did say a lot more. We should look at the record. At one stage he had just come from his latest briefing from Treasury and he was all revved up on interest rates. Strong and resolute, on ABC radio he said that there was `still a lot of response coming through' from the cuts to interest rates over the last 18 months. Critically, he said:
Therefore, there is simply no need to pump prime.
He backed that up a couple of days later when he said:
Further easing now would not affect the economy until 1992, when the recovery should be well under way--a case of too much, too late.

He supported that. He said that he had advice from Treasury and the Reserve Bank and that if their advice had been that now was the appropriate time to ease monetary policy, that would have happened. He was strong and firm on monetary policy. Five days later we get the great back-flip after a bit of political pressure on the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). He gives the Treasurer the wink and the nod, and the Treasurer is all over the place trying to substantiate his position on interest rates and monetary policy.

The Treasurer should give the House and the Australian population a clear and concise statement of exactly what is his view on monetary policy. What role does he think monetary policy has, as one of the levers which he as Treasurer must employ in the management of this economy? If the Treasurer was not rolled on Monday on the interest rate issue--he was extraordinarily defensive in his announcement of this change, feeling the pressure of criticism before it had even arrived--he should explain to the House what changed between this week and last week. What additional data persuaded him that what he said last week was wrong? If there are data, if he has something substantial, today he should give us the information and the solid facts. Perhaps a clue is to be found in the comments made yesterday by Mr Fraser of the Reserve Bank when he said that the fall in business investment is particularly worrying. Is it particularly worrying to the Treasurer and, if so, on what basis is he concerned? We should take another key area--wages and superannuation. The other day at the Press Club the Treasurer said:
Superannuation will turn us into a nation of savers.

That is just plain wrong. If the Treasurer wants to counteract that, I invite him to do so. When he stands he should give us a substantial argument to back up his proposition. I say that he is wrong. I say that with his superannuation proposal he will throw people out of work and boost inflation; all he will do is take the savings out of one pocket and put them into the tax concession pocket of superannuation. He is not going to boost national savings. The truth is that national savings have been falling and the Treasurer has no policy response for that.

We should look at some of the Treasurer's statements on wages policy. This really is a doozey. When we get a Labor Federal Treasurer walking into wage-tax trade-offs like a bull in a china shop, we really know that he is in trouble. Again, he had a briefing from Treasury. He was all revved up as to what the right line was. He was absolutely honest at the Press Club on 21 August when he said:
I believe there is little room for further tax cuts, particularly as part of wage/tax trade-offs for the life of this parliament.
He went on to say:
I just don't think wage/tax trade-offs are affordable in the future.
The Canberra Times told the story a couple of days later when it reported:
The Treasurer, John Kerin, took less than 24 hours to retreat from his declaration that there would be no tax cuts, especially wage-tax trade-offs with the ACTU, during this term of Parliament.
Mr Kerin said in Sydney yesterday that he was only talking about 1991-92 and `certainly 1992-93 is not something I am shutting out of my mind'.

That is just not true. It is on the public record. The Treasurer did a back-flip. He had political pressure applied to him again and he turned as quickly as the phone call came in from the Prime Minister.

This whole edifice, including the superannuation issue, leads to further unemployment. If the Treasurer is the honest John he claims to be, why does he not table the Treasury data that have been provided to him which show the unemployment effects of his decision--and throw in for good measure the CPI effects. The fact is that the Treasurer is not prepared to release the data. He is not being as frank as he ought to be on that key issue.
We should look at unemployment. We can hear the theme from Laurel and Hardy through each one of these key issues, including unemployment. The Treasurer said:
We certainly will have unemployment of the levels of around 8, 9 or 10 per cent for the next two years.

I ask the Treasurer: which is it? There is a big difference between 8 per cent and 10 per cent for people who are going to be thrown onto the unemployment scrap heap as a result of his policy. A few days after that he said:
We believe we'll be getting below 10 per cent by about this time last year, next year sorry,--
being sorry is not much help--
and then it will continue.

What did the Treasurer mean by that? What did he mean by `it will continue'? What is his assessment on unemployment? Where are we going? He should make that assessment and then give us a policy prescription to meet it.

The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) is responsible for Medicare, but this Medicare decision is one of the central planks in the Treasurer's Budget. Some $167m in the first year is blowing out to a cost to the Budget of something like $700m. In the Age this morning there is a headline that says `Medicare fee: Howe fights on'. The Age says that the Minister is sticking to the line. The Treasurer's name ought to be up there in lights as well. The Treasurer should be sticking to the line and sticking to the Budget. Instead, on the very day that the Treasurer released the Budget he was backing off on the Medicare decision. At his press conference he said:
A Labor Government would prefer not to touch Medicare.

That was a central plank. He ought to have made it quite clear that he stood behind that decision and that he is prepared to fight for it.
