Instead we have seen the Government shove one of the central planks of a key policy issue off to a committee comprising three backbenchers. As with investment and unemployment, all the assumptions in the Treasurer's Budget are unravelling in front of our very eyes.

The Treasurer was playing with fire on the question of superannuation on property trusts and the redemptions freeze policy that he introduced. It was a doozey. He was reported as saying that he could guarantee that investors in frozen property trusts would get their money back under the new arrangements. His minders worked awfully fast on that one; so they should. He is about to claim the title of the Rob Jolly of Federal politics.

It would be fair to say that the Treasurer has to come to grips with some new issues, but on the matter of Coronation Hill, for example, the Treasurer was the Minister responsible in that era. He knew what was at stake. His public position was quite clear prior to the decision being made. At that time he said, `I think it has become a very important issue; I think we should give it the go ahead'. That was a clear endorsement. However, in his first week as Treasurer he sat in the Cabinet room, on a critical issue nominated by him, and just allowed himself to be rolled, as the Prime Minister moved on yet another one of his shady deals. All these embarrassing gaffes, all these sudden about- faces and all these misleading answers spell just one word--confusion. John, honestly, you are a personable character, I like some of your jokes--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Not many.

—-Not all, but no-one questions the Treasurer's bona fides. He is an honest sort of battler but, quite honestly, he is not coping with the key policy issues that confront him. He has inherited an economic mess and has inherited the vicious personal fight that is going on between the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the ex-Treasurer. In the midst of all this turmoil the country looks desperately to the Treasurer to provide some sense of leadership, some sense of resolve to find the pathway out of the recession. Instead, we get reluctance and we get the indecision that Peter Walsh told us we would get the day the Treasurer was appointed. We get the bumbling and we get all that sense of a crisis of self-confidence, which the Treasurer has portrayed in recent weeks.

SPEECH.PARA: His Budget is unravelling, and I say to the Treasurer that there are things that he can do. He could fix that health policy; he could fix that depreciation decision, which is still a mess since the March statement; he could put a wages policy in place; he could reform the tax system and stop taxing people who export; and he ought to do something about looking forward to a mini-Budget early in the new year. If he is not sure where to start, the Treasurer should take the one that is floating around from members of the Left and do exactly the opposite of every proposition that they put.

Mr Deputy Speaker, when I sit down you are going to call Australia's Federal Treasurer, and that just happens to be you, John. That will be an opportunity for the Treasurer to put the last three months behind him, give the House and the Australian public a clear statement of his assessment of the Australian economy, and then go on to give us a succinct and clear statement of the way in which he would employ the policy avenues available to him in the months ahead. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The title of the matter of public importance today was almost totally ignored by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith). The only point that he possibly made referred to Medicare. I want to assure all honourable members that, regardless of the outcome of the examination of the Medicare co-payment by a Federal parliamentary Labor Party committee, there will be no change to the Government's fiscal stance. As set out in the Budget, the Commonwealth's fiscal strategy sets the basis for a steady and sustainable recovery and for future job growth. This, of course, contrasts with the confusion in the Opposition on fiscal matters. All that the Opposition appears to believe is that there should be large cuts in government expenditure, regardless of the consequences for employment or for future economic growth.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter of public importance is breathtaking for its opportunism, cynicism and disregard for the strategic development of economic policy under this Government and also for its cynical misrepresentation of the Budget brought down by the Government on 20 August. The Deputy Leader said something about wanting a more productive, more competitive economy. That is what we have been on about for eight years. This MPI is opportunistic because it ignores the hollowness and emptiness of the Opposition's response. It is cynical because members of the Opposition do not even pretend to have a set of answers that would respond in a categorical way to the task of rebuilding growth and lowering inflation. They want to add to inflation. While we are getting on with the business of making responsible decisions, the shadow Treasurer is getting on with the task of saying, `Wait till Christmas'. Which Christmas? Christmas is always coming.

The Opposition's disregard for economic policy is best highlighted by the venal attack of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) on the Governor of the Reserve Bank, in which he claimed that Mr Fraser had condoned an easing of monetary policy that `will simply underwrite the wages deal which his masters have cooked up with the ACTU'. That is just contemptible ideological claptrap.

In addressing the matter of public importance we need to background it against figures just released today showing, from a survey of job vacancies, increases for the first time since the peak in September 1989. I would certainly caution honourable members, as I always do members of the press, that this is just another partial indicator and needs to be kept in perspective. As I continually emphasise, working on one figure does not make an economic body builder. Nevertheless, the tentative signs of recovery and economic good health are with us.

In addressing this matter of public importance, let me explain the objectives of economic policy and the process of economic policy for the beginners on the benches opposite. It is critically important for us all to understand these points. Any trained chimpanzee can get up and say, `Tighter fiscal policy. Cut, cut, cut. Lower interest rates. No support for the unemployed'. I could train a lower primate to get that lesson down pat in just a few short weeks. I note, just in passing, that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has got that message down pat.

The task, however, for governments is to put policy into place, to work through the political, economic and cultural processes in order to get decent policy up. That is a lesson that should be scorched into the Opposition. The Fraser years--those years of maladjustment--demonstrated the difference between rhetoric and actual results. The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) comes in here each day blackened by the blank sheet which was his list of achievements during the Fraser years.

This Government now has in train the most ambitious economic reform program ever seen in this country. Secretly members of the Opposition are just a bit envious. They know that under this Government taxation has been completely reformed; they know that superannuation is the right thing to do; and they know that reforms to our rail system, our roads, our electricity system and to our system of government regulations and rules are exactly the right things to do. Members opposite are just sitting there and are secretly terrified of the reforms and the process of reform that are in place. Secretly they hope for a continuation of low economic growth. Secretly, like the honourable member for Bennelong, they believe that such times will suit them.
I can tell the House that the economy will improve; unemployment will come down; employment will grow; growth will again drive investment and an expansion of exports;

the current account deficit will stabilise and inflation will be kept under control; and the Australian economy, Australian industry, and Australian workers will all benefit from an industry structure that is more efficient, more competitive and more flexible, because of the reforms that we have put in place.

Let me turn to the process of reform, because there is a fabulous misconception around that the pure world of the computer driven economist opposite just drops out of the sky. It is not the case. Reform has to be negotiated past the rocks of special interest groups and the hard places of political and constitutional realities. In order to do this we need a process for reform. That is exactly what this Government has established. The 12 March statement set in train the process for reform of our private industries; the 12 March statement outlined the program of reform to tariffs and to business inputs and depreciation; and, further, the 12 March statement outlined the necessary steps to ease the adjustment costs for individuals. That is why so much emphasis has been placed on workplace training and that is why so much emphasis has been placed on increasing the skills of Australians. In short, the 12 March statement underpins the reform of our private sector.

The Government acknowledges, however, that the public sector has to change too. That is why the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) established the Special Premiers Conference, and that is why, for the first time in the history of this country, the Commonwealth, the States and local government are working to make government services and government instrumentalities better. Impartial commentators agree that if all governments can hold their nerve on the Special Premiers Conference process, which the Prime Minister has initiated, we have the greatest chance since Federation to make far-reaching improvements in the operation of governments and the delivery of services in this country.

After the March statement and the Special Premiers Conference process, the third leg of this crucial and integrated economic trifecta for this year was the Budget. In the Budget we exceeded even the toughest expectations laid on us. I do not need to reiterate the difficult circumstances in which we had to frame the Budget. However, I remind the House again that we saved $50m and all new policy was paid for from savings. In other words, we saved $50m from this time last year in terms of our expenditure. That was disciplined budget making and disciplined spending, and in this year all new policy has been gained from savings.

Even within such tight constraints as these we still succeeded in achieving real reform. The changes to our retirement incomes policy and the significant improvements in payments to low income families are reforms of great significance. We have initiated major reforms for our cities and continued the industry reform progress in the March statement. We have continued to provide increased support for labour market training and for environmental issues. We have done all this but still maintained the structural integrity of the Budget.

Compare all this with the apparent agenda of the Opposition. Last year, in an environment where we were expecting a surplus of $8 billion, its prescription was to cut. Do I have to read it? It is the same old stuff. Last year, the Sydney Morning Herald said:
Dr Hewson said the Government had not gone far enough in cutting spending, especially welfare expenses.

The headlines were `Budget not tough enough--Hewson', `Budget avoids tough choices'. All the time it is chop, chop, chop, cut, cut, cut. It is the only thing the Opposition knows. The Opposition's only motivation is political. It has no concern for what is appropriate. It has no understanding of the processes required to get good policy into place.

The Opposition never has a constructive suggestion and is bereft of detail in a few areas where it claims to have alternatives. The Opposition still has no health policy. It still has no details of a consumption tax. The absolute gutlessness of the Opposition has been demonstrated over the years by its failure to bring out alternative policies.

Even something as important as the new tax, which the Opposition is hell-bent on imposing on the Australian people, is so far nothing but a string of allegations, without details, about what the tax will do for, to or against people--mainly against.

Honourable members should listen to the string of ideological cliches from the Opposition. The Opposition wants a totally deregulated wages system, nil inflation, nil tariffs, a nil deficit, nil change in interest rates and constant cuts in government spending. This ideology is parroted as if the economy has no people, as if there are no politics and no State governments, and as if the rest of the world does not exist. For every political problem, the Opposition believes there is an economic equation of absolute and proven veracity. It is nothing more than theory and has its basis in synthetic models and market ideology.

The real world has little to do with short term theory or doctrine, and the perceptions of the financial markets are not everything. Real economic activity, real production and real growth come from investment. One cannot build a factory before morning tea on day one of a turn in an economic cycle.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition also tried somehow to get the question of interest rates into his proposition that the Budget was unravelling. Is the Opposition seriously saying that there should be no interest rate changes at all? Is it seriously saying that the only interest rate changes should be at Budget time? If the Opposition is saying the latter, it could say that the Budget has unravelled a bit. But that is absolute nonsense. Changes to monetary policy and interest rates are made continually through any one particular year. The only thing that is unravelling is the Opposition's confidence in its ability to sell a new, regressive, unfair tax to the Australian people.

I turn now to look at some of the other nonsense in the statement by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. He said something about pump priming, as if the interest rate issue was about pump priming. The reference to pump priming was entirely about spending beyond the cyclical effects of unemployment and the downturn--the recession--on the economy.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition wants me to say whether I was rolled on interest rates. Of course I was not rolled. We followed due process. I emphasise that we worked on the basis of accumulated evidence. The Reserve Bank Board did not meet in August and data was coming through the whole time. If the honourable gentleman cannot read that data, I am very sorry for him. I can give him the full litany of all the factors that went into the decision of the Government and the Reserve Bank. The Governor of the Reserve Bank put paid to all the snide remarks, cynicism and nonsense from the Opposition about this. Really, the story has died. When the truth has come out, the only person who believes his own baloney is the Leader of the Opposition.

There was also reference to superannuation. There are well-refereed studies that show that superannuation at the level we intend introducing it, phased in over the years, will certainly add to savings. The Opposition has also discovered a new model--the Murphy model. I have had a look at the Murphy model; it is in the library now.

TALK.START.PARA: —-You understand it, do you?

—-Yes. It is in the library now. Anyone can have a look at it. The whole problem of the Murphy model is that it is relatively small. It has about 20 behavioural equations. It uses quarterly data and embodies long run design features, which include optimising behaviour by producers and consumers and balanced, steady state growth. It is also extremely user friendly. It has been increasingly adopted in the financial community as a tool for exploring the impact of policy and other exogenous shocks on the Australian economy.

SPEECH.PARA: But models are models. If we compare this model with the McGibbon Sax Global model called MSG2 and factor in a cut in government spending, we get totally different results with the Murphy model from those with the other model. There are lots and lots of models around. One can plug in any figure one likes--this one was given to me by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition--and get whatever level of unemployment one wants. When the Opposition cites models as if there is some inherent veracity in all of this, it is having itself on.

Somehow the issue of Coronation Hill got into this. I do not know how that has anything to do with the alleged unravelling of this Budget. There is no unravelling at all in this Budget. Last year, we saved $50m between the time we brought the Budget down and now. Now, with a Budget of $101.5 billion, again we have done the job, and we will continue doing it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have to begin by disagreeing with the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith) on one thing. He likened the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) to Laurel and Hardy, but it is more appropriate to liken him to Basil Fawlty. He has the height of Basil Fawlty and he has that commitment to good lines; he loves to give us all a laugh. For example, one of the good lines I thought he used in his speech was that for eight years the Government has been on about a more productive and competitive economy. We have the worst recession we have had for 60 years!

SPEECH.PARA: He also said that our taxation system is completely reformed. We have a taxation system which is older than computer technology, older than television technology. We have one of the most old-fashioned taxation systems in the world.

The Treasurer attacks us for not having produced yet the details of our goods and services tax and tax reform proposals. We had the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), on the other hand, waxing lyrical in Question Time about all the great changes and improvements that have been achieved in the wholesale sales tax legislation. But the Government has not yet introduced the legislation to make those changes, or even drafted it. We have heard a very curious but, if I may say so to the Treasurer, very amusing response to a matter of public importance.

Finally, the Treasurer criticised and attacked the Murphy model. What he says about economic models may be all very well, except that his own Department's modelling is based entirely on the Murphy model. It must be remembered that the Treasury projections, continually quoted by the Treasurer, come from the Murphy model.

Like Basil Fawlty, the Treasurer is always one for a good laugh, a good line. But the Australian economy, to continue with the analogy of Basil Fawlty, is like the hotel Fawlty Towers--full of rats, bad food, beds that do not work, doors that fall off their hinges and so on. And there is Basil Fawlty rushing around, excusing himself, pretending that everything works, and using lots of cover-up lines. Honourable members would remember it all from the wonderful Fawlty Towers programs. The Treasurer, in his approach to the economy, is exactly like that.

It is said--I note that this has also been said by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Flinders--the Treasurer is an honest man. He is an honest bungler; there is no doubt about that. He honestly does not know what he is doing. He is the man who, when he answers questions, stands up and says, `The Treasurer'--then there is silence--`that's me', so that we are reminded who the Treasurer of this country is. It is a true statement, but not a very inspiring statement. He is the man who says to journalists--the Peter Hartchers of the world; young, struggling journalists, trying to get a story, digging around no matter how false the story is--on projections for the economic outlook, `Your guess is as good as mine'.

It is worth reflecting on whose guess is as good as his, there being a whole array of journalists with microphones, television cameras and so on. Their guess is as good as the guess of the man who has the resources of the Treasury behind him, the Murphy model to back him up and, presumably, is meant to be the chief economic manager of this country--that is, him.

We have a Treasurer whose first act 2 1/2 months after he became the Treasurer was to introduce his Budget. The question is whether it was his Budget, whether his first great act was indeed his own act. The Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) said:
Discussion of the Budget should have nothing to do with the leadership--
ho hum--
because the Budget strategy was essentially set when Paul Keating was the Treasurer.

Despite 2 1/2 months beavering away with the Murphy model and trying to understand how economics work, the Treasurer did nothing. Certainly he did nothing because, at a time when Australia faces--as we all, I think, know now--its worst recession for 60 years, we ended up with vacuous verbiage on Budget day, honest in its vacuousness.

What did the Budget do to reduce the foreign debt? What did the Budget do to address the balance of payments crisis? What did the Budget do to make Australia internationally competitive? What did it do to stimulate investment in our economy? It predicted that investment would decline over this financial year by 10 1/2 per cent. Where was the coherent industrial relations and wages strategy in the Budget? Where were the details of micro-economic reform?

I do not remember how long the Budget Speech lasted. It seemed hours, but it was probably only 20 minutes. There was nothing in it at all of any substance that addressed those issues. That is not to say there was nothing in it at all. There was the `mad cities' proposal which the Treasurer initially opposed--we all know he opposed it--saying that it was vague and impractical. Later on, the `mad cities' proposal having been announced and the Treasurer having been rolled, he said he wanted to turn office blocks into houses. So we have the concept of Pitt Street, Collins Street or whatever in Sydney or Melbourne being refurbished with a mass of welfare housing or high income housing. I am not sure what he has in mind. This is apparently the Treasurer's vision of the `mad cities' plan.

The Treasurer has a proposal in the Budget, which is apparently the former Treasurer's proposal, for an increase in superannuation payments to 5 per cent by 1994-95. If we use the Murphy model, if we use the models that are being used in the Treasury and that the Treasurer's projections are based on, by 1994-95 we will have 100,000 people thrown out of work because of this brilliant superannuation scheme.

The third initiative in the Budget is to correct the balance of payments problems, I suppose; to resolve our foreign debt crisis; to try to recover the terrible state of our economy; to get nearly one million Australians back to work. We now hear that the Medicare charge of $3.50 is, after all, too difficult. Presumably, this review is one step towards the increase in the Medicare levy. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised at the last election that that would not happen. He will not reiterate his promise. Goodness knows what other promises are now inoperative as a result of the last election.

When we address the general approach of the Treasurer--there is not much more to say than this about his general approach--the reality is that he just does not know what is going on. We can see that from his attempts to answer questions during Question Time. He made a very interesting speech to the Irish-Australian Chamber of Commerce on 1 August. By then he had been the Treasurer for two months. He revealed his great style, his flair when he said:
This is the first real chance I have had since becoming Treasurer to give my own speech--
Two months later, the first chance? To continue:
Up till now, advisers, minders and officials have been telling me that I must talk about things like fiscal and monetary policy.

Goodness me, fancy a Treasurer talking about things like fiscal and monetary policy! What a big surprise! As we well know, when the Treasurer stumbles into those topics he finds them very hard to handle, despite the claim--which, I must admit, I am finding increasingly hard to believe and think should be investigated--that he has an economics degree.

Let us look at some of the comments he made about the Budget surplus. On 5 June 1991, he was quoted in the Canberra Times as saying that it was `very important that we maintain a structural surplus'. On 20 August he was asked by a journalist:
Do you know. . .whether the Budget is in structural surplus or deficit or on balance?
He replied:
I would say it is slightly in deficit.

That is funny, because only a couple of months earlier he was saying it was very important that we maintain a structural surplus and it had gone into structural deficit. In other words, either he believes that his own policy has failed or else he takes the view that when a journalist gives three options, if one option is chosen, there is a chance in three of getting the right answer. I suspect the truth is that he opted for the latter strategy.

Finally, there was the great interest rate debacle. Let us try to remember that the Labor Party deliberately pushed up interest rates in order to resolve the balance of payments crisis. We should never forget that. We still have a balance of payments deficit of $1 billion a month or more. The argument of members of the Labor Party is: if that is the case, it is not a very good time to bring down interest rates. They thought that they had created all the pain by increasing interest rates to resolve the balance of payments crisis. But the funny thing is that without it being resolved the Government is now rushing to reduce interest rates. It has admitted now that its own policy is a complete failure or it has just decided--this is, of course, the real truth--that it is going to sprint to try to keep the present Prime Minister in a position of leadership.

Let us look at what the Treasurer has said on interest rates. Soon after the Budget he started off by saying that interest rates could not be reduced; that they would not be reduced; and that the economic circumstances were not right for them to be reduced. Finally, he reverses all that under the pressure of leadership.

In conclusion, we have a Treasurer who, sadly, at one of the most serious times in Australia's economic history, just does not have a clue what is going on. Putting Basil Fawlty in charge of a national economy and the livelihoods of 17 million people is not a funny thing. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham Mr D.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am happy to assist Opposition members in unravelling the Government's economic policy, because I realise they are economically illiterate and economically bankrupt. As the coalition has no credible economic policies, I can well understand its envy of a government which has clear policy aims and objectives. There is no denying that Australia is in the midst of a recession, a phenomenon currently affecting most Western economies. As a member of the international economic community, Australia is not isolated from the trends of other economies. It is, however, interesting to compare statistics of this recession and the recession that the Australian Labor Party inherited from the coalition when it formed government in 1983.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1983, the Government inherited a taxation system in disrepair and disrepute. In 1983, the top personal marginal rate of tax was 60c in the dollar. Under this Government's economic policies, which the coalition finds so hard to understand, that rate is now 47c in the dollar. In 1983, the bottom personal marginal tax rate was 30c in the dollar. This rate is now down to 21c in the dollar--once again, an achievement beyond the comprehension of the economic pygmies of the Opposition. In 1983, company tax was 46c in the dollar. It is now 39c in the dollar.

Let me continue to unravel. The Government has been able to achieve such reductions in the level of personal income tax by raising revenue from a number of other sources and making the tax system more equitable. The introduction of the capital gains tax, still bitterly opposed by the Opposition, has been a source of considerable revenue for the Government.

In 1990-91 the capital gains tax is expected to raise $631m. The Opposition is quite proud to say publicly that in the unlikely event of it winning government, it will abolish the capital gains tax. The question must then be asked: where will it raise the revenue lost from its abolition? It is not too hard to find the answer. The pay as you earn worker will again be asked to subsidise the rich friends of the coalition.

Who was it that strongly objected to the introduction of the fringe benefits tax? The Opposition was concerned that its rich business friends might actually have to pay for their lunch. It argued that Australian business would be crippled by the imposition of this unjust tax, because the smoked salmon, lobster and wine would be replaced by tuna, Perkins paste and cordial and business confidence would be lost.

The fact is that the fringe benefits tax has raised in excess of $1.26 billion. Like the capital gains tax, it is both just and equitable. It targets those who can afford to pay. Let the Ferrari driving Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) explain to a factory worker who takes his lunch to work in a brown paper bag why he should be happy to subsidise the business lunch. The reason the coalition is so bitterly opposed to the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax is that it means its friends and supporters will have less money to polish their silver spoons.

I can understand why a Party which has presided over the biggest tax rorts in Australian history needs help in understanding the policies of a government which stopped bottom of the harbour rorts. Labor's economic policies have made the tax system fairer for all Australians, and it is for this reason that the privileged sons of the aristocracy and the squattocracy are so bitterly opposed and resentful.

One may well ask: what is the Opposition's solution? A balanced Budget and the introduction of a consumption tax. It is obvious that the Opposition knows nothing about economics. It is equally obvious that it knows nothing about history.

I must admit that I thought I was in a time warp when I heard the Leader of the Opposition say, in his reply to the Budget, that the Government should have balanced the Budget. What a fine speech it was--full of sound and fury, long on rhetoric and short on detail. It really showed that the Leader of the Opposition has inherited a new title: that of the shadow--completely lacking in substance.

I thought I was hearing the ghost of Sir Otto Niemeyer, the representative of the Bank of England, sent to Australia in the Great Depression of the 1930s. It was Sir Otto's economic advice of a balanced Budget--now totally rejected--that contributed to prolonging the economic difficulties of the Great Depression. It is obvious that the good doctor's remedies will only make the economy worse. At Question Time today the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) quite rightly pointed out that the core of the Opposition's program means only one thing; that is, a spiv led, computer driven recovery. It is wrong in economics, it is wrong in equity and it is wrong in fact.

What will be the effects of the consumption tax--the Opposition's great recipe--on low income earners and the elderly? It will mean more inequality and more injustice. The consumption tax is a recipe for disaster. It attacks the poor and the disadvantaged members of the community. Its effects on inflation are well-known. One only has to look at the New Zealand economy to see the effects on inflation of a goods and services tax. What will the impact of a consumption tax be on unemployment? A consumption tax and a balanced Budget will only lengthen the dole queue. The reason we have all the empty words and the rhetoric--without the substance--coming from the Opposition is that it has no substance. It truly is the shadow Government, completely lacking in substance.

This Government will be remembered for the long term vision of the superannuation policy that has been brought down in this Budget--a recognition of where Australia is heading in the next century. What does the Leader of the Opposition say? On 18 August 1991, in a doorstop interview, he said:
. . . I don't believe that occupational superannuation makes any sense in a country like Australia.
What a disgrace; what a joke.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Shameful!

—-What a shameful statement by the Leader of the Opposition. When we look at who he purports to represent, and who he actually represents, we are not too surprised. We are in difficult times. No snake oil salesman solutions can be brought out in the difficult economic times that we are experiencing. The Opposition snake oil salesmen would have us believe that there are easy solutions. There are no easy solutions. There is to be plenty of pain, but at the end there will be sustainable recovery and gain for the people of Australia. In the 1993 election the electorate will have the opportunity to see the difference between what the Opposition offers and what this Government offers.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's view on the bottom line in the Budget is to apply the fiscal blow torch. Its fetish with deficits would condemn greater numbers to unemployment. Those numbers would be thrown on the scrap heap after nine months if the Opposition had its way. The Opposition needs all the help it can get in economic management. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The time for this discussion has expired.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Robert Brown, for Mr Beazley, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Government's November 1990 statement on micro-economic reform outlined changes to take place in the provision of telecommunications services in Australia. As part of these reforms, Aussat Pty Ltd will be sold to form the basis of the second carrier. A number of regulatory changes have recently been made by the Parliament to create a competitive environment for the second telecommunications carrier and new owner of Aussat.

The Commonwealth's 100 per cent share- holding in Aussat is to be sold and general telecommunications and public mobile licences awarded. Once ownership of the shares is transferred, Aussat will cease to be a government business enterprise. Accordingly, the Aussat Act 1984 will need to be repealed and a number of consequential provisions will need to be put in place so that the sale can be completed. After the sale, Aussat will be a privately owned company and subject to the laws that presently govern the corporate operations of such companies in Australia.

Consequential provisions are also required to extinguish Aussat's tax losses, to empower the Treasurer to give an explicit Commonwealth guarantee to Aussat's borrowings up to the point of sale, to appropriate funds to pay out those borrowings prior to the sale and to remove Aussat from future coverage of other Commonwealth legislation such as the Archives Act. Under section 80 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, a company may offset prior year losses against future income to reduce taxable income and income tax liability until such time as the accumulated losses have been used up.

Aussat's accumulated and projected trading losses to 30 June 1991 provide a potential future income tax benefit to a purchaser. While it is normal practice to sell an entity with any tax losses, doing so in this case would clearly have budgetary implications in future years. From a budgetary viewpoint, therefore, it is desirable that they be removed.

On the matter of Aussat's borrowings, in the period leading up to the sale, Aussat will continue to fund its operations from both revenues and borrowings. It is essential therefore that the viability of the borrowing program is maintained until it is paid out by the Commonwealth. Because of Aussat's high gearing, investor support of its borrowing program in the lead-up to the sale is heavily reliant on Commonwealth expressions of support for Aussat. Paying out the debt prior to the sale will have a twofold effect. Firstly, it will reassure lenders in the period prior to the pay-out and, secondly, it will facilitate the orderly sale of the company.

The appropriation provided for in the Bill is set at an estimated maximum amount allowing for contingencies such as the impact of variable interest rates applying to Aussat's borrowings between now and when they are paid out, the possible pay-out of one or both of Aussat's leveraged satellite leases as well as its commercial paper borrowings and any slippages in the timing of the pay-out due to factors relating to the sale itself. The figure is $800m, but the Bill provides for the actual appropriation to be set at an outturn figure below the maximum. The need to pay out the leveraged leases will not be known until the bidders, the banks and the Commonwealth decide as part of the sale negotiations how the satellite leases are to be treated. The amount of the debt pay-out will ultimately affect the price received for Aussat.

The explicit guarantee is required to support the restructuring of Aussat's borrowings in preparation for pay-out. Just prior to pay-out Aussat will consolidate its borrowings into a single credit instrument with the Common- wealth Bank to facilitate the logistics of pay- out. For its part, because of its very large exposure to Aussat through this arrangement, the Commonwealth Bank has quite reasonably requested that the Commonwealth guarantee the credit instrument up to the point of sale. The Bill provides for the guarantee to cease at the point of sale. The Bill also makes minor amendments to other Commonwealth legislation consequential upon the repeal of the Aussat Act 1984 and, in respect of other telecommunications legislation in particular, to correct drafting anomalies and to clarify the technical operation of some of the provisions of that legislation.

As indicated above, this Bill provides for a maximum of $800m which can be paid to Aussat in the form of additional share or loan capital. The amount actually paid will be determined by movements in interest rates between now and the time of pay-out, the timing of the actual pay-out and the treatment of the satellite leveraged leases. It is neither possible nor desirable to predict what the incoming sale proceeds will be, as this will be determined in the sale negotiation process.
On behalf of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley), I commend this Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Smith) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Robert Brown, for Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Overseas Students Charge Act 1979 to fix the amounts of the charges payable under the Act for the 1992 academic year. In accordance with established practice, the overseas students charge is adjusted annually in line with movements in the index of higher education charges. The amounts payable in 1992 are shown in the Bill. The charges are payable by overseas students enrolled in Australian education institutions under the subsidised program to which the Act relates. On behalf of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), I commend the Bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Chaney) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 September, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newell Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —- Last night in the House I expressed my pleasure at the fact that, since my raising of the need for the flood mitigation works in Lismore to be undertaken, the New South Wales Government has seen fit to raise the priority of this project in its submissions to the Federal Government under the Federal water resources assistance program. In anticipation of the successful completion of the consultation process, the New South Wales Government had sought and was given Commonwealth funds to allow the commencement of works during 1991-92.

SPEECH.PARA: The news which flowed from the Budget is the best news that the Government could give to the city of Lismore. It has been my No. 1 priority, and I do not mind admitting to the House how excited I felt when the announcement was made. It is just the news that we need to get things moving up in Lismore. A prosperous city, which Lismore is, will attract investment and break the cycle of unemployment for many.

Another aspect of the Budget which will impact positively on the far north coast of New South Wales is the increased funding of some $199m for labour market programs, which will bring the Commonwealth moneys made avail-able for such programs to a total of $514m. It will also provide further increases for vocational training, such as apprenticeships, TAFE and Skillshare programs--that is, real training for real jobs, which is the real need of the Richmond electorate, where the industry base is so small.

It is often asserted that Federal programs cannot deliver the goods on the ground because of the supposed isolation of Canberra from the real world. I want to pay tribute to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) for the way in which Commonwealth programs have built into them the flexibility to allow them to respond to local labour market conditions. It is clear that what suits the needs of, for example, north Sydney might not suit the needs of the unemployed on the north coast, at Byron Bay, the Tweed or Tyagarah.

In terms of labour market programs, no-one will change the face of the Richmond electorate and the imbalance in its industry base overnight. However, a number of strategies have been developed locally, underscored here by Budget initiatives which attempt to face the region's problems squarely. The first is the formation of what can only be described as a hard-nosed committee of people representing successful businesses, manufacturing and union interests from the region to examine the possibilities of the region on an industry by industry basis. That committee, called the Northern Rivers Regional Development Committee, was set up under the office of labour market adjustment program.

I have already described to this House the initiative of the people who set up the Norply mill in Kyogle. That initiative provided an example of value adding which we could all learn from. That operation is a fine example of what this nation must do over and over again. It is vital for the expansion of manufacturing within the Richmond electorate. Past practices of using our resources without value adding has meant that we have had a low return for what should have been a very valuable product. In Kyogle potentially valuable veneer was peeled from logs and sent away to be sold for a pittance. Today that same operation, through the perseverance and the foresight of people in the community --and helped by State and Federal programs--uses the veneer in a process to provide valuable plywood. A bonus was the creation of over 80 jobs which would have disappeared if the mill had closed.

One of the tasks of the OLMA committee is to identify and, where possible, foster similar value adding opportunities throughout this region. At the same time, training and skilling programs, whether conducted under the auspices of CES, DEET, Skillshare or TAFE, seek to respond to local needs.

I have used the term `stung to desperation' to describe how many of the unemployed in the electorate of Richmond feel about finding a job. However, like tackling flooding in the city of Lismore, turning around the legacy of the past on the north coast will not happen overnight. Nevertheless a beginning has been made to look seriously at applying what I have termed `the Kyogle syndrome' to the problem of our industry base on the north coast.

At the end of this month the first exchange of information between the three tiers of government and private enterprise within the Richmond electorate will take place. From that exchange we hope will emerge some real commitment for the region to work together to ensure that the lack of a substantial industry base is not just accepted and handed on to our children and their children.

The approach of this Government in dealing with problems for individuals who are unemployed contrasts starkly with the position embraced on the other side of the House, where, after nine months, recipients of social security payments would be cast adrift without any care for their future. That is the compassion which the Opposition parties would show to those who live on the New South Wales north coast, where unemployment even in good times far outstrips the jobs available.

Let me now turn the attention of the House to changes to the superannuation and retirement incomes policy. This Government has set a target to boost employer support for superannuation to 9 per cent of earnings by the year 2000. While honourable members on the opposite side of the House decry this move and attempt to portray it as one which will bring about the collapse of the Western world, let us look closely at the benefits. When this Government came to office in 1983, less than 25 per cent of the Australian population were covered by superannuation schemes. That figure has now risen, and probably something like 70 per cent of the population have some sort of superannuation scheme. The present move is well on the way to ensuring that, by the year 2000, every worker in this nation will be in such a scheme.

The obvious benefits to Australia have been spelt out by the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) and by other members on this side of the House. I want to draw the attention of honourable members to one unheralded benefit: more and more people upon retiring are choosing to move out of places such as Sydney and relocate to places such as the north coast of New South Wales. In that situation, the quality of life for those citizens is enhanced. The provisions of this Budget in relation to superannuation and retirement incomes policy will provide more and more Australians, upon retirement, with choices because the disposable income will allow them greater flexibility in making decisions about where and how they live.

I draw the attention of honourable members to just one of the many health initiatives contained in this Budget. I refer to the Government allocation of some $22.4m to improve the effectiveness and reliability of cervical cancer screening in a new four-year program which will target at-risk women. Many women, including older women, Aboriginal women, women from a non- English speaking background, and women from isolated rural areas are at present infrequently or never screened. Over half of the 1,040 cases of cervical cancer diagnosed annually could be prevented by a more effective national screening program. The cervical cancer screening program will be welcomed by all women.

In my own electorate of Richmond this program will join the mammography unit being set up at Lismore and the osteoporosis clinic being established to provide services for women. While it is important for all women to have these services, it is especially significant to the quality of life of women who live on the far north coast of New South Wales that these services should be available within the region. I give an undertaking to the women in the Richmond electorate that I will work to bring the benefits of this Government initiative to the Richmond electorate.

I want to refer to two other aspects of this Budget which will impact positively for the benefit of us all. The Budget maintains support for the design, construction and operation of the Australian pavilion at Expo 92 to be held in Seville, Spain, from April to October 1992. A key objective of Australia's participation at Expo 92 is to promote Australia as a tourist destination to the estimated 4.5 million visitors who will pass through the Australian pavilion during the Expo. The Australian pavilion's exhibits and programs will target the high priority, high growth European markets.

Another ambassador for Australia to the Seville Expo will come from the Richmond electorate. Spain's Expo 92 will have a kangaroo pub--an outback pub operated by Australian businessmen. The pub looks like a woolshed with an iron roof and a windmill outside it, and is expected to serve 30,000 drinks a day with Australian seafood and steaks. The 1,400 square metre pub will be in the centre of the 215 hectare Expo site in the national pavilion area. The pub will provide many of the visitors with their first experience of Australian lifestyle.

The tourism industry means a lot to this nation, and I am sure honourable members on both sides of the House wish the Australian exhibitors well. I am sure that that wish extends to the Australian pub, and I know that the group involved from Richmond will make good ambassadors for Australia. The success of that ambassadorship will be seen in the flow of trade and tourists to and from this country in the years following Expo. Naturally, we will be trying to snare an equitable amount for the north coast, which contains some of the most beautiful country in Australia.

Lastly, I want to refer to the increased allocations in the Budget for technical and further education and higher education. The training package announced in the Budget will strengthen the ability of what the Minister rightly describes as the nation's most extensive training scheme. It will provide high quality training to Australia's work force and for thousands of young people preparing and training for their working lives. In this regard I hope that the attacks upon the TAFE teachers' working conditions in New South Wales will cease.

To conclude, I must again commend this Government for the support it has provided for higher education in this Budget. I know that the debate about higher education charges will be waged on both sides of the House and on campuses right across the nation. However, I want to pay tribute to the Government for the fact that, over and above what is happening in the fees debate, it has provided new funding of $76m in 1992 and $42m in 1993 to help alleviate the pressures of over-enrolments and overcrowding.

That funding is over and above other commitments already made and the payment of the long awaited salary increases for academic staff in universities across the country. I understand that around $4 billion will be spent on higher education in 1992. Most pleasing is the announcement of 13,000 new places and the capital works program of some $266m for 1992.

In 1968 a report to the New South Wales State department of decentralisation and development entitled Some Sociological Aspects of Life in New South Wales Country Towns was published at Macquarie University in Sydney. As part of the compilation of that report a survey was undertaken in 12 New South Wales towns and provincial cities to isolate factors which impacted upon the quality of life. The chief finding of that survey was the major problem of the provision of tertiary education.

One of the credits which the Opposition surely would not seek to take away from this Government is its commitment to answering the question: how can access to higher education be provided for provincial and rural Australia? Just some 15 months ago I told this House of the importance of the impact which the former Northern Rivers College of Advanced Education had on the electorate. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: --One can well understand the concern of the Hawke Government that the Budget has been poorly received. However, I can assure it that it is not simply a matter of bad salesmanship, because disenchanted and very worried Australians have a very clear perspective of why the Budget has failed. No massive public relations campaign at taxpayers' expense and no gimmicks from the political charlatans and the imposters who have portrayed themselves as economic managers will succeed. The nation knows that the game is up, and so does the Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: People have had enough of the buck-passing by the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), and the `Your guess is as good as mine' honest acknowledgment from the present Treasurer (Mr Kerin). Lives, businesses and the economic and social heritage of this nation and its people are being shattered by the combination of Labor governments around Australia.

Only one Labor leader, in Queensland, who inherited a well run and balanced economy, retains any credibility. But time will see even his Budget deficit--which has now blown out to $3.9 billion--grow as spending proliferates and as State colleagues of Mr Goss, desperate for revenue, try to change the funding rules to compensate for their own mismanagement.

What then does the Budget tell us? It tells us that the number of unemployed will go up probably to one million. Within these figures we see a real tragedy. At least 300,000 people are now in the long term unemployed queue. Another 160,000 of the unemployed were yesterday's family breadwinners, and there are massive problems for youth and other people moving into the job market for the first time. The driving force--the motivation--behind the Budget should have been jobs. Instead, it is related to only one job--the top job.

While the Government seeks some answers to its paralysis, let no-one forget that it has been the honourable member for Blaxland who was the self-acknowledged architect of this mess. He `brought home the bacon'; he produced the `beautiful figures'; he was the Placido Domingo; he sang in the leading role; and he carried all of those on the Government side of the House meekly along the path to shattering the hopes and future of millions of Australians.

My real concern with the rhetoric of the Budget Speech is the absence of any objective assessment of the depths of the economic malaise and the reasons for it. This is not a recession brought on by drought, when recovery is usually rapid when production returns, when confidence returns and when the impact on business activity and infrastructure development is relatively minimal.

This recession and the deep-seated problems that exist stem from a total adherence to monetary policy with unsustainable high interest rates--the real villain in the devastation of our productive activity. It is paradoxical therefore that, as socialist regimes and policies tumble around the globe on an almost daily basis, Australians and Australia are being forced into embracing them.

This Budget has, for example, acknowledged that Medicare is slowly consuming itself and, with it, one of the world's best combinations of private and public health care delivery. But in making this acknowledgment, the Budget, by the action that has been taken, simply exacerbates the problem. Waiting lists at public hospitals will increase and the awful inequities that exist, particularly in my electorate of Mallee and other regions of Victoria, for many country people will remain. Community hospitals are bleeding financially as clients, unable to meet both the Medicare levy and private insurance, either forgo medical attention or travel to an already overstressed and under-funded public hospital system.

Obviously the Government itself is under pressure from unions and its own members to make changes to the Budget as far as Medicare is concerned. We know, for instance, that the existing Medicare levy meets only one-fifth of the cost of health care. My real concern is that the Government is being panicked through political expediency and as a servant to ideology to again follow the dictates of the union movement, thereby increasing the levy and further penalising the reducing number of taxpayers. There is simply no justification for people who wish to attend a hospital of their choice and fully cover themselves with insurance having to pay the Medicare levy as well.

A similar feature of the Government's philosophy, transferred into policy, is reflected in the superannuation scheme. Treasurer Kerin again is following the former Treasurer's early initiatives, placing employers under further pressure. The Government's decision to require all employers to pay 5 per cent of their wage bill into superannuation contributions from July 1992 will increase labour on-costs with the legislated route denying employers the opportunity to argue about incapacity to pay.

Some small businesses have been cushioned from the impact of what amounts to a Federal payroll tax by a change to the start-up date and the special provisions of a 3 per cent rate for those with payrolls under half a million dollars a year. The Treasurer points to raising the employer contribution further, to 9 per cent of annual payroll, by the year 2000 with consideration being given to requiring employees to pay some contribution. This was the sort of consideration that should have been given at the instigation of the superannuation scheme in the first place.

Of greatest concern to economic policy, however, will be the likely diversion of investor funds from productive capital investment to superannuation. Such a diversion of investment funds will be regarded by many in the business community as ill-timed, with spending on productive plant and equipment forecast to fall by 10.5 per cent this financial year--remembering that last year it fell by some 11.9 per cent. Such large successive contractions in plant and equipment spending will have the effect of limiting growth in the supply side of the economy, holding back the structural adjustments and reforms that are necessary, and greatly reducing our national capacity to bring down the horrendous current account deficit.

This mandatory dictate by the Government, which, as I said, takes no account of a business or an industry's capacity to pay, will be a further tax on jobs. Contrary to the views of the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Newell), who believed that this policy would increase the benefits to those in the work force, the real impact will be on those that are not.

Before turning to some specific comments on the impact of the Budget as far as country Australia is concerned, I wish to make two further observations. Firstly, economic factors are not the only cause of unemployment. The disintegration of family life, the impact of family law reform and a turning to welfare to treat the symptoms rather than the need for structural change are major contributing factors. A significant number of children are now being born into unemployment, who in turn will become parents of children in the same pattern. The widespread difficulties being experienced by many sole parent families as they seek low cost housing when there is a dearth of unskilled jobs are part of a new social phenomenon. A major demographic change is taking place in Australia and it is not being addressed.

Secondly, the Budget impact is intended as one of restraint when the obvious challenge is for stimulus for investment, for the production of wealth and in turn increasing employment. Lower interest rates and lower taxation should have been part of reforming policies but all with the aim of encouraging self- sufficiency. An incredible number of letters are being received in our electorate offices at this time from people who have been prepared to support themselves in the past and who are really wondering where this nation has gone wrong.

The Government made much of its family income package, but it is both a farce and a fraud for many financially stricken farmers and small business people. Let us have a look at some of these changes. We now have a $600,000 asset test on family allowance which will effectively exclude hundreds more families from this assistance. It has totally failed to address the inequities and anomalies with Job Search and Austudy. It is inequitable that a farmer's spouse who is actively seeking work is not eligible for the Jobstart allowance.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Shameful.

—-It is shameful, as the honourable member for Cowper says--and this is even though the family may have virtually no income. The asset test limit for JSA is $157,500. Realistically, very few viable farms are worth less than this. By implication the Government expects farm families with low incomes to sell the farm to provide themselves with income support. Where is the social justice here?
—-Socialism, not social justice.

—-Many farm assets are not divisible or saleable in the current economic climate. For those that are, the selling of part of a farm would mean the remaining farm enterprise would be a non- viable unit. There are very few jobs available to a farmer who is able to sell the farm as a whole. This expedient of selling the farm further reduces the economic activity of any region and in turn of the nation.

SPEECH.PARA: A farm is sold together with the home on it, so selling the farm means selling the home. The reluctance of many farm families to take this step is certainly understandable. If the Government imposed this requirement on unemployed urban families, there would be a justifiable outcry. Unlike other groups, the main asset of the farm family is not the home. It may be appropriate to apply the $157,500 threshold to other groups and to exclude the home from asset calculations, but for farm families it is not.

Why did the Government, in determining eligibility for the Jobstart allowance, not discount business assets by 50 per cent as it does for Austudy? Forty-six per cent of farm families today have absolutely no access to Austudy due to the assets test. The announced change to Austudy enables recipients of a pension administered under the Department of Social Security, or those receiving household support administered under the rural adjustment scheme, who apply for Austudy to be exempted from the Austudy asset test but this is no concession. The asset test threshold for Department of Social Security benefits, for example, is $347,000. So if applicants for Austudy were receiving a Department of Social Security benefit, they would already be required to have assets of less than the existing Austudy threshold.

No rural children should be barred from tertiary education because of their geographical position but this is occurring. Surely in 1991, when the Government talks of social equity, such a fundamental tenet does not have to be fought for.

I turn now to the Budget impact on primary industry in particular--on those who work in it and those who service it, and the significance of this sector on Australia's future and our standard of living. I point to some figures mentioned in this House this week by the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss). He made the point that the take home pay next year of the 4,600 public servants who work in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, and who are basically paid for by primary industry levies, will not be much less than the income of the 126,000 farmers they support. It is a very interesting figure and one that we should all be concerned about.

We all know that agriculture is notorious for its cycles of boom and bust, but sometimes they are caused by economic factors and at other times by dramatic swings in local climatic conditions. The current downturn, however, is not merely a low point in the ever recurring cycle of events. The evidence supports the view that the rural sector today is in the midst of a major economic and social breakdown.
Geoffrey Lawrence, a researcher with the Centre for Rural Welfare Research at the Charles Sturt University of New South Wales, has said:
Australia in the mid-80s was featured by falling commodity prices, high interest rates, increasing import costs, falling land values and increased farm debt.

The full extent of the rural crisis has never been fully comprehended but includes environmental degradation as farmers seek to work the land harder and the social malaise as rural towns and villages lose their human vitality. This is associated with a population migration, with the withdrawal of voluntary labour, usually that of farm and town women, and the reduction of Government services and facilities in response to the policies of financial restraint.

The degree to which farmers have successfully maintained viability until recent times has been observed by counsellors in my electorate of Mallee. The majority of farmers currently being counselled were debt free at the beginning of the 1980s. In the course of the 1980s, however, as many as 40 per cent of all farms have had periods of negative income. Under these circumstances, it is not surprising that many farmers have not been able to remain debt free. For instance, a Department of Agriculture study has shown that the average farm cash operating surplus for Victorian woolgrowers for the period 1985-90 averaged $46,000 per annum. It is expected that this figure for 1990-91 will decline to about $16,000--a drop of over 60 per cent--and we are now told that at least 30 per cent of all woolgrowers throughout Australia will have a negative income next year. Similarly, with wheat and other broad acre crops there was a 35 per cent decline in income in 1990-91, and for this year negative incomes are the order of the day for many farmers.

Farmers have been actively encouraged by many people over the years to increase farm size to ensure long term viability. Following above average harvests in the Mallee and the Wimmera in 1983, farmers competed for more land, causing land values to rise considerably. At the same time they were encouraged to lease machinery and to purchase new plant to gain tax deductibility. As a result, many farmers borrowed quite large sums of money. It was not foreseen that, as a result of this Government's action, money borrowed to pay inflated land prices and to purchase plant would become increasingly more expensive. Loans taken out at rates of 10 to 15 per cent very quickly escalated to 20 per cent and beyond. With rising interest rates and a poor run of seasons, many farmers in my community found themselves with serious financial problems. They have been further exacerbated by land values falling now by up to 50 per cent and beyond, which substantially erodes the remaining equity that farmers had in their farms and their ability to obtain carry-on finance.

This substantial debt, coupled with low commodity prices, is today the main force driving farming families into insolvency. Even if overseas agricultural protection abated as rapidly as could realistically be expected, resulting in less dumping of exports and lower trade barriers, and even if the economic policy of this country were competently managed, our farmers would gain only a temporary respite. There will continue to be unrelenting pressure on agriculture.

The mid-1980s crisis in most of the Mallee--it was not much different around the rest of Australia--was attributed to the severe drought of 1982, followed by the poor seasons and conditions of 1984-85. This had the effect of focusing attention on the short term needs of farming communities rather than on the long term changes which now seem inevitable. These trends have now re-emerged in the 1990s and are now increasingly prevalent across the entire region. At that time State and Federal governments were both willing and more able to provide assistance to those most affected than is the case in these times. For instance, in 1986 in the Mallee 900 farming wives were able to qualify for the unemployment benefit. It is estimated that this resulted in an injection of some $8m into my local economy. But, of course, the Government has now made changes to the eligibility criteria regarding the value of assets and joint ownership of family farms, which has meant that many farming families are no longer able to claim such benefit.

Many skilled farmers are now in extremely difficult circumstances. The average age of farmers in Australia in 1989-90 was 53.8 years. The present conditions--and actions of the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), whom I will never forgive--have ensured that we have lost from agriculture the next generation of skilled youth from our rural communities. I will never forgive the Hawke Government for this.

Many rural families are experiencing very high levels of stress and this, of course, extends into the small business community that serves them. When this is coupled with the comparatively low level of services, many country people have little choice but to endure an ongoing state of anxiety and distress. Survey data indicates that rural people experience 10 per cent more illness and have 28 per cent more hypertension and disorders than urban people. It is therefore bitterly ironic that people are withdrawing from many kinds of activities in the community, such as sporting organisations, service clubs, et cetera, at a time when the very social contact that they provide would be invaluable in alleviating the stress of the current crisis. The families most at risk are those who, in order to save money, cut themselves off from the rest of the community.

I have had recent meetings with professional and voluntary providers of services. The current conditions are as stressful on them as on their clients. The impact of the rural downturn on many towns and communities in my electorate, and no doubt right across the whole of Australia, is very similar to that of a natural disaster. When a community is engulfed by a bushfire or a flood, relief organisations swing into action. But there is no such comforting action in these circumstances.

It is not just the economic issues that are placing stress on rural communities. Of course, there is growing concern about soil erosion, salinity and the use of chemicals. These are all issues which confront farmers and put growing pressure on many farmers throughout Australia. No matter how passionately activists may feel about the threat that some farming practices pose to the environment, it is the farmers and the landowners who must accept the need for change and ultimately bear the cost. This Budget has failed. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —- Politics, as it is played within governments and parliaments which have built themselves on the Westminster system, really is about many things. It is about policies, priorities and programs. These Ps of politics, as they are often called, are determined at national and local level and are all about the interests of pressure groups and people. It comes back to things such as financial management and the very important issues of justice, equity and accountability. But it is also about alternatives.

SPEECH.PARA: In the system of government that we adopted from the British, there has been a traditional responsibility on oppositions not only to monitor the programs, the policies and the priorities set by a government; they also have a very special task, which is to present alternatives.

I listened with some interest the other day when the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) made what one could describe as a theatrical Budget reply. I give him full marks for the theatrics. But, when it came to performing that responsibility of presenting the alternatives, one could only give him a score of one out of 10. He presented no alternatives to the Hawke Government's programs of expenditure and receipts. He provided no explanation of a detailed Opposition strategy. He gave no alternative priorities and he gave no alternative policies.

What the Leader of the Opposition did was to play the game of generalisation. He played the game of criticism without construction. He played the game of opposition without alternatives. Why? I asked myself: why would he do that? Was it that he was not ready to come forward with these alternatives? Was it that he was trying to time strategically his run--or was it that he was afraid of scrutiny? I opt for the last. I believe that there is growing evidence that it is the fear of scrutiny that is the reason for the lack of detail and lack of alternatives from the Leader of the Opposition and other members of the Opposition.

Many pronouncements have emanated from those opposite, but they have been superficial; they have been one-liners. One notes when one goes through them that they have been targeting personal prejudices. They talk about things such as radical reform, which sounds great; but they never say what it means. They have these glib one-liners about the work ethic; but they do not really go into the issue, the detail, the substance. Then they get onto things such as the unemployed. They target personal prejudices on immigration and on those who they keep talking about as on the dole. Then they have a campaign of half truths; linked to that are deceit and, again, generalisations. To find out what those opposite believe, what they espouse or what they are saying, one has to dig--and that is often very hard to do.

But there are some certainties. The certainties are that those in the Opposition--the Liberals and Nationals federally--are committed totally to Thatcherism and Reaganomics. They are committed totally to total deregulation of the marketplace. If one looks at recent material that has come forward, one sees that they are committed to all the extremities of hard right capitalism.

On 13 August there appeared in the Bulletin magazine a cover story entitled `How Hewson would change Australia'. It was written and compiled by David O'Reilly. It is the first detailed exposition of the thinking--or one might say political mentality--of the extreme right wing elements that are now in firm control of the Opposition Liberal and National parties. It is a detailed analysis of the priorities, the programs and the policies of not only John Hewson but also many of his shadow Ministers. But it is also obvious that the Opposition has attempted to package these proposals so that they are politically palatable.

I put it to those who have read that article that it contains enough specific detail to put fear into the minds and hearts of every Australian who believes in fairness, equity and social justice. There is nothing that is very sure, but the Opposition program is truly a blueprint to force Thatcherism onto Australia.

I have listened to the Leader of the Opposition and he has admitted a number of things. In this article, and on other occasions, he has said that Australia under him would be `radically different'--his words. He plans to `re- sculpture the nation'--his words. He talks about a revolutionary shift from the public sector to the private sector. He is talking about massive privatisation. He is talking about the private enterprise control of community services, of aspects of education. He is talking about the private entrepreneurial control of welfare, postal services, communications, pensions and health care. He is talking about the total deregulation of airlines; this means the total deregulation of air safety, which must send shudders through thinking people. He wants to totally deregulate working conditions, wages and awards. He wants to bring about Hewson's Thatcher Australia.

I suggest that it is vital that all Australians understand just what the Hewson alternative really means. They need to understand how the Hewson plan--the blueprint--will affect them and their families. If we look at Britain between 1979 and 1988 when Thatcher controlled its society, we find that Thatcherism captured the hearts of the conservatives--particularly the extreme Right, the rich. Thatcherism clouded the minds of the economists--regrettably, even some of our own in this country.

Thatcherism caught the aspirations of the British people, who were looking for an alternative to what they saw were the problems and the difficulties of Britain in the 1970s. Thatcherism corralled the political thinking of the parties of the Right over there, just as they have done here with the Liberals and the Nationals. Thatcherism failed, yet we have here an Opposition Leader and his shadow Ministers running this line and saying that the Opposition will bring about a Thatcher Australian society. The fact is that the Leader of the Opposition and his extreme Right followers are desperate to cover up that fact.

We need not look at what Australian politicians in the Labor Party have said about Thatcherism; we can go to the British themselves. Nigel Healey is an economics lecturer at the University of Leicester. In the magazine Contemporary Review, in December 1989, he wrote:
Purging inflation from the system has cost Britain a decade of mass unemployment and burdened industry and home buyers with the highest interest rates since records began.
That is Thatcherism; that is what the Leader of the Opposition wants for Australia. Nigel Healey went on:
At the end of the decade the inflation rate was at almost precisely the levels inherited by the Conservative Government in 1979.
He went on further:
Purchasing power of the pound shrank by more than half.

Those opposite cannot blame the external factors; they cannot say that Britain was knocked off its course by oil shocks. They cannot say it was undermined by militant unions. They have to admit that it failed because of the economic direction, the economic emphasis, that Thatcher imposed on that country--the same economic emphasis that the Leader of the Opposition wants to impose on Australia. He is calling on Australia to adopt the same policies.

If we compare the period from the second quarter of 1979 through to the fourth quarter of 1988 with the two previous 9 1/2-year periods, we find that growth during the Thatcher period was distinctly lower than it was in the earlier two periods--even lower than in the 1950s. The growth of labour productivity--that is, the output per member of the employed work force--was lower than it was in the two previous periods of equal length. The only thing that did increase was labour productivity in manufacturing; yet statistics show that the growth rate of manufacturing production was still relatively low--less than one percentage point.

Average export volume for the two previous 9 1/2-year periods was 40 per cent, but during the period of Thatcherism from 1979 to 1988 it was only 32 per cent. Export volumes did not significantly increase, but imports increased by 93 per cent. Yet Hewson tells this country, `We will turn it around'. When there was a deterioration in the balance of trade there was an attempt to mask it with the growth that took place in oil exports. It did not last long. The statistics expose a deterioration in the balance of manufactures. We also see that Britain under Thatcher was worse off than all the larger European countries.
