If we talk about unemployment--which the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) raised today--employment fell by two million people between 1979 and 1983. There was a rise of over two million in the unemployed between 1979 and 1986, and this finally went to three million unemployed. In 1989 unemployment was still one million higher than it was when Thatcher came to power.

So where is the miracle of Thatcher? The Tories falsified the figures and they falsified private sector investment because they included in the figures the sales of public sector real estate instrumentalities. Ken Coutts and Wynne Godley, who are commentators, academics, summed the situation up. They said:
The performance of all the indicators has been poor, relative either to the past and to other countries or in many cases to both.

They said that improvement in productivity was confined to manufacturing; in contrast, productivity in the economy as a whole grew relatively slowly. John Wells of Cambridge University summed it up when he said that under Thatcher Britain had a trade deficit as large as any in her history. There was accelerating inflation. He said that Britain experienced the most severe output recession since the Second World War--with two consecutive years of substantial reductions in GDP. He also made the point that unemployment blew out to over three million. He said that the British manufacturing industry suffered more than at any other time, even during the Great Depression of the 1930s.

What do we find? Thatcher had to turn it around. She had to change track in 1983--almost with a complete U-turn--which led to mounting trade deficits and accelerated inflation. Clearly, there was no economic miracle under Thatcher--the Thatcher policies that Hewson now wants to place on Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —- Order! I remind the honourable member that he should refer to other honourable members by their electorates.

—-Thank you. In summary, under Thatcher there were higher rates of unemployment, a weaker external position and rising inflation. As I said, there was no economic miracle; in fact, there were significant increases in consumer prices. As for interest rates, the figure for 1988 was 9.8 per cent and for 1989 it was 13.1 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: When we look at the USA under Reagan we see exactly the same thing. The common characteristic is policies for the rich and the powerful at the expense of the poor, the disadvantaged, and the low and middle income people.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Sounds just like Australia, Keith.

—-Let us talk about Australia. The Bulletin article is the document that those on the shadow front bench have espoused as the blueprint. Let us take some of the proposals. If we look at the contributions from the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), the Leader of the Opposition and others, we see that all wages will have to be negotiated at enterprise levels. In other words, we will get back to hands full of threepences. We will get back to a situation like one we have in Rockhampton at the moment. A hotelier employed two girls--twins--but paid them one wage. The same fellow got a person to wait two hours before he was paid; that is called stand-by under the system that those opposite want to pursue.

SPEECH.PARA: How could the members of the National Party support the privatisation of postal services? It will mean that people outside the metropolitan areas will have a skyrocketing increase in the costs of postal services. At the moment, as we can appreciate, the cost of postal services in country areas is offset by the profits made in the capital cities.

The Opposition wants to force people to take out private medical insurance. There will be a fire sale of government property. The Opposition wants a war with the trade union movement. We know how irresponsible that is and the calamity it will cause. To use the words of the Bulletin, the Opposition wants to `sack tens of thousands of public servants'. Yet the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher) talked about the poor people who have suffered under the Labor Party Government. Of course the Government is concerned about unemployment. The Opposition wants to sack tens of thousands of public servants.

As for new taxes, the Opposition does not only talk about a goods and services tax. There is something interesting about a goods and services tax that those opposite have not admitted yet--that is, all the countries that have a goods and services tax usually have a linked welfare tax. That is what is done. All of the nations that have introduced a goods and services tax also impose on their people a welfare tax. Up to 23 per cent of all revenue gained by European countries comes from the welfare tax, where people pay for their own social security benefits. If the Opposition is going to have a goods and services tax it should come clean and talk about the other taxes that go with it.

Let us look at some of the Opposition members. The honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) wants to get rid of consumer protection. The honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) wants to sell off Telecom in 10 per cent sections. He wants to remove the cross-media ownership restrictions, in other words, allow the monopoly of the media by a few. He wants to slash the ABC funding. I can understand it if he wants to have a go at AM, because it has a biased approach. It starts off with its presenter saying what the Government said, and then it has a member of the Opposition commenting on what the Government said. It is a very clear but subtle way of being very biased when it suits it.

If members of the Opposition want to have a go at someone else, they should have a go at the Australian for its bias and bitterness. When the interest rates dropped it carried a headline `Labor turmoil on rates, Medicare'. Any other newspaper, such as the Morning Bulletin, says `Business greets interest rate cut' or words to that effect. If he wants to have a go at those sorts of newspapers, I do not mind; but let him come back to fairness.

The Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) wants open slather mining and enrichment of uranium. He wants to throw out the environmental impact assessments. The honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) is going to destroy equality in education. He wants teachers to be locally employed, so the poor areas will suffer. If people are rich, that is great; they will get by. What else does he want to do?

I heard the honourable member for Mallee talk about universities before. He wants to reintroduce tertiary fees for everybody. I do not like the idea of students having to pay $2,000, but under the scheme of the honourable member for Goldstein they will be paying $10,000 up front. People will have to buy their way into university--again a preference for the rich.

The shadow Minister for health, the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods), wants to dump hospital funding on the States. Senator Richard Alston, the shadow Minister for social security, child-care and retirement incomes, is going to slash sickness benefits and invalid pensions and, he says, save several hundred million dollars with a tough new medical test. I believe that is an attack on the integrity of doctors who at this moment assess whether a person should be on an invalid pension or sickness benefits. He is saying that we should have these tougher tests and save several hundred million dollars. People will not get unemployment benefits after they have been unemployed for nine months.

The Opposition wants to wipe out the superannuation arrangements. An amount of $3.6 billion in concessional tax has been provided by this Government to superannuants, and the Opposition wants to wipe out the superannuation scheme. The honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) is talking about taking out insurance to cover nursing home care. Again, this is the sort of thing I am talking about: welfare taxes. It is in the Opposition's blueprint. It is insurance to cover nursing home care. At the moment this Government subsidises nursing home care. It subsidises hostel care.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Poorly.

—-Poorly! It involves hundreds of dollars a week. Let me go further. Under a Hewson government the Liberal-Nationals--let the women of Australia hear this--would make women wait until 65 years of age to be eligible for the pension. The Opposition has kept it quiet until now. We are going to make sure that everybody knows about it. Women have to be 65 before they receive the pension. That is the only time that the Opposition mentions women. There is not another word about women in this whole policy. It does not care about them; it has nothing for them.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Michael Baume wants to privatise welfare. The honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock)--he probably will not be here after the redistribution--is attacking immigration. He wants to get rid of family reunions. He does not believe that immigrants who settle here ought to have some way of bringing their family out.

The honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) wants to sell off Qantas completely. The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) wants no protection for manufacturers or rural production unless dumping can be proved. Senator Warwick Parer is the one who gets the prize for the biggest furphy. The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), has just come into the chamber. But Senator Parer has to get the prize, because in this document he talks about saving $600m by abolishing the Department of Local Government. The total allocation for that Department in one year is $3m. This smart man--the man who represents the Opposition in this field--says that he will save $600m by doing away with the Local Government Department--and its total allocation is $3m.

Clearly we have an Opposition that does not have alternatives, except those that want to tear at the very fabric of the Australian society. It is attacking not only the poor and the disadvantaged, as the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission has said, with its goods and services tax, but it is attacking middle Australia as well. It is going to take away the top levels of tax and impact on them with an across the board tax on goods and services, and a welfare tax because, as I said, they normally go hand in hand. The alternatives being proposed by the Hewson extremists will devastate the quality of life and the purchasing power of the majority of Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —-How is Hawke doing?

—-That is not the point. I believe that we are getting it right. The Opposition has no understanding of the change that has taken place. If only it had bothered to think through what has taken place in tax reform. Under the Opposition parties the threshold was $3,200; now it is $5,400. No Australian pays tax unless he or she earns over $5,400. For a pensioner it is now over $9,000 a year. The Opposition's highest tax rate was 60 per cent; ours is 47 per cent. Its lowest tax rate was 30 per cent; ours is 21 per cent, with the Medicare levy. The Opposition has the audacity to say that it will look after the people of Australia. We know what it is about. We know that it is about looking after the rich and the advantaged. Its goods and services tax says just that. It has policies which involve bringing in fees and charging every university student up front. We know that the Opposition wants to take away the rights of people to get the unemployment benefit. We are talking about a $2,000 charge from us against $10,000 from the Opposition. That is unbelievable.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members--Ha, Ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —-Opposition members can laugh, but they know that David O'Reilly deserves a medal. The Bulletin magazine and David O'Reilly deserve an award for exposing the Opposition for what it really is, and that magazine should be reprinted in the tens of thousands across Australia. (Time expired)
--Before I call the honourable member for Menzies, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's first speech and I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-In December 1944, on the foundation of the Liberal Party, Robert Gordon Menzies, after whom my electorate was named, declared:

SPEECH.PARA: What we must look for is a true revival of liberal thought that will work for social justice and security, for national power and progress and for full development of the individual citizen, though not through the dull and deadening process of socialism.

Australia's present social and economic woes owe much to the dead hand of socialism, which stifles individualism and withers enterprise in this country at its roots. Rampant unionism hinders the vaunted but little recognised and little realised micro-economic reform in this nation and continues to keep our economy uncompetitive with its wasteful work practices. A plethora of taxes, including a tax on employment itself, punishes anyone in this country who is foolhardy enough to invest the capital and to work around the clock. People such as that are the people who employ over half the Australian work force.

This Government has nailed compassion to its masthead. We know that the Labor Government cares about the underprivileged. Perhaps that is why it spends all its time creating more of them. This Government likes to talk about the help it gives to low income families, but under this Labor Administration the great mass of Australian people who are responsible for creating the wealth of this nation have suffered a decrease in their living standards. Real after-tax earnings for average workers have fallen by 6.7 per cent between 1985 and 1990. Research by the Parliamentary Library puts total income decline for the four years 1985 to 1989 at around 10 per cent.

The honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) feigns concern for the Australian people. Where was that concern when the Budget was being framed? This caring and compassionate Labor Government boasts of the increase in employment it presided over until the recession that we `had to have'. But this increase was largely due to the number of women in the work force, and the second wage only served to mask a real decrease in living standards. Women went back to work because they had to, because their husbands could no longer provide for them and support a family on a single wage because of the rise and hike in interest rates up to 18, 19 and 20 per cent that we saw. A major study commissioned by Family Circle magazine and published in May of this year found that 86 per cent of working mothers work because of financial pressures on the family, not because they want to.

And what of that other jewel in the crown of the Labor Government, the beautiful set of figures represented by previous Budget surpluses? This, too, proved to be only paste. Much of this was money that was clawed back from ordinary Australians. Total taxation on individuals has more than doubled, from $23 billion in 1982-83 to almost $51 billion in 1989-90--largely due to inflation. This has pushed ordinary workers into even higher tax brackets. Average Australians now face a marginal tax rate of nearly 40c in the dollar, compared with 30c when Messrs Hawke and Keating came to power. Worse, changes to taxes and benefits have left average middle income families worse off.

For instance, a single income family with two children earning $22,000, even after an increase in income in line with the CPI and despite Federal tax cuts and the family package, was $226 a year worse off. A double income family with two children earning $42,500 was $409 worse off. But a double income family with no children earning $75,000 received an extra $891 a year, almost as much as the amount provided to a single mother with two children on welfare benefits, who got an extra $899 a year.

Under this Government top income earners have seen a drop in the top tax rate from 60c in the dollar to 49c, in July 1987. On 1 January 1990 the marginal tax rate on incomes over $50,000 fell from 49 per cent to 47 per cent. But the very rich, in fact, do not even pay those rates, as they receive a large proportion of the tax reductions, rebates and credits that are paid out in Australia, mostly because of the dividend imputation scheme introduced by the present Federal Government. This reduces the average millionaire's tax rate on net income to just over 26 per cent, the same rate as that paid by someone earning between $30,000 and $50,000. So people with net incomes of $500,000 or more are paying less tax than ordinary Australians earning $30,000 to $50,000. So much for the level playing field.

But this Government is apparently a caring and compassionate government--it must be because it tells us it is so often. The Prime Minister is a compassionate man. We have seen him shed a manly tear or two. Who are we to say that those are the tears usually ascribed to the reptilian inhabitants of Kakadu? Let us remember how the great Russian writer Tolstoy described the difference between sentimentality and sentiment. Tolstoy said that sentimentality was what the aristocratic lady demonstrated when she cried over a sad story in her box at the opera while her coachman shivered in the snow outside. If anyone wants to shed tears, prepare to shed them now--not just for one family but for the hundreds of thousands of Australian families who are shivering in this economic depression brought on by this Government.

This caring and compassionate Labor Government has thoughtfully furnished us with the bloody entrails with which we may read the portents of the future, like the ancient seers. The signs of human anguish are all around us in the hundreds, and in some cases thousands, of people queuing for jobs advertised, in the `For sale' signs out in the suburban heartland as once-secure middle income families now give up on their dream of home ownership, in the empty business premises on the High Streets and in the shopping centres of our towns and cities, and in the pages and pages of advertisements for sales of capital equipment. The machinery of Australia is rusting or being sold off, often to overseas buyers.

The real human tragedy is unquantifiable but nonetheless real for being so. For the past 10 years my wife, Margaret, and I have worked in marriage education and we have seen at first-hand how financial stress causes marriages to fall apart under extreme pressure. Some people have even committed suicide in this depression that we `had to have', feeling that the struggle was so unequal that they could not go on. There never was a level playing field, and it has become even more deeply corrugated under this Labor Government.

Let us pause for a moment and think about the more than 160,000 Australian families whose breadwinner is out of work. In July, 801,700 people were actively looking for work but still unemployed. Most are in the prime of their working life and aged between 25 and 54. Almost half are married. In one in four families in Australia there is someone who has no job. In other words, in 188,000 Australian families no-one has a job. Between them, those families have more than 175,000 children under the age of 14 living in homes where no-one has a job. The increase in the number of unemployed has been by far the greatest--50 per cent--in the group of people who are typically breadwinners.

Unemployment amongst teenagers has increased by 23 per cent, and amongst people over 55 by 35 per cent. Virtually the entire increase in unemployment this year has been in the medium to long term unemployment categories. What of the many thousands every month or so who give up looking for work and cease to be registered as unemployed? In July alone, 44,000 Australians gave up looking for work. Who can blame them when the only jobs that they see at the local CES office seem to be along the lines of `Clerk, able to speak German, Cantonese and Indonesian', as I saw recently?

Let us also pause to reflect on the bankruptcies brought about by the economic climate engineered by this Government that has been wont to tell us that it has been pulling all the right levers. The truth is that we are now in free fall with only the shreds of a parachute. This Government likes to hark back to the Fraser Government. During its term of office there were 30,945 bankruptcies, or an average of 3,868 per year. During the unholy alliance of Mr Hawke and Mr Keating, and now Mr Kerin, there have been 60,089 bankruptcies, or 7,511 per year. That means that bankruptcies have doubled and in the Labor States of Victoria and Western Australia the increase is 70 per cent or more. This is the fruit of high taxes, high interest rates and a program of disincentives for business and personal endeavour. Yet there will be no wealth to distribute if the wealth creators are tied and bound. That is the predicament that Australia is in today.

Faced with these problems, what response do we see from the Government? We see not solutions but slogans, which have replaced ideas. For example, `No child is to live in poverty'; we are to be the `clever country'; we were going to have a `soft landing'; now it is the recession we `had to have'. Also, `There can't be gain without pain'. There is nothing the matter with rhetoric; it is just that in this case it is not supported by any action. The latest slogan is `better cities'. This is the neutron bomb approach to social planning-- destroy the people but leave the cities standing. In this country, government has been reduced to a matter of style.

Mr Speaker, may I thank you, the Clerk and the other officers of the House for the warm welcome that I was given on my arrival here. I knew that my time would be interesting when the Clerk informed me that I had been seated next to the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). However, it has been depressing not to find the clash of great ideas in this Parliament at such a time of national crisis. Instead, we see the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) who, like the murderous Macbeth, displays `vaulting ambition which o'erleaps itself and falls on th'other'.

Meanwhile, the real issues that the Australian people want addressed are ignored or compromised in the internal squabbles of this moribund Government. Yet, now more than ever there is a time, there is a need for good parliamentarians--not party pooches as we see every day in Question Time, who mouth dorothy dixers at the appointed time from their so-called leaders. Edmund Burke once described a good parliamentarian as one who is responsive to his electorate and able to employ his judgment and his skills for the benefit of his constituents. I will try to follow the example of the former honourable member for Menzies, Neil Brown, who used his judgment and skills to serve not just the constituents of Menzies but the people of Australia.

I drive a Ford Falcon, which will indicate the breadth and diversity of the Liberal Party, which can encompass both Ferraris and Ford Falcons. A barrister by trade, I come from the great middle sector of Australia. My father ran a small trucking business and a small mixed farm in Gippsland. My mother, who, I am proud to say, is here today, carried on this work for 15 years after my father's death, often rising at 3 a.m. or 4 a.m to transport stock to market. I learnt early of the need to work hard to succeed and that I could rely on no-one but myself.

It would be tempting to believe that we are all equal and we all should receive the same portion of the cake, but that is a sure recipe for diminishing the cake. For all their socialist talk, Labor's Batman and Robin managed to rob the middle income earners to give to the rich. In 1983 the top one per cent of taxpayers earned as much as the bottom 11 per cent. By 1989 the top one per cent earned as much as the bottom 21 per cent. This is what the distribution of wealth is all about. This is the social justice that we hear so much of.

Much of my experience at the Bar was in general civil litigation. No-one could practise in the civil courts in recent years without appreciating the economic plight of so many in this country. In 1987 I represented grain handlers before the Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport. We demonstrated then the gross inefficiency of the transport infrastructure, dominated as it was by union and bureaucratic interests. Yet, five years later, real micro-economic reforms have not been implemented.

The second area in which I practised involved appeals by veterans against decisions of the Repatriation Commission. These people, now old and often disabled, gave the best years of their lives, often in disease- infested jungles. They prompted in me an appreciation of the sacrifices necessary to ensure the security of our great country from foreign aggression and to reflect upon the importance of our location on the rim of Asia. In 1989-90, approximately 36 per cent of all imports to this country were from Asia and some 56 per cent of exports were to Asia. Our opposition to the trading blocs in Europe and North America and other restrictions on free trade must continue, but we need to better utilise the opportunities presented to us in our own region.

My major interest in recent years has been in health law and bioethics, which include areas of national concern. Of bioethics I will only say now that I regret that the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) has apparently ignored wider community concerns by establishing exclusively within the scientific community a new Australian Health Ethics Committee with some of the same personnel from the widely discredited National Bioethics Consultative Committee. Appropriate regulation in sensitive and complex areas such as reproductive technology requires a system which is accountable and inspires public confidence. The current proposal will achieve neither.

The second matter is the appropriate funding of health and the question of how we allot priorities within those services. There is almost a $10 billion shortfall between the funding raised by the Medicare levy and the amount that is spent on Medicare. The current national health strategy is clouded by the usual pie in the sky socialist ideology which fails to ask the vital questions. What are the limits of our health care resources? What are the priorities of the current allocation and what are the principles and processes by which those priorities are to be determined?

Justice has to be more than glib sloganeering about universal coverage and equity. For far too long, we on this side of the House have allowed spurious claims of compassion from the Government to pass unchallenged. Almost a million Australians are unable to support themselves with the work that is their right, and the compassionate and caring Labor Government tells us that this is inevitable and will go on for years to come. This is the compassion that a charisma driven government, hell-bent on clinging to power, offers. But people must come before ideology.

The Liberal Party is not hamstrung by a big brother centralist ideology but orients itself around the needs of the individual and the family. It is guided by a pragmatic ideal which Robert Menzies spelt out in April 1939, when he said:

Internally my theme is justice. I declare my political creed here and now. It is that the essential end of government is not power or glory, but the good life for ordinary men and women. The ordinary man, as I know him, asks for a happy life, not a complaining one; for a full life and not an idle one. We must have industrial justice and social justice, industrial security and social security.

We can create an atmosphere in which social justice can flourish by encouraging the wealth creators, the great Australian middle class, so that we can best support the weakest and most vulnerable in our society. When Count Dracula arises to take over the leadership of this caring and compassionate Labor Party, let us not be taken in by more crocodile talk of equity and social justice achieved. Let us judge the caring and compassionate Labor Administration by all its pomps and deeds. By them this Government must be known. The real--not fictional--social justice that a coalition government offers will be the stake to impale this Transylvanian team. In the meantime, let us mourn their victims, the Australian people--and this, the 1991 Budget, will be their epitaph.
Honourable members--Hear, hear!
Debate (on motion by Mr Tickner) adjourned.

(a) call upon the UN Human Rights Commission to continue and expand its scrutiny and action over the human rights situation in Burma;
(b) affirm its support for the resettlement of genuine Burmese asylum seekers who are without other safe and reasonable alternatives; and
(c) call upon the Government of Thailand to accord Burmese refugees temporary safe haven and access to procedures for third country resettlement.
Time allotted--any remaining private Members' business time.

Mover--10 minutes.
Other Members--5 minutes each.

R G HALVERSON

5 September 1991

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 August, on motion by Mr Free:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: --Firstly, I congratulate the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) on his maiden speech. Anyone who follows his speech will be a pale resemblance of a speaker. The Opposition supports the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill. However, it should not surprise the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Free) if we take this opportunity to debate matters of far-reaching consequence.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank the Minister for his cooperation in being available when this matter is being discussed and for offering representations from the Department. I hope that will be an example to other Ministers. This Bill deals with an exemption for people with disabilities. For a long time justice has been denied to many people with disabilities. Justice denied is something that all parties are keen to redress.

This Bill is the result of a report tabled by the Industry Commission on 18 July 1990, Aids and Appliances for People with Disabilities. Some of the recommendations contained within the 230 pages of this report have been implemented. The Bill implements some recommendations in various forms, but there are still quite a deal to go and some are still awaiting implementation.
In his second reading speech, the Minister said:
These measures demonstrate the Government's concern that the taxation treatment of goods for use by people with disabilities be both equitable and responsible.

We happen to agree with that, and in connection with disabilities--I will say it once again--I believe these measures should be bipartisan and non-political because they relate to people who deserve every assistance so they can share in the benefits that our society offers. These measures, as I said, demonstrate the Government's concern arising from the report and certainly we share that concern.

I want to deal here with delayed justice as it specifically impacts upon disabilities. For nearly two years the Opposition has attempted to amend the Disabilities Services Act, not only to deal with these specific concerns but also to deal with other major concerns that we have as to factors which prevent a free flow of encouragement to people with disabilities thereby curtailing their full participation in this life. We have laid this private member's Bill on the table because people with disabilities, carers and parents must be able to plan more positively for their future and not suffer any further distress than is absolutely necessary. The sales tax amendments will help in this regard to a large extent.

In the amendments that we have proposed, we took the novel approach of suggesting that the principles and guidelines under the Act, which are at the moment in the hands of the Department for implementation, should come before this Parliament. We have made this suggestion so that all parliamentarians can reassert and reaffirm their commitment to disabled people through the principles and guidelines that will come before us. We suggest, as a novel approach, that there should be an appeals procedure--novel in the case of the Disabilities Services Act, because it is apparent in every other Act that there is an appeals procedure.

We have suggested the extension of the transition date from 1992 because we fear that Treasury would not be prepared to provide sufficient funds to allow that transition date to come and go, without some very harsh adjustments, particularly in the sheltered workshop area. We have suggested that there should be secure funding and, particularly, we have suggested that workshops should be an approved service.

In the disabilities area, where this sales tax relief was only one of the positives in the Budget, there has been concern expressed by many of the disabilities organisations. As I say, sales tax relief was one positive. I have noticed the dismay that resulted from the indexation factor for the block grants to voluntary services such as the Royal Blind Society, the Endeavour Foundation and the Australian Quadriplegic Association, which had been reduced by the Department of Finance from the 3.5 per cent, estimated and communicated to agencies in June 1991, to 1.5 per cent. This was the flow-on effect from the Budget but, in fact, owing to an administrative decision by the bureaucracy, it will mean a loss of some $60,000 to $90,000 this year for the larger organisations.

Organisations are told a likely indexation amount in June, and this is confirmed after the Budget is brought down. The 3.5 per cent was, in fact, an overestimate and the actual estimate for 1991-92 is 2.8 per cent. However, because the Department of Finance overestimated last year by 1.3 per cent, it has taken that off the 2.8 per cent to give 1.5 per cent. This is a gross example of government again changing the goal posts without telling the players.

It is also regarded within the industry that any benefit that will result from this $3m cost to Government for the sales tax exemption could be a drawback or a clawback by government of those amounts by reducing this indexation. As a result of this, many voluntary agencies--and I stress the word `voluntary' because we must always support and encourage voluntary agencies, who are already struggling with extra demand and too few resources--have been left with another unexpected big shortfall to make up. I just wanted to address those few matters of concern within the disability areas that this Bill rectifies only in part.

The elements of the package are clearly demonstrated within the Minister's second reading speech and also in the explanatory memoranda. The Bill will give effect to the Budget announcements on changes to sales tax exemptions for people with disabilities. In particular, it will extend the current exemption on goods used to modify motor vehicles, to adapt them for driving by disabled persons, to include vehicles used to transport such persons. It also makes it easier to establish eligibility for exemption in relation to goods designed and manufactured expressly for invalid persons. It places a cap on the maximum sales tax benefit applicable to new motor vehicles for use by certain Defence Force veterans and other persons with specific disabilities. The consequence is that, on the luxury car threshold, sales tax exemption will continue to apply up to a retail value of $45,462, but sales tax will be payable at the luxury car rate of 30 per cent on any amount above that threshold.

The exemption will be made available for such items as a general purpose tailgate, loader or hoist stored in the rear or the side of the second-hand passenger van solely to allow access for a passenger in a wheelchair. Similarly, heavy duty springs and material used to reinforce the floor of the van because of the additional weight would be exempt, and clamps and brackets fitted to the vehicle to hold the wheelchair in place would also be exempt.

The issue we raise in connection with this is that, as well-meaning as the intentions of the Industry Commission and the Government would be, there comes a time when it must be realised that some of the vehicles required for the transport of people with disabilities could quite easily exceed that retail value for luxury cars, and I wish to mention one. There are quite a lot of four-wheel drives on the road today--and I am talking about four-wheel drives in particular--that may be necessary to do the conveyancing required for a person, particularly when one considers the hoist and everything else that goes with it. So I would suggest to the Minister that his Department might look at this, not only in relation to a four-wheel drive but also in relation to the need for a heavier vehicle that is going to be classed as a luxury vehicle and not be eligible for the reduction or the exemption as suggested.

We note the defect in the taxation legislation as it stands at the moment in respect of wholesale sales tax. We also recognise its complications in arriving at an answer just in this respect, because if we consider the time consumed on the report, the legislation itself, the altering of the exemptions and the manner in which the exemption will be available, we realise that it is a rather complicated piece of legislative machinery. To emphasise that, we will be agreeing to the Minister's amendment, but it is yet another complication of the system that makes it necessary for the Government to re-think the legislation and to introduce another amendment to prevent some abuse of the system later on.

One has to ask the question: should any tax be as complicated as that in the Sales Tax Act? There are difficulties in connection with the implementation of a tax that has three rates and exemptions. One might say it is unwieldy, unmanageable and unintelligible, but mainly, critically, I think it is unfair in the manner in which it impacts on people. The sales tax does have that difficulty and I think we ought to bear that in mind.

I remember that during my years in public accounting, where we dealt particularly with income tax matters, very few people were regarded as specialists in the sales tax areas. In fact, by the time we took each State and central office, it was estimated that there were about 10 people who really understood the Sales Tax Act, and they were the people who were implementing it. It was not an Act that could be generally understood. As a result of the Sales Tax Act, we were certain that there would always be volumes of paper necessary, whether by legislation, regulation, in the schedules or the exemptions, the certification, the substantiation or in the inspections. Finally, if all those things were not in place, there would be the penalties at the end of it.

If we look at the Budget Estimates and the reality of the Budget over the last decade, from 1981-82 to 1991-92, it is interesting to see the size of the increase in the wholesale sales tax. In 1981-82 the sales tax figure was $2,854m. In the Estimates for 1991-92 it was $9,237m. By the end of the decade it had increased to almost four times the amount it was at the beginning of the decade. The fact that these types of adjustments can be made at a time when the consumer is paying the tax and does not really appreciate that it is there highlights the hidden nature of this tax. Over the decade from 1981-82 to 1991-92 the tax has had an influence on inflation and has impacted on the economy in many other undesirable ways.

In the last few years, it has been interesting to see the diminution in the sales tax brought about by the `recession we had to have'. In 1989-90, it was $10 billion. This was about the estimate for 1990-91, but it reduced to $9.365 billion, and this year it is less still. That stands in testimony to the `recession we had to have'.

There is no doubt about it: the wholesale sales tax is a hidden tax. I want to give just one example of the anomalies that are already in the system, and that concerns the component of sales tax on freight. For 15 years I have had complaints about wholesale sales tax from people such as cordial and soft drink manufacturers out of the major capital centres, because a big component of their manufacturing cost was freight, and that freight was taxed on the final product at the door of the manufacturer. They had to manufacture soft drinks with an impost against which there was no relief.

There is another aspect. If a country town or a provincial centre had the benefit of having a wholesaler in the area, it meant that that was the last point of contact, and the sales tax would be applied on the freight component from the manufacturer to the wholesaler. So there is a hidden tax--not only a hidden tax, but a hidden cost to business.

In the debate on Building a Competitive Australia , the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), suggested that $200m on business inputs from the goods and services tax would be eliminated or exempted. Where is that legislation? Over the last two days in Question Time, we have seen a great rush of knowledge on the subject by the current Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), but he does miss the point. He talks in terms of $200m coming off business inputs, whereas it is recognised around Australia that of that $9 billion to $10 billion collection each year $4 billion is an input to the costs of business and $1 billion is an impost on our exports.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy particularly should realise the disadvantage that our exporters suffer through that extra $1 billion impost; it places us in an unfavourable position with other exporters who do not suffer the impost. In particular, the exports of the European Community are free of any goods and services tax, or VAT as it is at the moment.

Worse than that, this impacts on our trade deficit. For 1991-92 we will still trade with a deficit of $14 billion, which will only increase our net foreign debt by that amount over the next 12 months. Our gross foreign debt currently stands at $170 billion. A lot of that is related to the fact that we export our dollars as a cost, and that tells against us in balance of trade and foreign debt figures.

There is no doubt about it: there is a current impost on business and employers; and there is also a current impost on lower income families and household goods in the form of the wholesale sales tax. Today the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) made the point that the wholesale sales tax is not a consumer tax. He is drawing a fine line by saying that it is a wholesale tax imposed at that point but is not a retail tax. The Treasurer should brush up on his economics, because there is no way in the wide world that he can claim it is not a consumer tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —-He was talking about the mark- up.

—-We were talking about a consumption tax. It is a consumption tax. As far as the imposition of a 20 per cent sales tax is concerned, who is the consumer of a commercial motor vehicle, a truck or a panel van; who is the consumer where an ambulance is concerned; who is the consumer of a four-wheel drive, prime mover or semi- trailer? I notice there is a 20 per cent sales tax on hearses. I am not sure who the consumer would be there, but I think it would be the next of kin. It is all related to the fact that down the line somebody is consuming the service or the goods that are being purchased under this sales tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at a business buying business equipment--office equipment, advertising material, photocopiers. All those types of things have a 20 per cent sales tax built into their prices; obviously that is then passed on as a cost of the business to the person who buys the final product or the final service. Business certainly is part of it. Let us look at stationery. Every time somebody picks up a writing pad, an envelope, a school exercise book or any paper like that, there is a tax in itself on the business, a tax on education, a tax on anybody who wants to use that writing equipment.

Let us see who is the consumer in another range of 10 per cent sales taxes. I think it has been evidenced already. Within the last two months, through one of our supermarket stores, the impost on the final consumption price of a normal week's delivery of groceries has been calculated. I think the load was priced at $145, and the wholesale sales tax content amounted to about $13, which would be a 10 per cent on-flow on these goods as far as a GST would be concerned.

One has to wonder whether these goods are necessities of life or are required for the livelihood of the family, particularly as they have the 10 per cent sales tax built in. I just want to mention some of them. There were biscuits--not cooked in the oven as they used to be years ago, as granny used to do; biscuits are now bought from the supermarket. There were ice-creams and ice blocks--not really a necessity of life, but getting fairly close to it for some people. There was fruit juice and fruit juice products. We are told we should be buying pure fruit juice and the result of that is that we get taxed 10 per cent.

We would want to encourage the drinking of non-alcoholic wines and beverages. Guess what that takes? A 10 per cent tax. What about flavoured milk--flavoured instant milk powder? The home wares that are required in a house--the furniture, the floor coverings, the blinds, the screen doors--all attract a rate of sales tax of 10 per cent. Of course, if one looks carefully, there is a consumption factor in that.

I have tried to indicate that there is an impost on business--it has been estimated to be $4 billion--and there is also a current impost on lower income families and household goods. At this stage, I move an in- principle amendment to the motion for the second reading of this Bill in the following terms:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for its ramshackle and inefficient wholesale sales tax system, and its failure to replace it with a fairer, broad-based goods and services tax'.

TALK.START.PARA: --Is the amendment seconded?
—-I second the amendment enthusiastically.

—-It is interesting to see who have been the supporters of a goods and services tax over a period of years. I could mention none more notable than the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland I understand that in his own way, before the ACTU entered the field, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was a grand advocate for an expanded consumption tax. He is also the man who has given us some other grand promises in his term as Prime Minister. The Prime Minister was the one who said there would be no capital gains tax; the man who said there would be no child living in poverty after 1990; and the man who said at the last election that there would be no increase in the Medicare levy. It will be interesting to see whether he realises the trifecta.

SPEECH.PARA: The assumptions made by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy in the last two days show an abysmal lack of knowledge of how business in this country runs, particularly primary industries. Yesterday the Primary Industries Minister mentioned that the farmers were worried about the enormous amount of paperwork that would be required. The Minister obviously does not realise that over the past four to five years there has been a substantial change in the income tax requirements. Every business and every taxpayer who claims a deduction now requires substantiation on paper. So the paperwork is already being done. A goods and services tax does not add to that burden; it uses the substantiation that is required at the moment. The only additional paperwork that would be required is a separate identification of the goods and services tax paid on inputs.

As I mentioned before, there is a tremendous sales tax component in the freight and carrying industry. There will be relief given for off-farm fuel. In conjunction with the GST change, that will reduce substantially the cost of transport around Australia. For those people who say there is a tremendous inflationary impact built into a GST, we could say also that the current wholesale sales tax already assumes the equivalent of a 6.5 per cent GST. That is already built in through the hidden charges. Again, examples have been given in connection with New Zealand. The Government has been levelling complaints against the mismanagement of the New Zealand economy, but that was at the hands of Mr Lange's Labor Government. It was Mr Lange who created the recession and Mr Lange who created the unemployment and the high interest rates. This, of course, has been matched by those people currently governing Australia.

I want to read into the record comments that have been made by some great authorities on this subject. These first comments were made between 4 June 1985 and 14 August 1985. They were attributed to the former Treasurer of this Parliament, the honourable member for Blaxland, and show what a great advocate we have for this goods and services tax. The comments start:

That means we are back to taxing income and taxing income alone. It is now time to take a more fundamental approach. It is time to establish a broader tax base with greater integrity, allowing the fairer sharing of the tax burden with lower rates of tax. To do something substantial about the marginal rates and about the average rates, to really cut the dependence on income tax. And to give us the prospect of indexing the system in perpetuity, you really need a consumption tax. It taxes income which is evaded and avoided, income which may never have been brought to tax under the income tax system.

I agree with that. There is $20 billion worth of untaxed income around Australia, and the goods and services tax would be able to cover that. If we want to know the success of that type of operation, we only have to go to Italy, which was able to increase its gross domestic product sufficiently to top Britain as the fourth most prosperous nation in the European Community. He continues:
It taxes that and produces a fiscal dividend. To the extent that the consumption tax taxes people on low incomes, we give it back in other compensation arrangements.
So he mentions compensation. He goes on:
Let me say that if I believed that the proposed switch to a consumption tax would have dire consequences, I would not have a bar of it.
But here he was, proposing it. He mentions the three main advantages of the tax:
First, it will allow a more rational indirect tax system than the current anomaly-ridden wholesale tax, which has multiple rates, numerous exemptions and fails to tax the service sector.
Precisely what I was saying a little while ago. He continues:

Second, it will enable us to generate tax revenues to provide for a major reduction in the marginal rates of income tax. No other tax has the same potential for this purpose. Third, it generates tax from those who will continue to evade or avoid income tax and that provides a useful net dividend for distribution to the rest of the community.
A few moments ago the honourable member for Menzies mentioned that, particularly in regard to taxing tax avoiders, and of course this is confirmed by the ex-Treasurer himself. His comments go on:

And earnings from this system, from assessing that black economy, will provide net income for the gentleman driving the tram. It will also put some extra deeners in the pocket of the bloke willing to get off his backside and earn a few extra bucks. People today get their tax taken each week out of their paypacket before it goes into their pocket. In other words, they pay their marginal rate and then they trot off to the shop to buy their necessities. You'd still go and buy your necessities, but you would buy it out of your relieved taxable income. In other words, it's just another way of collecting the tax, but we are not going to be collecting as much.
Again he considers that there can be a reduction in the amount of tax collected. He goes on:
The great value of a tax of this kind in terms of its efficiency will be its simplicity. There would be no exemption of the so-called necessities of life.
That is interesting. In 1985 the Treasurer of this country was saying that there would be no exemptions for the so-called necessities of life. He said:
I would argue that if this tax were to be contemplated with exemptions in significant areas, that would make it complex and administratively costly and would substantially delay its implementation.

That is interesting. I presume that the gentlemen in the advisers box know all about wholesale tax--however, if they do, they are of the very few people who do. I have mentioned only a few of those things, but I want to attribute them to the ex-Treasurer of this country.
Sitting suspended from 6.28 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —- The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1991 relates to a range of wholesale sales tax measures which assist persons with disabilities. But the Opposition, always ready to take an opportunity, has moved a second reading amendment which states:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for its ramshackle and inefficient wholesale sales tax system, and its failure to replace it with a fairer, broad-based goods and services tax".

Who is the Opposition trying to help? Through this legislation we are trying to help the disabled. These are the people who are very often on low incomes and spend much of their income on bread, milk, vegetables and clothing--all the things that the Opposition is intending to tax through its goods and services tax, which it calls fairer. People buy not just biscuits, ice cream and juice poppers--which the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) was talking about before and which have a sales tax on them--but a wide range of essential items that they all need. Of course, it means that nine times the number of businesses will be collecting the tax than collect it now.

A number of retailers have told me of the effect that a broad-based goods and services tax would have on people in country areas and people who are not in the best position economically, such as disabled people. One retailer told me that as the owner of a convenience store he knew that his customers would be paying $1.50 more on a $30 parcel of groceries than they would pay in a supermarket in a city. One retailer complained to me about his experiences in New Zealand. He told me that there would be far more paperwork for retailers and that they would have to complete returns. This is done monthly in some countries. Other retailers have told me that there would be far more opportunity for abuse by businesses, as operators may just put money in their pockets.

In New Zealand after the first year of operation of a consumption tax there was 19 per cent inflation. In the Taxpayer of 13 July, the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) said that the effects of the consumer price index would be quantified and would be quarantined. Quantified and quarantined: how about that! What does he mean--that it will be ignored? It can mean only that. What is the good of that? In the Taxpayer the Leader Opposition said publicly that the elderly who are not pensioners would be difficult to compensate. They sure will be. The tax will include people on superannuation, and also disabled people--the people we are trying to help through this legislation. It will include people on workers' compensation, perhaps, or on insurance. They are going to be hurt and they will be just as difficult to compensate, as the Leader of the Opposition says they will be, as those who are retired and are not pensioners. They are all going to be hurt by a goods and services tax.

Yet here they are, calling it fairer and more efficient. It will certainly be far more ramshackle and inefficient than the present taxation and sales tax systems. It will force people into becoming tax collectors. Under the threat of penalty businesses will become tax collectors for the proposed goods and services tax.

It is quite clear that disabled people will be hurt very much and not helped by the sorts of proposals mentioned in the amendment--just as they will be the worst hit by the other proposals of the Opposition, such as enterprise bargaining. In New Zealand now the minimum rate of pay for these people is $A4 an hour. In the United States a minimum of $A3 an hour can be offered. Who will be hurt? It is those very people we are helping now by assisting them to get full time work even though they are disabled. They will be the ones hit. The boss will say, `Look, Bill, I am sorry but I can only afford $4 an hour if I am to keep you. You know with your position you can't do as much as others, perhaps, and that is what I will have to pay you'. They are the people who will be hit. So there is no help whatsoever in the Opposition's proposal.

The reason for the legislation we are now considering is to assist disabled people. It will extend the sales tax exemption to goods used to modify a vehicle, new or used, for the transportation of a physically disabled pensioner or other passenger who is not a pensioner. Previously the exemption applied only to disabled drivers. Now it will apply to people who are buying a car principally for the use of transporting a disabled person. So it is going to be much easier for people, whatever their income--people who are retired, not retired, pensioners, non-pensioners--to obtain the tax exemption which is available.

The legislation will also place a cap equivalent to the sales tax payable on a motor vehicle at the luxury motor vehicle threshold on the exemption for new motor vehicles available to veterans and for other people with certain physical disabilities. This will improve the equity of the exemption because the tax benefit for eligible purchase of luxury motor vehicles will be a maximum in 1991-92 of $6,100. In other words, a maximum tax exemption of $6,100 will be available and it will be indexed.

These Budget measures are based largely on the recommendations of the Industry Commission report on aids and appliances for people with disabilities, but there has been some variation in detail and scope. For instance, the Industry Commission recommended exemption of computers for people with disabilities. We have found this difficult because the recommendation did not give us a well-targeted basis for a policy decision. In particular, it was felt by the Government that an assessment of the needs for computer equipment by people with disabilities was required before responsible and targeted policy decisions could be made. Consequently, the Government referred the issue to the disability task force for analysis by its working party on the costs of disability. This working party is due to report in time for consideration of the 1992-93 Budget. I hope we will then see some action to provide tax exemption for computers used as a communication aid for people with disabilities.

There is already an exemption under item 123 of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act for electronic communications equipment or components thereof which are expressly designed for persons with disabilities. For example, electronic devices which use speech synthesisers to convert text to speech and would assist a speech-impaired person to communicate with other people are exempt.

I am pleased to support the legislation and certainly oppose the amendment proposed by the Opposition, which condemns the Government for not introducing a broad-based goods and services tax. The very people it would hurt would be the disabled.(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: --I am glad to see my colleagues drawn to the House to listen to my contribution. Of course, the reason for the calling of the quorum was that the Opposition could not provide a speaker to this legislation. I think that indicates the lack of concern that Opposition members have shown for serious debate in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: What I would say about this legislation is that I have in front of me a media release from the Disabled Peoples International (Australia), the umbrella body for people with disabilities in this country. It is glowing in its praise of this legislation and the fact that the Government has taken this initiative.

The legislation follows on from the Industry Commission recommendations, and indeed in some respects is more generous than those recommendations. It allows for sales tax exemption for goods that are used to modify motor vehicles for the use of the disabled-- indeed for the transport of disabled people. This legislation allows the friends, relatives and families of disabled people to obtain sales tax exemption for the modification of their vehicles or for changing or improving their vehicles in some way to allow for the carriage of their disabled friends, relatives or family members.

This legislation is thoughtful and constructive and will improve the quality of life of those people who care for the disabled in our community. It has been well thought out and considered, and I think it will improve the circumstances of the disabled in this country.

The Industry Commission report made recommendations that certain changes should be made in the area of sales tax on computer products, but the Government considers that it is not appropriate at this time to move on those initiatives. The belief is that we need to more accurately target the requirements of the disabled in this area. Indeed, the disabilities task force will be pursuing this matter, as was indicated by the honourable member for Eden Monaro (Mr Snow), who spoke before me.
The interesting thing about this debate as it broadly focuses on sales tax exemptions is that the Opposition moved an amendment, which reads:

whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for its ramshackle and inefficient wholesale sales tax system, and its failure to replace it with a fairer, broad-based goods and services tax.

Opposition members have no shame. They are happy to come into this place and to talk about the goods and services tax that they are proposing, the proposal which was perhaps outlined in the Sydney Morning Herald today. It is not for us to know whether in fact it is the case, but certainly the outline that we would obtain from reading the Sydney Morning Herald suggested that they were proposing a goods and services tax on everything that moved of 22.5 per cent, and that will be underpinned by a flat rate of taxation at 30 per cent.

One is staggered by the preposterous proposals of Opposition members. They come into this place after the suggestion has been put forward--and it is not refuted by them that that is the basic structure of their tax--that this wholesale sales tax for which we are providing exemption in this legislation is too complicated. What they are proposing is that every retailer in the country will become a tax collector. They are proposing perhaps a VAT. VAT has some sense to it, but imagine how complicated it is, because every line of the transaction will require the individuals to determine the value added amount that will represent the VAT tax component.

One would find that that type of tax structure is an immensely complicated system in which all of those things that are presently untaxed, such as services and many of the necessities of life, will be taxed. Opposition members also say, `But presently you are taxing these items at 20 per cent'. One does not have to be top of the class in mathematics to understand what that means. If there is a wholesale sales tax on an item that has a wholesale price of $10, and the wholesale sales tax is 20 per cent, that is a tax of $2. However, on the retail price of $20, which one would assume reflects generally a 100 per cent mark-up, a 15 per cent wholesale sales tax would amount to $3.

The suggestion that in some way the structure of tax that we have at the moment, which is much more broadly based and better targeted than when we came into government, is in fact more of an impost on consumers is absurd. When one considers all of those items which are presently exempted and which the Opposition are proposing to tax, one finds the consequences of its proposals mind-boggling.

It has been said by many speakers on this side of the House that we have objections to the Opposition's broad-based consumption tax. The two principal objections that we have are that it is regressive and that it is unduly hard on those people who are on low and fixed incomes and those people who will not have the capacity to avoid the expenditures which we see as necessary and which are presently exempted from the wholesale sales tax system.

On top of that we see this tax as inflationary. It is the case that the costs of this broad- based consumption tax will flow through into wages and will have an inflationary impact, just at a time when Australia has finally put behind it the high inflation of the last two decades. The Opposition needs to understand that it is an inappropriate time for such a tax to be introduced, because we are going to keep saying it.

The point I want to make more than anything else in respect of this legislation, which I believe has the support of members on both sides of this House because we understand that by these exemptions those people who are disabled are appropriately eased of some of the burden that goes with their disability, is that the system of tax proposed by those opposite will be complicated. They come in here and suggest that the present system is unduly complicated. We recognise that there are problems with it, but for them to suggest that their system would not be complicated is misleading, dishonest and inaccurate. It is important for them to consider that, whatever the structure of their tax base will be. If it is to be a value added tax, a number of levels will have to be considered. In fact, every retailer in this country will have to be involved in the collection of that tax, and it is important for those opposite to consider that. But we are happy for them to continue to come in here and to push that barrow because it is a barrow that we find very attractive in a political sense.

Those opposite may think in some perverse way that their proposing of a policy which is unpopular will be an indication of their sincerity and forthrightness. In a perverse way they may take that position. But what I am saying to them is that it is clear to us that, whilst we recognise the limitations of the present structure, the structure that those opposite propose will be incredibly regressive, inflationary and complicated. The benefits in respect of savings and efficiency that have been suggested by many of those who support the Opposition's position are yet to be proven. They have certainly yet to be proven by international experience.

So we see ourselves in this debate as happily defending the present structure, with its imperfections, because the structure proposed by those opposite will be a political goldmine for us. I suggest to those opposite that they continue to come in here and tell us that the present structure is complicated, but they should not expect us not to tell the Australian population how complicated their proposal will be.

This legislation, which was introduced by the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Free), represents a breath of fresh air for the disabled community. It represents a fresh opportunity for them and it represents benefits to their families and friends and those who care for them, which is important. It is the sort of legislation that I am happy to support in this place because it will bring about a significant change for those people and for their lifestyles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth)--not surprisingly, given his limitations in these matters--is happy to support the position taken by his Government circa 1991. But we did not hear much from him in 1985 when his leaders were advocating it with all the strength that they could muster. So what we have seen really is a change such as that we have witnessed in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics where the hard line lefties have been called conservatives. I suppose what we have seen tonight has been the honourable member for Perth adopting a classical conservative position, even though he is as left as they come.

SPEECH.PARA: The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1991 makes a number of changes to various sales tax exemptions available to people with various disabilities. These changes were announced in the 1991- 92 Budget and largely follow the recommendations of the report of the Industry Commission on aids and appliances for people with disabilities.

The measures contained in this Bill are designed to remove a number of anomalies in the sales tax treatment of various goods and of motor vehicles designed for people with disabilities. These anomalies resulted in a number of inequities which the Opposition recognised and which were highlighted in the Industry Commission's report.

The measures are welcome in themselves in that they improve the operation of a small area of what is, generally speaking, an extremely inefficient and discriminatory wholesale sales tax system. The Bill is only one of many sales tax Bills that under this Government we seem to pass inevitably each year in a vain effort to patch up the wholesale sales tax system and make it in some way responsive to changing circumstances.

The wholesale sales tax system is plagued with anomalies which our legislative efforts in this place each year do not even begin to address. It is appropriate to note that, in recommending these changes, the Industry Commission drew attention to the grave deficiencies that attend the operation of the wholesale sales tax system in this area of exemptions for people with disabilities.

The Commission noted that for those exemptions that are conditional upon the type of buyer or on the number of items bought the Australian Taxation Office's administrative costs, and the private sector's compliance costs in observing these exemptions, are extremely high. High compliance and collection costs are, of course, amongst the major problems associated with the wholesale sales tax system generally.

The Industry Commission also made the important point that sales tax exemptions are `not the optimum way to provide assistance to people with disabilities'. Direct cash assistance would be a far more efficient way to compensate people with special needs who are reliant on these goods. However, since we are stuck with the wholesale sales tax system under the Hawke Government--and this system is widely used for social welfare purposes--it is necessary to ensure that sales tax laws operate in the most equitable way possible for people with disabilities and those in other special circumstances.

However, what this Bill really does is to highlight the need for the wholesale sales tax system to be scrapped lock, stock and barrel and replaced with a broadly based goods and services tax. The wholesale sales tax system has become a totally antiquated and inefficient means of raising revenue. Unfortunately, this has not stopped this Hawke Labor Government from milking every available cent from its sales tax system.

The Government has increased the amount of revenue raised through sales taxes from $3.5 billion in 1982-83 to $9.4 billion last financial year. I repeat that: when this Government came into office the figure was $3.5 billion and it increased to $9.4 billion last financial year. Of course, the figure would have been much higher had it not been for the recession, which has served to depress sales such that sales tax collections last year were down 7.6 per cent on the previous year.

The impact of the Government's sales tax grab on households has been particularly severe. Sales tax receipts under the Hawke Government have increased in real terms by 53 per cent per adult since 1982-83, the year it came into office. Of course, average weekly earnings have declined in real terms over the same period. Under the wholesale sales tax system, Australians are significantly worse off than they were in 1983. The wholesale sales tax is a hidden consumption tax on the purchases of all Australians. Few consumers are aware of which goods are taxed under this system or at what rate they are taxed. Accordingly, sales tax was described by Tony Thomas in the Business Review Weekly some years ago as `the sneakiest weapon in Treasurer Paul Keating's arsenal'.

Sales taxes are levied on a narrow range of goods at three separate rates of 10 per cent, 20 per cent and 30 per cent. These differing rates applied to a small range of goods severely distort production and consumption decisions, particularly in view of the fact that the commodity listings in the rates and exemptions schedules have failed to keep pace with changing consumer preferences. Items that were once deemed luxuries and so worthy of a high rate of sales tax are now considered to be necessities for which Australian households are forced to pay through the nose. Although wholesale sales taxes are levied on only a small range of goods, many of these goods are everyday household items which make up a relatively large proportion of a family's weekly budget.

Sales taxes are also levied in a highly inequitable way. For example, caviar, mineral water and oysters go untaxed, while chocolate biscuits, soft drink and ice-cream are each taxed at one of the various sales tax rates. The trend under the Hawke Government has been for the operation of the wholesale sales tax regime to become even more inequitable. Dr Neil Warren, from the University of New South Wales, has examined the changing incidence of Federal indirect taxes since 1975-76, in a paper prepared for the Economic Planning Advisory Council. His conclusions about the changes in the incidence of wholesale sales tax that have occurred since 1984-85--in other words, under this Government--are particularly damning. He concluded:
The changes to the wholesale sales tax appear to have increased the regressivity of this tax, both through changes to the effective rates of the tax and from changes in other factors.

This conclusion exposes the hypocrisy of the Government's scare campaign against the coalition's proposal for a broadly based goods and services tax. While the Government has been running around scaring little old ladies and others about the alleged inequities of a goods and services tax, it has been hitting those very same people with an increasingly inequitable sales tax regime--and significantly increasing sales tax collections year after year.

The wholesale sales tax is also a major burden on Australian businesses, labouring along with households under the effects of the recession. Sales tax falls heavily on goods that many businesses use in their production processes. It has been estimated in a study conducted by the Centre of Policy Studies at Monash University that nearly half of all sales tax is levied on intermediate business inputs--in other words, the wholesale sales tax is a significant addition to the costs faced by many businesses. Another 14 per cent is levied on sales of investment goods, adding to the cost of capital growth, while only 37 per cent is paid by final consumers.

The same Centre of Policy Studies report found that some 10 per cent of the final incidence of wholesale sales tax, equivalent to $9 billion, falls on goods for export. This translates into an average export tax of 2 per cent, at a time when improved export performance has never been more important. The Centre of Policy Studies concluded its study, entitled A Broad-based Consumption Tax for Australia, with this observation:

There is a general consensus that the wholesale sales tax system has lost any economic merit it may once have had and remains only as a politically expedient but economically inefficient revenue raiser.

The Hawke Government stands condemned for ignoring the consensus against the wholesale sales tax system and in favour of a broad-based goods and services tax. Every major business organisation one cares to name in this country supports a broad-based goods and services tax. There has not been a single major newspaper in Australia that has not, at some time in the last 12 months, editorialised in favour of a broad-based goods and services tax. The Government deliberately ignores this massive weight of opinion behind the concept of a goods and services tax in favour of what it considers to be an opportunity to launch a shameless scare campaign at the next Federal election--and in the interim--based on our proposals for comprehensive tax reform.

It is imperative that the wholesale sales tax system be scrapped as part of any attempt to reform the tax system in this country. The coalition is committed to a complete overhaul of the Australian taxation system, as part of a much larger package of economic reforms designed to return Australia to sustainable economic growth over the longer term. It was the conclusion of Professor Russell Mathews, writing as recently as 1987, that:
Judged by criteria of equity, efficiency, neutrality, simplicity and effectiveness, Australia has the worst taxation system of any advanced industrialised country.

So much for the empty words of someone eminently less qualified, the honourable member for Perth, whom we heard parroting earlier. Unfortunately, very little has changed since those words were written by Professor Russell Mathews. The coalition is determined to reverse this situation so that we can boast in Australia the best taxation system in the world at some time in the near future. For the time being, however, the Australian tax system is beset with problems.

Australia draws its taxation revenue from a very narrow base--namely, personal income taxes on wage and salary earners. In 1990-91, total income tax collections from individuals were responsible for 51 per cent of all revenue collected by the Commonwealth. Total income tax collections from individuals and companies in the same year accounted for 69 per cent of all revenue collections. Income tax accounts for even higher percentages of total tax collections when we take non-tax revenue out of these calculations.

As a percentage of GDP, income tax revenue has increased from 16 per cent in 1980- 81 to nearly 18 per cent last financial year. A narrow tax base means tax rates--in this case, income tax rates--must be set very high in order to raise the necessary revenue. No-one would dispute that our present income tax rates are much too high. The average income tax rate on all individuals has increased since 1980-81 from 21.1 per cent to 24.1 per cent in 1989-90. The top marginal tax rate of 47c in the dollar now cuts in at only 1 1/2 times average weekly earnings.
