High tax rates are distortionary in their effects on economic activity and introduce major disincentives into those areas in which they are levied. The disincentives generated by our high income tax rates are familiar to anyone who works for a living and is a PAYE taxpayer. Regrettably, with 831,000-plus people unemployed in this country and perhaps another million underemployed, there are few of those people who are paying PAYE tax these days.

There comes a time when there is simply no point to working any more and earning more income, since this will place the wage and salary earner into a higher tax bracket, or the extra earnings will be taxed at the top marginal rate of 47c in the dollar--plus the Medicare levy, which we have every reason to believe might be given a hike along in the very near future. The simple fact is that the harder you work in Australia, the more you pay in tax--which is an entirely perverse way of running a taxation system. If nothing else, it is counterproductive since less work means fewer revenue collections in any case. It is as simple as that.

The same disincentives apply to personal savings. The more one saves in this country, the larger the tax liability a person saddles himself or herself with. Once inflation has taken its toll, there is often little point in saving for the future. It is little wonder that our savings performance is so bad, both by historical and international standards, as I have described in this House on other occasions this week.

The distortionary effects of our high rates of personal income tax are even more serious, particularly in view of the fact that they are often hidden and, therefore, escape quantification and analysis. The high rate of personal income tax encourages people to save and invest in those areas that will serve to reduce their tax liability, rather than where their funds will earn the greatest return. That is one of the hindrances to satisfactory investment in this country. People will happily invest in areas that produce mega returns if that means they can escape paying outrageous amounts of income tax.

We also know that high rates of personal income tax drive people into the undeclared, black or cash economy--however one likes to describe it--which has been estimated to be worth some $20 billion annually. By definition, it cannot be quantified. If it could be, presumably such people could be tracked down and taxed. It may be $20 billion--the estimates go much higher.

There is a major incentive to evade tax under the current income tax regime, despite the significant risks and costs that can be involved in such evasion. Not only are tax evasion and the black economy often a suboptimal use of resources, but both activities also increase the incidence of taxation on the rest of the community, creating more of the same perverse incentives and distortions. High rates of personal income tax are also highly regressive.

Many high income earners who might otherwise pay significant amounts of personal income tax are able to legally reduce their tax bill through such mechanisms as tax shelters, incorporation, dividend imputation and the inflation indexing of the capital gains tax. Needless to say, few of these mechanisms are available to low income earners. This is why we often find that those who have some of the highest incomes in Australia pay some of the lowest levels of income tax.

The principal change we need to make to our tax system is to spread the tax burden much more widely so that everyone pays a fairer share of tax. The introduction of a broad-based, single rate goods and services tax, as proposed by the coalition, will provide the basis for a much broader tax base. This, in turn, will permit a much lower tax rate which will have minimal distortionary and disincentive effects.

A low rate GST has the capacity to raise a significant amount of revenue for the Commonwealth, although we are obviously not interested in this revenue for its own sake. Combined with cuts in government expenditure, the revenue raised from our GST will allow significant reductions in personal income tax and the abolition of the burdensome wholesale sales tax system, as well as a compensation package for low income earners, social security recipients, pensioners and superannuants. The effect of the introduction of a GST will essentially be the reverse of all the undesirable consequences of the current tax regime that I have referred to. There is obviously some concern as to the effect that the goods and services tax will have on households, but the public should be reassured on that. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The speech made by the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) on the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill was a very interesting dissertation about the conservatives' taxation policies. It demonstrates that the honourable member for Curtin has total contempt for the disabled community because that is the community that the legislation that we are debating in the House tonight is all about. It is very disappointing that the honourable member for Curtin has such contempt for people who suffer with disabilities in our community that he could not spend one word in his ramblings talking about what the effects of this legislation will be. I am very disappointed that that was the case.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier this afternoon we heard from the shadow Minister for community services and aged care, the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), that there was a bipartisan position on the Government's legislative program with regard to disability services. It is unfortunate that the penny did not drop for the honourable member for Curtin. He raved on about the regressive taxation plans of the coalition, if it ever got the chance to be in power, and totally ignored what this legislation is about. I will bring the debate back to what the Bill is all about and what benefits will flow from it.

The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill continues the process of implementation of measures recommended by the Industry Commission report on aids and appliances for people with disabilities. Although it is only a minor Bill in the totality of sales tax legislation and the Budget framework, the Bill will have a significant impact on the financial situation of thousands of disabled people and their families.

The Bill modifies sales tax provisions by exempting goods used to modify a motor vehicle to transport a person with a disability and by simplifying the current exemption process for goods designed and manufactured expressly for use by persons with disabilities. These amendments are in line with the international agreement, the Florence Agreement, signed by the Australian Government last year, which proposed the removal of all tax levies on goods used by people with disabilities. These amendments build upon the previous action of the Government in removing all tariffs on imported goods such as pacemakers, defibulators and wheelchairs as of 1 January this year.

This legislation is a result of the Industry Commission inquiry into aids and appliances for people with disabilities. In fact, this Bill is, as my colleague the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) pointed out earlier, more generous than the Industry Commission actually recommended in that most of the amendments go further or are new initiatives of the Government. However, the Bill does not implement the Industry Commission recommendation that suggests that sales tax exemption be extended to computer equipment required to operate electronic communications equipment.

The Government has referred this issue to the disabilities task force for analysis by its working party on the cost of disability. The Government has acted in this way because of concerns about the meaning and implications of this particular element of the Industry Commission report. The Industry Commission recommendation was very narrow in its targeting and not fully explained. This issue will be reconsidered early next year in the lead-up to the 1992-93 Budget.

These changes to sales tax provisions will improve the equity of assistance measures available to people with disabilities. They are part of the overall policy direction of the Government in the disability services area which was outlined in this House this afternoon by the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) in his ministerial statement.

This Bill does not provide an exemption for general purpose goods for use by people with disabilities. This does accord with the Industry Commission recommendation that there are too many difficulties in restricting any concession for general use goods such as computer equipment, microwave ovens and air-conditioners. Over many years various governments have considered the possibility of providing sales tax exemptions for general purpose goods. By that I mean goods that are ordinarily used by people without disabilities where they are for use by people with disabilities.

Such an amendment has always been considered to be impractical for three reasons. Firstly, sales tax concessions by themselves are not the most equitable form of relief or assistance, because people derive benefits from sales tax exemptions only if they purchase new goods. Secondly, conditional sales tax exemptions involve considerable administrative costs both for the Australian Taxation Office and the private sector. Thirdly, exemptions for general purpose goods are open to abuse.

The broader issue of the extra costs experienced by people as a result of their disability is, as I said earlier, being examined by the interdepartmental disability task force. The equity of present arrangements will be addressed and recommendations made on how assistance could be better targeted to those people with disabilities facing substantial living costs. I am particularly delighted to be able to speak to this Bill this evening, unlike members of the coalition, who have rambled on but have not addressed the Bill at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —-They wouldn't know what you're talking about.

—-That is exactly right. It reinforces my commitment, and that of the Labor Government, to the continued process of reform in the disability services area. Further, the specific subject of this Bill--technical aids and goods required by people with disabilities--is relevant to my electorate as two very important service providers in this field are based there.

SPEECH.PARA: The Independent Living Centre is an incorporated, non-profit, non-government organisation providing free information and professional advice to the people of Queensland who face some disability. It provides a central resource on aids and equipment for children and adults with disabilities, including physical, visual and hearing impairments which may be alone or in conjunction with general medical, intellectual or psychiatric disabilities.

The Independent Living Centre operates, firstly, an equipment display, which is a comprehensive display of equipment for disabled people to see and try out, with assistance and advice from experienced, qualified staff, including occupational therapists. The equipment is not sold from the premises or loaned by the centre; rather, various manufacturers set up displays there and the staff of the centre provide advice to disabled people and their families when they call in. A second service provided by the Independent Living Centre is an information service. This State-wide information service provides information and expert advice on aids and equipment by telephone or mail to disabled people, their families and health professionals.

The Independent Living Centre was commenced in 1981. It is a federally funded program operating out of a building on the grounds of the Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital. I had the pleasure of touring through the facilities just a few weeks ago, at which time I had the opportunity to talk at length with the Director, Ms Louise Van Willigen, and to learn more of the services provided by the Independent Living Centre.

TALK.START.PARA: —-A very important service.

—-It is a very important service, as the honourable member for Denison points out. It is providing a very important range of services to the disabled people in Queensland and is part of the very comprehensive range of disability services funded by the Federal Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Also based in my electorate is another service provided for the people of Queensland. It comes from a group called Technical Aid for the Disabled. In fact, it also operates out of the Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital, and has been operating out of that centre for about 12 years. It is a unique service. It is funded by a home and community care grant from the Federal Government and brings together a range of technical people who are willing to volunteer their services to produce a range of different and specific aids or products which are required by disabled people but which they cannot commercially purchase from private industry.

Technicians are brought from Telecom, the railways and other areas where there is some technical expertise. These people give up their own time and use their skills to design, in consultation with the disabled person concerned, a piece of equipment that suits his particular need for his home. They spend many hours and a lot of effort producing this equipment at a very low cost--the Government provides the support for the purchase of the bits and pieces that may be required--and provide a major benefit to people who are disabled and who otherwise would have to suffer quite considerable disabilities coping with the problem that they have, a problem which can be fixed up with the provision of this piece of technical equipment that Technical Aid for the Disabled is able to produce for them.

This is a wonderful group of people. They bring together the very strong voluntary effort that people throughout the community are willing to provide, as well as some great technical expertise. They are very ably led by their President, Professor Richard Stevens. I have had the pleasure of meeting with the people who are involved with Technical Aid for the Disabled. In a few weeks time I hope to go through the centre with the Director, Mr John Williams, to learn more about what Technical Aid for the Disabled has produced. These are just two organisations serving the people of Queensland that will benefit because of the legislation that we are debating tonight. I am pleased to provide my support for the legislation.

As I said earlier, I am disappointed that in this debate members of the coalition have diverted their attention from what we are actually considering here--namely, assistance for the disabled community in Australia--and have used it as a grandstanding exercise for their consumption tax. I think it is rather sad--but not surprising--to find that the coalition parties do not really have an interest in issues concerning disabled people, but are rather more willing to twist the debate here this evening back to their base policies on the consumption tax and their other regressive tax measures.

I am pleased that this Bill is before the House. I am pleased that it will receive the support of the House. I know that the disabled people throughout Australia will appreciate the Government's efforts in making these amendments, because they know that it will mean a substantial financial improvement to their situation and provide a much better opportunity for them to make something better of their lives and their homes a bit more comfortable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-As previous members of the coalition have told the House, we wholeheartedly support this legislation, notwithstanding the amendment that we have moved, which I think is totally appropriate in the circumstances. This legislation highlights some of the great injustices that have existed in the wholesale sales tax area--I say `have existed' in this case, because the legislation is being changed.

SPEECH.PARA: About a year ago I happened to visit a service station here in Canberra to buy some fuel. As I was fuelling up I happened to look through the window and I saw a fellow sitting in a wheelchair having some service done, presumably to the motor in his wheelchair, which I think basically is very similar to a starter motor in a car. Whatever that work was, it was being completed and he drove himself out onto the driveway, across to the back of a van-type vehicle, hit a button at the back and a tailboard automatically came down. He drove his wheelchair onto the tailboard, hit the button again, which raised him to the level of the back of the van, drove his wheelchair in behind the steering wheel, locked himself into position, started the motor and drove away.

I was singularly and greatly impressed by that experience. I would say that this person was virtually a quadriplegic; he seemed to have very little mobility even in his arms. I could imagine how that person's life and his enjoyment of life had been massively improved by that technology. It is just such an amazing step forward. I was a member of the Road Safety Committee of this Parliament years ago and I remember when we conducted an inquiry into the licensing of drivers. During that inquiry we visited a hospital where disabled people were being taught to drive vehicles.

At that time an injustice that struck me was the difference between the circumstances of people becoming injured. With two people in particular, one was the subject of an industrial accident and that person had a brand new car to learn on, while the other had gone home after work, climbed onto his roof to repair a broken tile and had slipped off and fallen across a fence. The circumstances in which he was trying to improve his lifestyle were not nearly as good. I still think that this is an issue that this Parliament should look more closely at. I have considerable objections to certain aspects of the welfare program but, when a person is suffering a disability of that nature, my generosity on behalf of myself and other taxpayers knows no bounds.

In this legislation, the Government is taking some further steps to clarify the rights of those people in relation to their having a reasonable lifestyle, remembering that in any circumstances theirs is not a very happy lot. So, naturally, there is good reason to do it. I guess the pity is that it has taken so long. I have received complaints in the past where people, in trying to properly equip a vehicle for their personal use, have found that they had passed the threshold price of the so-called luxury vehicle and had seen that tax question raised. I understand that one of the principal purposes of this legislation is to ensure that it does not much matter who drives the vehicle; the point is that it is being used to assist a person with a disability. So, it is all positive.
I think the Opposition is correct to move this particular amendment, which says:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading--
in fact, as I have said, the Opposition has supported this legislation--
the House condemns the Government for its ramshackle and inefficient wholesale sales tax system, and its failure to replace it with a fairer, broad-based goods and services tax'.

The simple fact is that in all of these situations, be it the exemptions available to the agricultural industry or be it the exemptions available to people disabled in the circumstances that we have mentioned today, nobody knows how the system works, including in most cases the Australian Taxation Office.

I well remember commencing a wholesale business many years ago and ringing up the Tax Office and saying, `I want to be a good taxpaying citizen'. Remember that the tax Act as it applies to the wholesale sales tax makes the wholesaler the taxpayer. The wholesaler who makes a mistake cannot legally go to the person to whom the goods were sold and ask that person to pay the difference, because that person is not the taxpayer. The taxpayer is the wholesaler, and any mistake the wholesaler makes and any incorrect advice the wholesaler gets can bring the business down if the tax problem exists for long enough and the accumulated back tax gets to the point at which the business cannot afford to pay it and so goes broke. There seems to be very little concern or compassion in the Tax Office when these circumstances arise.

The simple fact was that I wrote to the Tax Office and said, `I have gone into the wholesale business. I will be selling liquor and goods associated with the servicing of the hotel industry such as paper goods, packages and things of that nature. What sales tax rate should I apply?'. I was told, `We are not going to tell you; you must tell us'. I had never been in a business before but I had to write the Tax Office a letter saying that I was going to sell this particular item and that I believed that my responsibility was to pay sales tax at a particular rate. When I submitted my list, which was quite comprehensive, the Tax Office wrote back and said, `You were wrong with this one and you were wrong with that one'. I presume that there might have been a few in there where I was wrong on the wrong side of the ledger, and I do not know to this day whether it corrected me in that case. But, of course, I dutifully passed it on to my customers who dutifully passed it on to the consumer. So the consumers paid.

So the first thing is that the system as it exists is dreadful. Out in my electorate we have the circumstances of a farmer who rang me up and said, `I want to improve my wool flock. I am prepared to go to the expense of individually identifying each sheep on my property with numbered ear tags, and when I shear them I will weigh every fleece. I want to buy a set of scales for that purpose. I have approached the Tax Office and under the laws I can have them tax exempt. They are classified as an aid to manufacture. But, of course, I cannot afford to have someone standing beside the scales writing down every fleece weight. I need a computer to help with that, and I can buy the electronic scales that will put that information straight into the computer'. But the Tax Office said to him, `But you might take that computer up to the house at night and play Atari games on it. You might actually use it for such dreadful activities as working out your tax liability. You cannot have a sales tax exemption for that. As we do not know which purpose you will use it for most, you will have to pay sales tax on it'. And so he did. We argued, we fought and we struggled--to no avail.

We went a bit further at one stage and found that, if one bought a plough to put in a crop, that was exempt because that was an aid to manufacture. Apparently, the tax boffins had worked out that if one ploughed something into the ground one was seeking to grow a crop. But when one went to buy a header the Tax Office said, `No, that is not an aid to manufacture; the crop has grown. That is only the thing by which you cut its heads off'. The Tax Office actually made those sorts of rulings.

Consequently, I support wholeheartedly the amendment, which attacks the Government for its ramshackle wholesale sales tax system. No-one knows how it works, and, of course, it is pretty unfair. Furthermore, we can compare this with a system whereby there would be a flat tax charged up front at retail. There is an old saying which refers to three words associated with good taxation--if there is such a thing; I am a bit of an anti-tax person myself. They say that the three words are `certainty', `equity' and `simplicity'. I am not sure that any of them apply to our current taxation laws in Australia. But I have always chosen to add a fourth one--`visibility'. I am totally in favour of taxes being where people can see them. I suppose this story is not so impressive to Americans, but I will never forget finding out that when you buy something in a shop in America which has a price on the shelf of, say, $10, you hand over your $10 and the shopkeeper says, `You owe me another dollar'. You ask what for, and are told, `That is the tax'. So you think, `Oh, that is the government's share'.

But why can we not have a sign at every bowser that says, `Petrol: 20c a litre plus tax'? It makes a lot of sense to me, because I believe that governments, whatever their political persuasion, should be answerable to the people for the taxes they collect. When I think $20 billion, or 20 per cent, of the present taxes raised from Australians this financial year is raised as indirect taxes--as consumption taxes--and the Aussies do not know a thing about it, I think that is taxation by stealth. Of course, as was pointed out in this House today, we levy some $300m of that on Telecom--which does not bother to write to its consumers every month saying, `Here is your account and this is the tax component of what we are charging you'. That is unfair and improper. I want low taxation, but I want it to be visible.

Here is an interesting little exercise. A motor car is something that most Australians aspire to, and as many as possible like to buy one that sells for around about $25,000 new--and there are a few left at that price. I did a quick calculation using some of the information provided to me in regard to this legislation. I am told that the maximum tax exemption that people can obtain under this legislation is just over $6,000, this being the 20 per cent tax at the $30,505 wholesale limit before a car has applied to it the extra 10 per cent luxury component. But, at 20 per cent, presumably on wholesale, the tax on a $24,000 to $25,000 car--which I assume would wholesale for about $20,000--would be about $4,000.

In other words, if we scrap the WST as we know it today we would have that car wholesaling not at $20,000 but at $16,000. Consequently, presumably, the retailer would take a slightly lower cash margin, applying the same percentage. But let us assume that the retailer is a bit greedy and sticks with the $4,000 profit. The retail value of the car is now $20,000, not $24,000. Because the Government still wants some revenue, and assuming that we then had a broad-based consumption tax, let us say for the first example at 10 per cent, the tax on that $20,000 vehicle is $2,000, not $4,000 as it is presently. And let us say that the government of the day is more greedy than that and wants 15 per cent. The tax would then be $3,000, not $4,000. These things have to be taken into account. People must realise that, if we have a system that does away with the established WST, which is a dog's breakfast, there will be some beneficial effects before the up-front tax goes on.

The rate of application of that tax and how it is spent are matters of concern to me, and I have the opportunity within the forums of the Liberal and National parties to talk about that--and I certainly will.

TALK.START.PARA: —-And you do.

—-Yes, I do. But the point I make is that, of all the taxing systems we have, the WST is the most dreadful. Nobody knows how it works, and nobody really and truly has any understanding of it or is kept informed as to what it means to them. But I thought that that little example of a motor car--we are dealing with motor cars here--was a very interesting proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to touch on another matter. Today the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) wanted to tell me--and I have the only electorate in Australia that has more farmers than any other interest group--that my farmers were somehow going to be a lot better off after the industry statement, because he said that from here on in farmers would be totally exempt from sales tax. The Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), immediately jumped up and asked about sedan motor cars and a few things like that. Okay, that depends a bit on use, but what the Minister said amazed me. I went back and got hold of the documents accompanying the industry statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I knew what I wanted was there because it was burnt on my memory. On page 5.21, under `Sales tax exemptions for inputs to goods production', it said:

The Government has decided to simplify and extend the exemptions from wholesale sales tax for goods used by manufacturers, miners and primary producers (i.e. goods producers). . . Some existing restrictions on the goods eligible for exemption will be removed. The following goods will become exempt when used in eligible activities. . .

Goods such as the ones I just mentioned were then listed. They include lubricants, which is fine; office furniture, equipment and consumables; and road vehicles when used exclusively within the production premises--in other words, where people did not drive them out of the farm gate. It went on to talk about transportation. Transportation is fundamental to production in primary areas. Nothing leaves a farm that at some stage does not run on a rubber tyre. Sometimes it goes to its final destination, sometimes it might go to the rail siding, but there is a part of every piece of primary production that moves on a rubber tyre. One would think that, in setting out to remove the sales tax burden from primary producers and all the other people who use road transport, if only to get the product to the next stage of transport--be it rail or shipping--that would have been included.

But what does the statement tell us? It mentions transportation of goods by rail, which is fine. It also mentions transportation by pipeline--I know a bit goes by pipeline--and conveyor belt between production premises, eligible storage facilities or exempt ports. The Government got right down to the pipeline and the conveyor belt, but left out the truck.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I wonder why?

—-I can tell the honourable member why: the railway unions told the Government it could not put it in. It might have improved the competitive position of road transport; it might have given the farmer a break. We cannot have that, of course, because the railways have got to survive. What is the Minister on about? Fifteen per cent of national GDP is paid in transport; one dollar in seven is spent by Australians on transport. Eighty per cent of traffic between Melbourne and Sydney goes on the road--and the Government left it out! The Minister gets up here today and tries to tell us the wonderful things the Government has done under WST for my farmers! They are not very grateful. Let me give honourable members a classic example, because I used to run a transport company.
—-Are they going to vote Labor?

—-I do not think they will, because they are awake. They have heard the rhetoric but have not seen the change. Let me put a simple measure on the cost of wholesale sales tax when a person runs a truck. I carted cement from Perth to Port Hedland, about 1,000 miles in the old fashioned measure. On the rig that I used, which was a double- bottom road train, I used to wear out one tyre a trip if I was lucky. That was just normal wear and tear. I used to carry 40 tonnes, only one way, and I was paying in excess of $20 sales tax on that tyre. Fifty cents a tonne of the $40 or $50 I used to get in those days was going out in sales tax on my tyres--to say nothing of the sales tax on my batteries, my spare parts and everything else I had to buy. The fact of life was that I made sure that people paid for that, whatever the rate was.

SPEECH.PARA: That was the sort of tax burden I was passing on to consumers in the north-west, and nobody knew about it. This industry statement does not take it out; the burden on remote area dwellers is still there and it is a disgrace because every mode of production, be it in the capital cities or the country, is reliant on road transport at some stage. There is a cost being fed in and the Government was either too stupid or too dishonest to understand it.

As I have said in this Parliament before, I have never yet been able to establish who I dislike most: the dishonest or the stupid. Sometimes the dishonest bloke does give me a run for my money. In this Parliament at the moment I do not know which label to put on this Government, but I am starting to think `stupid' is probably the right word. People who leave road transport out of a statement like the industry statement and then claim that massive benefits have been given to production are talking through their hats.

The Minister is to be condemned for trying to put that argument over in this place. After all, Ministers are required by our rules to tell the Parliament the truth. In supporting this legislation, which is positive, I point out-- (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Deputy Speaker, it was a great shame that, because of time, you had to intervene in what I considered to be a marvellous speech, one that is illustrative of some of the difficulties with the wholesale sales tax that is currently applied in Australia. I want to commend the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) for the clarity with which he presented examples of the difficulties and confusion that have arisen from the application of the wholesale sales tax.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation before the House tonight is the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1991, which contains three basic measures. The first measure extends the current exemption on goods used to modify a motor vehicle to adapt it for driving by a disabled person to include vehicles used to transport such persons. The second measure in the Bill is to make it easier to establish eligibility for exemption in relation to goods designed and manufactured expressly for invalid persons. The third part of the Bill provides a cap on the maximum sales tax benefit applicable to new motor vehicles for use by certain Defence Force veterans and other persons with specific disabilities.

I welcome the measure because it is long overdue that people with disabilities are considered when they come to seek transport or when they seek to have aids and appliances which will make life more interesting and more bearable for them. I regard this as a compassionate measure on the part of the Government.

The Government is a strange sort of mixture of compassion and harshness. On the one hand, it does something like this, costing $3m in this year and $3.5m in a full year, but, on the other hand, the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) introduced legislation for disabled people which is so restrictive and prescriptive that wonderful organisations such as the Challenge Foundation and many others are deeply concerned about pushing disabled people out into the community, forcing them to fend for themselves. Here we have a little measure in a sales tax Bill to assist disabled people but, on the other hand, we have broad measures which will seriously disadvantage and damage the well-being and lifestyles of disabled people.

I am particularly pleased with the provision that extends the exemption to the vehicles to be used as transport for disabled people. I have come to know a fine Australian company which produces special passenger vehicles--`SPV' they call themselves--by taking Australian motor cars, doing a body stretch on them and dropping a middle section into them. They are designed specifically by fine Australian engineers, manufactured to very high levels of expertise, thoroughly road tested, to allow for the transportation of disabled people.

Competing against this Australian made motor car has been the common London cab. The London cab is a fully imported vehicle and it is familiar to most Australians because it is starting to appear in our city streets. The London cab has had some favouritism shown to it in the way in which it has been treated for tax purposes. I have thought for some time that it is a tragedy that the Australian manufactured vehicle, which sells for about the same price, does not have some concessions applied when it comes to the transportation of disabled people.

One vehicle is built and is capable of being used for the transport of disabled people by its manufacture, and that is the London cab. The special purpose, Australian manufactured vehicle is a specially built piece of equipment. It has a marvellous finish, is beautifully designed and is expertly built by the company. Despite some representations on my part, I am afraid that until now the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) has failed to understand the claim of this Australian company. In fact, the correspondence I have received completely ignores the main thrust of my representations and concerns and the damage being done to the company by what I would regard as some unfairness in the competition it faces.

I believe that this amendment will now provide for the manufacturer of the Australian vehicle an opportunity to sell its vehicles freely on the Australian market. I believe that these Australian vehicles will become an alternative transport for disabled people. They will be extremely popular because the side of the vehicle opens and it is possible to wheel a wheelchair right onto the floor of the vehicle, lock it down and transport two people very safely and easily from place to place. For those people who are confined to wheelchairs this will be a marvellous measure.

I hope that the Minister will quickly advise me if I and the company concerned have misinterpreted the application of this sales tax exemption, because it is something that it has been seeking for some time. I know that, whilst it will be across-the-board, it will now start to level the playing field, which is a term that I do not like--it will start to make things more equitable for the company concerned. This will mean that the cost and availability of transport for Australians in Australian made vehicles will be improved.

I would also like to pay tribute to the Government for the step it has taken in exempting goods designed and manufactured expressly for invalid persons. Within the electorate of Mitchell there are a number of organisations which have the task of specifically supporting, assisting and providing accommodation and workplace opportunities for disabled people. There is the Warrah School, Cumberland Industries, Macall Colony Gardens, Inala and the Hills School, as well as the hidden group of individuals, those disabled people living in nursing home accommodation.

I trust that the provisions to grant exemption for goods designed and manufactured for invalid and disabled people will allow those in nursing homes or in disabled institutions to take advantage of those aids that assist them, whether it be in getting to and from their bed or wheelchair or allowing them to bathe without discomfort. All of those things that become so much a part of life for disabled or invalid people will be decreased in price through this measure. What a sensible measure that is.

It is regrettable in many ways that the Government has had to take some measures to rectify what is a strange system of taxing people--that is, the wholesale sales tax. It is a tax that has been fiddled with and changed by governments from the time of its introduction. Subjective assessments are made as to whether an item is a luxury or a non-luxury item for the application of the wholesale sales tax.

For instance, because caviar and oysters are considered to be a food, they are not taxed. On the other hand, chocolate biscuits and ice-cream, and even kids' drinks, are taxed because they are considered to be a luxury. I cannot follow the concept of a government that claims it is simplifying the tax system but, by exemptions and extensions over the last five years, has succeeded in trebling the amount of money that it is taking from Australians by the wholesale sales tax.

We are talking about transportation, and the relief for disabled people from the cost of their transport vehicles is to be much welcomed. On the other hand, the wholesale sales tax is not applied to aeroplane flights, but a 20 per cent wholesale sales tax applies to caravans. A taxi service has no wholesale sales tax on it, but a bicycle carries a 20 per cent sales tax. Therefore, despite all of its promises, the Government has not succeeded in rectifying the problems and differences that these judgments apply to the Australian community, whether the thing is a luxury item, a middle range item or just a revenue raising item. So the extension of the wholesale sales tax, since the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) became Treasurer, and continuing today, is something that few Australians realise.

The application of the wholesale sales tax covers a range of goods in Australia. Few people really understand--Mr Deputy Speaker, I know that you do because you have made a particular study of this matter over the last few weeks; I am sure of that--the wide range of goods--the hundreds of items--on which sales tax is applied. The interpretations that have to be gained by wholesalers from the Taxation Office as to whether one level or another of wholesale sales tax applies, whether or not an item is exempt, or whether the tax is fully applicable cause great confusion.

I have a number of expert wholesalers and retailers within my electorate who trade with each other. In some instances, depending on where invoicing takes place, the transport component is or is not included in a good. Somebody can take the invoice at the point of delivery--the wholesale outlet--and have no transport included in the wholesale sales tax. But if the invoice is issued at the front door it includes the whole of the transport component--the cost of the truck and the driver and the wear and tear on that vehicle is added to the price and taxed. There is a myriad of inconsistencies.

In one part of Australia one deputy commissioner will apply one level of wholesale sales tax and in another part of Australia another level will be applied. It is only where manufacturers move across State boundaries and wholesalers move from State to State that they understand these inconsistencies. There is no rhyme or reason to some of the decisions, or to some of the goods that are included.

For instance, until fairly recently if someone wanted to have a tax free shower it was cheaper to use dog soap because there was no sales tax on dog soap but there was on the soap that you and I would normally use. What a strange thing to have in Australia. This is the weirdness of the system the Government pretends to support and wants to go on supporting. It seems strange to me that with the so-called compassion--the fake compassion--that the Government has, things such as baby powder for infants are taxed at 20 per cent. Is the Government afraid that the baby's mum or dad might use that powder?

I do not know what is wrong with the Government when it tries to justify such an antiquated, ramshackle system as the wholesale sales tax. Over the last few weeks Government members have become the defenders of the current system. They have become the defenders of the secret tax, applied without knowledge to the purchaser, never marked up, and kept secretly in the warehouses of the wholesalers who make out their accounts and send the cheques in to the Government. They are the tax collectors, secretly collecting tax from Australians without their being aware that pens and papers, hair combs and brushes, lawn-mowers and toilet paper, and even Ovaltine and Milo, have a tax of 20 per cent on them.

I believe that the defenders of this current system need to look at some of the rationale that was presented to the tax summit by their own leaders. The only reason they were pushed off that course was that the union movement said at that time, `We will not wear it'. Listen to the words used by the honourable member for Blaxland at that time in regard to the necessities of life. In the Australian Financial Review of 13 June 1985, he is reported as saying:

At the moment we all have to buy the necessities; if you're not buying them you can't live. And you buy them now out of your after-tax income, after it has suffered these very high repressive marginal rates. So you pay 46 cents in the dollar and then still buy your necessities. What we are saying is you buy the same necessities, but out of your relieved tax income.

That is the proposal that the Opposition is putting to the Australian people: out of a relieved income, there is a greater capacity to buy the necessities of life. That is the proposal that should be implemented, instead of sticking with this ramshackle system, so inconsistent, so thoughtless and so poorly thought out as it applies in Australia at the moment, and instead of sticking at the same time to our very high marginal rates of taxation.

In the provisions before the House tonight are some thoughtful measures to exempt those who are disabled from paying sales tax for their transport vehicle or those providing transport for them, which, I think, is even more significant. It makes it easier for those people purchasing goods designed and manufactured expressly for invalids to buy without the imposition of sales tax. That is to be welcomed. But we have this consistently strange attitude of the Government. On the one hand, it gives a little bit of encouragement and, on the other hand, it has a general system which is oppressive and not supportive of the Australian community.

I would like to persuade the Government to be courageous and pick up the opportunity to change the tax regime in Australia to give Australians a bit more of a chance. Why not follow the words of, say, the honourable member for Blaxland in the Australian? So many members opposite want to support him and see him in the Prime Minister's chair. I see my colleagues from New South Wales in the chamber. I know that almost to a man they would have that view. But almost to a man they are failing to accept the logic and the rationale of chucking out this wholesale sales tax system; of picking up the tax cheats; of applying a tax that will pick up some dollars from the tourists in Australia, who come to Australia and use our services and who now pay very little for their use.
The honourable member for Blaxland said in the Australian of 2 July 1985:

The Government believes that it is now time to take a more fundamental approach. It is time to establish a broader tax base with greater integrity, allowing a fairer sharing of the tax burden with lower rates of tax.
On 18 February 1985 the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said:
Now it seems to us that there therefore has to be a substantial increase in indirect taxation.
They were talking about a consumer tax, a goods and services tax. That was the cause they were arguing. It was a cause that the Government has walked away from.

Those who are here in support of the honourable member for Blaxland, those who want to see a change in the prime-ministership, have to deal with this issue because, if they continue to reject these reforms of the wholesale sales tax, they are rejecting many advantages for their fellow Australians--advantages in having a consistent, easily understood tax at a low level across a range of goods and services; in reducing personal income tax; and in providing protection and exemption from the impact of that change to pensioners and low income earners. They are the advantages that they are rejecting on behalf of their fellow Australians. If they accept these measures, they will encourage those people who wish not to pay tax to save, because if they want to put their pay or their returns from their hard work into savings, there is no tax paid on those goods. So savings are encouraged by a broad-based GST.

There would be an improvement in trade because there would be an exemption from a GST on those goods which have been traded overseas. There would be assistance to local manufacture because there would be a decrease in the cost of goods and services used to produce products. A broad-based GST would be more rational and more easily understood. It would deal with the cash economy, estimated by some to be $40 billion a year. How would Government members deal with that? With a broad-based GST those people receiving cash, whenever they spend any money, will be paying taxation. That does not happen under the wholesale sales tax.

Members of the Government have done nothing about bringing the cash economy into gear, but we intend to do something. What are they afraid of? Are they the friends of those who deal in the cash economy? What influence do they bring to bear on the Australian Labor Party? Why can members opposite not take a stand against this issue?

Finally, there would be the capacity to reduce income taxes for all Australians-- lower income tax so that people would have more of their own money to spend. These are most desirable objectives that the Australian Labor Party should copy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —-in reply--I take this opportunity to thank all those honourable members who took part in this debate, particularly the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow), the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) and the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson), whose remarks were relevant and of great assistance to all of those who listened to the debate. I thank also the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) and the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), who also displayed a kind of consistency in that none of them was prepared to direct his remarks to the Bill. We were not this evening debating the Disabilities Services Act; we were not debating the March industry statement; and we were not debating the Opposition's plans for a consumption tax. There will be another occasion on which we can do that, and we in the Government are looking forward very much to it.

SPEECH.PARA: There are some particular points that should be addressed at this stage. I acknowledge the kind remarks of the honourable member for Dawson and I welcome his desire for a degree of bipartisanship on the question of assistance for disabled people. I particularly noted his remarks about heavy vehicles, four-wheel- drive vehicles and those which would be priced above the threshold specified in the legislation. I point out to him that the report of the Industry Commission, had the recommendation contained in that report been adopted, would have taxed those vehicles in full. In fact, the Bill gives people in that position a tax benefit of $6,101 in the current financial year and excludes the costs of modifications for the purpose of determining the exemption.

I point out also to the honourable member for Dawson that such vehicles would be fully taxable under a broad-based consumption tax offering no exemptions. Equally, following up his remark about a 20 per cent tax on commercial vehicles equating to a kind of consumption tax, I point out that this of course is a tax at the wholesale level and not a tax at the retail level, which is what would occur with a GST.

On the general question of a consumption tax, as I say, I am not particularly interested in getting involved in a detailed debate on that this evening. The proper time for that will come when the Opposition finally reveals the details of its proposals.

I reject the charge that the sales tax legislation is unnecessarily complicated and difficult to administer. It is certainly not when compared with a proposal that the Opposition would be putting up. There were some complaints during the debate, for example, about the cost to business of certification and the difficulty with paperwork. I point out that the administrative costs of collecting a dollar of sales tax revenue is only 40 per cent of the cost of collecting a dollar of income tax revenue. I point out that, under the wholesale sales tax regime, there are some 75,000 taxpayers in the system. A consumption tax would be likely to increase this number by tenfold, correspondingly increasing compliance and administrative costs.

I also make the point that the wholesale sales tax does offer the capacity to target particular products and particular groups where governments wish to achieve special objectives. I point to the example of the removal of sales tax on recycled paper, for example. To promote a particular objective the Government removed the wholesale sales tax on recycled paper, thereby promoting its use. In this particular Bill, to assist a particular group of people in the community, a wholesale sales tax is removed in particular cases to assist disabled people.

The Opposition, while extolling the virtues of a GST throughout this debate, has failed to tell us whether it would be providing exemptions for goods used by disabled people as provided for in this Bill. I would have imagined that the whole point of a broad-based GST would be that it would offer no exemptions, as so many honourable members of the Opposition participating in this debate and earlier discussions have told us. I think the Opposition will have to come clean, particularly during discussion on this Bill which offers exemptions from the wholesale sales tax for disabled people in particular instances.

Would a GST offer exemptions for goods purchased for particular purposes? Further, would it offer exemptions for services purchased by disabled people? All of this presumably we will find out in the fullness of time--on 25 September at the National Press Club, or whenever it is going to happen. We on the Government side are looking forward to this very much. The spectacle that we enjoyed this evening of white-faced Liberals coming in here at the behest of their Whip to argue----

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Minister began his speech by saying that members of the Opposition had not been relevant to the subject because they had spoken about a goods and services tax rather than sales tax exemptions. In his reply, he has devoted himself almost entirely to replying to the goods and services tax. By his own admission he is out of order. I ask you to direct him to return to the subject matter of the Bill.
--The Minister is in order. He is responding to debate which has been going on previously this evening.

—-As I pointed out, I was simply forced to reply to a number of points that were raised during that debate. In response to some remarks made by the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) on the subject of the Industry Commission report, I point out that the measures contained in the Bill in many instances go beyond the recommendations of the Industry Commission, particularly the new exemption for goods used to modify vehicles to transport people with disabilities. It is a Government initiative, one not recommended by the Industry Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments to exemptions for motor vehicles for use by certain Defence Force veterans and other people with specific disabilities again are more generous than the Industry Commission recommendations. In a number of other respects as well, the Bill goes beyond the recommendations of the Commission. In some instances it does not, and they were mentioned in the second reading speech.

The Government rejects the Opposition's amendment. In the committee stage I will be moving an amendment on behalf of the Government to omit the proposed change to exemption item 123. The change was intended to clarify item 123 in borderline cases; it was not intended to expand the scope of the exemptions available. It is now believed that such a change might have a wider impact than originally intended and provide the potential for abuse and some loss of revenue. It is not proposed at this stage to proceed with that change but to subject it to further consideration. I will be moving that amendment during the committee stage.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 4, page 2, lines 21 to 23, omit paragraph (b).

The amendment will omit the proposed change to exemption item 123. That change was intended to clarify item 123 in borderline cases. It was not intended to expand the scope of the exemptions available under the item and was initially understood to be revenue neutral. However, it is now believed that such a change could have a wider impact than originally anticipated and there could be the potential for abuse and subsequent loss of revenue. As a consequence, it is proposed not to proceed with the change at this stage but to subject the change to further detailed consideration. I present the supplementary explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: --As I said in the course of the debate, the Opposition will not be objecting to the amendment. I draw the attention of honourable members in the chamber to the fact that there is a complication in the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act, in spite of what the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Free) might say. This Bill was introduced in the first sitting week of this Parliament. The amendment which has been moved today indicates that there is a complication. This is very detailed legislation--there are schedules, regulations and everything else. Nobody can deny that we have a ramshackle and unfair system within the Sales (Exemptions and Classifications) Tax Act. I think the Minister is demonstrating precisely that. There is no precision about this legislation; it is not something that can be targeted.

SPEECH.PARA: I recall the Minister saying in his second reading speech that he can target various aspects. A target was made to tax luxury cars at 50 per cent. That was badly targeted and, after a certain amount of time, the Government had to acknowledge that in order to make sure that the luxury car market survived. Targeting can be carried out successfully but, equally, it can be carried out badly. The same types of targeting mechanisms are available within the GST as are available within the wholesale sales tax. I thank the Minister for the opportunity to be able to respond to some of the comments he made during his second reading speech.
Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with an amendment; report--by leave--adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr Free)--by leave-- read a third time.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I rise to speak on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1). A little later tonight I will make some comments about the overall Budget strategy and why I am a strong supporter of the Government's better cities program. I will also make a few comments about the administration of the New South Wales Government. Before I do, I would like to make a few comments in response to some of the things that have been said by earlier speakers tonight about the Opposition's proposal to introduce a consumption tax if it is successful at the next election.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an area that deserves a great deal of consideration by this Parliament and the Australian people before they have the opportunity to pass judgment on Dr Hewson's proposal to introduce a consumption tax of 15 per cent, 22 per cent or whatever figure he decides to set. At the moment the Opposition is seeking to put together a consumption tax which is the greatest con job this country has ever had to consider.

It is very important to go through some of the arguments which we have heard tonight. The honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) has told us that, because there is no sales tax on oysters or caviar, the Government should tax bread and milk. Tonight he was saying that, because there are some luxury food items which are not subject to wholesale sales tax, then the Opposition plans to levy a consumption tax of 15 per cent or 22 per cent, whatever it is, on everything that we need to eat and drink. That includes bread, milk--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Caviar and oysters.

—-Yes, caviar and oysters will be caught. Whereas the honourable member opposite may spend a lot of money on caviar and oysters, I can tell him that low income earners in my electorate do not. Low income earners in my electorate do not have the money for those luxury items that are mainly subject to the 30 per cent wholesale sales tax at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is also seeking to levy this 15 per cent or 22 per cent consumption tax on every dollar which is spent by these people. These lower middle income earners do not have large sums of money to put aside in shares and investments or into savings accounts. They have to spend almost all of their income to make ends meet. They are going to be hit harder than the people who are very comfortable, who drive Ferraris, who have mansions in Double Bay and up the Highlands like Dr Hewson and who are not required to spend almost all of their income on clothing and food, on looking after their children and on simply purchasing their groceries and food at the supermarket. That is why the consumption tax is regressive. That is why the Opposition proposal will hit lower and middle income earners harder than those people who are better off, and that is why the Labor Party will fight this proposal tooth and nail.

TALK.START.PARA: —-What about the income tax cuts?

—-It is interesting to note that it is the shadow Minister at the table who is supporting this consumption tax, a man who has made his reputation as being one of the leading lights of the New Right. The simple point I would make to him is that I would ask him to consider that at the moment 75,000 people fill out the paperwork and send cheques regularly to the Tax Office to pay the wholesale sales tax. How many people will have to fill out the paperwork for the Opposition's 15 per cent or 22 per cent consumption tax? Not 75,000 as is required with the current system, but 750,000 people every month, every week, every day or however often they are required to send in these pieces of paper. Ten times as many retailers and 10 times as many business people will be required to fill out the Opposition's consumption tax paperwork. The Opposition claims that it is the party of small government and yet thousands of extra public servants will be required in the Tax Office just to process all the paperwork that the small businessmen will be required to complete just so Opposition members can follow their own ideological hang-ups and bring in a consumption tax because Margaret Thatcher brought in a VAT.

SPEECH.PARA: That is why we are doing this--because Opposition members have had their agenda set by Margaret Thatcher. Opposition members have said that a Labor government in New Zealand introduced a consumption tax and, therefore, we are not necessarily only following the views of the British Conservative Party. I enjoy it every time they make the comparison with New Zealand because I am sure that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, are aware that the New Zealand Government initially brought in a 10 per cent consumption tax. The Government of New Zealand adjusted the compensation for pensioners and worked out ways which, it said, would ensure income tax rates could be cut. However, within a very short time what did that Government do? It increased the consumption tax from 10 per cent to 12 1/2 per cent.

That is the hidden agenda of the Opposition. That is the reason why it wants to bring in this consumption tax. Opposition members know that, once they have a consumption tax established, it will be easy for any future Liberal government to raise taxation by stealth by simply jacking up the consumption tax from 15 per cent to 22 per cent to 30 per cent or to 35 per cent whenever it needs extra money to fund its particular programs.

The Opposition still has not told us how it intends to compensate pensioners who are going to be greatly disadvantaged by the consumption tax--pensioners who have to spend almost every dollar that they receive on purchasing goods which they need to make ends meet. We have had no explanation at all from the Opposition as to how they will be compensated. The Opposition might come up with a certain figure to compensate pensioners receiving the full rate of pension; but what about the part rate pensioners, the people on railway superannuation? How is it going to provide adequate compensation to those people who are battling to make ends meet?

TALK.START.PARA: —-They don't care about them.

—-As the honourable member for Parramatta says, the Opposition does not care one little bit about the battlers in the electorates of Parramatta, Dobell or McPherson who are battling to make ends meet on a railway pension.

SPEECH.PARA: Even if the Opposition comes up with a compensation package for pensioners, how will it compensate people for the fact that overnight the value of the savings of every person in this country will be devalued? If a consumption tax of 20 per cent is introduced by the Opposition in one or two years time, it will mean that an item which now costs $100 will cost people $120. That is the old way the Opposition's consumption tax will work.

TALK.START.PARA: —-False. What about the wholesale sales tax reduction? False. Absolutely false.

—-I hate to give the honourable member the bad news, but the Opposition has said that this proposal will raise more money than the total receipts for wholesale sales tax. I make it very clear to the honourable member that, if the Opposition introduces a 20 per cent consumption tax, for example, $100 worth of bread or milk will cost $120. As a result, the spending power of people's savings will decrease by 20 per cent overnight.

SPEECH.PARA: How does the Opposition plan to compensate all of the people for the fact that their savings are devalued? The Opposition has not advanced any mechanism for providing adequate compensation to the pensioners, the superannuants, the school kids with savings, the farmers or anyone else out in the community. Those people will certainly know the day the Opposition brings in this consumption tax, because overnight it will be slashing their spending power.

The price that will be paid is that the 22 per cent or the 15 per cent consumption tax will bump up the price of milk, bread and doctors' fees. It will be levied on electricity bills and on council rates. I can see the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) in the chamber. I alert him to the fact that every time he goes to the barber, he will be subject to a consumption tax on the cost of a haircut. (Quorum formed)

I thank my Labor colleagues for coming into the chamber. The honourable member for Parramatta was correct when he said that he did not think many members of the National Party of Australia would come in here to hear me talk about a consumption tax because they are so embarrassed about the Opposition's policy on a consumption tax.

The point I was making was that the honourable member for Mitchell argued earlier tonight that, because there is no wholesale sales tax on caviar and oysters, there should be a consumption tax of 22 per cent on bread, milk and all the other necessities of life.

TALK.START.PARA: —-That is typical from a yuppie.

—-That is typical of a yuppie, as the honourable member suggests. I make the point that not many pensioners in our electorates would be spending money on caviar or oysters. But they would be spending it on bread and milk, which of course are not subject to sales tax.

SPEECH.PARA: The important thing is that the Opposition says that its consumption tax would be visible but that the current wholesale sales tax is secret. The point I make is that anyone who has travelled to the United Kingdom or any of those countries that have consumption taxes or VAT will probably have had the unpleasant experience of having found something on the shelf that they wished to purchase, having taken it to the cash register with their money ready and having been slugged with an invisible consumption tax which the retailers have not shown on the prices of the goods displayed on their shelves.

It is very clear which is a secret tax: it is not the wholesale sales tax, which is seen in the price displayed on the shelves; it is the VAT, the consumption tax or whatever else is levied. I simply ask those opposite who say that their proposal would get extra money from the black economy: how many people with large sums of money who have not paid income tax are spending money on bread and milk and how many are spending money on Ferraris, mansions, oysters and caviar? It is very clear that the wholesale sales tax ensures that it mops up a large amount of that money that goes through the black economy.

Having been tempted by the Opposition to make a few comments on a consumption tax, I had better return to the Appropriation Bill. The important thing to note about these proposals is that the Budget provides this country with a foundation for recovery, with the Budget Papers demonstrating that this year's economic growth is expected to be about 3.7 per cent. Whilst employment has fallen by 300,000 and caused increases in unemployment in my electorate and others around the country, in the life of the Hawke Government we have seen employment increase by more than 1.3 million. That is a rate of employment growth per year which is more than three times the rate of employment growth during the Fraser years. So, when Opposition members get up in this House and shed crocodile tears for Raymond or other people in their electorates who are undergoing the great difficulties of unemployment, I simply suggest to them that they compare the success of this Government with that of the Fraser Government. This Government has created 1.3 million jobs--a rate of employment growth three times that of the Fraser years.

It is fair to try to make a judgment as to whether the Government is doing enough to ensure that the economy picks up at the right pace. We can be very proud of the fact that, for example, last year exports of manufactured goods grew 20 per cent--something which demonstrates great scope for hope for the coming year.

The housing industry is growing rapidly. But, most importantly, we have had a dramatic fall in interest rates over the last 18 months or more. Of course, during that period there have been some criticisms of our previous Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), and of our side of politics. Those opposite have said with hindsight that we kept interest rates too high and that, if we had eased interest rates earlier, perhaps unemployment would not be as bad as it is. But, in perhaps accepting those criticisms, it is worth while to compare this Government's decisions in lowering interest rates with the Opposition's policy. Virtually every time that Treasurer Keating and Prime Minister Hawke supported the Reserve Bank of Australia in dropping interest rates in the last 18 months, the Leader of the Opposition accused the Reserve Bank Governor, Bernie Fraser, of acting for political reasons.
I have a quote from the Leader of the Opposition on 31 January 1990 when he was shadow Treasurer. He was asked by journalist Martin:
Can we say that that cut in interest rates then wasn't justified?
The then shadow Treasurer replied:
I think there's little doubt that the Treasurer's pushing the pace on interest rate reduction to meet his political timetable.
But as recently as today in this morning's Australian, 18 months later, we have the headline `Hewson attacks Reserve governor', with the opening paragraph:

The Federal Opposition intensified last night its assault on the one percentage point cut in interest rates from claims of political motivation to a personal attack on the governor of the Reserve Bank, Mr Bernie Fraser.

I wondered whether perhaps the Opposition had made a mistake and put out a press release from 18 months ago. But, no, that was not the case. The Opposition has not changed its tune. It has opposed a cut in interest rates all along.

If the Government had followed the Opposition's arguments and kept interest rates higher during the past 18-month period, what would have been the effect on employment at that time? We would have had higher unemployment and a deeper recession. It is a bit rich that Opposition members come into this House and complain about unemployment. The policies that they have been advocating in the last 18 months would have kept interest rates higher and made that recession worse.

Let us look at fiscal policy. The Opposition has argued that this Government's deficit of $2 billion is $2 billion too high. It would rather have had a balanced Budget. It would rather have cut government spending by $2 billion. Even the Opposition's own economic analysts show that a reduction in the deficit of $2 billion would have meant a reduction in employment of 46,000 Australians. But those opposite would have had interest rates higher. They would have had a lower Budget deficit and, of course, the obvious result would have been a deeper recession and a longer period before the economy recovered. So I do not think that anyone would believe that the Opposition has the answers to Australia's current economic difficulties. This Budget has laid the foundation for recovery and for growth in the economy of 3 3/4 per cent-- something which deserves endorsement by this Parliament.

In the few minutes left for me to speak, I wish to make a comment on the Government's better cities program. It was certainly a long time coming. But this Parliament has faced up to the Federal Government's national responsibilities to improve the quality of our cities. In fact, in my maiden speech I drew attention to the great urban problems in my own electorate. It is my fond hope that this program can ensure that people who suffer from isolation in my electorate due to the inadequate transport system and the people who suffer from having inadequate hospital services, a degraded environment and inadequate employment opportunities can have these addressed in the better cities program put forward by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe).

Instead of the Opposition's seeking to bag this program, perhaps it might seek to be a bit more constructive and to join other State and local government authorities in ensuring that this money goes to improve the quality of life in Australia, in our cities and outer suburban areas and also in our rural and provincial cities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: --The honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) has fallen into the trap that most members of the Government seem to fall into these days. They peddle misinformation and deceit. They are doing it unashamedly and blatantly and I can only interpret that as meaning that they are actually running scared. They know that they have been there for almost nine years and that they have blown the opportunity to reform the taxation system.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government was on the right track back in 1985. The former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) in his address to the National Press Club on 5 June 1985, said:

Firstly, the consumption tax. There are three main advantages of this tax. First, it will allow a more rational indirect tax system than the current anomaly-ridden wholesale tax, which has multiple rates, numerous exemptions, and fails to tax the services sector. Second, it will enable us to generate tax revenues to provide for a major reduction in the marginal rates of income tax. No other tax has the same potential for this purpose.
I remind the House that this was the honourable member for Blaxland talking at the National Press Club on 5 June 1985. Speaking about a consumption tax, he said:
Third, it generates tax from those who will continue to evade or avoid Income tax. That provides a useful "net dividend" to the rest of the community.

The Government was on the right track back then in 1985; but, as we know now, the history of the situation is that the Government was rolled by the ACTU. Yet the honourable member for Blaxland was right then. The great irony of all of this--as we hear Government members getting up and peddling this misinformation--is that the Government knew it was the right thing to do. I suppose it hurts the Government now to see us going about implementing the tax reforms that it so much wanted to implement back in 1985. The matter goes further. In the Australian of 18 February 1985, the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, said:

We have got in this country a position where our marginal tax rates are too high and they are biting in too early . . . They are disincentives and people rightly feel that they have got too high a burden of direct personal tax. So for obvious reasons of personal hardships, incentives and economic efficiency we have got to bring those rates down and bring them down substantially. Now it seems to us that there therefore has to be a substantial increase in indirect taxation.

What more support does the Prime Minister need for the introduction of a broad based consumption tax? Yet the Government has been dishonest. This is where the Government stands condemned, because it has persevered with the hidden wholesale sales tax. I want to remind the House of this fact, because it speaks volumes of the duplicity and dishonesty in the way that Government members speak on this issue. Wholesale sales tax revenue has increased from $3 billion in 1983 to over $10 billion in 1991--a massive increase in percentage terms in the hidden wholesale sales tax. The Government has done this by stealth. It does not stand up and tell us where the tax is applied; it does it quietly. The tax is hidden and yet it is an enormous tax burden. It is a hotchpotch of inequality and unfairness.

I believe that this Government will stand condemned for its inability to come to grips with real tax reform--tax reform to do what the Prime Minister said, to remove disincentives. The Prime Minister wanted to do it, but he has not been able to do it. The trade unions, at that time, gave the Government its marching orders and the great losers have been the Australian economy and the Australian people.

I will speak now directly on the Budget. I do not shrink from taking on the debate about the goods and services tax. The Government can throw everything it likes at us, but I remind it that good things will come to those who wait; in due course we will provide the details of our tax reform package and it will be grasped with great enthusiasm by the people of Australia. As we look back over the weeks when we have heard garbage, misinformation and dishonesty, the Government will stand even further condemned. It will have egg all over its face.

The Hawke Government's ninth Budget has been a complete flop. In fact, `flop' is probably an understatement, because it has been an abject failure. It has failed because it has been broadly perceived as being completely irrelevant. It is irrelevant to today's economic environment. It is irrelevant to families who continue to be worse off than they were 12 months ago.
