It is irrelevant to the people lining up for food parcels at the Brotherhood of St Laurence or the Salvation Army, as I reminded the Prime Minister in Question Time the other day. It is sadly irrelevant to the almost one million people who are unemployed, many of whom are on the scrap heap. A sad thing is that many of the unemployed are becoming unemployed at 39--as was a constituent the other day--45 or 52 years of age. People of 50 are coming to me saying, `What do I do? Do I wait until I go on the age pension?'.

Of course, the Budget is also irrelevant to the many Australians whose businesses have gone bankrupt because of this Government's policies. We heard today in Question Time a reference to the enormous increase in bankruptcies that this country is experiencing.

Fundamentally, this Budget is irrelevant because it fails to address the key issues. Already, the Budget is falling apart, as we might have expected it to do. Government Ministers--even the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) the other day--and members are distancing themselves from it. Perhaps we expected too much from the Budget. Perhaps there were unreasonable expectations of it. Australia desperately needed to see light at the end of the tunnel, but it is not there.

A Budget is a plan or a blueprint for the future. It is something to be grasped as the basis for a course of action. But this Budget is none of that. At a time in this country's history when, perhaps like no other time, there needed to be a way forward, there is none. Instead, there is policy paralysis. Everything is ad hoc. What is right one day is not right the next. We are reminded, increasingly starkly, of the similarity here with the dying days of the Whitlam Government--a rudderless ship drifting helplessly.

It is really difficult to identify the worst features of the Budget. It has few redeeming features. The overall forecast deficit--somewhat understated--of $4.7 billion is an indictment of the ability of the Government to be consistent. With some justification, the former Treasurer claimed some accolades for the Budget turnaround in recent years from deficit to surplus, and I am prepared to say that that was no mean feat. There was a clear need to ensure that the public sector was in balance and that there was a zero public sector borrowing requirement. That was indicated by the economics of the time. It was appropriate. It indicated a commendable shrinking in the total Commonwealth debt. But the projected $8.1 billion surplus for the 1990-91 Budget failed to eventuate and now we have this Budget. Even with the forecast deficit of $4.7 billion, once again the Federal Government must put its hand into the domestic savings pool--this at a time when clearly the Government needed to be disciplined, needed to cut spending more and needed to pursue a tight fiscal policy.

Of course, the situation has been made even worse since the Budget was brought down. This was not the Budget to bring home the bacon; it was the Budget designed to save the boss's skin. The Budget reeked of left wing interference. We know that the Prime Minister depends on the support of the Deputy Prime Minister, the Leader of the Left, for his job. This Budget was clearly about the Prime Minister keeping his job--as I reminded him in Question Time--while hundreds of thousands of other Australians struggle to keep theirs.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Selfish old man.

—-He is very selfish. He was called a methuselah the other day. Talk about priorities! What did we get out of this Budget? We got the great better cities program--a sop to the Left. We do not have any details about it.
—-And never will.

—-And we probably never will. It is the Deputy Prime Minister's pet project for the unemployed, the bankrupt and the destitute. They are really excited about the better cities program. They will have better park benches to sleep on perhaps, and better footpaths on which to line up for food parcels. Somehow, ironically, the better cities program is on but Medicare is left choking and gasping. The $3.50 co-payment, which will raise $163.9m in 1991-92, compares with the cost of the better cities program of $56m in 1991-92.

SPEECH.PARA: Maybe we do need better cities. But is this the time? Is this fiscal responsibility? Is it appropriate? Where is the discipline which the former Treasurer, with his schoolmasterly manner, imposed? We know that it has gone out the window, just like the Medicare copayment appears to have done since the Budget.

The Opposition has long been pointing out the failures of Medicare. We support the concept of those who can afford to pay being asked to pay. We applauded the Government's biting, albeit tentatively, the ideological bullet and finally admitting that Medicare was failing. It has taken it a long time to get to that point. Now even that one commendable aspect of the Budget has changed.

I move on to a slightly different tack. Families are the fundamental unit in our society. Family breakdown, which is almost endemic in Australia, causes innumerable other problems. One of the primary causes of family breakdown is financial hardship. I want to remind the House--I hold the Government responsible for this--that the average family is considerably worse off now than it was at the last election. Many families are struggling.

Even though interest rates have come down, the damage has been done. We heard the honourable member for Dobell's self-congratulatory remarks about how the Government had brought interest rates down. He needs to be reminded that it was this Government that put them up in the first place. It ought to bring them down. We applaud the fact that they have come down. We hope that the fall is sustainable. We believe that the latest reduction of one per cent was politically motivated, but time will tell once again.

Through those months and years of high interest rates many families had their savings depleted. There remains a great deal of uncertainty about whether the breadwinner will have a job next week or next month. In many families both partners are forced to go out and work. This creates great hardship and stress in the home, particularly as children in many of our cities come home to an empty house.

In this area of concern about the family, once again the Government is big on rhetoric but meagre in substance. I am prepared to say that there is a commendable recognition in the Budget of the plight of rural families. We do not resile from giving credit where it is due. The raising of the family allowance supplement threshold from $18,000 to $19,300 will be a help. The Budget statement suggested that there will be some additional assistance for 200,000 families.

The point is that most families are still paying too much tax. A lot of the problems that we are having in this country get back to the tax system. Is it any wonder that that is where we are placing emphasis? Is it any wonder that that is a key area for reform? If we can fix the tax system and make it fairer and more equitable, and if we can introduce incentive into the tax system, we will address many of these problems.

The honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) in his eloquent maiden speech earlier this afternoon made the point that families are bearing the brunt of the recession and an inequitable tax system. That continues to be the case. It has got worse and worse. It is in the area of tax reform that the Budget is so lacking. The Government has no policy initiatives of any sort to address that particular area. The Government has nowhere to go in respect of serious reform of the tax system. All we have is more tax. Everywhere we look we have more tax.

The superannuation levy is nothing more than another tax. In this particular case it is a payroll tax in disguise. It is another tax on employment in Australia. The sad fact about that particular tax is that it will lead directly to more unemployment. Estimates say that it may lead to an additional 100,000 on the scrap heap by the year 1994-95.

Many have talked in this debate about superannuation and the need to encourage people to provide for retirement. We do not have any argument with that concept at all. We have a great argument with the methodology, as many others have said. The other side of the tax is that it is clearly inflationary. In that sense it will have a significant impact on pensioners and low income earners, which is not offset in any way. The Government talks to us about the compensation in our proposal. There will be compensation, and we will make that clear. Where is the compensation that the Government has given for the wholesale sales tax that has increased from $3 billion to $10 billion? There is not a hint of compensation there and not a hint of compensation for other taxes that have been inflationary.

The tax system is desperately in need of reform. I was reading the other day that the Deputy Commissioner was saying--what a stark remark it was--that in 1936 the Income Tax Assessment Act had 127 pages and today there are 5,100 pages of tax legislation. It has just been patched and re-patched.

Between 1982-83 and 1989-90 Commonwealth tax revenue per head of population increased from $2,660 to $5,300. Over the same period--that is, the time that the Hawke Government has been here--average individual income tax, which was 21.3 per cent of income in 1982-83, had risen to 24.1 per cent by 1988-89. Marginal tax rates also continue to be too high, and this is a major disincentive to people working harder. Over the same period we also know how deplorably low productivity growth has been. It has been virtually zero, whichever way we measure it over those years. If ever we needed a glaring deficiency, that is it. Why would anyone want to work harder in a system such as we have in Australia whereby the harder we work the more we are penalised for working?

Perhaps the most interesting program mentioned by the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) during his Budget Speech was the endangered species program. The Government has increased the funding for that program to $5m. This begs the question as to whether it is legitimate for the Government to spend taxpayers' money protecting Labor Party members of parliament. (Time expired)
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —- Order! It being almost 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mack Mr E.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —- The tragedy of the Strathfield gun massacre has stunned the nation. After five such tragedies in the past four years, together with the spread of guns to school children, following the pattern of the United States, gun violence can no longer be ignored. Richard Glover wrote recently in the Sydney Morning Herald:

SPEECH.PARA: Guns don't kill, people do. Yes--but it's guns that turn a domestic argument into a shooting. It's guns that convert a punch-up into a murder, and guns that make a suicide out of a depression. And it's semi-automatic guns that escalate a murder into a massacre.

The causes of gun violence go much deeper than just the availability and use of guns. Gun crimes are part of a general tide of violence in society, male violence, drugs, the alienation of individuals and the increasing displays of violence and weapons in films and television.

We have to look closely at many aspects of our society--at our education system, at the inequalities of wealth and opportunity, at our political system, at the constitutional problems of Federal-State jurisdictions and at the way that our culture stamps people with success or failure. There is some evidence that the armaments industry sees Hollywood as its main showcase for the full range of weapons, from hand guns to the latest high tech jets, and funds it accordingly.

Our adversary two-party political system, which prevents either major party taking a strong position where there is any well organised lobby in the community, is a factor. This was shown at the 1988 State election in New South Wales where the Greiner-Murray Opposition irresponsibly and shamefully exploited former Premier Barrie Unsworth's stand on gun control. The present cat and mouse search for a `bipartisan approach' by the Government and the Opposition in New South Wales is a pathetic admission that the interests of political parties always come before the public interest. Similar manoeuvres in the areas of immigration, abortion and tobacco advertising show the failure of the party system to cope with strong minority groups. All these aspects have to be addressed. It may take years, but we can wait no longer.

The Federal Government has no choice but to get heavily involved in gun control and not hide behind the Constitution. State boundaries are meaningless with the portability of weapons and mail order. It is farcical for the Australian Capital Territory to waste time on elaborate gun control laws or even for the New South Wales' politicians to posture, when Tasmania has been the gun buyers' cut price supermarket.

There are some legitimate considerations that have been put forward by the gun lobby, but the paranoia of the right of citizens to bear arms against the possibility of some sort of coup must be rejected. Likewise, the frightening tendency of extremist groups to amass huge arsenals and engage in war games with weekend `people hunting' trips, as are advertised in Queensland at present, must also be rejected.

The facts are that at the moment there are at least 3.5 million guns in private hands in Australia. Some 25 per cent of Australian homes have a gun. The fundamental problem is availability. Every effort and measure must be taken to prevent proliferation of all guns except to legitimate owners; that is, rural producers, sporting clubs and police. There is no case for private ownership of military weapons or for keeping guns in the home in urban areas. Both shooting clubs and law enforcement bodies should keep secure armouries at central locations.

Penalties for premeditated misuse of guns should be increased to a level that would dramatically reduce crimes such as armed hold-ups. The difficult censorship problem in film and video has to be addressed. We can no longer go on with the increasing public diet of ultra-violence and massacre movies. It is frightening to realise that in Australia today the box office success of movies is almost proportional to the level of violence.

Licensing and controls on gun ownership and use must be implemented, but we should never pretend that this is any more than a minor remedy to the problem. The increasing trend of violence in society must be addressed at all levels, not just at the level of gun control. All governments in Australia have to give a lead by moving away from the trend to the American style escalation of official violence as the response of its police forces. Such a response is totally self-defeating.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —- There are many outstanding community organisations operating throughout Australia. These groups provide a wide range of services and support functions for local communities, and in many cases to specific groups of people throughout Australia. It is widely recognised that community organisations play a vital role in our society and help to enrich the lives of many people. This is true both for those people who play an active role in the operation of an organisation as well as those people that the organisation comes into contact with.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to tell honourable members about one of those groups, Focal Extended Inc. It is an organisation which is very active within the Oxley electorate and one for which I have a great deal of respect. This group was originally formed in recognition of the need for those involved with the intellectually disabled to adopt a coordinated approach to the very significant changes that were taking place in the delivery of services to these people in Queensland during the early 1970s. Although the organisation was first established in the Ipswich area in 1974, it has since expanded quite dramatically, with its membership including intellectually disabled people and their parents and relatives, as well as many other members of the community with an interest in the welfare of this group.

The membership of Focal Extended is primarily in Queensland; however, it does have members interstate and from overseas. Since its formation, the range of functions undertaken by Focal Extended has become quite broad, with it now providing a wide variety of support and information services to the intellectually disabled and their families. It also plays an advocacy role on behalf of its client group, promoting the welfare and rights of the intellectually disabled and their parents and families.

More recently, Focal Extended has moved towards providing housing to meet the specific needs of its client group and, in particular, to ensure security of tenure for these people throughout their lives. This is clearly in line with the Hawke Government's commitment to providing the best quality of life for all people with disabilities and allowing them to have an independent lifestyle. There is no doubt that Focal Extended plays a very important role in our community. However, like all organisations, it needs funds in order to be able to provide those services. A large part of the funds used by Focal Extended comes from the efforts of its own members, and the usual hard task of fundraising involves selling raffle tickets, seeking donations and holding stalls and pie drives. Anyone who has been involved in any community group knows of the amount of time and effort that goes into this type of fundraising.

Recently, however, Focal Extended had an opportunity to do something a little different. It held an art exhibition, with works from some of the leading artists, including Eric Whisson. This exhibition would not have been possible, however, had it not been for the support given by the sponsor, Citibank. Because of my association with the banking industry prior to entering Parliament, as an employee and union official, and my close association with Focal Extended Inc., the beneficiary of this exhibition, I was very pleased to be invited by the sponsors to perform the official opening last month.

As honourable members would be aware, recently I have been involved in this Parliament's inquiry into the Australian banking industry. During the inquiry most of the attention has been towards `kicking' the banks, so it is very refreshing to be able to stand here tonight and offer some praise to the industry, and to Citibank in particular, for its community-minded spirit in supporting community groups such as Focal Extended. The funds raised from this exhibition provided much needed assistance to enable the organisation to continue its good work and it helped to relieve the burden placed on its group of dedicated fundraisers.

I believe that it is appropriate that Citibank, one of the world's largest banks, should receive recognition for its efforts. Citibank has operated in Australia through its subsidiary Citicorp since the early 1930s and provides its Australian customers with a wide range of banking services, as well as life insurance and superannuation. To Mr Ken Rushworth, Queensland Manager, Citibank Retail Bank, I offer my personal congratulations for the bank's willingness to support this worthwhile community project.

This particular exhibition was not the first or only time that Citibank has provided sponsorship to important community projects. In Queensland alone, over the past few years it has supported the Royal Children's Hospital Foundation, the Abused Child Trust, the Asthma Foundation, the Queensland Cancer Fund, the Paraplegic and Quadriplegic Welfare Association and the Shaftesbury Citizenship Campus. Citibank is also involved, or has been in the past, in supporting the Peter MacCallum Cancer Institute, the Doxa Youth Welfare Foundation, the Multiple Sclerosis Society, and many other worthwhile organisations.

Citibank's willingness to work with and to assist the general community in this way is a shining example of the public-minded attitude that we would like to see exhibited more frequently by the business community. Again, I say congratulations to Citibank and to Focal Extended for their cooperative approach to assisting those people with disabilities. I hope that the example shown by Citibank is followed by many more businesses and industries in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —- Many constituents in the La Trobe electorate come from non-English speaking backgrounds. Many of them have been in this country for a very long time. Although in many cases they speak and understand English better than those people who were born here, these migrants still enjoy communicating in their mother tongue. One of the few avenues left to them to hear their native language spoken has been to listen to SBS radio 3EA. People in the Dutch speaking community of the outer east of Melbourne are quite angry at the most unfair and inappropriate manner in which rescheduling of Dutch programs has occurred. The few hours a week when they could tune into the radio and listen and laugh along with the Dutch language programs being broadcast gave them a feeling of keeping in touch with their roots, with their heritage.

SPEECH.PARA: The broadcasting time for programs in the Dutch language has been cut almost in half. In comparison with other language groups, the Dutch speaking community is experiencing severe discrimination. For example, there are 5,956 Filipino language households and 18,278 Dutch language households. The number of Dutch language households is more than three times the number of Filipino language households, yet the new scheduling by SBS Radio 3EA provides one third more Filipino language programs than Dutch programs. Is it because the families from Dutch speaking backgrounds have merged so well with the Australian community that they are being passed over? That is a good question.

Many of the Dutch migrants who chose to come to Australia from the remnants of war- torn Europe have become upstanding and prominent citizens within our Australian community, and particularly within my electorate of La Trobe. They have worked hard and they have contributed much to the local communities in which they have settled. The Dutch flower growers and the nurserymen of the Dandenongs attract tourists from all over the world to their magnificent floral displays. The Dandenongs and flowers are synonymous with the Dutch community in my electorate of La Trobe.

Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands has visited my electorate. Indeed, the Dutch community has worked together to build at Montrose a retirement village named in her honour. Beatrix Village at Montrose has a reputation for providing a touch of the Netherlands for the older members of the community who migrated from Holland many years ago; yet it is totally immersed within the wider community that is the township of Montrose within the Australian electorate of La Trobe.

The Dutch language households in my electorate are an integral part of the community in which they reside. They are contributors, not takers. It is indeed a pity that for their efforts to become part of the Australian community the elderly Dutch will have one of the few pleasures of their retiring years denied them. The abolition of the popular Dutch radio program that was previously broadcast on Sunday afternoons on SBS Radio 3EA has caused much grief and anger in the older Dutch community. These people are feeling a great sense of loss at the rescheduling that has taken place--all for no apparent reason.

Dutch radio programs have been slashed out of all proportion, and I am quite angry about those cutbacks. The Dutch speaking community deserves a better deal. I call on this Government to reconsider its decision to slash Dutch radio programs and to immediately reinstate the Dutch programs on SBS Radio 3EA, Melbourne.

This Government talks about a multicultural Australia. As is so often the case, it is very good at talking, but when it comes to action it falls well short of the mark. The Dutch speaking community has participated in the establishment and enrichment of this great nation, particularly since the Second World War. This Government has an obligation to ensure the maintenance of accessibility to Dutch language radio programs through SBS Radio 3EA in Melbourne. I call on the Government to take remedial action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —- Last Saturday Channel 10 in New South Wales broadcast a program called Australia's Young Achievers. This program is held as a yearly event. It is available to young people up to 25 years of age who are nominated because they have excelled, whether it be in art, sport, science or in a career. One of those young people who received Australia's Young Career Achiever award is Michael Danielle. Michael Danielle, I am pleased to say, is a resident of my electorate who in 1989 at the age of 18 opened his own jewellery business. He is not only an artist; he is also a wonderful person. He did, with the backing of his parents admittedly, go into this business in Ware Street, Fairfield. Through his skill, his general hard work and, as I said, his magnificent ability not only to design and create but also to make magnificent jewellery, he now employs some nine people. I believe that he has shown, not only by his actions but also by his skill and the way in which he has conducted and expanded his business, that he is a person who is truly representative of a young achiever.

SPEECH.PARA: I was very pleased that I had the opportunity in 1989 of opening that business for him. In fact, I was exceedingly pleased to hear that a young man whom I knew so well personally had been nominated for and had received that award. He has grown in strength in that business and, at the age of 20, now runs two businesses. He has just opened his second business at Riverwood.

TALK.START.PARA: —-He is a good bloke. I met him.

—-In fact, the Treasurer, who is at the table, met the young man the other night. He was at a function that we both attended. I am saying this because many things have been said in this Parliament in the Budget debate about the assistance that we are giving to the youth and the unemployed, and much has been said by the Opposition on where it feels unemployed people are going today. I make this speech to give an example of what has been achieved by a young man with determination, skill and ability. He is a son of Italians who had settled in this country and who had at least said to their family, `You must learn to stand on your own two feet. We will assist you all we can, but you must learn either a profession or a trade so that you can give back to the country that has given us a home'.

SPEECH.PARA: This man has done more than that. This man has created employment and is providing continuing employment. He has prospered, and he will continue to prosper because he has that determination to succeed. I believe that he is a shining example to all other young people throughout Australia. The award of Career Achiever of Australia is a fitting award to give to him. I know that he very proudly accepted it and very shyly said in his thanks that he did not believe that he should have received it but that he was proud to have it in his possession.

I am very proud to bring to the notice of this Parliament the fact that the electorate of Prospect has not only multiculturalism, which the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) was rather concerned about, but also fine upstanding people who are able to generate employment and to project in their careers and, most importantly, young people who have a future ahead of them. They have a future which they have not relied on somebody else to make; a future that they have carved out for themselves; a future which they will strive to work with and for; and, most particularly, they will provide for others at the same time.

Michael Danielle has, through his artistic ability, become renowned throughout the area and I know he will continue to prosper. I wish Michael Danielle well. I wish all of those other young achievers who received awards the other night well. Most particularly, I hope that they become examples to our future Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: --The decision by the Victorian Government to close the Maffra Hospital in my electorate is a sad chapter in the administration of regional public health care policy. The closure of the hospital represents nothing more than a net reduction in health care resources in the region. There will be no expansion in the current level of services at the Gippsland Base Hospital in Sale. Discard that illusion. That is no more than an accounting exercise. The simple fact of the matter is that there are no gains to be had by any health care service in the region because of this decision. All that will follow from the Budget initiative to close the Maffra Hospital will be a net reduction in acute health care facilities for the region; that is, a reduction of services for a community whose age structure and demand is for exactly that type of service.

SPEECH.PARA: Currently the health and care service profile of the hospital is perfectly attuned to its community's needs. Its total resources are used efficiently and tailored to local requirements. Few hospitals can boast this match between the demand and supply in health care services. Importantly, it is because they lack balances of this type that larger metropolitan hospitals struggle to achieve equivalent efficiencies. Given the demographic character of the region--80 per cent of the population of the Maffra and Avon catchment are aged between 0 and 49 years--demand is predictably for acute care services.

As all those here tonight understand, the struggle over past years has been to graft available health care resources onto regional demand. This issue has been at the heart of every effort to design an efficient and equitable health care policy for rural Victorians. None of us sought special status for the region. All we sought was to ensure that available health and care resources were effectively targeted and that the local community had reasonable access to the appropriate level of facilities. Now we are seeing that simple strategy based on those simple principles wrecked.

If there were some inherent inefficiencies in the operation of Maffra hospital, action of the kind the Government has undertaken might be understandable. If there was some argument that the region was overserviced relative to the rest of the State, it might be possible to swallow the decision. But the decision does not spring from efforts to improve efficiencies in the distribution of health care resources; nor was it derived from an appreciation of the needs of the wider region. Essentially, then, the decision to close Maffra Hospital and to strip 30 acute care beds--not 20 but 30 acute care beds--from the region's available public health resources was an arbitrary one.

Despite the conventions and the regulations of the Victorian Health Act, no consultation with the hospital, let alone the community and other hospital service providers, was undertaken. This is hardly how policy processes bearing on the important issue of regional health care policy should be enacted. The Government has simply barrelled in and torn down years of careful planning by hospital authorities and staff and local communities.

But still other myths about this decision need to be exploded. There are claims afoot that in exchange for the axing of the 30 acute beds the State and Federal Governments will re-establish Maffra hospital as a centre for aged care nursing home beds. There are no such published or publicly stated intentions. No provision has been made in the Federal Budget for the expansion of nursing home beds beyond commitments entered into earlier this year.

The State Government's decision to close the hospital does not herald any plans for a new aged care policy for the region. There are no additional spending proposals to extend services for aged care facilities for the region. Once again, the simple fact is that Maffra hospital will be converted into a 30-bed nursing home, which is the minimum number necessary to justify public funding. There is no new aged care blueprint for the region. There is no detailed plan to capture the full advantages of the physical and human resources at Maffra to boost the provision of aged care across the region.

In conclusion, I believe there might have been some sympathy for reviewing the charter of the Maffra hospital if it had been based on consultation with regional authorities and local communities. The community might be responsive to such measures if they were presented as a strategy for public health and aged care which made some more determined effort to meet the needs of regions such as Gippsland. But those are opportunities the Government passed up.
In short, then, the decision to close Maffra hospital simply signals a retreat from past efforts to ensure adequate provision of rural health care services. Nothing more need be said of the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —- I enter this debate to make a public appeal to the banking industry to immediately lower the interest rates its members are charging on Bankcard. Everyone realises that the Reserve Bank dropped the official rate down to 9.5 per cent; yet, despite that, despite the major changes, the massive cuts, that have taken place in official rates over the last 18 months--down from 18 per cent to 9.5 per cent--the Bankcard rates have barely moved.

SPEECH.PARA: I extracted some figures yesterday and found that Westpac is still charging 24.6 per cent, the ANZ Bank 23.88 per cent, National Australia Bank 24.6 per cent and the Commonwealth Bank 22.75 per cent.

Honourable members will recall that when Bankcard came into being the rate was 18 per cent, or 1 1/2 per cent per month. That was exorbitant and it was criticised, but it is certainly nothing like today's rates. Since Bankcard was introduced, we have seen a lift from 18 per cent to 21 per cent, and then to this 24.6 per cent high, and it has remained there. Despite all the changes that have taken place in all the other types of rates--the drops that the banks have seen and they have brought about on the moneys that they have to pay on deposits--they continue to hold up Bankcard rates. They say the reason is that they are constantly facing losses. Personally, I believe that is baloney. They do not come good with the figures; they simply say that. I argue that it is part of their strategy to try to force governments and the community to accept doing away with the interest-free period and also accept some sort of fee. I simply will not accept that. I know the consumer movement across Australia will not accept it.

On one hand banks are telling us that they are suffering losses, yet they continue to promote Bankcards. I have yet to come across any person who ever asked for an increase in his or her threshold. People say they got a letter from the bank simply saying that their borrowing rights had increased from $1,000 to $2,000 or $1,500 to $3,000. The same is true when people turn 18: if their parents bank with a certain bank they get the offer of a Bankcard.

Yet the banks say that they are losing so much. The fact is that they are making considerable profits. They also use these Bankcards to get their clients involved in other products. They are gaining from the interest and profits they make on other products.

Clearly, there is a need for the banks to be responsible. They are being commercially immoral. They are pretty tough words after the sorts of comments my colleague the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott) made about Citibank, but here is a bank that is obviously doing the right thing. The rest of them are grabbing people by the throat financially and squeezing as hard as they possibly can. There is a need for rates to fall by 10 per cent; there is a need for greater community pressure; and I am also calling for Government pressure to see whether we can bring these rates down.

The banks seem to be laws unto themselves. They are quick to slash interest rates on their deposits. One can see from the figures that there are still billions of dollars in passbooks; the banks pay 3.75 per cent. I have come across an example where Westpac, in other savings categories, is paying 3 per cent interest on moneys held in accounts. The banks also introduced fees for anyone who had less than $100 in some kinds of accounts.

If one looks at the rates they are paying, the ANZ has a low on term deposits of 5.25 per cent. If one looks at the rates they are charging, on personal loans Westpac ranges from 16.5 to 21.25 per cent. Banks are avaricious when they are charging people, yet when it comes to paying on deposits they are very shy about coming forward with reasonable interest rates and returns.

But Bankcard is the issue--and also the sorts of rates banks are charging on business. There are cocktail loans where banks will allow a person a minimum overdraft. I know of a case where they allowed an overdraft of $10,000, but the other $10,000 had to be on Bankcard--a cocktail loan forcing up the overall cost of money. Banks have introduced their own credit squeeze.

Banks are doing the same thing with housing. When they knew the rates were going down they raced out and got as many people as possible to go into fixed loans rather than take the advantage of the variable house loan. I have figures showing that the Commonwealth Bank has a fixed loan of 14.25 per cent, which is higher than all the other banks. It is despicable that our own Commonwealth Bank is prepared to abuse its position as a banking organisation to take advantage of people in this country. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 30 May 1991.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will he further broaden the indirect tax base if the Government is returned at the next general election; if so, (a) what (i) additional items will be taxed and (ii) items currently taxed will be taxed at a higher rate and (b) what will be the new rates in both cases.
(2) If he is unable to provide the information referred to in part (1), when will he be able to do so.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Reform of the taxation system has been a major priority of the Government since coming to office in 1983. With significant changes to the tax system behind us, a period of consolidation is now intended. Notwithstanding this, the tax system is kept under constant review and the Government will continue to make further adjustments to improve the equity of operation and integrity of the Australian Taxation system. For instance, the Government announced in March a significant broadening in the range of goods exempt from sales tax when used by manufacturers, miners and primary producers. The cost of this exemption is estimated at $375 million in 1992-93 (first full year of impact). These changes are part of the review to simplify the administration of the wholesale sales tax system which was announced by the Government in the 1990-91 Budget.
Apart from the work of this review, it is not possible for the Government to predict whether it will consider other adjustments to the indirect tax system in the future.
I would note, however, that the recent ALP Conference held in late June in Hobart rejected proposals for the introduction of a consumption tax.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Anderson Mr J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 6 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service (AQIS) employed any consultants since 1989; if so, in respect of each consultant, (a) who (i) was the consultant, (ii) were the AQIS officers involved and (iii) the consultant's executives, (b) what was the nature of the work undertaken, (c) over what period and for what duration was the work performed, (c) what was the cost of the consultancy, (d) what were the consultant's findings (e) what action was taken as a result of those findings and (e) will he provide copies of the consultant's recommendations.

(2) Have any internal or external audits or investigations been conducted into the selection, appointment and management of any consultancies conducted for AQIS; if so will he provide details of each audit or investigation and any resulting action taken?

(3) Have any cases of potential or actual conflict of interest been alleged or established concerning selection, appointment or management of consultancies performed for or by AQIS since 1989; if so will he provide full details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Griffiths The Hon A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. A listing of consultants hired by AQIS since January 1989 has been prepared and will be provided to the honourable member. Excluded from the listing are those employees who are hired under contractual arrangements and whose tasks relate directly to the ongoing administration of AQIS. Given the substantial administrative resources required to answer in detail each of the questions asked by the honourable member, the information provided has been limited to the essential elements of the question.
Should however, the honourable member require a more detailed response concerning a particular consultancy, or contractual staff, I would be pleased to have this information made available.

(2) An investigation is currently underway into an allegation of conflict of interest. As this investigation is not complete I am unable to provide further details at this time. No other audits or investigations have taken place, however, as part of the ongoing review of AQIS systems a brief review of consultancies was conducted by AQIS Corporate Services Branch, in October/November 1990, to ensure the practices in place for handling consultants were appropriate.
This review highlighted areas where administration could be improved and senior AQIS staff were advised of the recommendations.
(3) The issue of conflict of interest is of real concern at all times for bodies such as AQIS,
which are involved in regulatory activities. Conflict of interest is specifically treated in the AQIS Code of Conduct and the Personnel Management Manual.

As noted in my response to question two, allegations have recently been made regarding a case of potential conflict of interest. These allegations are at present the subject of a full investigation but I am unable to provide any details at this time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 20 August 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister able to say whether the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has reduced the citizenship fee from $35 to $20 for aged pensioners.

(2) Are Australian passports for adults available only for a 10-year term and at a cost of $87; if so, why are elderly travellers not given the option of obtaining a passport for a lesser term at a lower cost.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs reduced the citizenship fee for aged pensioners from $35 to $20, effective from 6 March 1991.

(2) Australian Passports for adults are available for a maximum 10-year term at a cost of $87. This issuing fee is set by the Government as a fee for issue, and is not related to the validity period of the document, nor to the financial circumstances of the applicant. There is no provision in the Passports Act or Regulations for either a reduction of fee or length of validity, for aged pensioners. When the Treasurer announced an increase in the fee in 1987 he also stated that, in future, the fee would be adjusted annually by applying the variation in the Consumer Price Index. This measure maintains the real value of the passport fee at the 1986-1987 level.
It is the Government's view that as the passport issuing fee is incurred in most cases only once every ten years, is not an unfair financial burden on applicants.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: A mobile review team visited Esperance on 18 and 19 July 1991. It comprised 4 DSS officers.
(a) 47 people were interviewed during the visit.
